DOC.HEAD: House Passes Aid to Panama, Nicaragua; Senate Expected to Delay
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is turning up pressure on Congress to quickly enact his aid request for Panama and Nicaragua, as the House-approved measure faces delay in the Senate. The House voted 362-59 Tuesday for a $2.4 billion spending bill that provides $720 million for the two new Central American democracies. The measure includes nearly $1.7 billion in other spending, most of it for domestic programs such as disaster relief, food stamps and Forest Service firefighting. The bill is partly funded by a $1.8 billion cut from the Pentagon budget that amounts to the first use of a ``peace dividend'' from lessened East-West military tensions. Bush called his appeal a ``laser-like request to help Panama and Nicaragua,'' and State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said failure to pass the package quickly would threaten the fledgling democracies and be like ``playing with dynamite.'' But while the Senate prepares to consider a companion bill authorizing aid programs for the two countries, it seems in no rush to take up the money bill itself. ``We have a problem lighting a fire under the Senate to move the bill,'' said a senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``There is an alarming lack of enthusiasm to get this through the Senate.'' An aide to Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said the senator believes the administration is sending too much money to Panama and Nicaragua and not enough to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. That means Bush's Thursday deadline for passage of the money bill apparently will not be met, and that the measure will be before the Senate when Congress returns from its 12-day Easter recess later this month. The administration sent its ambassador to Panama, Deane Hinton, before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday to argue for the urgency of aid. ``That money is desperately needed, and needed now,'' Hinton said. He said Panama's government is bankrupt and dealing with 30 percent unemployment and that the public has high expectations following December's U.S. invasion that ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``Investors lack confidence until they see what the United States is going to do,'' Hinton said. In Nicaragua, President-elect Violeta Chamorro will take office April 25 faced by a litany of immediate problems, Ms. Tutwiler said. ``She will inherit an economy that is bankrupt and a country that will run out of oil as early as July. Hundreds of thousands of Nicaraguans will be returning to their country _ former Contras and their families, demobilized soldiers and refugees from 10 years of war,'' the State Department spokeswoman said. ``Congress must decide whether these Nicaraguans will return as an army of the unemployed, unable to feed or support their families, or as citizens of a democracy in which jobs and opportunities are available,'' she said. In the House, the supplemental money bill for the balance of fiscal 1990 easily survived attempts to strike out or trim foreign aid sections. But the attempts drew derision from the bill's supporters. ``I am amazed at the number of flat-headed members in this House who are all too happy to spend whatever it takes'' to support wars ``but wouldn't spend a penny to prevent the necessity to fight those wars in the first place,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, sought to cut 5 percent from the foreign aid portions of the bill, charging the measure was ``busting the bank. ... Before we ship money overseas, let's take care of our own country first.'' Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., countered: ``This amendment shows why people are fed up with Congress _ because we're looking at the little bitty `Did I get mine' ... instead of taking care of the security of our people.'' The House bill includes Bush's full $300 million request for Nicaragua. But it trims $80 million from the $500 million he sought for Panama, diverting $30 million of that to aid African countries, $20 million to Caribbean nations and $30 million to refugee programs.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Clean Air Bill; Debate Shifts to House
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto W8
DOC.TEXT: The debate over tougher air pollution controls shifts to the House with Senate approval of a sweeping clean air bill imposing new emission curbs on automobiles, factories and electric power plants. The Senate voted 89-11 late Tuesday to approve a far-reaching bill aimed at reducing urban smog, toxic industrial chemical releases and acid rain pollution. The House Energy and Commerce Committee was working behind closed doors today on the House version of the bill. A final committee vote is expected by the end of the week. President Bush called the Senate action ``a historic vote'' that will ``affect generations to come as we work to build a cleaner, safer America.'' The last time either the Senate or House approved changes in federal clean air laws was 1977 despite growing concern in recent years about dirty air. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who unsuccessfully sought over the past decade to change federal clean air laws, called the Senate bill ``a tremendous victory'' and a significant improvement over current air pollution requirements. ``We can no longer delay. The American people want action. They demand action,'' Mitchell said. The lopsided Senate voted capped weeks of jockeying among senators over the legislation, which was a compromise with the White House. Senators from the Northeast and California sought to toughen auto pollution controls but failed in narrow votes. Several attempts to cushion the Midwest from the high cost of acid rain controls also failed, as did an effort to help coal miners who could lose their jobs under new pollution requirements. Many senators expressed concern over the bill's cost, estimated at about $21 billion a year when it takes full effect toward the end of the decade. Mitchell acknowledged the new emission controls would be expensive to industry, but he argued ``the costs of inaction will be higher than the cost of this bill.'' Health experts estimate air pollution may account for 50,000 premature deaths every year and add $40 billion a year to health care costs, he said. But to many senators, particularly from the Midwest, the vote represented an agonizing choice between cleaner air and concern about the measure's impact on employment and electric bills back home. ``This bill will absolutely decimate my state of Illinois,'' declared Democratic Sen. Alan Dixon, whose state has utility plants that rely on high-sulfur coal as well as miners whose jobs would be jeopardized by new measures to combat acid rain. Dixon was among the 11 senators who voted against the legislation. Four were from states that would be hard hit by stringent acid rain control provisions. ``I cannot vote for legislation that will destroy the livelihood of thousands of hard-working men and women ... that will bring economic ruin to communities throughout Appalachian and Midwestern states,'' said Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who unsuccessfully sought financial help for coal miners affected by the bill. Among key provisions of the bill are: _Tighter automobile tailpipe emission controls, requiring that new cars run cleaner and reduce smog-causing pollutants. Cleaner fuels would be required for fleets and automobiles in most polluted cities as well as for urban transit buses. _A reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning utility plants by 10 million tons a year, curbing acid rain. _Reductions through the installation of the best available control technology of toxic chemical releases by industry, including controls on about 200 chemicals linked to cancer, nervous disorders and birth defects. The bill would require states to implement specific pollution control plans to clean up urban smog and establish requirements to cut pollution by 3 percent a year until federal air quality standards are achieved. The timetable for cleaning the air of urban smog ranges from five years to 15 years for most of the nation's cities. Because of the severity of its problem, Los Angeles is given 20 years. Supporters of the legislation noted government figures that 150 million people breathe dirty air in more than 100 cities from Lewiston, Maine, to Los Angeles. Industrial plants release an estimated 2.7 billion pounds of toxic chemicals, including carcinogens, into the air each year; and acid rain pollutants are endangering streams and lakes across much of the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Cries Fowl on Some Duck Labeling
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department is launching a quackdown on duck growers who call their birds Long Island ducklings even when they're raised as far away as Wisconsin or Pennsylvania. The action comes after a five-month investigation into alleged mislabeling of ducks. It was prompted by a complaint from Rep. George Hochbrueckner, D-N.Y., whose eastern Long Island district includes some of the region's last duck farms. ``We're not looking for anything other than fairness,'' Doug Corwin, a fourth-generation duck farmer, said Tuesday from Aquebogue, N.Y. ``I'm objecting to the bogus address, which gives the restaurateur or the consumer the misconception he's getting a Long Island product, which in fact he isn't.'' On March 21, the Agriculture Department sent letters to five duck processors telling them it found their labels false or misleading, said Jim Greene, a spokesman for the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. Department investigators, doing what Greene called basic gumshoe work, found that some duck farmers' only connection to Long Island was a post office box. Yet their products carried such labels as ``Pride of Long Island's South Shore'' or ``Genuine Long Island Distributed Duckling.'' ``The issue is simply that in order for it to be labeled Long Island duck or duckling, the animal has to have been raised or slaughtered on Long Island,'' Greene said. He identified the five as: Concord Farms Inc. of Concord, N.C.; Joe Jurgielewicz & Sons Ltd. of Shartlesville, Pa.; Culver Corp. of Middlebury, Ind.; Maple Leaf Farms Inc. of Milford, Ind.; and Maple Leaf Duck Farm Inc. of Franksville, Wis. The five have 60 days to respond to the Agriculture Department. Then, if the ruling becomes final and they continue to put Long Island labels on their ducks, the agriculture inspector at the plant won't let the birds off the premises, Greene said. Barbara Bender, marketing director for Concord Farms, said ``Long Island duck'' is merely a marketing phrase. ``It's not a breed. It's a place,'' she said. Even when they sell restaurants North Carolina duck, the restaurants still list it on the menu as Long Island duckling, she added. But on Long Island, Corwin said the mislabeling has cut into his market, particularly in places like Florida and Texas. ``Our problem comes in markets where we are not well-known,'' he said. ``Say if we were asked for a bid, we could not outbid a plant in the Midwest that had lower costs, and yet the bids would specify genuine Long Island products.'' Those out-of-state farmers also are trading on Long Island's reputation for raising leaner, meatier ducks, said Joe Gergela of the Long Island Farm Bureau. Long Island produces about 2 million ducks a year, down from about 5 million to 6 million 30 years ago, Corwin said. Production has declined steadily over the years as land development, high taxes and escalating utility costs squeezed out farmers. At one time, Long Island had nearly 100 duck farms. Now there are about a half-dozen. Corwin, whose great-grandfather began raising ducks in 1908, produces about half the island's annual total. ``I'd like to keep growing ducks out here for a few generations,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: LBJ Admirers Gather for Reunion
DOC.TEXT: Angered by a new book picturing Lyndon B. Johnson as a self-centered politician obsessed with power, admirers of the 36th president are gathering here this week to celebrate his ``large and generous vision of America.'' The occasion is a reunion recalling the 25th anniversary of Johnson's inauguration as an elected president on Jan. 20, 1965. On Tuesday, a new 30-minute documentary film,``Lyndon Baines Johnson: A Remembrance,'' was previewed at the Motion Picture Association of America theater. Produced by Academy Award-winning documentary maker Charles Guggenheim of Washington, the film presents an image of Johnson hardly recognizable to readers of ``Means of Ascent,'' the second volume of Robert Caro's LBJ biography. The book portrays Johnson in his youth as willing to do almost anything to satisfy an all-consuming political ambition. Caro has said a subsequent volume will show more positive qualities that Johnson displayed as senator and president. The film, made up of black and white still photographs and the voices of former Johnson associates, concentrates on Johnson's labors on behalf of civil rights legislation and touches briefly on the troubles that the war in Vietnam brought to his administration. It ends with journalist Bill Moyers, who was one of Johnson's press secretaries, saying, ``He was many things: proud, sensitive, impulsive, flamboyant, sentimental, earthy, mean at times, bold, euphoric, insecure, magnanimous, but temperamental, melancholy, and strangely ill at ease. He has such a large and generous vision of America in his best moments as a prosperous, caring, just society. This was a mind not given to rest, and neither, I think he would say, should we.'' On Friday, organizers say approximately 1,000 former White House staffers, ambassadors, telephone operators and others from the Johnson White House will gather for a social event to launch a book, ``LBJ: The White House Years,'' by Harry J. Middleton, director of the Johnson presidential library, with photographs by the late White House photographer Yoichi Okamoto. ``I find it far more skillful and I think useful than Mr. Caro's,'' said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America and a former Johnson aide. Joseph Califano, a Johnson aide who later became secretary of health, education and welfare in the Carter administration, asked to comment on Caro's book, said of Johnson: ``Was he a tough politician? Sure he was. Could he be a bare-knuckles fighter? Sure. Were no holds barred? Absolutely. But what is totally missing from Caro's book is any sense of what drove the man _ of the vision that he had.'' The observance is scheduled to wind up Saturday with panels of journalists discussing ``In Search of LBJ'' under auspices of the National Press Foundation and the LBJ Foundation, and former Johnson administration officials discussing ``Social Welfare Issues from the 1960s to the 1990s.'' Many of the same group will gather May 5 in Texas for a two-day seminar at the LBJ Ranch near Johnson City, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Killer Bee Not a Major Threat, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: In some Agriculture Department circles the buzz words these days are Africanized honeybees. Not ``killer bees,'' mind you. That's all beeswax dreamed up by Hollywood and the news media. The USDA has a new ``backgrounder'' report to straighten things out. ``Africanized honeybees from Mexico are expected to arrive in Texas sometime during 1991-92 by natural spread, although some swarms may arrive sooner,'' the report said. The early arrivals could be occasional swarms coming from South and Central America aboard ships. Those ``are a concern, but they are not major threats'' to Americans or the U.S. beekeeping industry, it said. Some domestic beekeepers are fearful that the spread of Africanized bees could jeopardize the U.S. industry, which includes commercial crop pollination services as well as honey production. It has been a long trail for the Africanized honeybees, descendants of 26 African swarms imported by researchers in Brazil in 1956 who were trying to develop more productive models than the traditional European honeybee. As the Africanized swarms multiplied and spread into neighboring South American countries they also marched north across the continent, gaining an evil reputation. By the early 1980s they were in Panama, and it was obvious their march would take them into Mexico and into the United States. ``Researchers named them Africanized honeybees,'' the report said. ``However, as a result of widely publicized stinging incidents, the name `Killer Bee' was picked up by the movie industry and the media to describe the Africanized honeybee.'' The report said everyday risks such as auto accidents ``pose a much greater risk statistically'' than death from beestings. According to routes indicated by the report, the bees are expected to make their U.S. entry near the southernmost tip of Texas. The Africanized bee is more dangerous than its larger European cousin, which, incidentally, was introduced into North America by European settlers. Or maybe it isn't. It depends how many are involved. ``Unlike the docile European honeybees common in the United States, the Africanized honeybee quickly defends its hive and will pursue intruders longer distances,'' the report said. ``The venom from one Africanized honeybee sting is no more potent than the venom of a single European honeybee sting.'' One of the widely reported characteristics of the Africanized bees is their defensive behavior in which hundreds or thousands quickly and aggressively respond to an intruder, each carrying a potential sting to the victim. ``Even though mass stinging attacks are terrifying and could be life-threatening, they are not common,'' the report said. ``The best defense for avoiding stings from all stinging insects _ not just honeybees _ is common sense.'' The report added: ``If you find yourself near large numbers of honeybees, calmly and quickly move away from the area.''

A government report says northern areas of the Great Plains still suffer from lack of moisture for crops and pastures, but farther south the story was too much rain. ``Rain improved winter wheat condition in portions of the central Great Plains'' during the week of March 26-April 1, the Joint Agricultural Weather Facility reported Tuesday. ``Crop condition was mostly good in Colorado and Kansas. Nebraska's winter wheat was fair to good.'' In the southern plains, too much moisture caused some yellowing of the wheat crop and hampered fertilizer application. The crop condition was said to be good to fair in Oklahoma and Missouri. Rain improved winter wheat in northern Texas but excess moisture was a problem in some areas. ``Winter wheat was mostly good in the Corn Belt and good to fair in the Southeast,'' the report said. ``Powdery mildew was a continuing problem in Georgia.'' In the West, lack of moisture put stress on winter wheat in the Columbia Basin of Oregon, the report said. Washington's wheat was in good-to-fair shape, although Russian wheat aphids were a problem in the eastern part of the state. Pastures and livestock were reported in good-to-fair condition in the Mississippi Delta region and in the East. Ranges in most of the West needed rain, but livestock was said to be in ``mostly good' condition. The facility is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments. Weekly reports cover crop conditions but do not include production forecasts.

Japan has moved ahead of the United States as the world's largest pork importer, says an Agriculture Department report. The U.S. market share of world pork imports dropped to 28 percent in 1988 from 34 percent in 1985, said the report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service. Meanwhile, Japan's import share rose to 28 percent from 18 percent. ``For 1989 through 1990, the United States' market share is forecast to fall, then remain at 25 percent, while Japan's share is forecast to rise to 31 percent,'' the report said. The rise in Japan's pork imports was attributed to ``domestic pressure calling for greater availability'' and lower prices for meat. Also, the report cited the government's move to reduce import levies.

DOC.HEAD: Steelmakers Paid Workers to Attend Rally Against Union Position
With PM-Clean Air Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two steel companies paid employees' expenses to travel here, against their union's wishes, to rally against a clean-air bill that the industry opposes, according to company and union officials. The United Steelworkers of America, which supports the bill, used memos and telephone calls to try to hold down the size of Tuesday's demonstration. Members of a Steelworkers local in Pennsylvania decided not to come because the union leadership advised against it. Still, the demonstration on the Capitol steps was attended by about 150 workers, many from USX Corp.'s steelmaking plants in Gary, Ind., and Fairless Hills, Pa., and the company's ore facility at Mountain Iron, Minn. USX paid the expenses of its workers who attended, said spokesman Ernie Glenn. LTV Corp. also sponsored some of its steelworkers from Cleveland and Warren, Ohio, so they could come, according to spokesman Chuck Hess. ``We look at this as sponsoring a rally for employees who have expressed concern about this legislation and what it might mean for them and their families,'' Glenn said. ``I'm not going to comment on what the international (the union) says or does.'' When he heard about the rally at the end of last week, Steelworkers President Lynn Williams sent a memorandum to union directors nationwide. ``The steel companies are attempting to take advantage of our basic steel local unions by planning an all-expenses, company-paid rally in Washington,'' the memo said. ``It is not a rally which the United Steelworkers of America supports. The steel companies are not themselves opposing the act, but are using our members to front for them.'' Charlie Grese, president of the union local at the USX plant in Clairton, Pa., said in a telephone interview that he changed his mind about attending after speaking to Williams and other union officials on the phone. ``There's no question we were about ready to come down,'' Grese said. ``I told the company I would have to take this past the international union and would not come down without authorization from the international president.'' Grese said he decided not to go after being told by the union's chief lobbyist that the rally would do little good because ``it was too late to change any minds.'' The Senate approved the bill, 89-11, Tuesday night. Demonstrators at the rally opposed a requirement in the bill that people living near steel plant coke ovens could not be exposed to a cancer risk of more than one in 10,000 over 70 years. The demonstrators expressed concern that such a guideline was unrealistic, and could force the mandatory shutdown of dozens of coke ovens. Coke, which comes from coal, is a raw material of steel. Coke ovens can emit benzene, a carcinogen. Billy Gray, a coke oven worker at the Gary plant, said concern about shutting down coke ovens led him to attend the rally even though he knew the union leadership backed the legislation. ``It's a big union, a democratic union,'' he said. While the major steel companies oppose the bill, the union says the measure provides enough time and leeway for steelmakers to avoid hardships. Under the bill, steel producers that make extraordinary efforts to control leakage from coke ovens would be given until 2020 before non-complying ovens would be closed. The union believes the industry duped workers in ``a crude campaign of deception'' by making it seem there is a possibility of ``immediate job loss'' from the bill, said union spokesman Gary Hubbard.

DOC.HEAD: Sequestered Poindexter Jury to Begin Third Day of Deliberations
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Jury resumes deliberations 9:45 a.m. EST; will be led
DOC.TEXT: The jury in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial is being sequestered until it reaches a verdict, after two members told the judge they were contacted by the news media. The panel of eight women and four men was returning to the U.S. courthouse today to consider the criminal charges against the former national security adviser. Members spent Tuesday night in a hotel after U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene ordered them sequestered. It was disclosed in court Tuesday that Washington Post reporter Nora Boustany had telephoned juror Leroy Witherspoon at home after Monday's first day of deliberations. Witherspoon said he hung up on her twice. Juror William Harris said he was contacted Monday evening by a woman identifying herself as a reporter. He hung up and she didn't call back. Greene said the ``irresponsible behavior of the press leaves me no alternative'' but to have the jurors ``taken by the marshals'' to a hotel each night. ``I certainly don't want to have a mistrial,'' Greene said. Both jurors will remain on the panel because they ``were alert and intelligent and didn't allow'' any conversation about the case to take place, said Greene. Poindexter lawyer Richard Beckler said he had no objection to the two jurors staying on the panel. Washington Post editors instructed Boustany to find out how to get in touch with Witherspoon after the verdict, said Robert Kaiser, the Post's assistant managing editor for national news. ``She did this by calling him up to ask him,'' said Kaiser, adding that she had made a mistake. The judge said the Post's explanation was that the reporter ``just came from Lebanon'' and ``didn't know the rules.'' Kaiser said the second juror was not contacted by a Post reporter. Also on Tuesday, Greene denied jurors' request for copies of 5,000 messages which were deleted from Poindexter's computer system days before he resigned. The messages were preserved on a backup computer tape and some of them have been admitted as evidence. Many, however, remain highly classified and were not introduced at the trial. The deletion of the computer messages is specified in the indictment as part of Poindexter's alleged effort to obstruct Congress on the Iran initiative. Poindexter's lawyers say it was routine for departing National Security Council employees to purge their computer systems. Poindexter, who was national security adviser to then-President Reagan from late 1985 to November 1986, is charged with conspiring to obstruct Congress, two counts of making false statements to lawmakers and two counts of obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair. He is accused of covering up Oliver North's secret Contra resupply operation and the U.S. role in a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Cavazos Bristles at Democrats' Education Bill
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos says he's convinced that some House Democrats are playing politics with the president's bill to improve U.S. schools. ``The bottom line is simple _ some people just have a difficult time giving the president any credit for the efforts and leadership he has taken in improving and restructuring our nation's schools,'' said Cavazos. He chastised the House Education and Labor Committee for not advancing the administration's $1.5 billion bill to upgrade education. An alternative offered by Chairman Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., is a ``ploy to sidetrack the president's bill,'' Cavazos said. ``I am disappointed'' that the administration legislation has been treated ``in a highly partisan fashion,'' Cavazos told the subcommittee on elementary, secondary, and vocational education. ``It is not a partisan bill _ it is an education reform bill. However, many education leaders testified in favor of Hawkins' bill, including Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association; Franklin Smith of the Council of the Great City Schools; and Gordon Ambach, director of the Council of Chief State School Officers. The subcommittee, however, became embroiled in a partisan war of words. Rep. William F. Goodling, R-Pa., who introduced the administration's bill with 98 cosponsors, complained that the Democrats' bill was ``177 pages thrown together in two weeks with not much thought'' and very few details on how various sections would be implemented. Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich., took exception to Cavazos' claim of partisanship and accused him of ``schizophrenic rhetoric'' that praises Bush for his educational programs while criticizing the Democrats for theirs. He also said the president is seeking a 2 percent cut in the education budget. Rep. Harris Fawell, R-Ill., estimated that the Democrats' version would cost $50 billion in five years and said, ``Nobody in the budget committee could begin to take it seriously.'' The Senate in early February voted 92-8 to approve and send to the House the Excellence in Education Act, initially submitted by Bush last spring. The bill seeks to combat drugs in public schools, establish a presidential merit schools program and increase aid to schools seeking to reduce dropout rates. One controversial section would award $25 million in federal funds over three years to the recently established National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. Hawkins' bill would increase by $1 billion the authorized amount for Head Start for fiscal 1991, fully fund the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children by 1994 and expand the Even Start Program. It also would increase aid for dropout prevention, deterring drug abuse and assisting the handicapped, illiterate and disadvantaged. Ambach of the Council of Chief State School Officers said Hawkins' bill includes the president's key initiatives, other congressional initiatives and ``expansion of several current programs in a comprehensive approach to federal action toward national priorities and goals for education.'' Smith, superintendent of the Dayton, Ohio, public schools, said Hawkins' bill ``pays particular attention to balancing the twin concerns of excellence and equity, issues that are of vital interest to urban schools and the children they must serve.'' But Lawrence Patrick Jr., president of the Detroit Board of Education, testified that with passage of the administration's bill, ``we truly believe we can become a significant point of light _ an urban star shining bright _ illuminating successful quality educational reform across the nation.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Considering Cutback in Stealth Bomber Production
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, facing growing congressional opposition to the costly B-2 stealth bomber, is weighing plans to scale back production of the aircraft, says Air Force Secretary Donald Rice. In his first public comments on the Pentagon's review of major weapons systems, Rice said the Defense Department is examining other options to the current plan to buy 132 bombers at a cost of more than $70 billion. ``We think there are some alternate profiles ... with some very modest effect on the total cost of the program,'' Rice told the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on defense Tuesday. Major concerns in the Pentagon center on the possibility that purchasing less than the full fleet will force up the cost of a single, radar-evading bomber, now estimated at about $530 million. Rice said pending legislation that would stop production at the 15 bombers currently being built would mean a total program cost of $33 billion to $34 billion. Based on those numbers, a single plane would cost more than $2 billion, he noted. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has been reviewing the alternatives, Rice said. The Air Force has scheduled another briefing for the Pentagon chief on the B-2 on Thursday. President Bush's $307 billion defense budget for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, calls for $5.5 billion for the stealth bomber program, including the purchase of five planes and other expenses. But in the mid-1990s, the administration is projecting purchases of 10 planes and later 24 in a single year with annual costs of nearly $10 billion. Rice said the most efficient production rate for the plane's manufacturer, Northrop Corp., is 29 planes a year. But the Air Force secretary conceded that it will be difficult to persuade Congress to spend almost $10 billion a year on a single weapons program. Pressed for the options the Pentagon is weighing, Rice said: ``I can't give numbers except to say several billion dollars a year less than peak funding level'' of close to $10 billion. ``It would inevitably get up to a lower production rate on the order of two-thirds, perhaps three-fourths what had been peak rate,'' Rice said in reference to the 29 bombers a year. Democrats and Republicans on the panel made it clear that the B-2 program, for which the government has invested more than $23 billion, faces an uphill fight in Congress. Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., a proponent of the stealth bomber, questioned Rice on the alternatives to the full fleet of 132 bombers _ a total that many lawmakers say is unlikely. ``I'm trying to help you guys with this weapons system,'' Kasten said. ``Today it's hard to help.'' The ranking Republican on the subcommittee, Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, wondered whether the Air Force had considered abandoning the next generation of programs such as the B-2 bomber, the C-17 cargo plane and the Advanced Tactical Fighter. Stevens said several of his colleagues were thinking about sticking with the weapons and planes currently in use and looking ahead several generations to other programs. ``We have a lot of back-burner people on this committee,'' Stevens said of his colleagues who want to set aside the Air Force's high-tech programs. ``You know it and we know it.''

DOC.HEAD: Target Prices Must be Tied to Production Costs, Senators Say
DOC.TEXT: If Americans are to continue paying less for food than anyone else in the world, target prices set by the government for crops must be tied to production costs, say five senators working on the price-support section of the 1990 farm bill. ``U.S. consumers today spend just 10.4 percent of their disposable income on food, the lowest level in history and less than consumers in any other country,'' Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., said Tuesday. But ``the producer's share of each dollar spent on food has dropped to an all-time low,'' he said at a news conference called to outline legislation expected to be the basis of the target price and income support section of the Senate farm bill. Meanwhile Tuesday, a House subcommittee approved a dairy program for the House version of the massive legislation that Congress designs every five years to set agriculture policy. Under the House dairy program, the government would buy up to 7 billion pounds of milk products, at $10.60 per hundred pounds, if they can't be sold on the open market. Farmers who produce more than their share of the government's limit would get a sharply lower amount. The key to the legislation is reducing butter production which, because of low consumer demand, is ending up in government warehouses. The Senate has not yet acted on dairy. Kerrey was joined by Sens. James Exon, D-Neb.; Tom Daschle, D-S.D.; Tom Harkin, D-Iowa; and Kent Conrad, D-N.D., to push for raising target prices on so-called program crops _ wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and rice. The legislation would cost about $12 billion annually, said Kerrey, who has led the fight against a Bush administration proposal designed to lower target prices. The government sets target prices to assure farmers a certain income. If the market price does not reach the target price, the government pays the farmer the difference. The senators said their plan would protect family farms, which an aide to Daschle, Mark Ulven,said was important as a guard against higher supermarket prices. If agricultural production were in the hands of just a few corporate farms, food prices would also be under their control, he said. Kerrey said the plan's aim is not to heavily subsidize farmers. He said the Democrats are interested in seeing farmers produce for the market, not government subsidies. But, he said, ``recovery is fragile,'' and the government should assure that farmers' production costs are covered. Provisions in the proposed legislation include: _Tying target prices to increased production costs. _Raising loan rates, which help determine market prices, by more than 20 percent next year, and setting a floor on the loan rate of $2.10 for corn and $2.75 for wheat. _Establishing a normal crop acreage base for each farm that is the total of the farm's current crop-specific bases, plus the average acreage planted to soybeans during the last five years. _Raising income support levels on oilseeds, oats and barley to levels comparable with wheat and corn.

DOC.HEAD: Homosexuals on News Staffs Decry Their Papers' Coverage of Gay Issues
DOC.TEXT: In the first survey of its kind, homosexual members of the staffs of American newspapers say their papers do a poor job in the way they treat news about gays or of concern to them. The gay journalists said their papers treat them fairly and give them opportunity to advance, but rarely call on their insights into gay lifestyles in the same way black reporters are asked to help guide coverage of black issues. And some newsrooms ``harbor a palpable undercurrent of bias,'' a summary of the findings concludes. One respondent commented that her colleagues who ``make snide homophobic comments and jokes'' are ``the same people who write those sensitive stories and editorials!'' The survey was being made public today at the annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. It was undertaken in response to outgoing ASNE President Loren Ghiglione, who asked whether ``anti-gay discrimination infects today's newsrooms.'' When word circulated that the survey was to be undertaken, 205 homosexual members of the staffs of U.S. newspapers volunteered to respond. Three-fifths said they were openly gay, and two-thirds signed their questionnaires. Ninety-two percent said they knew other people on the staff who were gay and the majority of them estimated that fewer than 20 percent of the homosexuals on their papers were openly gay. Many experts estimate that one American in 10 is gay. ``Why does it matter?'' asked Leroy F. Aarons, an executive of the Oakland (Calif.) Tribune who coordinated the project. He said the subject is important because ``more than ever before, editors are grappling with a swirl of social and political currents around alternative lifestyle issues.'' ``Domestic partners legislation, gay adoption, anti-discrimination laws, fundamentalist attacks on the gay lifestyle, morality and public responsibility and, of course, the still-raging AIDS epidemic have brought once-easily ignored issues into demanding focus,'' he said. The respondents gave especially low ratings to the way their papers treated gay lifestyles, community events and politics and only slightly better ratings to treatment of violence against gays, civil rights issues and legislation. As for terminology, nearly a third said they found the term ``homosexual'' to be prejudiced, explaining that it refers narrowly to sex whereas the term ``gay'' refers to lifestyles or issues. Another report at the meeting looked at what happens to newspapers when they are taken over by non-local ownership. A majority of the editors said firms owning multiple newspapers are more interested in profits than in the communities they serve and that freedom of the press is in more jeopardy when the ownership of papers is concentrated in fewer hands. Some editors said that group ownership was likely to enrich a local paper because the group brought greater resources to it; some said group ownership led to homogenization. Editors of 234 newspapers, half group-owned and half independent, took part. The report noted that 50 years ago, there were 1,559 independent, locally owned dailies and only 319 under group ownership, but now there are only 389 independents and 1,233 group-owned papers. Group-owned papers, the report said, were likely to offer ``better career opportunities, more sharing of ideas, less pressure from advertisers and special interest groups, greater overall financial resources and access to outside experts to help solve problems and train staff.'' Independent papers, on the other hand, were likely to offer ``larger newsroom budgets, better understanding of (the) local market, more flexibility in making decisions, greater involvement in the community, less turnover of key personnel, few levels of bureaucracy and a tendency to be peculiar.'' The ASNE's annual survey of minority employment on newspapers showed that 7.86 percent of newsroom editors, reporters and photographers were members of racial minorities _ a scant increase from last year's 7.54 percent. When the survey started in 1978, blacks, Hispanics, Asians and American Indians constituted 3.95 percent of the news staffs. The figure has risen gradually each year. ``In these tough economic times, perhaps any increase in the percentage of people of color should be applauded,'' said Ghiglione said. But Merv Aubespin, chairman of the ASNE Minorities Committee, said the slight gain was ``embarrassing for our industry, which prides itself on putting the spotlight on the ills of society.'' The survey said minorities make up 4.6 percent of newsroom supervisors, 8 percent of copy editors, 8.7 percent of reporters and 10.7 percent of photographers.

DOC.HEAD: 1.5 Million Households Didn't Get Census Forms Because of Foul-up
DOC.TEXT: Some 1.5 million households nationwide received no census forms because the Census Bureau failed to print post office box numbers on the mailings, officials said. Each form will have to be delivered by census workers to the homes, instead of to the boxes, before the census can be completed, Gail Kremenec, spokeswoman for the regional census office in the Chicago suburb of Westchester, said Tuesday. Officials were unable to estimate the cost of the foul-up but said they don't expect any significant delay in completing the 1990 census. About 106 million forms were mailed nationwide in the last week of March. But forms destined for people who have their mail sent to box numbers went out without the numbers, and the Postal Service was unable to deliver them, census officials said. ``We're getting them back by the mailbag. It's pretty widespread across the country, rural and urban areas. I think we've gotten back about all we're going to get,'' said Judith Petty, chief of the census processing staff in Jeffersonville, Ind. The Jeffersonville office is the clearinghouse for all undelivered census forms. Ms. Petty said each bag must be sorted by hand and the forms redistributed to district offices so they can be delivered by census workers. ``I've got about 30,000 forms to hand-deliver,'' said Don Leadill, manager of the Census Bureau's Peoria office. The Postal Service checked the Census Bureau's mailing lists before distributing the forms, but the post office box problem was not discovered because addresses with box numbers weren't checked, Ms. Kremenec said. Ms. Kremenec said census employees hired to do door-to-door surveys next month will be pressed into service to deliver the forms. ``We already have the staff on board to go to every house that we didn't get a response from,'' she said. However, in at least two central Illinois districts extra census employees will have to be hired, at $6 per hour, to deliver the forms. Leadill said he will hire people for the task, as will Jerry Harder, district manager in Bloomington. ``We have about 15,000 forms being returned to us as undeliverable,'' said Harder, whose largely rural district includes 13 counties. But he said, ``We don't consider it a big problem. ... It's no big deal.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Hits the Hot Dog Circuit for Fellow Republicans
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is planting saplings and shaking money trees as he travels a transcontinental $1,000-hot-dog circuit to raise cash for fellow Republicans. ``I am president at a fascinating time. We are Republicans at a fascinating time,'' Bush tells audiences of contributors who have paid a grand apiece _ sometimes for no more than a frankfurter _ to see him in person. For a handshake and a photograph and perhaps a few personal words from the chief executive, the price of admission rises to $5,000. Although Bush may have what Texas GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams calls ``wonderful coattails,'' his main help to candidates this early in the election cycle is as a drawing card to help fill campaign war chests. And with his high ratings in the public opinion polls, Bush's success at bringing in the green is all but unsurpassed. His stops this week for candidates in Ohio, Indiana and Michigan raised about $1 million per stop. Consequently, Bush, a former Republican National Committee chairman, plans to do more fund raising for other candidates than any president in history, White House aides say. White House political operatives and the RNC so far have blocked out 25 days of political travel for the president through the end of August. ``That's really 50 events, since we try to do two every day,'' said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. And that doesn't take into account September and October, when campaigns really heat up and when Bush will be on the campaign trail almost constantly, Ms. Glen said. Bush will campaign for at least 15 GOP Senate candidates and 16 GOP gubernatorial candidates, Ms. Glen said. The president will leave most House candidates to Vice President Dan Quayle and members of the Cabinet, but will do some campaigning in key congressional races, she said. The president uses events like Tuesday's tree-planting ceremony in a downtown Indianapolis park to help defray the costs to candidates and to state GOP parties. Taxpayers pick up part of the tab when the president includes a non-political event with a campaign stop. ``You know, two weeks ago I told an audience that I'd been planting so many trees all over the country that I might have to open a branch office,'' he told the Indianapolis audience, which groaned in unison at his pun. ``I knew it,'' he said. ``I tried it once before and got the same groan. This one is going out of the speech from now and evermore.'' At a fund-raiser Monday night in Cincinnati for GOP gubernatorial candidate George Voinovich, a dance band with an accordion struck up ``Hail to the Chief'' and somehow made it sound like a polka. Now, it isn't often that you hear ``Hail to the Chief,'' the presidential march, on an accordion. But it's one of the things a president has to get used to when he's out on the campaign trail. Wealthy Cincinnati Republicans in expensive suits, furs and diamond jewelry stood around stuffing dripping chili dogs into their mouths and straining to catch a glimpse of Bush. Most seemed delighted to be there, although some grumbled quietly about the food. Even the president seemed apologetic. ``These are the most expensive hot dogs in the state of Ohio,'' he exclaimed. Although usually the food fare is more upscale than hot dogs, the fund-raisers basically follow the same formula: $1,000 for the basic ticket, $5,000 for a more intimate ``grip and grin'' session that either precedes or follows the main event. The fund-raisers all contain a standard stump speech by the president _ praising the local candidate, praising the state, saying a particular race ``will be among the most crucial in America,'' saluting the nearest major league baseball team and remarking on pro-democracy changes in the world. ``Opportunity ... is the freedom to root for the team of your choice, to vote for the candidate of your choice, or to eat the vegetable of your choice,'' he told a fund-raiser in Dearborn, Mich., Tuesday night. Bush also bashes Democrats in each speech _ a guaranteed crowd-pleaser. There's another part of the formula that Bush follows at all the fund-raising luncheons, banquets and hot dog fests. He never eats. Instead, he usually tries to sneak out afterward and sample a local restaurant.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Over Treasure Become Tortuous
DOC.TEXT: Gold whose value skyrocketed as it sat on the sea bottom for 133 years has lured Columbia University into a court battle over the wreck of the SS Central America. The trial that opened Tuesday originally pitted the Columbus-America Discovery Group, a group of 100 investors with exclusive rights to search the ocean bottom for the wreck, and the 45 companies who claim ties to the ship's original insurers. But it was complicated by an announcement that Columbia was entering the fray. The Ivy League university contends one of its researchers provided data used to locate the gold-laden wreck that is valued at $450 million to $1 billion. The exact location of the ship, which sank in 1857 about 160 miles off Charleston, S.C., is contained in files sealed by U.S. District Judge Richard B. Kellam. Columbia's attorneys maintain a 1984 sonar survey by Dr. William Ryan, a Columbia oceanographer, was the basis for the wreck's discovery. That survey was funded by Harry John, who once held 47 percent of the stock in Miller Brewing Co., and Jack Grimm, a Texas oilman. According to the school, Ryan later shared the data with Thomas G. Thompson, president of Columbus-America, without realizing Thompson would use the material for his own ends. Thompson and his company recovered a ton of gold from the wreck last summer. Company officials believe two tons remain. Thompson agrees that the wreck was located near the point Ryan's data would indicate but denies Ryan's data was used to locate it. Richard T. Robol, an attorney for Columbus-America, an Ohio-based company, described the university's claim this way: ``It's a lot like an astronomer taking a picture of the sky. That picture might contain an unknown planet, but the astronomer never sees it. Then, 30 years later, after exhaustive research, a second astronomer identifies the unknown planet, and the first tries to claim he found it 30 years earlier.'' Columbus-America officials say Columbia in any case lacks the equipment to excavate the wreck, which lies 1{ miles down. Before Columbia stepped in, the trial was a simple matter over whether the wreck had been abandoned. The insurance companies contended that although their corporate predecessors paid off $1.2 million in claims for the disaster, they never abandoned claims to the gold. Attorneys for Columbus-America argued that the companies did not own the treasure just because they insured it. The SS Central America ran into a hurricane and sank on Sept. 12, 1857, as it sailed to New York from California. Reports at the time put the number of dead at between 362 and 423 of the 578 people on board. Among the cargo were three tons of gold bars and freshly minted ``double eagle'' gold coins from the San Francisco mint. That gold was worth $1.6 million at the time and would be worth about $450 million at today's prices. In addition, many passengers were carrying fortunes they had made in California, and Columbus-America officials believe the total treasure could be worth up to $1 billion. The gold recovered last summer is being held by U.S. marshals in an undisclosed location.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Tracks Hottest House Prices
DOC.TEXT: Housing prices in Palm Beach, Fla., shot up 24.1 percent in the last year, making it the fastest-rising housing market in the country, says U.S. News & World Report. In this week's issue, the magazine lists the 25 U.S. metropolitan areas where median prices for existing homes climbed by the greatest percentages between the first quarter of 1989 and the first quarter of 1990. Akron, Ohio, where prices were up 22 percent, was second, followed by Greenville, S.C., Mobile, Ala., and Sacramento, Calif. The survey, carried out with the WEFA Group, a consulting firm based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., found that the estimated median price for homes in the West Palm Beach metropolitan area was $117,183 in the first three months of this year compared to $94,400 a year earlier. The hottest housing markets are not necessarily the most expensive. In Akron, even after the 22 percent jump, the median home price was estimated at $68,314, well below the national median of $93,100. The magazine survey also tracked the nation's coolest housing markets, topped by Youngstown, Ohio. Median prices there dropped 12.6 percent in the past year. DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Affirms Restrictions on `Baby Bells'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Court of Appeals says it agrees with a lower court that the seven Bell operating companies cannot enter the long-distance or telephone equipment businesses. However, Tuesday's ruling reopens the possibility that the so-called Baby Bells can sell electronic information services to homes and offices. The decision means that U.S. District Judge Harold Greene must consider anew whether the Bell companies may be allowed to develop so-called ``electronic Yellow Pages,'' allowing consumers to shop and bank _ among other possibilities _ via cheap, easy-to-use video terminals. A prototype system in France, called Minitel, already serves 5 million homes and offices and offers 8,000 different services. The three-judge appeals panel found that Greene ruled correctly when, in his 1987 ``triennial review'' of the American Telephone and Telegraph Co. antitrust settlement, he sustained the original order barring the seven spinoff companies from competing with their one-time parent in the long-distance and telephone manufacturing arenas. But appeals judges Abner Mikva, Harry Edwards and Laurence Silberman faulted Greene's legal reasoning when, as part of that same review, he only partially opened the door for the operating companies to expand into computer-based information services. Greene allowed the Bell companies to offer computer gateways and access menus for databases and services offered by other firms _ but not to generate those services themselves. That precluded them from pursuing a U.S. version of France's government-operated Minitel system. Kenneth Pitt, media relations director of Bell Atlantic, expressed excitement over the appellate ruling, though he conceded Greene could still rule against the Bell companies offering a variety of prospective services that include banking, home shopping, news, real estate listings, and medical monitoring.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Orders Speedier Schedule for Harris Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has ordered speeded-up handling of the case of Robert Alton Harris, who would have been the first person executed in California in 23 years if not for a reprieve. The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday voted 6-3 to leave intact a stay of execution issued by a lower court. That prompted predictions from prosecutors that the case would sit for months in the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. But before Attorney General John Van de Kamp could request quicker handling of the case, the appeals court Tuesday ordered it. The first written arguments from Harris' lawyers, normally due in 40 days, must be submitted by April 13. Remaining briefs from both sides will get an additional 17 days rather than 44, and the hearing is two weeks later, May 14. No deadline is set for the court to make its ruling. The panel consists of Judge John Noonan, who issued the order last Friday blocking Harris' execution, and Judges Arthur Alarcon and Melvin Brunetti. Harris, 37, convicted of the 1978 murders of two San Diego teen-agers, stood to become the first person executed in California since 1967. He has come within four days of execution twice _ in 1982 and again Friday, when Noonan granted on stay to consider whether Harris received competent psychiatric assistance at his trial. Hours after he was to have been executed at 3 a.m. Tuesday, Harris was removed from a special cell near the San Quentin gas chamber and returned to death row. Noonan's stay of execution centered on whether the psychiatrists hired by Harris' lawyer at his 1979 trial should have tested him for brain damage or other mental disorders. A psychiatrist and psychologist retained by current defense lawyers found brain damage, symptoms of fetal alcohol effect and other disorders and concluded that the previous experts were incompetent for failing to test for those problems. Van de Kamp contends the U.S. Supreme Court, in a 1985 ruling on the issue, did not intended to allow a newly hired psychiatrist to evaluate the work of earlier experts. Noonan's order would also open the door to a wave of attacks on cases in which the defendant's mental state was at issue, Van de Kamp said.

DOC.HEAD: Hope Triumphs Over Experience
DOC.TEXT: Divorced people go to the altar at higher rates than single folks, a new government report says. There were 807 marriages for every 10,000 divorced women in 1987, the National Center for Health Statistics reported. That compared to 589 marriages per 10,000 single women. Among men, the marriage rate was 1,157 per 10,000 divorced men, compared to 488 for single ones, the center said. Marriages involving single women and divorced men increased from 6.9 percent of all marriages in 1970 to 11.0 percent in 1987. Those involving single men and previously divorced women rose from 6.4 percent to 10.4 percent of marriages over the same period. And over that time span, marriages involving two previously divorced people rose from 10.7 percent to 19.1 percent of marriages across the country. Even though the figures are for 1987, that is the most current detailed information on marriages.
DOC.HEAD: Foley Says He Would Vote Against Flag-Protecting Constitutional
DOC.TEXT: Amendment

House Speaker Thomas S. Foley says he will vote against a constitutional amendment to protect the flag if the Supreme Court throws out the federal law against flag burning. By tradition, the Speaker of the House rarely votes and Foley has not done so since becoming speaker 10 months ago. But Foley said he would come off the speaker's podium and vote ``no'' if the House considered a constitutional amendment. Foley last year supported passage of the law against flag burning. But he said amending the Constitution, and especially the First Amendment definition of ``elemental freedoms of this country,'' was not justified. The First Amendment ``is the most sacred part of the constitutional document, and to amend it for these reasons would be extraordinarily unwise,'' Foley said. ``I think the judgment of history would be unkind on the Congress or the state legislatures if that were to occur.'' The Supreme Court has scheduled oral arguments for May 14 on whether it will uphold the judgment of two federal courts that the flag burning statute passed by Congress last year is unconstitutional. Foley has promised a House vote on a constitutional amendment within 30 days if the court rules against the statute.
DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says Justice Unit Will Review Findings of Gray Leak
DOC.TEXT: Probe

Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says he will direct the Justice Department's internal disciplinary unit to review the results of an FBI leak investigation. Thornburgh said Tuesday the Office of Professional Responsibility will review the inconclusive results of an FBI inquiry into leaks about a criminal investigation involving alleged financial irregularities in the office of Rep. William Gray III, D-Pa. The leak to CBS News _ at a crucial time while Gray was running for House majority whip last spring _ produced a storm of criticism from Democrats on Capitol Hill who charged it was politically inspired. It forced the Justice Department to take the unusual step of saying that Gray was not a target of the investigation, and that he was cooperating with the FBI. The extensive leak investigation ordered by Thornburgh failed to identify the source with certainty. The attorney general's decision in December not to refer the matter to the OPR for possible disciplinary action was criticized by several lawmakers, including Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. At a hearing of the panel Tuesday, Thornburgh told Biden that he would ask OPR to review the report produced by the FBI investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Richards Camp to White: No Apologies
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards is offering no apologies for her campaign tactics after former Gov. Mark White likened her behavior to that of Gestapo chief Heinrich Himmler. Stopping short of endorsing Attorney General Jim Mattox over Ms. Richards in the April 10 Democratic runoff for governor, White on Tuesday said he would vote in that race _ but not for Ms. Richards. ``I will never endorse Ann Richards. I will never support Ann Richards. And I will never vote for Ann Richards,'' said White, whose comeback bid collapsed when he finished a distant third in last month's Democratic primary. ``I've always thought he (Mattox) was one of the toughest campaigners I've ever seen, but what Ann Richards has done would make Himmler blush,'' White said. During a campaign stop in San Benito, Ms. Richards said: ``Well, that's too bad. ... I really don't think that it's like Mark White to call anyone a Nazi.'' The Republican nominee for governor, oilman Clayton Williams, had courted White, hoping to win the ex-governor's endorsement. Williams' press secretary, Bill Kenyon, said: ``We're happy with the governor's statement. We think it illustrates that moderate-to-conservative Democrats have no real choice in this runoff and the general election we believe that they will be attracted to Clayton Williams.'' White criticized Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, for TV commercials and speeches in which she alleged that he had profited from public service and helped his old law firm obtain state bond business while he was governor. White said Ms. Richards ``willfully and knowingly smeared me with false accusations that she knew at the time to be untrue.'' ``She didn't do it just once in the heat of an argument. She did it with inexcusable regularity in the last days of the campaign,'' White. Ms. Richards' campaign manager, Glenn Smith, said the campaign stands by its TV commercials critical of White. ``Ann Richards fulfilled the pledge she made when she announced her candidacy _ she said she would run a positive campaign until she was attacked _ and she was, by both her opponents,'' Smith said. ``Like all of us, Mr. White should support any candidate he chooses, and I'm sure he'll let his conscience be his guide.'' Meanwhile, Mattox charged Tuesday that he has signed statements from witnesses alleging Ms. Richards has used illegal drugs in the past 10 years. He faced three reporters alone because Ms. Richards declined to attend the debate, citing a previous commitment. Mattox said he has ``proof from the perspective of individuals that have said to me that Ann Richards has used certain drugs.'' Mattox refused to identify his informants. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, has been under fire for weeks for refusing to say whether she ever used illegal drugs. She has said only that she has not used any ``mood-altering'' drugs in 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,442.94, down 316.78 points, or 1.1 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Employers View Child Labor Violations as Inevitable
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Deparment's crackdown on child labor law violations was called ``nitpicking'' by one businessman and criticized by others who said it contradicted the government's goal of finding jobs for teen-agers. Nearly $3 million in fines have been levied on fast-food restaurants and other businesses for nearly 11,000 violations cited in a three-day federal sweep, Labor Department officials said Tuesday. Most of the violations involved teen-agers working more hours or later hours during the school week than is allowed under federal law. Others were illegally employed in dangerous jobs, such as using power-driven meat slicers, dough mixers and paper balers, the department said. Most of the companies fined agreed violations had occurred but said they were petty and unavoidable. The crackdown seemed to contradict Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole's recently expressed concern about jobs for youngsters, said Deborah Jackson, president of Morgan Memorial Goodwill Industries Inc., a Boston affiliate of Goodwill that was fined $6,000 for various violations. ``On the one hand the DOL is citing an organization as fine as Goodwill and on the other hand Elizabeth Dole is making a statement, and the two don't seem to be in concert,'' Jackson said. One of the violations charged that youths illegally packaged plastic toys in boxes, she said. ``If not this kind of job, I'm not sure how they intend to provide opportunities,'' she said. ``Frankly, the job's safe enough for my 9-year-old.'' Reams food stores in Utah were fined about $20,000 for violations involving about 80 youngsters. ``The violations were not flagrant at all. In most cases, they involved kids working 10 minutes beyond their three hours,'' said general manager Dick Cheney. ``We feel that we've obeyed the spirit of the law, and that they're nitpicking. They're on some kind of crusade.'' Dozens of companies were listed from around the country, including individual restaurants that are part of the McDonald's, Taco Bell, Jack in the Box and Burger King chains. Nearly half the fast-food restaurants and other businesses targeted in the sweep were found to be employing children illegally, said William Brooks, an assistant labor secretary. Of the 3,776 firms investigated, violations were found at 1,750, he said. The largest fine, $29,050, was levied against GFF Foods, a Moore, Okla., supermarket where juveniles operated a paper-baler, used to smash cardboard boxes. Gary Pierson, an attorney for store owner Truman Talley, said, ``I don't believe my client had any intent to do anything illegal or to risk the health of any employees.'' Mike Doty, a 19-year-old deli employee at GFF who has worked at groceries since he was 14, said the store seemed strict about use of hazardous machinery. ``The box crusher has signs all over it saying anyone under 18 is not supposed to use it, and here they keep a pretty close eye on it,'' he said. Dole defended the crackdown, saying new findings reinforce ``our belief that the trend toward violations is growing.'' Companies have the right to appeal the fines they think are unfair. Federal law forbids 14- and 15-year-olds from working more than three hours on a school day or 18 hours a week during the school year. Eight hours are permitted on weekend days and 40-hour weeks are permitted in summer and during vacations.
