DOC.HEAD: Honduran Immigrant's Dream Ends in Fiery Death in New York
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Life choices are limited in this small, dusty town, and Jose Manuel Marquez Hernandez was among the young people who looked to the United States for a better future. For Marquez, 24, the immigrant's dream of prosperity ended on March 25 in a fire at the Happy Land Social Club in New York City. He and six other young Hondurans were buried this week in El Progreso, a town of 30,000. They were among 87 people killed in the fire. At least 78 were Hondurans, most from the northern Atlantic coast region. The local victims came from poor families and had few choices: a lowly job at one of the U.S. fruit companies that made Honduras the original ``banana republic''; a dead-end job in San Pedro Sula, a coastal industrial center of 600,000 people; or immigration to New York, a promised land of jobs, education and opportunity. Marquez left six years ago. ``He wrote me last month,'' said Gregorio Hernandez, his uncle. ``He had gotten his high school equivalency diploma; he was applying to go to college.'' Meanwhile, Marquez worked at a factory, cutting leather to make clothing, handbags and shoes. Even at minimum wage, he earned enough to survive and send money home to his mother. ``I wrote him back,'' Hernandez said. ``I said: Become a professional. A professional never goes hungry. A professional lands on his feet anywhere life throws him.'' Hernandez was the first person in his family of nine children to finish high school. ``My three older brothers only finished the eighth grade because back then there wasn't a high school here and my father didn't have the money to send them to San Pedro Sula,'' Hernandez said. The brothers worked for the Tela Railroad Co., a subsidiary of Chiquita Brands, which has extensive banana plantations in Honduras. Hernandez became a supervisor at a textile factory in San Pedro Sula and assumed the leadership of the extended family because of his education and job in the big city. Wanting something better for his own children and those of his brothers and sisters, he sent his daughter and Marquez to New York to live with relatives. ``He never once failed with his monthly money for his mother and his brothers and sister,'' said Hernandez. When Marquez's older sister, one of four children, started college in San Pedro Sula, Marquez sent her a new typewriter. When he came home for Christmas, he brought gifts: a book for an aunt, sunglasses for his twin younger brothers, a small stereo for the family and money for his mother, who has been separated from his father for years. ``He was her sole support,'' said Hernandez. Marquez's Christmas visit was the first since he left El Progreso. Last Sunday, he returned in a slate-blue coffin on a Red Cross charter jet that carried the bodies of 47 other Hondurans as well. The Hernandez clan and neighborhood friends met him, as they had at Christmas. ``We've had to borrow money to pay for the funeral and the plot in the cemetery, about 1,200 lempiras ($300),'' said Hernandez. ``We're not rich, but we had to give him a proper burial.'' At the crowded cemetery in El Progreso, a boyhood friend, Jose Cardenas, 24, perched on one of the simple, cement-covered graves painted pink, blue and white and overrun with weeds and dust from unpaved streets. Cardenas had also gone to New York, but was deported last year as an illegal alien. ``Leaving here for New York is a change of life for the better, because there is nothing here,'' he said as Marquez's funeral procession arrived. ``You stay here and do this,'' he said, pointing to a rag-clad grave digger, ``or you go to New York.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Leader Confident Despite Setbacks, U.S. Hostility
DOC.TEXT: He was impish, indignant, humorous, uncompromising and, of course, long on words _ another typical evening for President Fidel Castro. And his message was clear: Cuba's revolution, at age 31, is stronger than ever, thanks in no small measure to the patriotic feelings stirred up by TV Marti transmissions by the United States. The scene was Tuesday night at the Palace of Conventions, where Castro regaled more than 200 foreign and local journalists for more than two hours. He held their attention throughout and was mobbed afterward. Castro even found good in the collapse of one-party communist rule in Eastern Europe, saying Cuba will be able to benefit from the mistakes committed by the region's ousted Communist leaders. Cuba chose the right path, Castro said, because capitalism has brought to the rest of Latin America rampant disease, inflation, unemployment and illiteracy. He said Cuba had virtually eliminated those problems. He brushed aside a question about predictions of his demise, saying ``only God knows,'' and feigned indignation when a Mexican reporter said he looked tired. Castro invited journalists from all over the world to visit Cuba this week as it engages the United States in a war of words and electronics over Voice of America telecasts to Cuba. The transmissions, known as TV Marti, began March 27 and Cuba immediately began jamming them. This week, Cuban officials have been showing off their jamming operations to the foreign reporters. While denouncing the trial U.S. telecasts in the strongest terms, Castro said Tuesday that they play right into his hands. ``This war, this aggression, this hostility, far from weakening the revolution, is strengthening it. It exalts the patriotic feelings of the people, their honor, their pride,'' he said. ``The more they attack the revolution, the more stupidities they go on doing, the stronger the revolution will be.'' Cuba's official news agency, Prensa Latina, paraphrased Castro's comments and the news conference and said: ``He warned that Cuba can also carry out surgical operations and remarked that such a U.S. action could end in war.'' Thus far, despite many predictions by Cuban officials of a strong response, Castro has been content just to jam TV Marti transmissions. The stated U.S. goal is to bring entertainment and balanced news to Cuba, but Castro calls the project a ``gross instrument of subversion.'' He suggested that a future target may be another U.S. broadcast operation, Radio Marti, which Cuba has allowed to function relatively unfettered since 1985. Castro said it would be wrong to assume that Cuba will allow the United States to beam radio waves at the island indefinitely. The ideal solution, he said, is to allow Cuba the same radio access to the United States. But he did not see that as a strong possibility. ``The United States cannot refrain from pursuing its feeling of being the owner of the world,'' Castro said. On Monday, President Bush hailed TV Marti as the latest U.S. effort to broadcast ``the truth'' to Communist countries. The television station is named after Jose Marti, a hero of Cuban independence. One result of U.S.-Soviet detente, said Castro, is an increasingly aggressive American attitude _ peace for the superpowers but not for countries on the U.S. enemies list. ``United States policy implies the right to intervene in Latin America or anywhere in the world,'' Castro said, citing U.S. military actions in such countries as Panama, Libya and the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Arthur Houghton Jr., Former Steuben Glass President, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Arthur Houghton Jr., former president of Steuben Glass and one-time chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has died at 83. Houghton died Tuesday at Venice (Fla.) Hospital after a brief illness. Houghton was a great-grandson of Armory Houghton, who founded Corning Glass Works in 1851. He became president of Steuben Glass, a Corning subsidiary, in 1933 and built its worldwide reputation during his 40 years in charge. Company legend has it that shortly after he took over Steuben, Houghton spent a Sunday smashing every piece of glass in a company warehouse to show his dissatisfaction with the design. The company's new designs came to be shown in museums in this country and abroad, and Steuben adopted the slogan ``From ash can to museum in half a century.'' Houghton was president of the Metropolitan from 1964 to 1969. In 1969 he was became chairman of the museum's board and served until 1972. He sat on the New York Philharmonic's board from 1952 to 1965 and served as chairman from 1958 to 1963. He was also vice chairman of a committee to create Lincoln Center, where the Philharmonic moved in 1962. Houghton is survived by his wife, Nina, a son and two daughters by previous marriages. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Knocks Off NBC in the Ratings
DOC.TEXT: The Oscars and a Barbara Walters special helped ABC knock NBC out of the No. 1 spot in the ratings after 23 weeks on top. Carol Burnett made a triumphant return to prime time on NBC; the Whoopi Goldberg-Jean Stapleton series ``Bagdad Cafe'' had a strong debut, and ABC's new ``Equal Justice,'' a lawyer drama, finished in the middle of the pack. For the week, ABC was first during the week ended April 1 with an average rating of 14.8, NBC was second with 13.3 and CBS third with 11.7, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. figures released Tuesday. Each point represents 921,000 homes. The last time NBC dropped to No. 2 was the week of Oct. 9-15, when ABC had the World Series. ``The Academy Awards clearly lifted us up there,'' said ABC spokesman Jim Brochu. The Academy Awards, a 3{-hour endurance event Monday, was No. 1 in the ratings. The ``Barbara Walters Special,'' featuring interviews of Chevy Chase, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Warren Beatty, was sixth. ``Carol & Co.'' a half-hour comedy-variety show on Saturday featuring Miss Burnett and an ensemble company, was in ninth place on NBC. ``Bagdad Cafe,'' based on the movie about a German tourist stranded at a remote desert diner, was No. 18 for CBS. The half-hour show is on Friday. ``Equal Justice,'' ABC's Wednesday night case for an hour-long legal drama, was tied for 44th. A two-hour ``Equal Justice'' movie on Tuesday was tied for 37th. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``The 62nd Annual Academy Awards,'' ABC, 27.9; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 23.8; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 21.7; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 21.4; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 20.4; ``The Barbara Walters Special,'' ABC, 20.3; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 20.0; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 19.5; ``Carol & Co.,'' NBC, 19.0; and ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 18.4. ABC was first in average ratings for the network news shows with a 10.3, but after seven weeks in third place, CBS edged into second place. It beat NBC by one-tenth of a ratings point, averaging a 9.4 rating to NBC's 9.3.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Shootings Scotch Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: Two more reported sniper attacks on buses have set the clock back on contract talks between striking drivers and Greyhound, which says it won't negotiate until a week passes without violence. A supervisor unloading a bus carrying four passengers in Miami late Tuesday discovered dents above a window that indicated someone fired a shotgun at the bus en route from San Antonio, said Greyhound Lines Inc. spokesman Steve Mead. No one heard or saw the blast and no one was injured, he said. Miami police had no information on the matter, Robert Neff, a duty officer, said today. Earlier Tuesday, a Southeastern Trailways bus was hit by sniper fire on Interstate 65 about 50 miles south of Louisville, Ky. Neither the driver nor the lone passenger was injured. A Greyhound spokesman, Steve Scarpino, said the gunmen attacking Southeastern may be confusing the independently owned line with other Trailways lines Greyhound owns. Greyhound, which has offered a $100,000 reward for evidence against snipers who have fired on at least 30 buses since the strike by 6,300 union drivers began March 2, called off talks set for Monday, Mead said. ``We're not going back to the table until the violence ends,'' he said. ``We just want one week without violence.'' The company blames the union for the violence. The union has suggested the company's refusal to negotiate is partly to blame for the violence. ``We certainly aren't doing this. We want to get back in to negotiations,'' said Ed Strait, president of Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions. ``I wish whoever's doing this would stop. They're not helping; they're hindering. We're not on strike against the public.'' The union struck over wages and benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We realize the Soviet Union has economic, political and military interests in Lithuania that cannot be cut all at once. These problems involve not only the Soviet Union and Lithuania but Europe and the whole world. So we need to talk. We want somebody to hold a dialogue with us.'' _ Egidius Bickauskas, the Baltic republic's representative in Moscow, after a breakthrough meeting with a key adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

``We can no longer delay. The American people want action. They demand action.'' _ Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, on Senate approval of a sweeping clean air bill imposing new emission curbs on automobiles, factories and electric power plants.
``It may not stop kids from smoking, but it puts another roadblock in the way.'' _ Mayor Jerry Briggs of White Bear Lake, Minn., on the city's ban on cigarette vending machines.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Warning Against Wearing Black On Mourning Day
DOC.TEXT: Chinese are being warned not to wear black armbands or white flowers of mourning on Thursday, the annual holiday when Chinese honor their dead and a potential time for anti-government protests. Chinese sources said today that some offices and factories in Beijing were advising workers against displays of mourning on Qingming, when Chinese traditionally sweep the graves of their ancestors. The Beijing city government has issued orders that ban organized group visits to cemeteries unless permission is received from authorities. Overseas dissident groups have called on students to ``stroll'' through Tiananmen Square on Thursday in a silent memorial to the hundreds of people killed when the military crushed the pro-democracy movement last June. A similar appeal to stage ``protest strolls'' on Sunday was thwarted when police closed the square to the public, ostensibly for daylong ceremonies to promote civic enthusiasm for the Asian Games. The games are to be held in Beijing in September. The government wants to avoid a repetition of the 1976 Qingming festival, when thousands streamed to Tiananmen to honor Premier Chou En-lai, who had died earlier in the year, and protest the party's leftist leaders. Suppression of the protesters helped lead to the downfall of the leftists. Beijing citizens are also being told by officials at work and school to stay away from Tiananmen Square, the focal point of last year's demonstrations. Factory leaders have been warned they will be held responsible if workers are involved in any protests. A source on one university campus said some students planned to go to the square on Thursday, but that most were frightened and would stay away. They have been told they face expulsion or assignment to work in a remote rural area if caught protesting. Police and military presence around the 100-acre square has been particularly heavy in the past week, partly because the National People's Congress, China's parliament, is holding its annual session in the Great Hall of the People west of the square. Today 300 to 400 police clearing the square for the closing session of the congress pushed and struck with clubs people who were slow in leaving, a foreign witness said. It was not clear if anyone was injured. Since Sunday, two Americans, a reporter and a student, were detained for an hour or more by police for photographing police or soldiers on the square. They were told taking photos of people without police permission was not allowed.

DOC.HEAD: Government Temporarily Suspends King After He Refuses To Sign Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: King Baudouin, a devout Catholic, stepped down temporarily today rather than sign into law a bill ending the country's 123-year ban on abortion. After relieving the king as head of state, the government enacted the abortion bill and asked Parliament to restore him as monarch at a special session on Thursday. The highly unusual move, made at the king's request, let the government enact legislation to allow abortion in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy and relieved the king of his constitutional duty to sign into law a bill he strongly opposes. Parliament adopted the bill last week. The royal suspension came after Prime Minister Wilfried Martens' center-left government consulted with the 59-year-old king, who insisted he could not sign the legislation. The king's powers are largely ceremonial. He has no real legislative powers but under the constitution he signs into law all the bills. In practice, the king also plays an active role behind the scenes, consulting regularly with government ministers. He has repeatedly acted to defuse disputes between Dutch- and French-speaking political parties, which often are locked in linguistic disputes. In public speeches he also has urged Belgium's 6 million Dutch and 4 million French-speakers to be more considerate of one another. The government made clear King Baudouin insisted on finding a compromise on the abortion legislation. ``Judging that his conscience did not permit him to sign the abortion bill ... the head of state asked the government and the Parliament to find a legal solution in which the need of the good functioning of parliamentary democracy can be reconciled with the right of the king not to act in violation of his conscience,'' it said in a statement. The statement said the royal suspension was legal under the constitution, which provides for the removal of the monarch if he or she is deemed to be ``in the impossibility'' of executing his functions. That clause had only been applied once before. In 1940, King Leopold III, Baudouin's father, was suspended after he was taken prisoner by Nazi Germany. After the war, Leopold could not return home because of a controversy over his wartime conduct. His brother, Prince Charles, became regent and was succeeded by King Baudouin in 1950.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Wanted: One millionaire to help a small, rural district build a new school. A Riverview School District citizens' group in this town 20 miles from Seattle took out a $175 ad in The Wall Street Journal, asking for someone to donate $1 million-plus for a school the district can't afford to build. The group has received a few responses, but no big bucks. A Colorado stockbroker has offered to set up a charitable trust for wealthy people who don't have heirs. A special education professor said he will donate up to a year of his time. And a Virginian gave the group suggestions on how to set up a fund-raising network. ``People do care,'' said Carol Van Noy, a member of the school committee that placed the ad. ``But our millionaire hasn't come forth. I'm hopeful. We really do need $10 million.'' That's what Riverview School Superintendent Karen Forys estimated as the cost to replace the current high school and middle school complex, which is overcrowded. The ad, which ran Thursday, will be run once more for free on Thursday because the newspaper misspelled the district's name as Riverside. ``We'll be checking the mailbox everyday,'' said committee member Laura Ritter. ``Maybe it just takes a while for this to sink in.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Dampens Northeast; Cold Spell in South
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell throughout the Northeast early today, while much of the South shivered in unseasonably cold temperatures. Showers were scattered over New York and New England. Snow fell over western Pennsylvania. Rain also fell in Montana. Winter lingered in the South, with temperatures in the 30s and low 40s in Georgia, Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas and Alabama. On Tuesday, it was more like summer over parts of the northern Plains. Leander, Wy., set a record for the date when the temperature rose to 71. Elsewhere Tuesday evening, rain fell over central and southern New England, eastern Pennsylvania, New Jersey and much of New York. Snow showers fell over Ohio, south-central New York, western Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Showers and thunderstorms developed over northwest Texas, central and northern Utah, southeast Idaho and Colorado. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 88 degrees at Yuma, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Voters Reject `Vanna White Veto'
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin voters curtailed the ``Vanna White veto'' power that let the governor strike letters from words to change the meaning of legislation, and an Assembly member survived the state's first recall attempt since 1932. Kansas City, Mo., voters Tuesday rejected a curbside recycling program that would have cost households $1.89 a month. St. Louis voters approved a 3.5 percent hotel-motel tax increase to help build a 70,000-seat, domed stadium. Two blacks were elected to a new nine-member City Council in Tulsa, Okla., created because of an NAACP lawsuit challenging the city's at-large voting system. Only one black had served in the city's governing commission in the 1980s. Voters also re-elected Mayor Rodger Randle. In the Bismarck, N.D., mayoral election, voters chose Bill Sorensen, a 40-year-old businessman over city Commissioner Leroy Walker and Lee Palmer, an 18-year-old high school senior. Palmer won 1,291 votes, or 11 percent, after campaigning with $80 and a platform supporting youth, the environment and ``general things like care for the elderly.'' In Wisconsin, Gov. Tommy G. Thompson once used his veto to change the amount of time a juvenile could be held in detention, crossing out ``48 hours'' along with selective letters to make the time read ``t-e-n day-s.'' A constitutional amendment curtailing that power was approved 386,178 votes, or 62 percent, to 238,807, or 38 percent, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting. Foes of the unlimited veto _ named for Vanna White, the letter-turner on ``Wheel of Fortune'' _ said it gave legislative power to the executive branch, violating the constitutional separation of powers. The amendment still allows the governor to strike words, numerals or entire sentences _ just not individual letters. ``Despite the complicated wording of the amendment, the public basically understood that the governor should not have the authority to create new words,'' said state Senate President Fred Risser, a Democrat. Thompson's legal counsel, Raymond Taffora, said Tuesday night the governor was ``disappointed by the vote because the governor's partial veto authority needs to be as broad as the Legislature's ability to pass items.'' Wisconsin voters also re-elected Donald W. Steinmetz to a 10-year term in the state Supreme Court in a close race against Richard S. Brown, a deaf appeals judge. Unofficial returns from 99 percent of the precincts showed Steinmetz defeated Brown 350,245 votes to 326,310, or 52 percent to 48 percent. In northern Wisconsin, state Rep. Jim Holperin defeated challenger Brian Sherren in a recall. Holperin was targeted by those opposed to allowing Chippewa Indians to exercise treaty rights to go spearfishing off the reservation. Holperin, a Democrat, survived Wisconsin's first legislative recall in 58 years by receiving 10,494 votes, or 61 percent, to 6,707 votes, or 39 percent, for Sherren, a Republican. Holperin opposed spearfishing of spawning fish but got in trouble with sportsmen over his support for a proposal to pay a band of Chippewas $10 million for some of their treaty rights. The Indians rejected the proposal. Sportfishermen and people in the tourist industry say they fear the spearfishing will deplete fish stocks.

DOC.HEAD: City Bedeviled by Precinct Number
DOC.TEXT: A suburb is having a devil of a time with its new voting precinct number. Deer Park Council members approved a resolution Tuesday asking the commissioners of Harris County to renumber Precinct 666 because some religious folk view the number as symbolic of the Antichrist. ``Deer Park is a fairly conservative, religious community, and it's just a stigma they don't want,'' said Harvey Petree, a Deer Park city councilman. ``I had never heard that the three sixes had any religious connotation,'' said County Commissioner Jim Fonteno. ``If I would have known then what I know now, I would have just asked the clerk to skip a number.'' Election officials redrew Precinct 470 in August because it had grown to include 3,200 residents, Fonteno said. The county splits any precinct with more than 3,000 residents each August, with the new numbers taking effect in March. When the Deer Park districts were split, the new jurisdiction got the next available number, 666.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Chinese Fugitive Narrowly Escapes to West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lede, SUBS 5th graf to CLARIFY that Chai fled China in past week and reportedly arrived in France on Sunday. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Speaking in...'
DOC.TEXT: A woman who became one of China's most wanted fugitives after last spring's pro-democracy movement tried several times to flee the country before getting out this past week, a newspaper reported today. Chai Ling helped lead the movement that was suppressed June 4 when troops shot their way into central Beijing, driving student protesters from Tiananmen Square and killing hundreds of unarmed civilians. Ten months later, the 23-year-old activist has emerged in the West with her husband, Feng Congde. Both were on a wanted list of 21 student leaders sought by the Chinese Communist authorities, who call the pro-democracy protests a ``counterrevolutionary rebellion.'' Chai made a dramatic appearance on Hong Kong television Tuesday night from an undisclosed location to announce her escape. Although the broadcast did not say where the interview was held, sources said she was in Paris. The couple reportedly arrived there Sunday. Speaking in a near whisper, the haggard-looking Chai vowed to keep fighting for democracy and paid tribute to student leaders who gave their lives for freedom. ``There are still many, many people who sacrificed their lives, who shed blood, who shed sweat and tears, for freedom and democracy,'' said Chai, frequently pausing to hold back tears. ``They are still in jail, or in exile, suffering the insufferable,'' she said. ``Wherever you are, friends, please accept our heartfelt blessing.'' Feng sat by her side and covered his face as he wept. Their escape received massive coverage in Hong Kong's newspapers today, reflecting the widespread sympathy the pro-democracy students in Beijing have generated in the British colony, which is to revert to Chinese rule in 1997. In Taiwan, newspapers printed her televised statement and picture on front pages. The mass-circulation China Times of Taiwan said the fugitive couple ``tried several times to leave the border but failed to take action because of problems at the reception end.'' They finally escaped ``the tight network of Chinese public security personnel, went through a tough journey and setbacks, then left the mainland,'' according to a story by a reporter the newspaper said had interviewed Chai. In her televised appearance, Chai said: `The road to freedom was very difficult, very long. Because of that, as I reached the last step toward freedom, I almost ran out of energy. I looked up to see this free world, to breath the fresh air.'' The 10-minute television tape appeared to be filmed in an apartment or hotel room. According to the China Times, the couple fled Beijing by train shortly after the June 4 crackdown. Chai and Feng soon separated and remained apart for eight months before reuniting two months ago. Chai was among the three most prominent student leaders of last spring's demonstrations. One leader, Wu'er Kaixi, fled to the West weeks after the crackdown. The other, Wang Dan, was captured by Chinese authorities in Beijing. A native of Shangdong province and a graduate student in the Department of Psychology at Beijing Normal University, Chai assumed the title ``commander of the headquarters to defend Tiananmen Square'' before the crackdown. Two Norwegian legislators nominated her for the 1990 Nobel Peace Prize. The China Times said Chai and Feng plan to resume their studies after a period of readjustment to living in the West.

DOC.HEAD: Town Under Curfew After Bombing and Backlash Kills 36
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Congress Party members walking out of parliament, comments by Sikh lawmaker, INSERT 4 grafs after 5th pvs, `The nurses'...' Picks up 6th pvs, `Militant Sikhs...'
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary troops patrolled a Punjab town today to try to prevent further violence after a bombing blamed on Sikh extremists killed 33 people and enraged Hindus retaliated by killing three people. People were confined to their homes by a curfew imposed on Batala shortly after Tuesday's bombing of a Hindu religious procession. Police said 33 people were killed and 68 injured when the bomb exploded as about 100,000 Hindus celebrating the birth of the warrior-god Rama paraded through a crowded vegetable market. Most of the victims were Hindus, though some Sikh onlookers were among the casualties. Immediately after the blast, Hindus beat to death two women nurses at a nearby hospital and a Sikh policeman, witnesses said. The nurses' religion was not immediately known. They were killed because a Hindu crowd was furious at finding no doctors on duty at the hospital, the witnesses said, speaking on condition of anonymity. In New Delhi, members of the opposition Congress Party walked out of Parliament when Speaker Rabi Ray refused to allow the Lok Sabha, or House of the People, to discuss the violence. At a Sikh temple near Parliament, the most influential Sikh leader in Punjab condemned the killings of the Hindus. But the leader, lawmaker Simranjeet Singh Mann, also added: ``Sikhs are being massacred. Our constitutional rights are being steamrolled.'' He then led a procession of about 200 Sikhs to Parliament. When Mann arrived he was not allowed in because he was carrying a sword, a Sikh religious symbol, and refused to leave it outside. Militant Sikh separatists, who want to create an independent nation for their religious minority, have killed more than 500 people this year in Punjab, a prosperous northern farming state where they hold a slight majority. Tuesday's attack was one of the worst this year. On March 7, a bomb and rifle attack by Sikh militants killed 34 people in the predominantly Hindu town of Abohar. Batala, a predominantly Hindu town of 120,000 people, is 25 miles northeast of Amritsar, a major center of the Sikh separatist movement and site of the faith's holiest shrine, the Golden Temple. After the bombing, Hindu crowds went on a rampage and hurled stones at a police station 450 feet from the blast site, said Gur Inder Singh Bhuller, deputy inspector general of police. He said five policemen were injured, and their colleagues fired in the air to disperse the mob. Witnesses said the mobs set fire to several shops and vehicles and tried to torch a Sikh gurdwara, or place of worship. Punjab state police, many of whom are Sikhs, were withdrawn from Batala to stop the backlash. Some people accused police of not providing sufficient security during the Ram Navami celebrations. Members of the federal government's Border Security Force were deployed in Batala after the blast. They patrolled on foot and in jeeps equipped with light machine guns. Senior police superintendent S.K. Goel said the bomb was hidden in a motor scooter parked outside a cigarette kiosk. He said he did not know if it had a timing device or was detonated by remote control. Goel said the bomb probably was planted by Sikh radicals. Other officials, speaking on condition of anonmity, also blamed Sikh extremists. Many of the victims were blown to pieces. Fragments of bodies and blood-stained vegetables were flung across the market. ``There was a loud sound. Then the entire area was covered with dark smoke and fire, which rose as high as electric poles,'' food vendor Pre Nath said from his hospital bed in Amritsar, where he was treated for leg injuries. The violent Sikh separatist campaign began in 1982 in Punjab, where more than 1,800 people were killed in the separatist violence last year. Nationwide, Sikhs make up only 2 percent of the population of 880 million while Hindus comprise 82 percent. Sikhs, whose faith has roots in Hinduism and Islam, say they are culturally and politically discriminated against by Hindus.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Pleads Guilty to Endangering Child
DOC.TEXT: A woman accused of trading her baby for cocaine has pleaded guilty to attempted child abandonment and endangerment of a child. Lisa Price, 24, admitted that she tried to abandon her 3-month-old son at the Who Care's-So What Bar in September. She also admitted to Jackson County Associate Circuit Judge Leonard Hughes that she endangered her son's health by leaving him lying on the hood of a car outside the bar. But she did not admit during court Tuesday to giving the child to a drug dealer in exchange for $20 worth of crack, as witnesses at the bar alleged. Her son, now 10 months old, is in the care of the Division of Family Services. In exchange for the guilty plea to both misdemeanors, prosecutors dropped three felony charges against her and recommended she be placed on two years' probation. Hughes agreed to do so. According to assistant prosecutor Jeff Bushur, Price said she was just trying to give the baby to someone who could care for him.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Anti-Viral Herpes Drug Effective Against Chickenpox
DOC.TEXT: A drug used to treat genital herpes has been found to speed up children's recovery from chickenpox, a University of Minnesota study says. Acyclovir reduced the number of itchy blisters and shortened by a day the normal five-day course of chickenpox in 50 Twin Cities children who received the drug, according to a report in this month's Journal of Pediatrics. Acyclovir is ``a safe and effective treatment'' for the illness, which almost every American gets sometime during childhood, said Dr. Henry Balfour, the pediatrician who headed the study. Balfour said Tuesday that the finding is important because most complications develop near the end of a typical five-day infection. He said some doctors may delay prescribing acyclovir until results of a larger, 10-city study are released, probably later this year. Other doctors may limit the use of acyclovir to youngsters 11 and older, who tend to have the most severe cases of chickenpox, Balfour said. But he predicted that its use eventually will be widespread. Chickenpox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus, a member of the herpes family of viruses, so it was natural to try the herpes drug against it, he said. About 3.5 million Americans a year develop chickenpox. About 4,000 children are hospitalized each year from complications of the disease, which include skin or ear infections, pneumonia and brain infections, Balfour said. No chickenpox vaccine is licensed for use in the United States, but vaccines are being tried in other countries, he said. In the study, within a day of developing their first chickenpox sores 50 youngsters got a syrup containing acyclovir, and 52 others got one with no medication in it. The children getting the acyclovir ended up developing an average of 336 skin lesions, compared with more than 500 lesions for those who didn't get it. Healing started within a day after the youngsters got acyclovir, compared with two days for those who didn't get it. Blood tests a year later indicated that acyclovir didn't interfere with the youngsters developing immunity to this virus, a process that normally prevents a person from having a second case of chickenpox. The study, sponsored in part by Burroughs Wellcome Co., manufacturer of acyclovir, was carried out from February through June 1987. Testing for immunity and analysis took two years.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Leader Urges Moslems to Release Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi urged Moslems to celebrate their holy month of Ramadan by releasing foreign hostages held in the Middle East, Libya's official news agency said today. Col. Gadhafi specifically mentioned Jacqueline Valente, a Frenchwoman captured on a yacht off Cyprus in 1987 by Abu Nidal's Libyan-backed Fatah-Revolutionary Council, the JANA news agency report said. Gadhafi appealed to ``Moslems the world over in his capacity as the leader of the international Islamic People's Command calling for releasing the hostages and prisoners of conscience on the advent of the blessed month of Ramadan _ the month of love and tolerance,'' said JANA, monitored in Rome. Ramadan began in late March. The JANA dispatch said Gadhafi stressed Islamic humanitarian values and called for refraining from detaining innocent people. ``He has called to mind the hostages in the Middle East of various nationalities and religions, in particular the French hostage,'' Jacqueline Valente. She was captured along with her two daughters and five Belgians. The Abul Nidal group claimed they were Israeli spies. Her whereabouts are unknown. The children, then aged 7 and 6, were freed in December 1988, reportedly after Gadhafi intervened. After their release, Gadhafi urged ``liberation movements in the Middle East'' to free the rest of the hostages. The group has not been included on the list of Western hostages held in Lebanon. Eighteen Westerners, including eight Americans, are missing and presumed held captive. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk to Meet With Mandela, Political Leaders for Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk will meet Nelson Mandela and other top leaders Thursday for talks on stopping widespread unrest and reviving negotiations on ending white-minority rule, officials said. Government and opposition officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said today that de Klerk will meet in Cape Town with Mandela and hold separate talks with a wide range of political leaders. Expected to attend the talks are Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, heads of tribal homelands, leaders of various political parties and top government ministers. Mandela and several other African National Congress leaders will meet de Klerk privately for talks on efforts to end political violence. The talks also will focus on reviving peace negotiations that were stalled when the ANC pulled out of an April 11 meeting. De Klerk's meetings with a wide range of leaders represent a major drive by the government to resolve the issues. Mandela told a news conference today that he could not say when full-scale talks on ending white-minority rule would be held. ``That will depend on the result of the discussions we are going to have tomorrow,'' he said. Police said today that three people were killed in vicious black factional fighting around Edendale in Natal Province that has claimed at least 58 lives in the past week. Two other people died in factional fighting in other parts of Natal, they said. Police commanders in the Edendale said the area was still very tense with sporadic clashes between rival war bands. Mobs set fire to at least eight homes and more than 12,000 refugees had fled the area, they said. South Africa has been hit by a wave of political violence in recent weeks that has claimed hundreds of lives. The fighting has ranged from tribal clashes in Natal to violent protests in black urban townships. Zulu leader Buthelezi appealed to Mandela to join him in efforts to stop the fighting in Natal. Buthelezi urged Mandela not to allow politics to interfere with peace efforts. ``I appeal to him to stand above politicking about life and death,'' he said in a statement. ``When people are dying and people are being maimed, black leaders should have the courage of their convictions to go to the trouble spots and to mediate between the warring factions.'' Mandela pulled out of a joint rally with Buthelezi in the Edendale area Monday after saying the time was not right. Mandela did tour the area Monday and Tuesday, appealing for peace. The Natal fighting, which has claimed about 3,000 lives in recent years, pits rival Zulu factions of the ANC-backed United Democratic Front against Buthelezi's conservative Inkatha movement. Both groups are anti-apartheid, but they differ over plans for South Africa's future. Mandela agreed to meet de Klerk Thursday after the ANC suddenly pulled out of planned April 11 talks with the government. The talks were to focus on ways to remove barriers to full-scale negotiations on ending white-minority rule. The ANC said it was pulling out to protest the police killing of nine black protesters March 26 in the black township of Sebokeng outside of Johannesburg. ANC leaders say they will hold talks once the government imposes controls on the police. De Klerk legalized the ANC and other black opposition groups in February and released Mandela after 27 years in jail. He has promised to end white rule and share political power with the black majority.

DOC.HEAD: Third Northeast Democratic Governor Decides Against Re-election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, `Gov. Judd...' to CORRECT that actions already were taken to erase New Hampshire deficit.
DOC.TEXT: A decade ago, governors in the Northeast were riding a wave of economic growth to political heights. But hard times have plunged them into the depths of a political depression as well as an economic one. Vermont's Madeleine Kunin on Tuesday became the third Northeastern governor to decide against re-election this year, announcing she won't seek a fourth two-year term. Her state's budget has been sharply cut, while a 12 percent increase in the personal income tax has been proposed. All three of the retiring governors are Democrats whose political futures cascaded with the economy and failed legislative programs. ``There's economic depression and also depressions in the political world. I think we're in one,'' said Frank Bryan, associate professor of political science at the University of Vermont in Burlington. ``One of the symptoms of political depression is the candidate says, `The hell with it. It isn't worth it to fight through this anymore.''' The governors apparently are tired of the burdens and negative reaction they would face in re-election bids next fall. ``This is really a typical pattern for difficult economic times,'' said Larry Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia who follows governors closely. ``When a egion is in trouble economically governors are simply encouraged to retire. They get tired of the burdens and also realize they might be defeated. They don't want to go out that way.'' That apparently was the case with Govs. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and William A. O'Neill of Connecticut. Dukakis won the 1988 Democratic presidential nomination partly on the strength of the ``Massachusetts Miracle.'' That economic takeoff began unraveling even during Dukakis' White House campaign. Dukakis announced more than a year ago that he would not seek a third consecutive term. His state faces a deficit of at least $780 million. Two weeks ago, O'Neill said he would not seek a third full term after his standing in the polls dropped. His unpopularity apparently stemmed from nearly $1 billion in tax increases he approved last year. ``The big question is if there are going to be any exceptions to this process,'' said Paul Watanabe, head of the political science department at the University of Massachusetts at Boston. Watanabe said political analysts will be watching whether Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, a potential Democratic presidential candidate, is able to buck the trend. ``In some respects so far he has,'' said Watanabe. ``I think he's been effective in indicating his ability to manage a crisis within New York and his ability to do so is going to significantly effect perceptions of him as a viable national figure.'' Cuomo is facing his third consecutive year of budget deficits and is talking about $1 billion in higher taxes. He has said he expects to seek re-election to a third term but has made no formal announcement. The GOP has branded Cuomo the ``Michael Dukakis of New York,'' but the Republicans have not put up a strong candidate of their own. Independent polls still give Cuomo high ratings. Cuomo said Tuesday that being a governor has become more and more difficult largely because the federal government is shifting more financial responsibility to the states. The economic woes thus far have not derailed the plans of the region's three Republican governors to seek re-election. Gov. Judd Gregg of New Hampshire has overcome a $160 million deficit. The Legislature cut services, laid off state employees and raised taxes on cigarettes, beer, gasoline, rooms and meals, business profits and real estate transfers. Gregg opposes a general sales and income tax. Maine is facing a $210 million deficit, but Gov. John R. McKernan said he is not abandoning his re-election campaign. He has strong opposition from his predecessor, Democrat Joseph E. Brennan, who has made the budget problems a key issue. Even though Rhode Island Gov. Edward D. DiPrete's popularity in a recent Brown University poll dipped to an all-time low of 30 percent, he is seeking his fourth two-year term. DiPrete is saddled with a $100 million deficit and has made cuts in social programs.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Second Satellite Functioning as Planned
With PM-Israel-Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Israel's second experimental satellite is orbiting the earth every 90 minutes and will remain in space for about 60 days, Israel Space Agency officials said today. ``Until now, all funcitons are working as planned and we are very satisfied with it,'' space agency administrator Moshe Bar-Lev told Israel radio. The 350-pound satellite, Ofek-2, was launched Tuesday by a three-stage rocket developed by Israel. Bar-Lev said the satellite had circled earth 16 times so far and that scientists are able to contact it the every time it passes over the country. The director of the space agency, Yuvall Neeman, said the Ofek-2 was lifted into space by the ``Shavit'' _ Hebrew for comet _ launcher which was developed by the Israel Aircraft Industries. ``It has two stages that are big rockets and a third and last stage which is really a small engine used to put the satellite into its proper orbit,'' he told The Associated Press. He said the engine was a slightly modified version of the Shavit rocket that lifted Israel's first satellite, Ofek-1, into space on Sept. 19, 1988. Ofek-1 remained aloft for four months. The Yediot Aharonot and the Al-Hamishmar newspapers quoted foreign reports as saying the Shavit was a modified version of the launcher designed to propel the Jericho-II, a surface-to-surface missile with a range of 1,375 miles. Earlier foreign reports said the Ofek-1 was also launched by the rocket that propels the Jericho-II. Neeman said he had no information of the Jericho missiles, and a spokesman for the Israel Aircraft Industries said he knew nothing about any such missile.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Says Chinese Leadership Is `Strong'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Li saying leadership strong, no comeback possible for Zhao. Edits throughout to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng said today that the Chinese leadership is ``united and strong,'' and he rejected the possiblity of a comeback for his disgraced predecessor Zhao Ziyang. In a 90-minute news conference, his first meeting with foreign reporters in almost a year, Li said: ``I don't think I'm extremely capable or extremely rich in political experience or entirely up to this job.'' But he added that he was ``somewhat more confident than when I was nominated to the post'' in 1988 for a five-year term. Also today, the National People's Congress, or parliament, closed its annual session after passing bills on Hong Kong and joint ventures aimed at reassuring a doubtful world the doors to China remained open. The 2,700 deputies to the 15-day session also approved a work report by Li that said China would never yield to threats against its socialist system. In the report _ China's version of a station-of-the-nation address _ Li hailed the ``victory'' over the pro-democracy movement, which troops crushed in June in an assault on central Beijing that claimed hundreds of lives. But at the news conference, Li's first appearance before the foreign press since June, he refused to specify who ordered the crackdown, saying that force was used ``only after a long period of patient waiting'' and after the nation and its socialist system was jeopardized by anarchy. The 62-year-old premier appeared relaxed and confident, but his responses were generally vague. ``The core of leadership with (Communist Party chief) Jiang Zemin as the nucleus is united and strong, and I believe it commands the support of the Chinese people,'' said Li, who declined to speculate on his own political future. He said the decision by parliament Tuesday to name Jiang to replace senior leader Deng Xiaoping as chairman of the state Central Military Commission confirmed the army was ``under the absolute leadership of the party.'' He said Jiang's appointment to the last official post the 85-year-old Deng had held would ``contribute to political stability.'' Jiang was named head of the 48-million-member Communist Party in June after Zhao was purged for allegedly supporting the pro-democracy students and dividing the party. Li said Zhao, who has not been seen in public since May, was in good health, living at home in Beijing and had not been imprisoned. Zhao, who was stripped of all his party posts, remains a party member but investigations into his activities continue, Li said. He doubted whether Zhao, who still commands a wide silent following in China because of his reformist policies, could stage a political comeback. ``I don't think that is the prediction of the majority of the Chinese people.'' Li said the just-concluded parliament session would ``inspire the Chinese people to work with one heart and one mind to promote political and social stability.'' The congress wields little political power in China's party-dominated system. In his state-of-the-nation report, delivered on parliament's opening day, Li said economic sanctions imposed by Western nations after the crackdown would fail, and China would stand firm against any foreign and domestic ``hostile forces'' trying to subvert Communist Party rule. All proposals submitted by parliament Chairman Wan Li were passed by overwhelming majorities. The two key bills approved today define the basic law for Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997 and amend the joint venture law to further protect foreign investors in China. The basic law provides that Hong Kong will have a high level of autonomy on all matters except national defense and foreign affairs after 1997, and that its capitalist system will be untouched for 50 years. It also says the legal system adopted under British colonial rule will in general be kept, and that Hong Kong will remain an international financial center and free port. Political activists in the colony have expressed misgivings about the basic law, saying it will impede democratic reform in Hong Kong and give Beijing arbitrary powers to declare a state of emergency. The amendments to the 1979 joint venture law were seen as a gesture to foreign investors wary of doing business in China after the crackdown. They stipulate that the lifetime of a joint venture, previously limited to 30 years, can be open-ended, and guarantee that such ventures will never be nationalized ``under normal circumstances.'' The law was also amended to say a foreign partner could be elected chairman of the venture. Previously, the Chinese side headed the board, even when the foreign partner's equity share exceeded 50 percent.

DOC.HEAD: More Prisoners Break Out of San Diego County Jail
DOC.TEXT: Eight inmates escaped from an overcrowded San Diego County jail in its third breakout since December. Seven of the latest escapees were still at large this morning, a sheriff's spokesman said. One was recaptured Tuesday night shortly after the eight cut their way through bars and kicked out a third-story window at the South Bay Detention Facility, said Sgt. Jim Cooke. A rope made of several knotted bed sheets was left hanging from the window. Officers circled the jail and were searching the area, Cooke said. Six escapees remain free from 13 who broke out in March and seven who escaped in December. Soon after last month's escape, county officials authorized $103,000 in security improvements at the jail, including the hiring of private guards. Other improvements authorized but not expected to be completed for three months include new motion sensors, window grates and exterior cameras. The jail, which is designed to house 192 inmates, frequently holds more than 800 prisoners. Since January 1989, 51 inmates have escaped from the county's seven jails and 24 have been recaptured.

DOC.HEAD: Crash Landing for Dumbo
DOC.TEXT: Disneyland's aging Dumbo the Flying Elephant crash landed, slightly injuring a teen-age passenger and grounding the park ride for a least a month of repairs. The fiberglass elephant car carrying the girl fell about 5 feet to the ground when a metal support beam snapped, Disneyland spokesman Bob Roth said Tuesday of Saturday's accident. ``Wear and tear is what it amounts to,'' Roth said. ``We'll have to wait to see what work needs to be done but it'll be closed at least a month.'' The 13-year-old girl, who was not identified, was treated at Disneyland's first aid station for a bumped nose and minor bruises, Roth said. She was taken to a hospital and returned to the park later in the day. The Fantasyland attraction, based on an elephant in a Disney animated feature in the 1950s, is among the oldest in the 35-year-old theme park. Fiberglass elephant cars rotate around a pivot and passengers in the cars manipulate a lever to make the cars move up and down. ``It was due for a major rehabilitation in about a month,'' Roth said. The ride is overhauled once a year by Disney technicians, he added. A family of three suffered scrapes and bruises in a similar accident on the Dumbo ride a year ago, Roth said.

DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian to Charge for Temporary Exhibit on Dinosaurs
DOC.TEXT: In an unusual but not unprecedented move, the Smithsonian Institution will charge fees for a temporary exhibit opening next week. Smithsonian Undersecretary Dean Anderson said the charge for ``Dinamation's Dinosaurs Alive and In Color'' was an experiment that will allow the museum to display an exhibit that otherwise would be too expensive to produce. The exhibition on dinosaurs at the Museum of Natural History will cost $4 for adults, $2 for children under 12 and will be free for children under 3. ``We pride ourselves on being free to the public.... We have a sense that coming to the Smithsonian (is) tantamount to an exercise of citizenship. Only if we're doing something very special does it make sense to charge a fee,'' Anderson said. The Smithsonian joined with Dinamation International Inc. of San Juan Capistrano, Calif., in a joint venture to develop and show. The Smithsonian will receive a share of the profits of the show, which runs through Sept.3. Anderson noted that the museum charges admission for its planetarium and films at the Air and Space Museum. And officials said the Smithsonian's Arts and Industry Museum charged 25 cents for an exhibit on drug abuse in the early 1970s. The National Zoo, also run by the Smithsonian, will test an admission charge for another dinosaur exhibit, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Restorers Will Not Remove Additions to Michelangelo Fresco
DOC.TEXT: Restorers cleaning Michelangelo's ``Last Judgment'' have decided not to remove changes another artist made to cover images deemed offensive in the Sistine Chapel fresco, Vatican Museum officials said. In 1564, Pope Pius IV, after siding with some 16th-century church officials shocked by nude figures in the 60-by-30-foot painting on the wall above the chapel altar, ordered artist Daniele da Volterra to cover up the most ``indecent'' nudes. Fabrizio Mancinelli, directing the cleaning of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel frescoes, told a news conference Tuesday that instead of painting over Michelangelo's creation, da Volterra substituted his own fresco after first removing Michelangelo's. ``Since the additions are in fresco _ removing the original fresco _ there is no real choice to take away those portions,'' said Kathleen Weil-Garris Brandt, a New York University art historian who is a consultant on the Sistine Chapel project. Mancinelli and Ms. Brandt said a conference of 54 international specialists who met last week at the Vatican decided there would be no attempt to remove the additions. Michelangelo painted the ``Last Judgment'' more than 20 years after he finished the ceiling, which he worked on between 1508 and 1512. The painting, now hidden by scaffolding, depicts a forceful Christ standing in judgment surrounded by apprehensive saints, angels and mythological figures. Mancinelli said the work to clean the masterpiece, the last phase of the Sistine Chapel restoration, will take about four years, including the time needed for scientific evaluation of the painting and the cleaning methods to ensure the work is not damaged in the process. The chapel restoration has been been surrounded by controversy. Critics led by James Beck, a Columbia University art historian, charged that the restorters were removing some of Michelangelo's retouchings and altering the colors of the frescoes. Mancinelli said the team left Michelangelo's work intact, removing only a dirty glue-varnish that had been added by restorers in the 17th and 18th centuries. To protect the newly cleaned frescoes and still allow them to be seen by thousands of visitors each day, the Vatican is regulating the humidity and has installed anti-dust carpets.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Charges Blue Baby Was Nicknamed `Smurfette'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Today was...' to add that baby was only blue temporarily.
DOC.TEXT: A couple are suing a hospital for $4 million, complaining staff members nicknamed their baby ``Smurfette'' because her skin was accidentally dyed blue. The suit claims Kirsten Madsen was ``subjected to the callous, distressing remarks ... among which was the reference to her just-delivered daughter as `Smurfette.''' Smurfette is a character in ``The Smurfs'' cartoon show. The Smurfs are elflike creatures with blue skin. The suit says Mrs. Madsen was injected with blue dye in her womb to test for a urinary tract infection 12 hours before she went into labor at Baptist Hospital year ago. Hospital spokeswoman Debbie Koch said no one at the hospital has any knowledge about use of the term ``Smurfette.'' ``Today was the first time any of us have heard those words used,'' she said. ``We have no reason to believe that to be true.'' Koch said the baby was discolored temporarily and was not harmed. The suit, filed last week, asked damages for negligence and for ``extreme, distressing and permanent emotional damage, humiliation and ridicule.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Government Troops Retake Key Guerrilla Town
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian government troops backed by tanks and heavy artillery today retook a strategic town held by non-Communist guerrillas, according to guerrilla and Western sources. The district capital of Tmar Pouk fell late this morning after continuous heavy attacks that began the previous day, the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Tmar Pouk is in northwestern Cambodia close to the Thai frontier. It was held by the two non-Communist guerrilla factions opposing the Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government: the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and fighters loyal to former monarch Prince Norodom Sihanouk. Government troops backed by Soviet-made tanks and artillery attacked Tmar Pouk from positions to the south that had been retaken over the past weeks, a senior Liberation Front official said. Guerrilla sources also reported a heavy government attack on a Liberation Front military headquarters at Boueng Trakuan opposite the Thai town of Taphraya, 30 miles north of Aranyaprathet. Western relief workers in Taphraya said the shelling across the border was so heavy it shook houses in the town. As many as 5,000 refugees have fled the fighting to the giant Site 2 refugee camp, about 60 miles north of Aranyaprathet, Western relief officials said. Western diplomats said there were reports that thousands more civilians had fled Tmar Pouk to take refuge in remaining guerrilla-held areas inside Cambodia, which the guerrillas call ``liberated zones.'' The diplomats expected government troops would continue their push northward to the last remaining Liberation Front stronghold of Banteay Chamar. ``This spells the end for the liberated zones. The only remaining stronghold of Banteay Chamar will now fall for sure,'' one of the diplomats said. A senior Liberation Front official said the fall of Tmar Pouk occurred because a shipment of Chinese weapons failed to arrive. China is a main backer of the guerrillas. Western relief workers also said there were reports of heavy government attacks on Khmer Rouge positions opposite the town of Trat on the southernmost part of Thailand' border with Cambodia. These had occurred over the past few weeks, but the sources had no more details. The government launched a major counteroffensive in late February, and has succeeded in retaking much of the area seized by the guerrillas shortly after Vietnam said it had withdrawn all its pro-government troops in late September. The Vietnamese invaded Cambodia in late 1978 to stop border attacks by the communist Khmer Rouge, which controlled Cambodia from 1975-1978. During that time, hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people died from Khmer Rouge executions, famine and civil unrest. The Vietnamese-backed Cambodian government has been fighting a coalition of three major Cambodian resistance groups _ the Khmer Rouge, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and followers of Sihanouk _ for control of the country. International peace efforts have so far failed. Earlier today, Sihanouk returned to Bangkok from Beijing en route to his home in a liberated zone in Oddar Meanchey province, north of Tmar Pouk, a spokesman for the prince, Ek Sereywath, said.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Resume on Forming New Government
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's major political parties today resumed talks on forming a government on the eve of the opening session of the country's first freely elected Parliament. The major powerbrokers in the coalition talks said they were optimistic that a new government could be formed soon, but not before the middle of next week. The conservative Alliance for Germany, which won the most Parliament seats in the March 18 elections, is trying to form a coalition with the Social Democrats, who finished a distant second. The major parties met separately today after meeting together the day before. Spokesmen later said it was unlikely a new government would be formed this week. The talks are crucial to the formation of a Cabinet that will lead negotiations with West Germany and the former World War II allies on unification of the two German states. The Alliance for Germany led by Lothar de Maiziere, the likely premier of the nation, favors rapid reunification, while the left-leaning Social Democrats want a gradual melding of nations. The negotiations took on an air of urgency this week after West Germany's central bank recommended a 2-1 conversion of East German marks to West German marks as part of a currency union. East German parties united in opposition to that proposal and called for a direct 1-1 conversion to ease the withdrawal pains of unemployment and high prices as East Germany sheds it socialist system. But the Social Democrats still are opposed to the more conservative elements in de Maiziere's coalition. Much of the wrangling has been over the distribution of Cabinet posts in a newly formed government. ``There are indeed as before substantial differences, but these are not insurmountable,'' lawmaker Richard Schroeder, leader of the Social Democrat faction in Parliament, said Tuesday. Social Democrat spokesman Guenther Krug said there would not be a coalition if the Social Democrats' positions were not adequately represented in a coalition platform expected to be hammered out during negotiations. The first openly elected lawmaking body in the nation's history is to convene on Thursday in what will likely be a ceremonial session with little substantive political action. Since East Germans toppled the hard-line government of Erich Honecker in October, a Communist caretaker has been running the economically troubled nation. The talks have been hamstrung over allegations that many members of the new Parliament cooperated with or worked for the former secret police of the old Stalinist leadership. Social Democrat leader Ibrahim Boehme resigned over the weekend because of such allegations, although he has denied involvement. De Maiziere has denied similar allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Testing in San Francisco of Abortion Pill Proposed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf, `But testing...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with FDA response. Drops BRF-- designation.
DOC.TEXT: The city Board of Supervisors is considering a resolution to urge the Legislature to pay for testing in San Francisco of the French abortion pill. A group of doctors has formulated a plan to test the pill, called RU 486, at three San Francisco hospitals. It is estimated that clinical trials involving some 200 women would cost $60,000 to $100,000. The proposal, introduced by Supervisor Terence Hallinan on Monday, was developed at the urging of former city Supervisor Carol Ruth Silver. She heads an organization aiming to make RU 486 available to women in the United States. The federal Food and Drug Administration has indicated it would not approve clinical trials of the drug because of the Bush administration's objections to abortion. Moreover, anti-abortion groups oppose the pill. Testing in California could be conducted under state legislation originally passed to help speed testing of AIDS drugs. However, FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said Tuesday: ``California law for testing only involves drugs that are made, tested and sold in California. If the drug is imported, it triggers FDA jurisdiction.'' The FDA has allowed only one group of U.S. researchers, at the University of Southern California, to import the drug for a limited trial.

DOC.HEAD: Some States Take Exception in Adopting King Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Backers of... to CORRECT that New Jersey is not among states where holiday could fall on a weekend.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-King Holiday, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Martin Luther King Jr. Federal Holiday Commission counts 46 states _ going on 47 _ as having an official state holiday honoring the late civil rights leader. But not everyone agrees on that count. Arizona, New Hampshire and Montana will be the only states without a King holiday with the governor's promised signature of a bill approved last week in Idaho, according to Margie Hollums of the commission staff. But North Dakota's holiday isn't paid, and Louisiana's is by proclamation rather than legislation. And some of the King Day states give employees other holiday options. Three states have established the holiday as a day other than the third Monday in January. Louisiana makes it Jan. 19, Maryland Jan. 15 and New Jersey the Monday after Jan. 15. Backers of the King holiday sometimes have argued that it is not official unless it is adopted by legislation as a paid holiday on a weekday. Under that logic, the number of states with a holiday will be no more than 45 and as few as 43, depending whether the dates set by Louisiana and Maryland fall on weekdays in any given year. Washington, D.C., Puerto Rico, Guam and the Virgin Islands have a paid holiday, the first two by legislation and the latter two by executive order.

DOC.HEAD: Water Crisis Eases in Fuel Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7 `The Midland...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with spill leading edge passing Midland, East Liverpool closing intakes.
DOC.TEXT: Threats to water supplies created by a fuel spill in the Allegheny River waned as the slick snaked along the Ohio River toward Ohio and West Virginia. ``In our tests we're seeing a marked dissipation in the amounts of fuel throughout the rivers,'' said Betsy Mallison, spokeswoman for the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources. The concentration of petroleum 5 feet deep in the Ohio River at West View dropped from 75 parts per billion at 1 p.m. to 25 parts per billion six hours later, Ms. Mallison said. The spill, which stretched 14 miles through the river in industrial Beaver County early today, came from at least 75,000 gallons of diesel, gasoline and kerosene seeped from a severed interstate pipeline into an Allegheny River tributary Friday after a mudslide near Freeport in rural Armstrong County. The Allegheny flows into the Ohio River at Pittsburgh. The spill at one time had threatened the water supplies of up to 1 million people along the Allegheny and Ohio rivers. The Midland Water Authority, about five miles east of the Ohio and West Virginia state lines, closed its intakes at 11 p.m. Tuesday, and the spill's leading edge passed about 2{ hours later, plant manager John Uccellini said. The authority serves 11,700 Beaver County residents in Midland, Ohioville and Industry. Uccellini said state environmental officials would test the water for oil concentrations, and the intakes likely would be reopened later today. Across the Ohio border, officials in East Liverpool were testing the water but had detected no trace of oil as of 8:45 a.m., said Joe Miller, chief of the East Liverpool filtration plant. The water authority in East Liverpool, which serves about 7,000 customers, closed two intakes near the surface of the water but hoped to continue drawing water from an intake at the bottom of the river, Miller said. The state National Guard offered 100 water tankers to Midland area residents, said Russell Chiodo, director of the Beaver County Emergency Management Agency. ``I pray that we don't need them,'' he said. The spill was no threat to other water systems serving Beaver County because those systems draw well water, Chiodo added. Freeport, the first city to stop drawing water over the weekend, reopened intakes that were closed for 3{ days. Ten water plants along the Allegheny had resumed use of river water Tuesday night, Ms. Mallison said. About 20,000 residents of Harrison Township were asked to boil water to kill bacteria that might have grown in the system when it was empty, she said. Nine oil-collecting booms on the Allegheny were removed because they weren't necessary, said federal Environmental Protection Agency spokeswoman Carrie Deitzel. Sixteen other booms remained in the river. The state is calculating environmental and lost-water costs to be charged to the owner of the severed petroleum line, Allentown-based Buckeye Pipeline Co., said Mark McClellan, the Department of Environmental Resources deputy secretary. The company also could face fines for delaying notification of the spill to the state, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hemophiliacs Live with Uncertainty of AIDS Infection
DOC.TEXT: For more than half of the nation's 20,000 hemophiliacs, the AIDS virus is a fixture of daily life _ just like the blood protein supplements that both keep them well and gave them the dangerous infection. Like Ryan White, the Indiana teen-ager whose fight against AIDS bias made him a national symbol, most hemophiliacs became infected during the early 1980s before anyone knew that the virus was spreading silently by means of their medical treatment. Hemophilia is an inherited disorder in which blood fails to clot properly. To prevent uncontrolled bleeding, hemophiliacs need infusions of factor VIII, a blood-clotting protein that their bodies lack. The substance is refined from the blood of many donors. The treatment became tainted with HIV, the AIDS virus, between 1978 and 1984. Better cleansing techniques eventually made factor VIII free of HIV, but by then, thousands of hemophiliacs were already infected. The National Hemophilia Foundation in New York now estimates that about 55 percent of the nation's 20,000 hemophiliacs carry HIV. The uncertainty of when or if they will develop AIDS is a simple fact of life for these people. About 1,200 of the 125,000 AIDS victims since the epidemic began have been hemophiliacs. But those numbers are likely to grow, perhaps substantially. ``This is what scare us the most,'' said Alan Brownstein, executive director of the hemophilia foundation. ``All of these people were infected at least six years ago. As we learn more about the incubation period, we know we are getting closer and closer to a time when even more people with hemophilia will get AIDS.'' To help forestall this, the drug AZT is now recommended for infected hemophiliacs whose blood counts fall below a certain level. However, some doctors say that many outwardly well hemophiliacs are reluctant to begin routine treatment with this medicine. In fact, despite their high risk, hemophiliacs often appear reluctant to face up to the possibility that they might die from AIDS. Brownstein said that in some parts of the country, one-third of hemophiliacs have not been tested to see if they are infected. Some say this denial is simply another facet of going through life with a disease that makes routine chores and pleasures hazardous. For people with severe hemophilia, a fall or a cut can cause dangerous bleeding. ``There are strong denial elements that exist for many hemophiliacs. If they didn't have denial skills from early childhood, they never would have taken the training wheels off their bikes,'' said Dr. Richard Lipton of Long Island Jewish Hospital. Dr. Bruce Furie of New England Medical Center in Boston said some infected hemophiliacs seem to take comfort from the fact that physicians cannot tell them with 100 percent confidence that they will get AIDS. ``They are living normal and productive lives,'' he said. ``They went through their crisis three or four years ago when they found out they were infected. Most of them are still going along with their activities but with the knowledge that they are playing Russian roulette and don't know when or if the gun will go off.'' Making factor VIII free of HIV was expensive and the cost of therapy has increased 10-fold since the discovery of AIDS. Routine treatment of a patient with severe hemophilia can now range from $50,000 to $100,000 a year.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Obit-Vaughan
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of records made by jazz singer Sarah Vaughan: ``Send in the Clowns,'' with Count Basie Orchestra. ``Irving Berlin Songbook,'' with Billy Eckstine. ``A Time in My Life.'' ``Send in the Clowns.'' ``Sarah Vaughan Live in Japan.'' ``More From Japan.'' ``Sarah Vaughan and Jimmy Rowles Quintet.'' ``After Hours.'' ``At Mister Kelly's.'' ``At the Blue Note.'' ``Favorites.'' ``Great Harmony.'' ``Great Songs From Hit Shows.'' ``Sarah Vaughan With Her Trio.'' ``In a Pensive Mood.'' ``In a Romantic Mood.'' ``Linger Awhile.'' ``No 'Count Sarah.'' ``Vaughan and Violins.'' ``Wonderful Sarah.'' ``Body and Soul.'' ``I Cover the Waterfront.'' ``The Divine Sarah With Bud Powell.'' ``It's Magic.'' ``Lover Man,'' with George Treadwell Orchestra, Richard Maltby String Orchestra, Dizzy Gillespie, Charlie Parker. ``The Divine Sarah Vaughan: the Columbia Years.'' ``Mean to Me.'' ``Lullaby of Birdland.'' ``The Complete Sarah Vaughan on Mercury.'' ``Sarah Vaughan in Hi-Fi,'' with Miles Davis. ``Sarah Vaughan in the Land of Hi-Fi,'' with Ernie Wilkins Orchestra. ``Sassy.'' ``Broken-Hearted Melody.'' ``After Hours.'' ``Sassy Swings the Tivoli.'' ``Sarah + 2.'' ``Sassy Swings Again.'' ``Sarah Vaughan-Michel Legrand.'' ``Live in Japan.'' ``How Long Has This Been Going On?'' ``Crazy and Mixed Up.'' ``Brazilian Romance.''

DOC.HEAD: Neighbor Convicted in Slaying of 13-Year-Old Girl
DOC.TEXT: The family of a 13-year-old girl screamed and shouted obscenities after a jury convicted a Long Island neighbor of brutally murdering her. Robert Golub, 22, sat quietly at the defense table after the verdict Tuesday while Kelly Ann Tinyes' relatives yelled obscenities at him. Kelly's battered, slashed body was found in the Golubs' basement March 4, 1989, a day after she disappeared. Prosecutors said Golub lured her there with a phone call, then beat, strangled and sexually mutilated her. Kelly's mother, Victoria Tinyes, pounded the railing in front of her and screamed. ``Are you happy now with what you did? Are you happy now?'' she cried at the Golub family. Golub's sister Adele, sitting with her parents, stood up and shouted, ``I didn't do anything!'' ``You know what you did,'' yelled a Tinyes supporter. Court officers ushered the Tinyes family out. The convicted murderer's parents cried as their son was led away in handcuffs. They left the courthouse without speaking to reporters. ``I'm just sorry I didn't get my hands on him,'' Kelly's grandfather, Victor Giordonello, said outside the courtroom later. Nassau County Court Judge Marvin I. Goodman ordered that Golub be evaluated by a psychiatrist before his sentencing June 1. He faces up to 25 years to life in prison. Since the arrest of the elder Golub son, Tinyes family members have verbally confronted the Golubs, who live four houses away on a tree-lined road in suburban Valley Stream. Neighbors have ostracized the Golubs, shouting ``Evil!'' and ``Animals!'' as they went in and out of their home. The two families attended court daily during the nine-week trial; neither family returned home Tuesday night, staying with relatives instead. During the trial, court officers occasionally had to restrain Tinyes relatives when they verbally attacked the Golubs in the halls. In one fracas, a Tinyes supporter shouted at the Golubs, ``Your son belongs in a cage!'' Several neighbors who refused to give their names said they hoped the Golubs would move. ``Time has come now for them to move out,'' said one woman. ``We don't want them in our neighborhood. That's the only unfinished business.'' Eggs have been smashed against their front door, their windows have been broken and fires have been set in their garbage cans. Defense attorney David Grossman said an appeal was being considered.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Newspapers Cited as Examples of Excellence by ASNE
DOC.TEXT: Ten small newspapers have been cited as examples of excellence by the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Chosen from newspapers with less than 50,000 circulation were: The Bradenton (Fla.) Herald; Daily Camera in Boulder, Colo.; The Times in Gainesville, Ga.; Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald; La Crosse (Wis.) Tribune; The Capital Times in Madison, Wis.; The Sun News in Myrtle Beach, S.C.; Naples (Fla.) Daily News; The Day in New London, Conn.; and the West County Times in Pinole, Calif. ``I think this is one of the most thorough evaluations of small newspapers ever undertaken,'' said Jim Herman, editor of the Traverse City Record-Eagle in Michigan and chairman of the society's excellence in small newspaper project since its inception two years ago. ``Our goal is to find small newspapers that are doing outstanding jobs and to learn from them.''
