Herman said ASNE's selection process began last fall when 1,356 small daily newspapers were invited to compete. More than 450 newspapers were submitted for consideration and regional judges narrowed that field to 74 finalists, he said. In January, 13 judges gathered at the Poynter Institute in St. Petersburg, Fla., and selected the 10 winners. The judges included editors, journalism educators and readers. ``The papers were graded on a wide range of criteria,'' Herman said. ``One of the most important was that they have an independent style and that they have a strong sense of place.'' It was the second year ASNE has honored excellent small newspapers. Last year, 14 were chosen.

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Soviets See Signs Of Dialogue On Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New with fuller Baker quotes, comments from Soviets; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today there are indications the Soviet Union may be considering a referendum in Lithuania as a way of shaping the future of the independence-minded Baltic republic. But Baker also registered ``a degree of concern'' about the Lithuanian situation as he prepared to begin three days of talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Baker is hoping Shevardnadze's visit will produce a plan for a peaceful settlement in Lithuania as well as a date for the next superpower summit meeting and progress on U.S.-Soviet arms control accords. At the State Department, Baker said Lithuania ``will be at the very top of the issues we will be discussing.'' Talking to reporters after a meeting with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, he said ``we are anxious to see these developments proceed peacefully and be resolved through dialogue.'' Baker was buoyed by the meeting Alexandr N. Yakolev, a close adviser to Gorbachev, held in Moscow on Tuesday with a delegation of officials from Lithuania. ``There would appear, at least, to be the beginnings of such a dialogue,'' Baker said. ``... We are encouraged as well that we see references coming from both sides to the concept of the possibility of some sort of a referendum approach.'' A Soviet foreign ministry official, appearing on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America,'' reaffirmed the Kremlin's pledge to deal with the secessionists in a peaceful way. ``Mr. Shevardnadze will certainly describe our attitude and reiterate our intention to work toward resolution of the situation through dialogue and in a peaceful manner,'' said Vitaly Churkin, an adviser to the foreign minister. Last Thursday, Lithuanian leaders informed the Kremlin they were ready to discuss the issue of a referendum on secession if Gorbachev agreed to talk with them. The Soviet leader, having demanded the nullification of a March 11 declaration of independence, did not respond immediately. But the meeting with Yakolev indicated the two sides may be trying to find a way out of the impasse created by the declaration and Gorbachev's refusal to accept it. Baker's remarks today suggested he shared in that judgment. Also on the agenda is the war in Angola between the Soviet-armed government and U.S.-aided rebels. Baker is trying for a cease-fire but insists on a commitment from the Luanda government that it will share power with the UNITA guerrillas led by Jonas Savimbi. Before the opening round beginning late this afternoon, U.S. officials had no word on whether Shevardnadze brought a reply from Gorbachev to Bush's letter last week reiterating U.S. hopes for a peaceful settlement in Lithuania. But the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they hoped Gorbachev and Shevardnadze would spell out how the Soviets plan to come to grips with the secessionist movement in the Baltic republic. Arriving here Tuesday, Shevardnadze likened events in Lithuania to an earthquake, but he also pledged to engage in ``honest dialogue'' with the independence movement. While the foreign minister's remarks had a conciliatory ring, he also emphasized the importance the Kremlin attaches to the Soviet Constitution and Soviet laws. ``You must understand the importance of that question for the Soviet Union and the Soviet people,`` Shevardnadze said. Bush and Baker have no intention of scrapping plans for the summit over Lithuania, officials said. The selection of a precise date in June depends on the Soviets scheduling a People's Congress in Moscow the same month. Bush and Gorbachev hope during the summit to sign an accord to limit their long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. However, claims that the overall cutback would amount to 50 percent came under challenge on Tuesday. A senior administration official, declining to be identified, told The Associated Press the United States would wind up with only slightly fewer deployed warheads than in the current arsenals. When warheads kept in storage are taken into account, he said, the U.S. total actually would exceed the current level. The official said that from the U.S. standpoint the principal virtue of the treaty would be to force a reduction in long-range Soviet SS-18 missiles. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said the treaty would cut the SS-18 force in half and also reduce the total of deployed Soviet missiles by about half. ``The treaty is based on equality,'' she said, reading from a statement. ``Since Soviet force levels exceed our own in the most dangerous and destabilizing systems, their reductions will be somewhat larger.''

DOC.HEAD: President Promises Medellin Leader No Extradition
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with president saying Medellin leader will not be extradited to U.S. if he surrenders. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco today said the leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel will not be extradited to the United States if he turns himself in. It was the first time Barco had made such a promise to a drug trafficking suspect since he ordered a government crackdown on traffickers in August. Barco made the offer to the Medellin leader, Pablo Escobar, in an interview with the Colombian radio network RCN. ``Mr. Escobar has said that he is going to give himself up, and I say that if he surrenders I guarantee the judges will judge him with complete impartiality,'' Barco said, referring to Colombian courts. In the last seven months, the Barco government has extradited 15 trafficking suspects to the United States. Like all other trafficking suspects, Escobar faces no drug charges in Colombia. He does face several murder charges, including one for the slaying of a newspaper publisher, Guillermo Cano. Cano was killed in a submachine-gun attack in front of his Bogota daily newspaper El Espectador on Dec. 17, 1987. The newspaper had been crusading for government action against drug traffickers. In the interview today, Barco guaranteed Escobar a fair trial in Colombia. No major drug trafficker has ever been tried, convicted, sentenced and imprisoned in Colombia on any charge. Seventy-five judges have been killed in Colombia in the last 12 years. Many of them were handling drug trafficking cases. It also is common knowledge in Colombia that some federal judges can be bribed. Several judges are dismissed each year for corruption. Cocaine bosses bent on halting extraditions have stepped up their terror campaign. On Monday and Tuesday, traffickers killed at least 12 police officers in and around Medellin, officials said. Last week, traffickers threatened to set off a bomb in Bogota for each new extradition. The threat was issued after the government extradited to the United States a drug suspect following a two-week hiatus. The chief of the national police, Gen. Miguel Gomez Padilla, told reporters late Tuesday that police reinforcements would be sent to Medellin to handle the increased violence. In January, the Medellin cartel curtailed attacks while making peace overtures. It said its leading figures were willing to surrender if the government promised not to extradite them to the United States. Barco's government rejected the offer at the time. Early Tuesday, two gunmen pulled Sen. Frederico Estrada from his car in Medellin and fled with him in another vehicle, police Chief Col. Alberto Otalora told a news conference. Anonymous callers to news media said the Medellin cocaine cartel had kidnapped Estrada and would release him soon with a message for the government. Otalora said Estrada had opposed traffickers' attempts to persuade the government to open peace talks. Police said the Medellin cartel has offered $4,290 for each national police officer killed in Bogota and Medellin, and $100,000 for each member of an elite 2,000-man anti-narcotics unit. No members of that force have been killed. The cartel also threatened last week to resume killing government officials, judges, police and the owners of El Espectador. On Tuesday, El Espectador said in a front-page statement it would suspend its entire editorial column until the government gives the paper adequate protection. The editorial column, often filled with denunciations of traffickers, was a strip of blank, white paper two columns wide and 12 inches long.

DOC.HEAD: Cell Transplant Gets Diabetic off Insulin Temporarily
DOC.TEXT: A transplant of insulin-producing cells enabled a woman with diabetes to go without daily insulin injections for more than two weeks, say researchers at Washington University. However, after that period, the woman's body began to reject the transplant, doctors said. Researchers David Scharp and Paul Lacy said Tuesday that the case was the first time transplanted cells temporarily eliminated the need for insulin injections in a patient with juvenile-onset diabetes. Researchers previously had only been able to reduce the need for insulin, they said. The results were announced in the April issue of the journal Diabetes. The 36-year-old patient was one of several given a pancreatic islet cell transplant during pilot clinical trials at Washington University School of Medicine and Barnes Hospital in St. Louis. Islets are pockets of hormone-producing tissue that release insulin. The transplanted cells, injected into the patient's liver, were removed from the islets of two cadaver pancreases. Jay S. Skyler, vice president of the American Diabetes Association and professor of medicine at the University of Miami, said the study was promising, but he cautioned that it was only one step toward a cure. ``We still have a ways to go,'' Skyler said. ``Now we've got to figure out why it's only temporary.'' Skyler noted that researchers have been able to reverse diabetes in rodents using this procedure since 1972 but until now had been unsuccessful in applying it to humans. ``It's an exciting step, one that's been elusive for a very long time,'' Skyler said. ``It was almost getting to the point that many people were getting totally discouraged that the corner would ever be turned.'' Scharp also warned that it might be years before islet cell transplantation became a routine treatment for diabetics. ``We are immensely pleased that the grafted tissue was able to satisfy all of the patient's insulin requirements before it was rejected,'' said Scharp, who conducted the transplant. ``Our first trials, in 1985, were designed to determine that islet transplants were safe. In this study, our primary goal was to determine if we could isolate, purify and transplant enough islets to bring a patient completely off of insulin.'' Within 10 days of the transplant, the patient no longer required daily insulin injections, according to hourly blood-sugar tests. She remained independent of insulin until the 25th day, when evidence of tissue rejection appeared, and she began to require gradually increasing amounts of supplemental insulin. The case ``shows that islet transplantation is a feasible approach to controlling insulin-dependent diabetes and clearly establishes the need to move on to larger clinical trials,'' said Lacy, a pathologist at Washington University who devised many of the techniques used to isolate and purify human islet cells. Lacy said the researchers hope to draw on previous research to find ways to combat rejection of the cells.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Takes Aim at Fast-Food Fat Content
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's and other fast food chains should give customers a break and reduce saturated fats in their products, said full-page ads placed today by a multimillionaire who lobbies against heart-threatening foods. Advertisements appeared in The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, USA Today and at least 10 other major newspapers proclaiming: ``McDonald's, Your Hamburgers Have Too Much Fat!'' Phil Sokolof, an Omaha businessman who has waged a one-man campaign against highly saturated fats in processed foods, called on McDonald's Corp. and other restaurants to reduce the fat content of their hamburger meat by 10 percent. About five newspapers declined to run the ad, Sokolof said in an interview. The ad singles out McDonald's because it is the industry leader, but Burger King and Wendy's also use too much fat, he said in an interview. The Los Angeles Times rejected the ad because it violates a policy of not accepting advertising that is a direct attack on another company or individual, said Laura Morgan, a spokeswoman for the newspaper. McDonald's reacted with outrage. ``I think this kind of advertising is sensational, ridiculous, and I think it's reckless,'' McDonald's senior vice president Dick Starmann said from Oak Brook, Ill. ``I'm surprised that McDonald's is singled out because over the years we are the ones who have led the way in reducing fats in our menus,'' he said. ``We think we have the leanest hamburger meat available today.'' McDonald's serves 22 million people a day and has 11,000 restaurants in 52 countries. A Burger King spokeswoman said Sokolof praised that company four years ago when it began frying onion rings and fish in vegetable oil. ``The only product that we use a combination of animal fat and vegetable oil is french fries because our customers say they prefer it that way,'' Cori Zywotow said. Sokolof, 67, blames high cholesterol for a near-fatal heart attack he suffered 24 years ago. He started the National Heart Savers Association in 1985 and it is supported largely through his own contributions. After he launched a national advertising campaign in 1988, nine major food processors, including Nabisco, Kellogg's, Pepperidge Farm and Keebler, agreed to begin phasing out cholestorol-elevating fats from products such as crackers, cookies, candies, cereals, cooking ingredients and TV dinners. Today's advertisement said more than half of all Americans have too much cholesterol in their blood and 25 percent have dangerously high levels. It said a McDonald's Big Mac with french fries contains 25 grams of saturated fat while a lean beef sandwich has only 3 grams of saturated fat. Starmann countered that a Big Mac with french fries contains about 19 grams of saturated fat. McDonald's uses a combination of beef tallow and vegetable shortening to cook its fries but is testing cholesterol-free vegetable shortening that would eliminate beef tallow, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Former Aide Testifies Civil Rights Leader Paid People To Attend Rallies
DOC.TEXT: The anti-drug rallies of a controversial civil rights leader drew small crowds until he started paying people $5 each to attend, a former associate testified. ``I'd tell him what the count was and he'd give me the money and I'd go out and pay everybody,'' Kevin Watkins, the former office manager for the Rev. Al Sharpton's National Youth Movement, said Tuesday of the highly publicized rallies. ``And what was the payment?'' Assistant Attorney General Victor Genecin asked. ``Five dollars apiece,'' Watkins replied. Watkins, who left the group in 1987, testified at Sharpton's fraud trial in Manhattan state Supreme Court. A 67-count indictment against Sharpton alleges that he stole more than $250,000 in contributions to his youth group, and that he illegally billed it as a nonprofit, tax-exempt organization, from 1985 through 1987. Sharpton maintains he never took money from the group he formed about 20 years ago as a teen-ager. Watkins also testified that money raised at a star-studded, anti-crack dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria in 1986 never made it into the group's bank account. ``We had several arguments about the money from the celebrity dinner,'' Watkins said. ``He would tell me, `That's my money and I do what I want with it.''' Under cross examination by defense attorney Alton Maddox, Watkins, an administrative assistant at the Army recruitment division, said he joined the movement in late 1985 and ``faded away'' in early 1987. He said he was paid $75 a week or about $4,500 in all but did not report the income on his tax returns. He denied that he was promised leniency in exchange for his testimony. Watkins disputed Sharpton's claims that the National Youth Movement's 20,000 members provided anti-drug rallies, voter registration drives and employment services through 15 offices nationwide. Watkins testified that he knew of no members outside about 10 staff people and of no office other than one at St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn. ``To this day, I have never heard of the National Youth Movement outside of New York,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Both Soviet, Lithuanian Sides Heartened by Top-Level Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Soviet comment, Lithuanian events today, expected demonstrations. Changes byline. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet and Lithuanian officials were heartened today by a more than three-hour meeting of representatives of the breakaway republic and a top aide to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Yuri D. Gremitskikh, called the meeting Tuesday night between a Lithuanian delegation and Alexander Yakovlev, a progressive member of the Presidential Council and the Communist Party Politburo, ``a positive sign.'' It was the first high-level contact between Lithuania and the Kremlin since the day after the republic declared itself independent March 11. ``I think it's very important that Lithuanian representatives are aware of the ideas and thoughts that are held here in Moscow,'' Gremitskikh told reporters at a briefing today. ``Our colleagues in Lithuania just have to tear themselves away from their narrow views and look at all these problems through the prism of the fact that a new basis for the federation is being created.'' In a separate news conference, Ivan D. Laptev, the new head of the Soviet of the Union, one of two chambers of the Soviet legislature, said: ``I'm convinced there will be a successful dialogue.'' ``A decision will be found that will be satisfactory to both sides,'' said Laptev, the progressive editor of Izvestia. Lithuanian legislator Egidijus Bickauskas said of the meeting: ``We are very, very encouraged.'' ``If there are people who at least want to listen to us, it's very good,'' Bickauskas said. The clash of wills over Lithuanian independence has included an order from Gorbachev for Lithuanians to relinquish all weapons, the arrest by Soviet troops of some Lithuanian deserters, the takeover of several Vilnius buildings by Soviet soldiers, movements of army reinforcements and a sharp war of words. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze was in Washington for talks with President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III and said the Kremlin intended to hold ``honest dialogue'' with the Lithuanians. An expected meeting this morning with Soviet Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin did not occur, according to a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian office in Moscow. She was unable to say if it had been canceled or postponed. The Lithuanian legislature, which began meeting in the late afternoon, was scheduled to respond today to Gorbachev's decree that the republic renounce its declaration of independence before any talks begin. Suggestions by some Lithuanian Communists that the small Baltic nation suspend its declaration of independence for six months in hopes of appeasing Gorbachev were adamantly opposed by members of the Sajudis pro-independence movement, according to Anatole Lieven of The Times of London, one of the few correspondents not expelled from Vilnius by Soviet authorities. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis and the overwhelming majority of Lithuanian citizens interviewed by The Associated Press over the past two weeks said Soviet military intimidation had not ebbed their determination for independence. ``If somebody expects Lithuania to renounce its independence act, there will be no such answer,'' Bickauskas said. Sajudis planned pro-independence rallies in several Lithuanian cities tonight, but spokesman Yuri Romanenko said one scheduled for Vilnius was canceled to prevent a clash with an anti-independence meeting set for the same spot in front of the parliament building 90 minutes earlier. As with earlier anti-independence demonstrations in the Lithuanian capital, publicity was handled by the Soviet army, which dropped announcements from a military helicopter on Tuesday, Romanenko said. Gremitskikh also said today that Soviet officials had never halted their dialogue with Lithuanians, and he specifically cited a visit to Vilnius by several members of the national parliament. The only such trip was taken by a group of democratically minded deputies who strongly supported Lithuania's bid for independence and called on Gorbachev to end his intransigence and start negotiating. On Tuesday, the Supreme Soviet parliament approved a bill setting procedures for secession from the Soviet Union. The Soviet constitution allows republics to secede, but until the legislation was passed there was no legal mechanism for beginning the procedure. The law, which becomes effective when it is published in the Soviet press, requires two-thirds of a republic's voters to approve secession in a referendum and calls for a subsequent waiting period of up to five years while the Soviet Union and the republic negotiate terms of secession. Bickauskas said Lithuania had no means of implementing its proclaimed independence if Soviet soldiers continued to interfere in the republic. ``We have declared independence, but we very well know that tanks are moving on our soil every day and night, and they take over one building after another,'' he said. ``We realize the Soviet Union has economic, political and military interests in Lithuania that cannot be cut all at once. These problems involve not only the Soviet Union and Lithuania but Europe and the whole world. So we need to talk. We want somebody to hold a dialogue with us,'' Bickauskas said. On Saturday, Gorbachev said secession talks could take place if Lithuania renounced the independence declaration. Landsbergis responded Monday that Lithuania did not intend to rush toward freedom and invited a Moscow representative for talks in Vilnius.

DOC.HEAD: Guards Sue To Bar More Inmates
DOC.TEXT: Guards at Graterford State Prison have sued the state, claiming they are endangered by overcrowding in the nation's fifth largest prison. The lawsuit, filed Tuesday in Commonwealth Court, asks the court to order the state to reduce the prison's population to ``safer, more manageable levels.'' It also asks for improvements in the prison's sewage, water and electrical facilities. The lawsuit is believed to be the nation's first by prison guards seeking to relieve prison crowding, said Michael Fox, assistant to the executive director of Council 13 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. AFSCME is the union for state prison employees. The Department of Corrections declined to comment until it sees the suit, spokeswoman Sherri Cadeaux said. The 61-year-old, 62-acre, maximum-security prison northwest of Philadelphia has a capacity of 2,734 inmates. Tuesday, it held 4,212 inmates, including 510 serving life sentences and 24 on death row, prison spokesman Alan J. LeFebvre said. They are controlled by 506 corrections officers, Lefebvre said. But 65 guard positions are unfilled because the state can't find anyone to work for the $17,200 starting salary, Lefebvre said. ``The concern is that the inmates could take over if they wanted to,'' Fox said. ``We are hoping we can relieve it before it gets to that point,'' LeFebvre said. He said the crowding causes long waiting lines for meals, food shortages, delays, equipment breakdowns and a higher level of tension. Vince Carocci, spokesman for Gov. Robert P. Casey, who is named in the lawsuit, said Casey has proposed spending $180 million for 3,000 new prison cells. Carocci said the state also has accelerated hiring of guards and is ``exploring the salary issue.'' A class-action lawsuit on behalf of the inmates charging that the crowding violates their constitutional rights was dismissed in federal court, LeFebvre said.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Rejects Soviet Proposal to Neutralize Reunited Germany
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher opened a round of meetings with top U.S. officials today, rejecting a Soviet proposal to neutralize a reunited Germany. Emerging from a meeting at the State Department with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Genscher repeated his nation's stand that a unified Germany should remain a partner in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``A neutralized Germany would not contribute to stability in Europe,'' he said. ``On the contrary, it would increase instability.'' ``We want to see German unification making a contribution to stability in Europe,'' he said. Baker then escorted Genscher to the White House for a meeting with President Bush. Genscher and Baker told reporters that the timing of the so-called two-plus-four meetings on German unification depend on the organization of the East German government following its recent national elections. The participants in the negotiations include both German nations plus the four nations that emerged victorious after World War II: the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. The formula still under discussion is a device to compromise the Soviets' initial demand for neutralization of its World War II enemy and to allay concerns among Germany's neighbors who sufffered devastation at the hands of the Nazis. Genscher has taken the lead in promoting the continuation of a unified Germany in NATO with a concession to the Soviet Union that Western troops would not be moved into what is now East Germany. The West German foreign minister offered his government's thanks to the United States for its support of the German unification process. He said West Germany is determined that the process proceed with ``full openness'' and with complete consultation with his nation's allies and neighbors. ``We don't want to act behind the backs of others,'' Genscher said. ``We are interested in and we intend to see German unification making a contribution to civility in Western Europe,'' he said. Baker said he and Genscher discussed a wide range of issues, including the problems posed by German unification, conventional arms control and the possibility of a 35-nation summit meeting this year, as proposed by Soviet Presidzent Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Bush administration already has endorsed the summit idea, but only if a treaty, now being negotiated between NATO and the Warsaw pact to reduce troops, tanks and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe, is ready for signing.

DOC.HEAD: City Council Votes for Needle Cleaning Kit
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in the nation's second-largest city approved the distribution of chlorine bleach for cleaning needles to slow the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug users. The council vote was unanimous Tuesday after an emotional hearing in which one unidentified man was escorted from chambers when he tried to shout down supporters of the program. The $25,000 allocated for distribution of kits containing bleach and condoms was part of an $85,000 AIDS prevention and education program. The bleach kills the AIDS virus on needles, which drug addicts often share. The money also establishes a central AIDS treatment and information center. San Francisco is the only other governmental agency in California that distributes bleach to clean needles. New York also distributes bleach _ and recently withdrew from a program to distribute clean needles. Critics of the programs charge they promote drug abuse. Supporters say drug abuse will continue regardless of whether needles are sterilized to prevent AIDS. Dave Johnson, the city's AIDS policy and program coordinator, estimated that 7 percent of intravenous drug users in Los Angeles County carry the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The City Administrative Office said the $25,000 will pay for 50,000 to 62,000 bleach and condom kits. City officials said they had no way of estimating how many intravenous drug users would use the kits.

DOC.HEAD: Grammy-Nominated Singer Out of Hospital After Back Injury
Retransmitting to fix cycle designator.
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan left a hospital today, two weeks after a bus crash broke her spine, and the Miami Sound Machine vocalist promised she would soon be back performing at ``100 percent.'' Estefan thanked doctors, nurses and staff at the Orthopedic Institute Hospital for Joint Disease for their work in ``putting me back together.'' She called the experience ``the most difficult thing in my life,'' and said she was ``thankful for the miracle of being alive.'' The singer faced reporters, cameras and hospital workers from a wheelchair. But she ended her news conference by standing, unaided. Estefan, 32, was injured March 21 when her tour bus was struck by a tractor-trailer on an icy Pennsylvania highway while en route to a performance. She was transferred to the hospital one day later, and doctors implanted two steel rods to stabilize the area where she broke vertebrae. ``All the positive prayers and thoughts sent my way helped me in my recuperation,'' said Estefan, who was accompanied by her husband Emilio. The couple's 9-year-old son also was injured in the crash. Doctors have estimated it could take up to six months for her to fully recover.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Chief Says He's Negotiating With Inmates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 5th pvs, `He commended... to UPDATE with newspaper editor's account today of visit inside prison. Pickup 7th, `Serle said...' ^By SYDNEY RUBIN
DOC.TEXT: The governor of Strangeways Prison said today he was holding difficult negotiations with a dwindling band of rebellious inmates that still controlled part of the prison. One prisoner died Tuesday of injuries suffered during a riot at a Sunday chapel service, and prison governor Brendan O'Friel said he feared that another fatality may come to light as guards regain control of the prison. Fewer than a hundred prisoners still held control of the upper floors of four wings today, following a third night without heat or light in the ravaged cellblocks. Up to two dozen inmates occupied prison roofs today, and one group hung up a banner that said ``No Peace.'' ``We're now in a delicate and difficult situation ... but my hope is that these negotiations will result in a peaceful end to this incident,'' O'Friel told reporters. He commended his staff for containing an ``explosion of evil'' on Sunday, when he said more than 1,500 inmates were out of control. The editor of the Manchester Evening News, who spent 10 hours inside the prison Tuesday as a neutral observer requested by the prisoners, said inmates complained of ``mental and physical brutality, misuse of drugs in controlling prisoners, poor food and cramped conditions.'' In a story published in today's edition of the News, editor Michael Unger said the areas he saw were devastated. ``Strewn around the stench-filled wings were smashed toilets, wrecked television sets, ripped-out telephones, and huge steel doors ripped off their hinges. Water was pouring down, and the stink of burning was almost too much to bear,'' Unger wrote. Ivor Serle, a guard and chairman of the local Prison Officers' Association branch, said about 20 ``hard core of the hard core'' prisoners were stopping other inmates from giving up. Serle said 68 inmates were still on the loose. A spokesman for the Home Office, whose jurisdiction includes prisons, put the figure at under 40. Thirteen guards were hurt by flying bricks, poles and other objects on Tuesday as they tried to regain control, Serle said, and six had to be hospitalized. Manchester-born Derek White, 46, died Tuesday in North Manchester Hospital after suffering head wounds and chest pains. He had been jailed at Strangeways while awaiting trial on charges of indecent assault and sodomy. In English prisons, sex offenders, child molesters and convicted policemen are among inmates kept apart from other prisoners for their own safety. White was among a group of 50 such prisoners being held in a segregated wing when other prisoners at a religious service in the prison on Sunday overpowered guards and took their keys. The rioting prisoners used the keys to gain access to large areas of the prison, including the segregated section. Officials said they attacked White and other members of the group and in a general rampage through the prison started fires, smashed fixtures and got onto the roof, tearing off tiles and hurling them down at guards. British newspapers have speculated that up to 30 people may have been killed in the rioting, although officials say such reports cannot be confirmed as long as parts of the prison are still held by inmates. The father of a youth who was in the same wing as sex offenders, segregated because of his age but on a different landing, said on BBC-TV news Tuesday that his son told him he witnessed six murders. The youth was transferred to a jail in the south of England where the father said he saw him on Tuesday. The father, who refused to be named and was shown in silhouette, relayed his son's account of kangaroo courts in which makeshift ropes made from sheets were tied around the necks of prisoners. Inmates' relatives say other factors adding to tension at the 122-year-old prison include overcrowding, with up to three prisoners in cells built for one, unsanitary conditions and prisoners locked in cells for up to 23 hours a day. With a prison population of 47,000, Britain has the highest number of inmates per capita in Western Europe. Strangeways was built in 1868 to hold 970 men. It had 1,648 prisoners on Sunday. It contains inmates of all categories, from very dangerous to low risk.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Mayor, Councilman Indicted in Racketeering Case
DOC.TEXT: Hialeah Mayor Raul Martinez surrendered to the FBI today on charges that he conspired with a city councilman to extort payoffs from developers in exchange for approving zoning changes on properties. Gov. Bob Martinez on Tuesday suspended both Martinez and Councilman Andres Mejides without pay after they were indicted by a federal grand jury following a five-year investigation into the operation of the state's fifth-largest city. ``These are extremely serious charges that go to the very essence of trust in government, and the people of Hialeah deserve to know that their officials have the public's best interest in mind at all times,'' said the governor, who is not related to the mayor. ``Until these charges can be resolved, these two officials should not hold their positions of trust.'' Both city officials and were scheduled to appear this afternoon before a federal magistrate. ``Martinez obtained benefits, including money and property for himself and others, by expressly using and threatening to use the powers of his office as Mayor of the city of Hialeah,'' the indictment said. Raul Martinez, 41, was named in two Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organization counts, along with seven extortion-related counts, and faces a maximum 180 years in prison and fines of $2.25 million, said Marcella Cohen, first assistant U.S. attorney. ``Keep the faith and at the end, I am going to prevail because I am innocent,'' Raul Martinez said in a message to constituents Tuesday. Mejides, 51, also was named in the two racketeering counts, along with four counts of obtaining property by extortion, and faces maximum penalties of 120 years and fines of $1.5 million. The government also claims that Martinez must forfeit $900,000 in property and cash that he allegedly obtained from racketeering activities. Mejides must forfeit $24,000 in property, the government said. City council president Julio Martinez, who is not related to either the governor or suspended mayor, was sworn in late Tuesday as acting mayor. Former city council candidates Paulino Nunez and Evelio Medina, who were the highest unelected vote-getters in the last city election, were sworn in to fill the resulting council vacancies. The indictment Tuesday also named several other current and former Hialeah officials as unindicted co-conspirators. The indictment charges that between 1981 and 1987 half of the city's eight elected officials repeatedly shook down developers and builders seeking to rezone property in Hialeah. Raul Martinez has been mayor of the predominantly Hispanic working-class city of more than 200,000 residents since 1981. He was handily re-elected to a fifth term in November after a campaign in which opponents raised the issue of his real estate dealings. The mayor replied that he had been under federal scrutiny for years, but apparently without any finding of wrongdoing. He has charged the investigations were politically motivated.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. March 30 El Paso (Texas) Herald-Post on child care: George Bush has promised to veto any child-care bill that discriminates against religious or church-based day care. His forthright commitment emboldens us to hope that good sense will prevail on this contentious issue, despite the inscrutable ways of Congress. ... Purists on the separation of church and state see this as a matter of principle. ... Let a tax dollar flow to a religious child-care center, and Calvin's Geneva is just around the corner. In fact, the use of child-care vouchers to pay for religious care would no more threaten the First Amendment than the hugely successful GI Bill, which covered veterans' costs at public and sectarian colleges alike. ... If even a fraction of eligible parents find in church congregations an extended family to help nurture their children, should the government discourage them? Whatever child-care bill emerges from the House of Representatives vote, the White House should scrutinize the process of reconciling House and Senate versions. Bush should restate his insistence that parents have a right to choose religious day care _ and follow up his pledge with a veto if need be.

April 2 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on the S&L bailout: While some of the nation's observers are running around saying, ``What are we going to do?'' about S&L failures and bailouts, several congressmen are doing something about it. They have introduced legislation to limit compensation packages at federally insured depository institutions. Enacting this one relatively minor adjustment could save taxpayers a substantial sum. In some cases, the failure of financial institutions is attended by bailouts for high officers. Perhaps the best example is the top management of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a Wall Street securities firm, which handed out some $350 million in bonuses just before filing for bankruptcy. Creditors rather than taxpayers were hurt by that payoff, but the potential is there for institutions backed by federally insured deposits. The proposed legislation would limit such golden parachutes at those institutions. Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. chairman William Siedman told a House subcommittee that his agency needs more authority to prevent excessive compensation at weakened institutions that are still operating. The FDIC should be given all the authority it needs to protect taxpayers, and then Congress and the president should make sure it uses it effectively toward that end.

April 3 The Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, Ariz., on fuel efficiency: Arguments for fuel efficiency are about basic common sense. Yet for years the simple wisdom of conserving something that is in limited supply escaped America. It was too complex for Ronald Reagan. His administration was determined to foil a 1975 law mandating higher fuel-efficiency standards. Thanks to White House clout and Reagan's backward thinking, the standard Congress originally planned for 1985-model fleets wasn't in place until the 1990-model cars. The victory went to Detroit lobbyists. The loss went to a nation that is increasingly dependent on imported oil and increasingly swaddled in air pollution. It was a commitment to waste in a world that must learn to conserve finite sources of energy and develop renewable ones. Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards had a beneficial effect despite the best efforts of Ronald Reagan and (the) Detroit lobby. Higher standards kept 360 million tons of carbon dioxide out of the air just in 1989, according to the Sierra Club. ... Higher fuel-efficiency standards are like finding an oil well. They save resources and blunt arguments about how the nation must sacrifice every wilderness for the sake of oil exploration. They reduce both pollution and the need for oil imports. For consumers, they could lower operating costs _ or at least help offset the higher gas taxes looming on the horizon. There isn't room in an environmentally conscious nation for any more coddling of automakers who cling to out-of-date ideas. ... Congress has to look out for the best interests of the nation, and provide a real incentive for car makers to offer truly efficient cars. Higher fuel-efficiency standards are a simple, easy strategy in a nation that needs to remember that conservation means more than just doing without.

April 1 Statesman Journal, Salem, Ore., on water shortages: As the state enters its fourth drought year, California officials have imposed new mandatory conservation rules to preserve water. The rainy season is about over, and snowpack levels are at less than 63 percent of normal. Although California makes the headlines, it shares with East Coast states and big cities in Texas and Arizona and New Mexico a problem that goes beyond a few drought years. The problem is that population and wasteful lifestyles are using up in a few years aquifer water reservoirs that took thousands of years to fill. In some areas, sucking up the pure underground water to drink, fill swimming pools, irrigate crops, flush toilets, wash cars has created a vacuum that allowed sea water to seep into the aquifer. Thus, even the diminishing supply of good water is contaminated. ... Misuses of water and excessive population growth have disturbed political stability in many areas of the world. The most volatile is the Middle East, where the scramble for more water has upset an already unstable region. ... No single approach will solve the impending water crisis. Holding down the rate of population growth is critical. So are new irrigation techniques, a new subsidy policy that discourages irrigation for crops that can be grown elsewhere, and incentives and penalties that encourage citizens and industry to conserve.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Approves Post-1997 Law for Hong Kong
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `Under the...' with 1 graf to CORRECT the date Hong Kong ceded to Britain. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The law...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-China
DOC.TEXT: China's legislature gave final approval today to the basic law by which Beijing will govern Hong Kong after 1997, but Hong Kong politicians immediately demanded it be amended. The National People's Congress, which largely rubber-stamps decisions by top leaders, made no changes of its own in the law, which was thrashed out over the past five years by a special Chinese-Hong Kong committee. Under the law Hong Kong, which has been ruled by Britain since 1842, is promised a high degree of autonomy within China and protection of its capitalist economic system for at least 50 years. However, many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million residents fear the guarantees are not strong enough, and they already are emigrating to escape coming under Communist rule. The law provides for a 60-seat local legislature in which 20 members could be directly elected at first, 24 members in 1999 and 30 members in the year 2003. It also sets up a complicated split-voting procedure that gives appointed legislators power to veto controversial bills. After Hong Kong residents loudly supported last year's massive pro-democracy protests on the mainland, China added provisions for declaring a state of emergency in Hong Kong and banned subversive activities and contacts between Hong Kong and foreign political groups. Hong Kong residents greeted the draft's publication in February with protests and demands for greater democracy. The colony's legislature voted 20-6 today to ask China to change the law before 1997. China's National People's Congress must approve any changes. Hong Kong legislator Martin Lee, an outspoken proponent of democratic reforms, said the law as passed was a ``regression'' from earlier versions because of the anti-subversion clauses. Chinese leaders have said repeatedly they will not allow Hong Kong to become a base for Chinese dissident activity. Tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents already have emigrated because of fear about life under Communist rule, and the pace has stepped up sharply since China used its army in June to crush the pro-democracy protests. A survey in August found that two out of every five residents want to leave. China's senior leader Deng Xiaoping, however, has praised the basic law as a ``masterpiece of creativity'' that can ensure stability after 1997. He said general elections and ``Western democracy'' were not suitable for Hong Kong. The National People's Congress, which approved the basic law by a vote of 2,660 to 16, with 29 abstentions and eight deputies failing to vote, also decided to set up a 400-member joint Hong Kong-mainland committee to prepare for the 1997 transfer.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: to conserve.
DOC.TEXT: April 3 Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal on the Idaho abortion bill: Abortion activists tossed Gov. Cecil Andrus of Idaho a hot potato ... by threatening a boycott of the state's most famous crop if he didn't veto a bill that would have given that state the nation's most restrictive abortion law. The governor, a longtime abortion foe, caved (in). He claimed the veto reflected his objection to the law's harsh provisions on rape cases and its unlikely prospects before the Supreme Court. The risk of ruining his state's economy must also have played a part, however. There's no question that abortion is both a wrenching moral issue and a legitimate subject for political debate. But some of the tactics employed by zealots on either side of the issue threaten to go beyond free speech or even civil disobedience. They threaten to undermine the democratic process. In the last two presidential races, candidates for the nation's highest office have faced a constant barrage of heckling and disruption from abortion foes. Now that the Webster decision has transferred much of the action to the state level, political discourse is being held hostage in state races. ... Those involved in the issue argue that the fate of some crop is small potatoes alongside the lives of women or the deaths of the unborn, but that misses the point. No matter how important the abortion issue is to those caught up in it, the tactic in Idaho threatened to ruin the livelihoods, if not the lives, of potato farmers. They were innocent bystanders who had no connection to the debate other than the accident of depending for their income on a product that could be turned into a convenient symbol. A tactic that attempts to make a political point by ruining the lives and fortunes of victims selected more or less at random isn't democracy in action or noble protest. It's a species of terrorism.

March 31 The Star-Ledger, Newark, N.J., on hungry children: The eventful developments of recent months have made for banner headlines and historic change in the world. The crumbling of communism in eastern Europe, the dismantling of the Berlin Wall, the invasion of Panama, the elections in Chile, the coup attempt in the Phillipines, to name a few, all have dominated the news. And while the world has been watching ..., scant attention is being paid to the needless deaths of tens of thousands of Third World children each day from hunger and poverty. The United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund in its State of the World's Children-1990 report notes that, if current trends continue, 100 million children will die in this decade from illness and malnutrition. It also notes that these deaths could be prevented at low cost if the nations of the world have the will to address the problem. A host of proposals that UNICEF says could save millions of lives a year would come with a $2.5 billion annual price tag. The figure is equivalent to what Soviets spend on vodka, what American companies spend on cigarette advertisement in a year and 10 percent of the European Community's annual agriculture subsidy. The UNICEF solutions should be seriously addressed. The time is overdue for the developed nations of the world to demonstrate their commitment to ending the unnecessary deaths of children _ children who are dying to know if these nations have the will.

March 30 Akron (Ohio) Beacon Journal on the nuclear threat: The threat of war between the United States and the Soviet Union has diminished, but not the threat to world order from other sources. A reminder of that came ... with the arrest in Britain of six people who were trying to smuggle a triggering device for nuclear weapons into Iraq. This is the new world threat: As tensions ease between the big powers, the increasing spread of weapons _ of increasing destructiveness _ can mean that regional conflicts will be international concerns. Or that smaller, terrorist nations can hold large powers hostage on their demands. ... It is time to put tighter controls on the spread of nuclear weapons technology and to expand and enforce nuclear proliferation treaties.

March 30 Beloit (Wis.) Daily News on Japan and the U.S. economy: According to a Japanese newspaper, a list of 80 suggestions to improve the United States economy has been delivered from Tokyo to Washington. The Japanese suggest the United States impose a value-added tax, abolish income tax deductions on home mortgage loans, build high-speed trains to reduce the demand for automobiles and even limit the number of credit cards U.S. citizens can possess. The object is to cut the multi-billion-dollar U.S. trade deficit with Japan. The United States isn't a basket case just yet, and doesn't need lectures from the land of the rising sun. The Japanese, flush with the economic success of recent years, shouldn't forget just how dependent their industries are on the American marketplace. Presumptuous pronouncements of this type just feed an existing American resentment of Japanese economic policies. It also glosses over a key point in the trade deficit situation, namely, Tokyo's protectionist policies which thwart U.S. companies' efforts to compete in Japan. There may come a day when Tokyo has the economic power to humble the United States, and dictate fiscal policies. But don't bet on it.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Marcos Attorney Claims Bush, CIA Knew of Real Estate Investments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Khashoggi opening statement, picking up 6th graf pvs, `The former...'
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' lawyer says the real estate deals that led to fraud and racketeering charges against her were originally suggested by George Bush, and that the CIA knew all about them. Defense attorney Gerald Spence also announced in opening arguments at Mrs. Marcos' trial Tuesday that he will try to call President Bush as a witness and will seek a sworn statement from Philippine President Corazon Aquino. In Washington, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater refused to comment on Spence's allegations. A lawyer for Mrs. Marcos' co-defendant, Saudi Arabian arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi, said today in his opening statement that his client had committed ``foolish acts'' in his business dealings but was innocent of fraud charges. ``If this wasn't such a serious charge, this would be funny,'' James Linn said in opening arguments. ``It is not the sinister thing that the government makes it out'' to be. Linn admitted that Khashoggi had many personal dealings with Marcos and that Khashoggi had signed one fake document involving the buildings, but said this was intended to help a Marcos associate, not to defraud anyone. Khashoggi, 54, once described as the richest man in the world, was trying to head off moves by creditors to foreclose on the properties, Linn said. On Tuesday, a prosecutor portrayed Mrs. Marcos as an uncontrolled spender who treated the Philippine National Bank as her ``personal piggy bank.'' The former Philippine first lady and her husband, Ferdinand, were indicted in 1988 on charges of stealing millions of dollars from their homeland's treasury to buy New York City real estate, jewelry and art. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii in September. Mrs. Marcos, 60, broke down in tears as Spence described her as a ``devoted wife'' determined to clear the name of her late husband. He denied that Mrs. Marcos had any part in the dealings on which the charges are based. ``Mrs. Marcos never wrote a check in her life, she never paid a bill in her life,'' Spence told the jury. Spence sought to trace the origins of the New York real estate deals to CIA concern, in the early 1980s, that the Philippines would fall to the communists. According to Spence, Bush, then vice president, visited Manila in 1981 and urged Marcos to abandon negotiations with Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi on an oil investment deal and put the money instead into American property. ``The evidence in this case is that the CIA was aware of every transaction that took place in this case,'' Spence said. Earlier, Assistant U.S. Attorney Debra Livingston charged that the Marcoses were ``partners in crime'' who used accomplices, fake documents and 13 ``shell corporations'' to steal $168 million in Philippine government funds and defraud U.S. banks of $165 million more. She said the couple used some of the money to buy four expensive pieces of New York real estate and other luxury items. She said Mrs. Marcos treated the New York branch of the Philippine National Bank as her ``own personal piggy bank. Every time she descended on New York ... she cracked it open, (taking) bundles and bundles of cash.'' Livingston said Khashoggi, 54, entered the picture after Mrs. Aquino replaced Marcos in 1986 and her government won a U.S. court order to prohibit any further transactions involving the four buildingss. Khashoggi, she said, committed fraud and obstructed justice by fabricating documents showing that he, not the Marcoses, had owned the buildings for several years. If convicted, Mrs. Marcos could get up to 50 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Khashoggi, once described as the world's richest man, could receive up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted. Spence said Mrs. Marcos never lost sight of her humble origins. ``She was beloved by the people,'' he said. ``If she took 30 minutes to dress for a head of state, she took an hour to dress for the little people.'' Spence said Mrs. Marcos had been unfairly treated for having had more than 1,000 pairs of shoes, left behind in Manila. ``One thing that made up this woman is how long she was barefoot,'' he said. He added, however, that most of the shoes were given to her by local shoe manufacturers, ``and most of them didn't fit.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Doctors Punished in Cash-for-Kidneys Case
DOC.TEXT: The General Medical Council took disciplinary action Wednesday against three doctors involved in a case in which four healthy people sold their kidneys for transplant operations. The harshest action was taken against Dr. Raymond Crockett. The council struck him from its register, meaning he may not prescribe medicine until he is readmitted to the register. He is eligible to reapply in 10 months. The council's Professional Conduct Committee found Crockett and surgeons Michael Joyce and Michael Bewick guilty of serious professional misconduct, but Crockett was the only one struck off the register. Joyce and Bewick were found to have failed to comply with guidelines on making checks on the histories of the patients and donors. Joyce was banned from taking part in kidney transplants for two years. Bewick was ordered to confine his services to the government's National Health Service for the next three years, and to submit detailed records of every transplant operation in which he is involved. They have 28 days to appeal. ``This whole case has been about the limits to which it is permissible for a doctor to go to save lives. That's all I have ever tried to do,'' Crockett said after the hearing. ``My concern was with four of my patients who were going to die without an urgent transplant.'' The committee chairman, Sir Robert Kilpatrick, told Crockett his conduct ``brought disgrace upon yourself and dishonor upon medical practice in the United Kingdom.'' During a 35-day hearing, the board heard allegations that Crockett arranged for kidneys to be transplanted from four healthy Turks into patients in London. Turkish authorities said the donors were paid $3,200 to $5,600. Ata Nur Kunter, who has been identified as the broker in the transactions, was not called to testify. ``Everybody knows, if you have money, you can buy a kidney,'' Kunter said in an interview Wednesday with Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. ``The GMC obviously don't want to hear my story and I have always suspected that there must be a reason,'' Kunter said. ``The GMC accuses me of being a kidney broker and of lying, and none of it is true,'' Kunter added. A spokesman for the medical council, who was not identified, said the committee had been advised by attorneys that it would be ``inappropriate'' to call Kunter to testify. Kunter introduced the four donors _ Ahmet Koc, Ferhat Usta, Natice Anutkan and Coskun Yenici _ to Crockett and said Crockett paid him to act as an interpreter. ``Four willing Turkish donors were presented to me and were fully assessed as fit and willing to give one of their kidneys,'' Crockett said. ``The General Medical Council found all these donors freely consented.'' Crockett said he believed his actions were correct _ ``right before my patients and right before my peers.'' ``I believe the question of money was largely irrelevant,'' Crockett said. ``And I do not accept in any regard that I was guilty of misconduct in any form.''

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Adopts Curbs For Off-Road Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet on Wednesday approved a proposal prohibiting off-road use of recreational motor vehicles. The proposal, if approved by the National Assembly, would bar 4-wheel-drive vehicles, cross-country motorcycles and other vehicles in areas such as sand dunes, marshes and mountain pastures. Brice Lalonde, secretary of state for the environment, told the Cabinet that the number of off-road vehicles in France had increased six-fold to 140,000 in the past eight years. He said the number was expected to triple by 1995. The proposed law was drafted because of concern that the off-road vehicles posed a threat to hikers and to the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Kills 22 People in Bogor
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain caused a river to overflow its banks, creating a flood that killed at least 22 people and left seven others missing, the official Antara news agency said Wednesday. The flood occurred in Cogowong village on Tuesday night. The village is about 30 miles south of Jakarta and was inundated when the Cidurian River overflowed, the news agency said. The flood also destroyed two bridges and damaged more than 40 houses, it said. Rescuers were still searching for the missing people on Wednesday, it said. No local officials were immediately available to comment on the report.

DOC.HEAD: First Charges for Violating Sanctions Against South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor filed charges Wednesday against two shipping agents suspected of violating Swedish trade sanctions against South Africa. The trial is due to start in May. It would be the first time a Swedish court has heard a case based on the 1987 trade ban, which was imposed because of South African apartheid. Prosecutor Curt Bokelund said he filed charges against the general manager and a clerk of Gemini Shipping Agency in Goteborg. The charges allege the defendants arranged eight deliveries of iron wire to Durban, South Africa via Hamburg, West Germany, from November 1987 to March 1989. The defendants face two years in prison if convicted. Their names were not released. Bokelund said both defendants denied the charges.

DOC.HEAD: East German-West German Traffic Accidents Soar After Border Opening
DOC.TEXT: Germans are not only steering themselves toward unification. Drivers from the two German states are also crashing into each other at an alarming rate. There have been about 10,000 accidents between West German and East German vehicles since the start of the year, the HUK association of West German auto insurers said Wednesday. Before East Germany opened its borders in November, the average annual rate was about 4,500, according to the insurers' group. Insurance settlements are often complicated by the nations' different laws. HUK said it and East Germany's state-owned insurers have agreed to streamline their claim procedures to make awarding of settlements simpler and quicker. HUK did not say how many casualties there were in the 10,000 crashes.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Man Flees When Caught Breaking Fast
DOC.TEXT: A Moslem man dived into a river and swam away to escape authorities who caught him smoking and drinking in violation of the Ramadan fast, a newspaper said Wednesday. A police official, Ahmad Zaki, said officers of the Religious Department caught the man breaking the Ramadan rules at a stall in Kuala Selangor town, 60 miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur, on Tuesday. They were questioning him when he bolted, leaving behind his cigarettes, Ahmad was quoted as telling the Star newspaper. The officers chased the man, but he jumped into the muddy Kuala Selangor river, swam away and hid behind some boats. The officers waited for an hour, then gave up and left. Ahmad said his officers also raided an office in Kuala Selangor on Tuesday and found several people drinking. They all jumped out of a window and escaped. However, he said, officers arrested 15 people consuming food and drinks at Pekan Tanjong Karang, near Kuala Selangor. They are to appear in court after Ramadan ends April 27. During the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, Moslems are to abstain from eating, drinking, and smoking from sunrise to sunset. The elderly, ill, and children are exempt. About half of Malaysia's 17.5 million people are Moslems. Under Malaysian law, fines for violating Ramadan range from $18 to $73.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: on it.
DOC.TEXT: April 2 The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune on Lithuania: In shaping a response to the Soviet Union's secession crisis, George Bush has wisely avoided the mistake of excessive interference. But his moderation leads him to err in the opposite direction. Bush has been so discreet in expressing sympathy for the cause of Lithuanian independence that one would hardly guess he endorses the American policy of 50 years' standing: that the Soviet Union's forcible annexation of the Baltic states, Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, through a secret deal with Hitler, was never legal. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev says he is committed to transforming his government into one based on law and consent. If so, President Bush will do no harm by reiterating what our country has always stood for. The brave Lithuanians suffered foreign domination for 50 years. Now they have elected a parliament that voted unanimously for independence. Their government is acting with dignity. In their vastly unequal face-off with the Soviet Union, they deserve the moral support of the United States.

April 3 The Los Angeles Times on capital punishment: A few minutes after 3 a.m. (Tuesday) in the darkest watch of the night, the penalty imposed long ago for (Robert) Harris' callous murder of two teen-age boys finally would have been carried out. But Monday's decision by the U.S. Supreme Court to uphold a stay granted by the Court of Appeals stopped the clock _ at least for now _ at 1 minute to 3. For more than 20 years, California has kept a kind of death watch of its own. Those who favor capital punishment _ as 78 percent of Californians do _ and those who oppose it _ as The Times does _ have waged a wrenching, often bitter struggle over this divisive issue. ... But had this ... scheduled execution gone forward, what would have been accomplished beyond Robert Harris' death? The two young men he murdered will not be returned to life, nor will the hearts of their families and friends be made whole. ... Would others have been deterred from murder by this killer's execution? According to a global survey of capital punishment conducted in 1988 by the United Nations, ``the evidence as a whole gives no positive support to the deterrence hypothesis.'' That is one reason, among many, why no other Western democracy maintains an active death sentence. ... Finally, all that can be said is that life dealt cruelly with Robert Alton Harris, that he dealt cruelly with others and that the state may yet deal cruelly with him. Reasonable people will differ on whether there is any justice in that, but none can say there is either goodness or mercy.

March 27 Stillwater (Minn.) Evening Gazette on Bush and broccoli: The jury will remain out for some time on President George Bush's war against drugs, but Bush has quickly earned a clear victory in The Great Broccoli Debate. No, the president hasn't swayed the nation to his side in hating the bouquet-like vegetable. In fact, the broccoli consortium that delivered five tons of the veggie to Washington claims that Bush's stink about being fed broccoli every time he boards Air Force One has actually made the veggie more popular in recent days. That was the first part of Bush's trilogy of victory. Another part is that those five tons of broccoli is going to feed D.C.'s hungry. The final part is the gem that this non-news story has become. Polls show that Bush, beginning his second year in the Oval Office, already is as popular as any president in U.S. history. His lighthearted approach, with the able assistance of the equally popular First Lady, only increase his approval among voters. Indeed, Bush has turned The Great Broccoli Debate into a public relations coup.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Quake Causes Minor Damage in Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake and several aftershocks shook an area in central Yugoslavia early Wednesday, causing minor damage and a power outage, the Tanjug news agency reported. There were no reports of casualties. The quake measured 4.9 on the Richter scale, the state-run news agency said. It hit about 50 miles west of Sarajevo. A series of aftershocks cracked walls in old buildings and caused other minor damage in the area, the agency said. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 4 on the scale can cause moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Feared Drowned When Boat Capsizes in Storm
DOC.TEXT: About 50 people were feared drowned when a boat capsized during a storm in northwestern Bangladesh, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The motor launch overturned Sunday night in the Jamuna River near Sirajganj, about 60 miles northwest of Dhaka, the Bangladesh Times said. The newspaper said about 30 of the 80 passengers swam to shore. Five bodies were recovered and the rest of the people were missing and feared dead, the Times said. It quoted a Sirajganj official as saying many of the passengers were children. At least 177 other people have died in the past 10 days in summer storms in Bangladesh. Most of the victims were killed when boats capsized and houses collapsed. The low-lying nation is constantly wracked by floods and storms.

DOC.HEAD: El Salvador, Rebels Reach Initial Accord at Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, ``The document...'' with 2 grafs to ADD that U.N. chief met with both sides today. Pickup 5th, `The civil...' Adds 5 grafs at end to UPDATE with further comment from rebels. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for El Salvador and the leftist rebels opened U.N.-mediated peace talks today and signed a declaration saying a truce in the nation's 10-year-old civil war is their ``initial objective.'' The accord said the parties would try to end ``the armed conflict through political means as speedily as possible.'' The declaration also said the negotiators hoped to promote moves toward democracy and respect for human rights in El Salvador and toward integrating the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front into society. The document also was signed by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who held brief separate meetings with the two sides today. Today's session, the first peace talks on El Salvador since October, was the first time the United Nations has sponsored such negotiations. The civil war has killed 72,000 people since 1980. The two sides also agreed on the format for future talks. They can either be face-to-face negotiations, mediated by Perez de Cuellar or his personal representative, or involve U.N. envoy bargaining separately with government and rebel delegations, according to the accord. ``The simple fact of agreeing on the procedure for the realization of the negotiating process is a considerable advance,'' Alvaro de Soto, Perez de Cuellar's special envoy, told reporters. Negotiators for El Salvador and the rebels shook hands before signing the accord at today's public ceremony. De Soto later talked with the two sides to discuss procedures for the negotiations, U.N. officials said. The parties then adjourned. No date or location for the next session of talks was announced. The teams were led by El Salvador's justice minister, Oscar Santamaria, and rebel commander Shafik Handal. De Soto has been working to resume a dialogue between the government and the rebels since President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador met with Perez de Cuellar in New York in February. Negotiations between the two sides were last held in October. They were suspended after a union headquarters was bombed in November and the rebels opened an offensive in San Salvador in which more than 1,000 people died. The agreement to resume peace talks came at a time of rising hopes for peace in Central America. Chances for ending the El Salvador conflict got a boost with the defeat five weeks ago of the left-wing Sandinista government in Nicaragua, which has channeled weapons from Cuba to the rebels, according to U.S. officials. Cristiani's rightist government also has been hurt by falling prices for coffee, a major export, and a drop in U.S. economic aid. Handal said the U.N.-sponsored dialogue must include issues such as restructuring the army and police, judicial reforms and the reform of El Salvador's electoral system. ``We are optimistic now because these negotiations are in the framework of the United Nations,'' the rebel leader told a news conference. ``This gives them a greater degree of seriousness and weight than in the past.'' The Salvadoran rebels, in an open letter to this week's summit of Central American leaders in Nicaragua, proposed a plebiscite on constitutional reform to reduce the size of the country's armed forces. The proposed reform would also purge the military of right-wing elements and subject it to civilian authority. The rebels urged that the plebiscite be held jointly with the 1991 elections for a new National Assembly in El Salvador. The letter said the rebels were willing to become peaceful political parties if an agreement was reached.
DOC.HEAD: END
Despite Collapse in Eastern Europe, Greek Communists Still Hope
DOC.TEXT: Despite the collapse of communism elsewhere in Europe, Greek Communists are hoping to share power in an alliance with the socialists after elections Sunday. The most recent polls predict the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress will win 10.5 percent of the vote, down from 11 percent it scored in November elections. The conservative New Democracy party is expected to remain at 46 percent and the Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, at 40 percent. If the conservatives fail to win a majority in the 300-member Parliament, the Communists may be able to share power again, as they have for the last 10 months. They teamed up with the conservatives after inconclusive elections in June, and then with the socialists in an all-party government in November. Meanwhile, Communist regimes in Eastern Europe were being toppled in popular revolutions. ``The Greek people will not judge us because of the myths that existed in Eastern European countries,'' said Mimis Androulakis, the Communist Party's key strategist and reformer. ``They have judged us by our decades of struggle for democracy and progress in Greece.'' The Greek Communists were outlawed from 1947 to 1974, and political scientist Mihalis Spourdalakis says this may have saved them. ``In Greece, the Communist left has always been identified with the struggle for civil rights, for parliamentary democracy. On the other hand, we have had an authoritarian anti-Communist tradition. Communism is therefore not identified with authoritarianism, but rather with progress,'' he said. Menia Mendrinou, a long-time Communist Party organizer, said the party's supporters may have ``been numbed by events in Eastern Europe, but they won't vote for any other party. They still believe that the party will protect their interests.'' The Communists contend that their jettisoning of the hammer and sickle emblem when they formed the Coalition in March 1989, and their alliance with the conservatives in June, were precursors of broader changes elsewhere. ``We knocked down the walls before they were knocked down in Europe,'' Communist Party secretary-general Grigoris Farakos is fond of saying. Opponents, however, believe that it is this ideological disintegration that has damaged the Communists. The Coalition of the Left and Progress was formed in March 1989, comprising the Communist party, dissidents who had left the party, and some former supporters of the socialists. ``The Coalition is going through a crisis of policy,'' said Angelos Hagios, a prominent Communist Party member who broke away after the party joined with the conservatives in June. ``These contradictions _ working first with New Democracy, then with both, then with PASOK _ show a lack of independent leftist policy.'' Even Androulakis, who is hoping to retain his Parliamentary seat in the port city of Piraeus, acknowledges the party has a fight ahead of it. He points out that a slight drop in popularity could cost the Coalition some of the 21 seats it has in Parliament, and its strength as a power broker. Hagios, a candidate for the newly formed leftist Popular Opposition, believes his party may win a seat in Parliament at the Coalition's expense. Pollster Panayote Dimitras expects the Communists may be further damaged by a burgeoning environmentalist movement. The environmentalists may improve on the one seat they won in November _ attracting voters who blame the three major parties for the 10-month political stalemate. ``If they win a second or third seat, everything changes. They become the key to power,'' Dimitras said. A recent decision by the Coalition to field joint candidates with the socialists in five constituencies has led to heated protests from some supporters. The move may block a New Democracy majority in Parliament by denying it of two of the three seats it holds in these areas. Opponents of the joint candidacies say it is incomprehensible that the Communists cooperate with socialists. The conservative-Communist coalition indicted former Premier Andreas Papandreou and members of his eight-year socialist administration on corruption charges last year. The Communists counter that a New Democracy government would change the electoral law in favor of larger parties, closing the door on further coalition governments. They also say it would adopt strict austerity measures in a bid to revive the economy. Analysts, however, point out that the Communists are already in danger of losing their reason to exist. They have recently accepted Greece's role in the European Community, after seeing the former Communist states of Eastern Europe seek ties with the EC. ``People will soon be voting Communist only for sentimental reasons,'' said Spourdalakis.

DOC.HEAD: Real-Life Turtles Live in New York Sewers, But Eat Little Pizza
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: They may not chomp on pizza and fight teen-age hoods, but they do live in New York City's sewers. Dank-dwelling snapping turtles have been pulled out from sewage treatment plants. Their diets sometimes consist of cold cuts. Some of the turtles recovered from the Bronx and Manhattan plants have weighed 50 pounds or more, according to Tina Casey, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection. ``They're big enough to do serious damage to any hoodlum,'' she said, but not quite the size of the characters of the new hit movie, ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' The last time any of the big snappers came out of a New York sewer was 1988, when two were found, lean, mean and on screens intended to sift tree limbs and other large objects from sewage, Casey said. Periodically, younger snapping turtles or other, smaller breeds are found. Workers at the Bronx screening station have kept a few of the greenish-brown reptiles around as pets, feeding them cold cuts and meatballs, she said. When a ``monster'' turtle surfaces, the department has the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals take it to upstate New York and set it free. But they have to be handled carefully _ the turtle's powerful jaws can ``easily put a nasty dent in your body,'' Casey said. Casey ran across the sewer turtles' existence two years ago while researching the mythical blind albino alligators that don't inhabit the city sewers after supposedly being flushed down toilets. While the sewers are too cold and too sparse of alligator food, they seem to be all right for freshwater turtles, she said. ``Alligators look tougher, but turtles really know how to survive in New York,'' she said. ``They're real New Yorkers.'' Two theories about how the turtles got into the sewer system get the most credence at the department. One suggests they are back-washed into outlet pipes from the Bronx River or maybe the East River, Casey said. The other is that the turtles hatch in ponds at the Bronx Zoo or Central Park Zoo and crawl out to find their way into the sewer system. Besides turtles, eels, pythons and other creatures have shown up in the city's sewage. Look for them if they make a sequel.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Rebukes Estonian Leader in Phone Call
