DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 6 grafs after 2nd pvs, ``Arnold Ruutel...'' to UPDATE with radio interview and reported Gorbachev quotes, editing to conform. Pickup 5th, ``Estonia said...''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev phoned the president of Estonia today and sharply criticized the Baltic republic's drive for independence, Estonian media reported. Arnold Ruutel, president of Estonia's Supreme Soviet parliament, told official television that Gorbachev used strong words and was generally very angry during the conversation. In a later radio interview, Ruutel said Gorbachev criticized Estonia's Supreme Soviet for declaring the republic an occupied state. ``When I heard of your resolution I was completely beside myself. You must declare the resolution null and void. It is an invalid one,'' Ruutel quoted Gorbachev as saying. ``It seems to me that I have to introduce similar measures as those taken in Lithuania,'' he quoted the Soviet leader as saying. Ruutel did not elaborate on those remarks when asked by the radio interviewer. Soviet soldiers and tanks moved into Lithuania after officials in the republic refused to back down on their claim of independence, but Moscow has repeatedly said it would not use force there. Ruutel said that after he explained Estonia's position and that it would not give up its desire for independence, the Soviet president calmed down, the television report said without elaboration. No further details were available from the reported phone conversation. Estonia said last week it would seek to re-establish independence at the end of a still-undefined transition period. But unlike their Baltic neighbors in Lithuania, the Estonians are taking a more careful line on secession and have called on Moscow to start negotiations. The Estonian parliament's deputy speaker, Marju Lauristin, one of the leaders of the People's Front political movement, said she was pleased with the conversation despite its beginning. ``In spie of this first negative reaction, it is a contact and every contact is needed for negotiations,'' she said. Lauristin said Gorbachev demanded from Ruutel a full report on the situation in Estonia. She said the report was being prepared and would be sent to the Soviet president as soon as possible. Gorbachev's call followed appeals from non-Estonian nationalities to Moscow to protect the rights of Soviet citizens in the republic. Estonia declared support for Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence and called on Gorbachev in a parliament resolution to halt army pressure and stop ``political provocations'' against Lithuania. The Baltic republics of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were independent from the end of World War I until Soviet annexation in 1940. Meanwhile, Edgar Savisaar, elected the republic's premier on Tuesday, said his government would focus on restoring independence, economic reforms and attempts to avoid conflicts among Estonia's ethnic groups. Ethnic Estonians make up only about 60 percent of the republic's 1.6 million people. Slavs and other non-Estonian nationalities have voiced fears that the republic's move toward independence would hurt their interests. ``The area where this will be solved is economic,'' Savisaar said. ``With politics, we can't make them happy, we can't improve it. ... But the Russians are also interested that the material side of life begins to grow better.'' Savisaar, the chairman of the People's Front, said following his election he would cooperate with all ethnic groups. He said a list of Cabinet members would be presented next week. His statements today appeared to confirm reports from sources who said the new government was unlikely to include any of the 27 legislators representing the interests of the non-Estonian population in the 105-member parliament. In another development, a bomb damaged a Soviet T-34 tank put up as a monument to Soviet soldiers who died in World War II near the Estonian city of Valga, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. Hours after the bomb attack Tuesday night, about 20 youths armed with clubs pushed away a soldier guarding the damaged tank, tore off a tarpaulin covering it and left. Police officers standing nearby did not intervene, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Sound Machine Singer Released from Hospital
LaserPhoto NY27
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan, who suffered a broken back in a tour bus accident, was released from a hospital Wednesday, saying she was thankful to be alive. The vocalist of Miami Sound Machine headed home to Miami. Her release came two weeks after she underwent spinal surgery. ``I promise I will work 100 percent to come back,'' she told reporters at the Orthopedic Institute for Joint Diseases. Estefan, 32, suffered broken vertebrae March 21 when her tour bus was struck by a tractor-trailer on an icy Pennsylvania highway. She was transferred to the New York hospital the next day, and doctors performed delicate surgery to implant two steel rods in her spine. But just two weeks after that trauma, she ended her news conference by getting out of a wheelchair and standing without help. Estefan thanked the hospital staff for their support and had warm praise for the private nurses who ``helped me learn to sit and walk again.'' She praised her doctors, who ``gave me a couple of spare parts to go home with'' and joked that her surgeon, Dr. Michael Neuwirth, assured her: ``I wouldn't beep when I go through airport security.'' All in all, Estefan said, she was ``thankful for the miracle of being alive.'' Neuwirth said the singer faces about six months of rehabilitation but added: ``We fully expect her to return and perform again.'' Estefan, who was nominated for a Grammy award this year, said she planned to spend the time exercising, reading, sleeping and eating. ``It's the first time in my life I'll actually have to put on pounds,'' she joked, and added: ``Hopefully, in a few months, I'll be back good as new.'' Estefan and her husband, Emilio, returned to Florida on a private jet provided by entertainer Julio Iglesias.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets West German Foreign Minister
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 new grafs after 10th pvs, Shevardnadze was ..., to UPDATE with White House comments; picks up 11th graf pvs, Bush was...
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich-Genscher met with President Bush today and predicted that 1991 will be the year Germany is reunited. Genscher conferred with Bush in the Oval Office on the recent East German election results, on Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's talks with U.S. officials, the Lithuanian crisis and other matters. The West German minister told reporters afterwards, ``We had very friendly talks and we agreed in all important questions.'' Genscher said East Germany's new, non-communist government probably will be formed by next week. ``We want to begin discussions with the new government ... on economic, monetary and social union between the two German states'' so living conditions can be improved in the former communist state. He said sub-cabinet diplomats from the two-plus-four powers will soon hold another meeting on the external aspects of German unification, and ``we hope that by the end of April the first meeting at ministerial level'' will be held. The participants in the negotiations include both German nations plus the four nations that emerged victorious after World War II: the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Asked when unification will occur, Genscher replied, ``I assume that the first all-German elections will take place in the year 1991 and that is also the year in which German unity will be achieved.'' He said Germany is sworn never to develop nuclear, biological or chemical weapons, and offered anew the assurance that ``There is nobody, no single person in Germany that would question the present Polish western border. This is something that is definite.'' ``We want to see German unification be a contribution to stability in Europe,'' said Genscher, who added that NATO membership for the new nation remains ``of great importance.'' The Soviet Union wants a united Germany to be neutral, not in NATO. Shevardnadze was opening three days of talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker III later today. The Soviet minister meets with Bush on Friday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush and Genscher primarily discussed upcoming sessions of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), the 35-nation talks that involve nearly all the countries in Europe, the United States and Canada. ``The foreign minister and the president agreed this is a good forum for providing a framework for stability as we go through the changes in Eastern Europe,'' said Fitzwater. He emphasized that the European conference ``will not replace (NATO) in any way.'' No date has yet been set for the Bush-Gorbachev summit, tentatively set for mid-June. ``We're hopeful to be able to have a date'' by Friday when Baker and Shevardnadze finish their talks, Fitzwater said. Bush was hearing later today from Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's emissaries on how Japan plans to open its markets to U.S. exports. The president also was presenting a crystal apple to the national teacher of the year. Inclement weather forced the White House to cancel plans for Bush to play tennis with several pros. Bush, flying between political speeches in Indianapolis and the Detroit area on Tuesday, expressed concern about Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's threat to destroy ``half of Israel'' with chemical weapons if the Israelis attack facilities in Iraq. ``This is no time to be escalating tensions in the Middle East,'' said Bush. He urged Hussein to ``forget about talk of using chemical and biological weapons.'' Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor before it was completed in 1981. Two Iraqis and three others were arrested in London last week on U.S. charges of trying to ship nuclear triggers to Baghdad. Bush said he has seen ``no evidence'' that Iraq now has the newest generation of binary, or two-stage, chemical weapons. The president was savoring two congressional victories Tuesday: a House vote for $720 million in aid to Panama and Nicaragua and Senate passage of the first new clean air standards in 13 years. But the senators were not expected to heed his plea to pass the Panama-Nicaragua package before leaving town Thursday for a 12-day Easter recess. Bush dismissed Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell's complaint about the administration's ``jigsaw puzzle'' approach to foreign aid. ``There's no jigsaw puzzle,'' Bush told reporters aboard Air Force One. ``These are laser-like, urgent requests.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Soldiers Bombard Guerrilla-Held Town, Take Another
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian troops bombarded a strategic guerrilla-held town in the northwest Wednesday after retaking another town, the guerrillas and Western sources said. Government forces took the district capital of Thmar Puok on Tuesday with heavy rocket, tank and infantry assaults, said Ok Serei Sopheak, a spokesman for the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. The Front, one of three guerrilla groups fighting the Vietnamese-backed Phnom Penh government, had held the town. The government forces struck from positions to the south retaken in recent weeks, another Front official said. Other guerrillas said the town fell Wednesday. There was no way to explain the discrepancy or verify the reports. Guerrilla and Western sources also said government forces on Wednesday were shelling Banteay Chmar, a district capital near Thmar Puok. They said it was expected to fall soon. If Banteay Chmar falls, the government will have retaken every major position the guerrillas seized after Vietnam announced last September it had pulled all its troops from Cambodia. Both towns are in Banteay Meanchey province and close to the Thai border. Guerrilla sources also reported a heavy government attack on the Front's military headquarters at Boueng Trakuan, across the border from the Thai town of Ta Phraya. Some of the rounds strayed into Thailand. Western relief workers in Ta Phraya said the shelling on the other side of the border was so heavy that houses shook. As many as 5,000 refugees fleeing the fighting have gone to the giant Site 2 refugee camp, about 60 miles north of Aranyaprathet, Western relief officials said. Western diplomats cited reports that thousands more civilians had fled Thmar Puok to remaining guerrilla-held areas inside Cambodia, which the guerrillas call ``liberated zones.'' The non-Communist Front is allied with two other guerrilla groups _ forces of former monarch Prince Norodom Sihanouk, and the Communist Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia by terror and famine until Vietnam's invasion ousted it from Phnom Penh more than a decade ago. Western relief workers said there were reports of heavy government attacks in the past few weeks on Khmer Rouge positions opposite the Thai town of Trat on the southern border with Cambodia. No details were immediately available. The guerrillas have blamed the recent reversals on an interruption in arms shipments from China, their main supplier, and on what they claim is the reintroduction of thousands of Vietnamese soldiers in Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Boesky to End Term Quietly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with formal release, add background; picks up 9th graf, `Asked about....'
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Boesky _ the biggest fish netted so far in the Wall Street scandal _ completed his federal prison term today when he was officially released from a halfway house. Boesky signed papers for his release and left the Brooklyn House Community Corrections Center at 5:05 a.m., said Richard Luna, a U.S. Bureau of Prisons official in New York. Boesky, 53, was transferred to the halfway house Dec. 6 from a minimum security federal prison in Lompoc, Calif. The former stock speculator lived outside the center, reported in twice a week and called in daily starting Feb. 5, Luna said. Boesky now must to report to a probation officer once a month for six months, officials said. Boesky's lawyer, Robert McCaw, would not comment on where Boesky has been living or what his plans are. When he was allowed to live outside the halfway house, Boesky was required to have a paying job, although officials declined to say what that was. In 1986, Boesky moved to settle insider-trading charges by paying $100 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission and agreeing to plead guilty to lying to federal regulators. He was sentenced to three years in prison, beginning his term in April 1988. He was released early for good behavior. Boesky is expected to testify against former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond financier Michael Milken, whose trial may not begin unitil 1991. Boesky also is expected to testify at the trial of former arbitrager John A. Mulheren on securities fraud charges. Mulheren, a former business associate of Boesky, was arrested for weapons possession and allegedly told police he planned to kill Boesky. Asked about Boesky's plans, a source close to Boesky said he is ``playing a very low profile and readjusting, staying away from the cameras and reporters.'' The source said Boesky would not give any interviews until he has finished his role as a government witness, if then. As part of his plea, Boesky agreed to cooperate with prosecutors in the continuing Wall Street crackdown and offered information that led to Drexel's record $650 million settlement of criminal and civil securities charges and the indictment of Milken a year ago. Drexel is liquidating now after its parent filed for bankruptcy protection in February. Boesky caused a stir in November when he was photographed by a New York tabloid in Stamford, Conn., with shoulder-length gray hair and a long, scraggly beard. He was spotted a month later in a business suit in New York City, his hair and beard neatly trimmed. Boesky reportedly is living in the New York area. He owns a 75-acre estate in Westchester County north of New York City, which recently has been under renovation.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Patient Ryan White Remains in Critical Condition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `Dr. Martin...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with doctor's comments today. Picks up 6th graf, `White, a...'
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson telephoned, Elton John flew into town and thousands of other who have never even met Ryan White offered prayers and get-well wishes for the teen-age AIDS victim clinging to life today. President Bush, who was in Indianapolis for a political fund-raiser Tuesday, planted a tree for White at a ceremony 1{ miles from the hospital where the 18-year-old lay in critical condition on life-support equipment. ``He's been fighting a courageous battle against a deadly disease and also against ignorance and fear. Ryan has helped us understand the truth about AIDS and he's shown all of us the strength and bravery of the human heart,'' Bush said. Dr. Martin B. Kleiman said White was heavily sedated so a life-support system helping him breathe would function more efficiently. ``He's holding on. His status deteriorated in the first day or two and then reached a plateau. Any patient who is critical must stabilize before he can recover and Ryan has stabilized,'' Kleiman said today. ``There have been patients who have been this ill and have recovered. We can maintain patients at this level for prolonged periods of time.'' White is on life support because AIDS left him susceptible to a respiratory infection. ``The majority of his difficulties derived from the inability of his lungs to support him,'' Kleiman said. White, a hemophiliac who contracted AIDS from contaminated blood products, has waged a five-year battle with the disease during which he grew from an object of scorn in his hometown of Kokomo into an international spokesman for AIDS patients. He fought a successful court battle to attend school and helped reinforce the message that AIDS cannot be spread through casual contact. Calls Tuesday from of well-wishers and celebrities with messages of love and prayers swamped Riley Hospital for Children, where White he was admitted Thursday with an AIDS-related lung ailment. When Jackson called, a speaker phone was brought to White's bedside in hopes the unconscious teen-ager would hear Jackson's words. ``He told Ryan he loved him and that God is with him,'' family spokewoman Carrie Van Dyke said. ``And he said, `Hang in there, buddy, and get better.''' Jackson befriended White a couple of years ago and gave him a car. White also was a guest at Jackson's California ranch during New Year's. John flew in from Los Angeles to spend five hours Monday with the family. He ``just raised their spirits tremendously, that someone of his stature would care so much to drop everything,'' Van Dyke said. Hospital spokeswoman Mary Maxwell said the flood of calls ``has been bedlam. We're getting calls from every small town in the United States. It hasn't let up.'' ``We handled 4,500 calls yesterday and we'll probably get 5,000 today,'' said Walt Linne, who oversees the switchboard. Callers conveyed ``good wishes, concern, prayers and love.'' Among those who left messages were actor Tony Danza, quarterback Joe Montana and country singers Johnny Cash and the Statler Brothers. White's mother, Jeanne, said it was her son's decision to be placed on the life-support system. ``The decision came entirely from Ryan. If Ryan had a chance, then Ryan wanted to go for it,'' Mrs. White said. ``All we can do is hope for the best.'' Mrs. White and her daughter, Andrea, 16, have remained at White's bedside since he was hospitalized Thursday. His father, Wayne White, who is divorced from Mrs. White, visited his son Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Brass Reject Lehman's Proposal to Reduce Active Duty Tours
DOC.TEXT: The Navy secretary and chief of the service's operations on Wednesday discounted a recent proposal by former Navy Secretary John Lehman that called for greater reliance on reserve forces as a cost-saving move. ``I won't begin by saying `nonsense' but a lot of it is,'' Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost said of Lehman's recommendation. A member of the House Armed Services subcommittee on seapower and strategic and critical materials gave Trost an account of Lehman's testimony. Lehman, who during his tenure in the Reagan administration presided over one of the largest naval buildups, told the Armed Services panel last week that the Navy should use more reserves and reduce tours of duty for active forces. The former Navy secretary proposed manys ships and planes manned ``50 percent by active and 50 percent by weekend warriors.'' But in the first public response by the Navy's top brass, Trost said the service has had ``difficulty attracting people of the necessary skills and the necessary numbers'' to the reserves. ``The result has been that we man our naval reserve ships with a higher number of active duty personnel than we would like,'' he said. Trost, who serves as the chief of naval operations, said that during the first nine months of his current assignment, he did not recall Lehman making those points offered in his recent testimony. ``Perhaps I'm missing something,'' he said. Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III, who also disagreed with Lehman's statements, said that savings realized from relying on the reserves would be no greater than 10 perent or 15 percent. ``Expansion of naval reserve should be limited to areas where its cost effective, mutual support can be provided to the active force because this Navy needs to provide for this nation's deterrence,'' Garrett said. The Navy secretary said in fiscal 1990, 26 ships will be moved to the reserves. The fiscal 1991 defense budget calls for putting 40 ships in reserve, he said. Questioned about the possibility of a 450-ship Navy, Garrett said he would fight any effort in the Bush administration to reduce the force. ``We will continue to argue our case with Congress and the (defense) secretary,'' he said. ``There are no plans in the five-year plan to go to a 450-ship Navy.''

DOC.HEAD: NY Court Says Welfare Recipients Entitled to Enough Money for Housing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4 and 7 to CORRECT to Jiggetts, sted Jiggettes or Jiggett.
DOC.TEXT: The state must give welfare recipients enough money to afford housing, New York's highest court ruled in a decision hailed as a victory for the homeless. ``A schedule establishing assistance levels so low that it forces large numbers of families with dependent children into homelessness does not meet the statutory standard,'' the Court of Appeals declared Tuesday. The court ordered a trial to determine whether New York state's welfare shelter allowance is inadequate. Welfare advocates had argued the shelter allowance was set far below market rates for even the cheapest housing. The case was brought by Barbara Jiggetts, a New York City woman who complained her shelter allowance forced her to choose between housing and food for her children. State Social Services Commissioner Cesar Perales, in a statement, said the ruling established a requirement for a reasonable housing allowance but did not conclude the state's welfare grants were inadequate. ``The New York state Department of Social Services is preparing for a trial on that issue,'' Perales said. But lawyers for Jiggetts said they believed the Court of Appeals' strong language would make it hard for a lower court not to order increased welfare rates. ``It's a great decision and it's very important for the welfare population of New York,'' said Allan Gropper of the state Bar Association's Project for the Homeless of the City. He said studies have shown as many as one-third of the homeless people in New York City had been evicted. Courts in Massachusetts and other states have made similar rulings recently, poverty law experts said. Jiggetts, a single mother of three, sued New York City social service officials in 1987 when she was being evicted from her apartment. She's since found housing, but other families joined the lawsuit and the state became the defendant, said Matthew Diller, a lawyer for the New York Legal Aid Society. New York state has more than 450,000 welfare recipients, two-thirds in New York City. Christopher Lamb, another Legal Aid Society lawyer, said the shelter allowance for a family of four in New York City is $312 a month. The Department of Housing and Urban Development reports the average market rate for a two-bedroom apartment for poor people in New York City is $566. ``People shouldn't be sent out into the New York City market and be told you have to find an apartment for a family of four at $312 a month,'' Lamb said. ``It's like hitting your head against the wall.'' Welfare advocates supporting the lawsuit contended that, in 1987, more than 60 percent of Aid to Families with Dependent Children recipients living in private housing were forced to pay rents higher than their shelter allowances.

DOC.HEAD: Government Finally Gets Better Count of Secrets: 6.8 Million a Year
DOC.TEXT: After seven years of trying, the government thinks it finally has an accurate count of how many secrets it creates: 6.8 million a year. That's a 35 percent decrease from the previous count, but nearly all the drop came when the Navy decided it really didn't originate more secrets than the rest of the government put together. It's still just an estimate but it appears that the ``top secret,'' ``secret'' and ``confidential'' stamps were wielded 6,796,501 times in the fiscal year which ended last Sept. 30. ``It appears that this unprecedented drop is primarily the result of more accurate counting, rather than an actual tremendous decrease in classification activity,'' said Steven Garfinkel, who has spent the past seven years trying to get the government to produce fewer secrets and count them more accurately. Garfinkel heads the Information Security Oversight Office, created in 1982 when then-President Reagan rewrote all the rules for classifying documents. In his annual report to President Bush, released Tuesday, Garfinkel praised the Navy for finally figuring out what he has been trying to count each year. The government doesn't actually count its secrecy decisions each year. It samples the number of times some offices decide to classify information. Then it projects those numbers to reflect the number of decisions in all offices. Moreover, there are two kinds of secrets: original secrets, of which 500,000 were produced last year, and derivative secrets, of which 6.3 million were created. For example, an official creates an original secret by deciding that all photographs from a spy satellite will be kept secret; another official creates a derivative secret each time he stamps one of the photos ``top secret.'' A derivative secret also is created when one official copies another official's original secret into a new document _ the government equivalent of the friend who says, ``Don't tell so-and-so, but I just learned that ....'' For 1987 and 1988, the Navy reported creating far more original secrets than the rest of the government combined. As Garfinkel put it in his report to Bush, both the Defense Department and his office ``expressed skepticism about the accuracy of these data.'' In 1989, the Navy learned what went wrong. Some of its sample offices were ``reporting the number of all classified documents on hand, not just classification decisions that they had originated,'' Garfinkel said. Fixing that error knocked about 3.5 million off the number of secrets created last year. Garfinkel said it didn't hurt that the Navy sampled seven times more offices than before, conducted its samples for almost half a year and provided all sample offices with ``extensive instructions and training.'' Of the four agencies _ the Defense, State and Justice departments and the CIA _ that create nearly 99 percent of the secrets, only Justice created more secrets in 1989 than 1988. Not only that, Justice reported significant increases in the number of overclassified and mismarked documents. But Garfinkel said that was far from a failure at Justice. He said the number of secrets rose because more FBI agents are assigned to catch spies and FBI field offices are keeping better records. The bureau creates more than 90 percent of Justice's secrets. In addition, Garfinkel praised the FBI for starting to review actual documents as well as surveying agents, which he said is how the bureau found the misclassified items. ``That's a commendable effort to achieve better quality control,'' he said. Overall in 1989, Garfinkel said, ``the strides were modest, but what's most important is we finally have the Defense Department count in the ball park. These numbers can provide a benchmark to look at future activity.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Still Aiming for Tuesday Launch
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Wednesday testing of the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope is taking longer than expected, but that should not delay next week's launch aboard space shuttle Discovery. The space agency had said testing of the telescope would have to be completed by midnight Wednesday for Discovery to lift off as planned Tuesday. That deadline was extended to Thursday morning. ``Tests are going fine. There are no problems. But it's going slower than we expected,'' said George Diller, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A 52-hour check of the telescope's scientific instruments was interrupted Monday by a power outage that knocked out air conditioning and forced the shutdown of heat-sensitive computers. Testing resumed Tuesday evening after technicians switched over to a newer backup power system capable of withstanding an electric failure. To accommodate the extra testing time, NASA has rearranged launch preparations, moving up certain things that normally would not have been done until later, Diller said. Charging of the telescope's nickel-hydrogen batteries, temporarily interrupted by the power outage, also continued Wednesday. The batteries will be charged until two days before launch, when the shuttle's payload bay doors are closed. Technicians planned to close out the shuttle's rear engine compartment this week. That involves making final inspections, removing protective covers for flight, installing last-minute items and cleaning the area. No extra time to solve problems is left, and any further complications will delay the mission, Diller said. NASA on Saturday moved the launch from April 12 to April 10 because preparations were ahead of schedule. Discovery is scheduled to lift off at 8:47 a.m. Tuesday with five astronauts who will put the telescope into orbit on the second day of the five-day mission. Once deployed, the Hubble will orbit 380 miles above Earth for 15 years, free of atmospheric distortion. It will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers will be able to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Government, Rebels Begin Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: El Salvador's government and leftist rebels met for U.N.-mediated peace talks Wednesday in a new effort to end their civil war, but disagreement quickly surfaced on the issue of a cease-fire. Both sides and U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar agreed to seek a truce as an ``initial objective'' on the way to a negotiated settlement. But Shafik Handal, chief delegate of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front guerrillas, made plain his group links acceptance of a cease-fire to progress on political reforms. The rightist, U.S.-backed government of President Alfredo Cristiani says suspension of fighting must have priority. The two sides signed a U.N.-sponsored declaration committing them to seek a cease-fire and a definitive end to ``the armed conflict through political means as speedily as possible.'' The accord called for promoting moves toward democracy and respect for human rights in El Salvador, and reintegrating the FMLN fighters into the nation's shattered society. The talks then recessed until May. No date or location was announced for the next round. El Salvador's civil war has killed some 72,000 people since it began in 1980. The rebels have come under pressure since the defeat of the left-wing Sandinista government in Nicaragua's Feb. 25 election. Nicaragua helped the FMLN for more than a decade. U.S. officials say Nicaragua also was a transit point for Cuban weapons shipments to the Salvadoran guerrillas. During a rebel offensive in November, a Soviet appeal for ending the bloodshed contrasted sharply with unflagging support for the guerrillas by Cuban President Fidel Castro. On Wednesday, FMLN representatives and Salvadoran government representatives led by Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria shook hands before signing the accord. The sides held brief separate talks with Perez de Cuellar at the U.N. building in Geneva and met with Alvaro de Soto, the U.N. special envoy for Central America, to discuss procedure. Both sides agreed that future talks can either be face-to-face or involve shuttle diplomacy by the United Nations between the two delegations. ``The simple fact of agreeing on the procedure for the realization of the negotiating process is a considerable advance,'' de Soto told reporters. Peace talks were last held in October. They were suspended after a union headquarters was bombed in November and the rebels launched their offensive in San Salvador. More than 1,000 people died in the fighting. De Soto has been working to resume a dialogue between the government and the rebels since Cristiani met Perez de Cuellar in New York in February. Handal said the new talks must include issues such as restructuring of the army and police, judicial reform and reform of El Salvador's electoral system. ``We are optimistic now because these negotiations are in the framework of the United Nations,'' the FMLN official told a news conference. ``This gives them a greater degree of seriousness and weight than in the past.'' The Salvadoran rebels, in an open letter to this week's summit of Central American leaders in Nicaragua, proposed a plebiscite on constitutional reform to reduce the size of the country's armed forces. The proposed reform would also purge the military of right-wing elements and subject it to civilian authority. The rebels urged that the plebiscite be held jointly with the 1991 elections for a new National Assembly in El Salvador. The letter said the rebels were willing to become peaceful political parties if an agreement were reached.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Exiled King Michael of Romania plans his first visit to his homeland since a Soviet-installed government forced him to abdicate 42 years ago, a spokeswoman said Wednesday. Michael plans to leave April 12 for what spokeswoman Danielle Maillefer termed a ``sort of private pilgrimage'' of no more than 10 days, accompanied by his wife, Queen Anne. The provisional Romanian government was informed of the private visit ``through diplomatic channels,'' Ms. Maillefer said. Michael left Romania four days after his Dec. 30, 1947, abdication. He said he signed the document because he was threatened his supporters would be massacred, if he refused. At a news conference shortly after the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu in December, the 68-year-old Michael said he would head a constitutional monarchy, if asked to by voters through a national referendum. ``If people want me to come back, I will come back,'' he said. Michael is related to the British and other European royalty and holds a British passport. He settled in Switzerland in 1956.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Rome's Olympic Stadium, rebuilt for the final of soccer's World Cup, will get a blessing from a former goalie: Pope John Paul II. John Paul has accepted an invitation from the Italian Olympic Committee to visit the stadium on May 31 and bless the remodeled arena, the Vatican announced Wednesday. Host team Italy will play its first game there June 9 against Austria and the stadium will be the site of the final of the month-long competition. John Paul, an avid sportsman in his native Poland, is said by his biographers to have been an enthusiastic goalie as a teen-ager in Wadowice. He visited the stadium, which was built for the 1960 Summer Olympics, for a Holy Year sports celebration in 1984. Workmen are now trying to meet the deadline to finish the modernization, which includes putting up a roof over the stands.

Actor John Cusack pleaded innocent to a misdemeanor drunken driving charge stemming from a Feb. 23 accident in which his sports car allegedly struck another car broadside. The innocent plea for the 23-year-old actor, whose films include ``Say Anything,'' ``Fat Man and Little Boy,'' ``Eight Men Out'' and ``The Sure Thing,'' was entered Tuesday during a municipal court arraignment.

A court has ordered actor Yves Montand to submit to a blood test to determine if he is the father of a 14-year-old girl whose mother has filed a paternity lawsuit. The court concluded Tuesday that Montand and former actress Anne Florange had a relationship for several years after they met in 1972 while making films in southern France. Montand, 68, could refuse the test, but would ``bear all consequences of this refusal,'' said the court. There was no immediate indication how the actor would respond. Ms. Florange asked that Montand pay $170,000 in damages and interest to cover the costs of raising the girl, Aurora. Press reports said Ms. Florange sued only after she became convinced that new scientific techniques could establish beyond doubt whether Montand was Aurora's father. Montand, known to American audiences for the films ``Let's Make Love'' and ``Z,'' had no children from his 33-year marriage to actress Simone Signoret, who died in 1985. But on Dec. 31, 1988, at age 67, he became a father when his girlfriend, Carole Amiel, gave birth to a boy.

Fawn Hall, introduced to America's television viewers during the Iran-Contra affair, will be taking some viewers to the beach this spring. Ms. Hall, who was Oliver North's secretary when he was an aide at the National Security Council, was in Pittsburgh on Tuesday doing pre-production work for KDKA-TV's ``Evening Magazine'' program. Ms. Hall's assignment is to report on three beach resorts favored by Pittsburgh vacationers. The segments, featuring Ocean City, Md., Myrtle Beach, S.C., and Virginia Beach, Va., will air starting April 25.

Actor Burt Reynolds testified in a lawsuit brought by the family of a veteran stuntman who was killed when his motorcycle plunged down a 40-foot embankment while filming a movie in the Arizona desert. Reynolds, a former stuntman himself, told a jury Tuesday that remote filming locations should have helicopters or some other form of transportation available. A film made by Reynolds, ``Hooper,'' included a character based on stuntman Dar Robinson, who was 39 years old when he died of massive internal injuries in the 1986 accident. ``His reputation was that he was the best in the business, especially for high falls,'' said Reynolds. Robinson died while filming a high-speed motorcycle chase for ``Million Dollar Mystery.'' The multimillion dollar wrongful death lawsuit filed against Dino De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and Productions Ltd. alleges that Robinson died because an ambulance was not available. It took two hours to get him to the nearest hospital. Defense attorneys maintain there was no ambulance on the set because Robinson felt it was ``bad luck'' and felt it was an insult to his stunt abilities. Reynolds, 54, testified in Superior Court that an ambulance was present on the set of ``Stick,'' a film in which Robinson performed a fall from a 16-story building without a protective airbag or net. ``It is my understanding that if you are doing a major stunt, there should be an ambulance present,'' said Reynolds, who also directed the film.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Require Newspaper Editorialists to Disclose Finances
DOC.TEXT: A state House panel approved legislation Wednesday that would require newspaper editorial board members to disclose their finances. The bill also would make it a second-degree misdemeanor for a newspaper to publish an unsigned editorial. A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee approved the measure on a 4-3 vote. It would include editorial board members in a present law that requires state employees to file financial disclosure forms or face a possible $5,000 fine. ``The real molders of public opinion is the press,'' said Rep. Elvin Martinez, one of the bill's 32 co-sponsors. ``They can take you and beat you and do anything to you, and they're immune. I think people have a right to know if their views are jaundiced by some financial interest.'' Barry Richard, attorney for the Florida Press Association, said the measure infringes on the First Amendment's guarantee of a free press and would never stand up in court. ``There's nothing in this bill to prohibit freedom of the press,'' said its sponsor Rep. Bruce McEwan. The legislation next moves to the full committee, where McEwan said he was optimistic of approval.

DOC.HEAD: Military `Top Gun' Pilot Daniel Shewell Dies at 47
DOC.TEXT: Retired U.S. Navy Commander Daniel J. Shewell, who choreographed the flight scenes for the movie ``Top Gun'' and was a commander of the real Top Gun school, has died after suffering a heart attack. He was 47. Shewell, a native of York County, Pa., died Saturday in the University of Tennessee Medical Center. His military funeral was Wednesday in New Freedom. In the late 1960s, Shewell graduated from the Navy Fighter Weapons School, nicknamed ``Top Gun,'' and served in the first F-14 squadron in the Navy. By the mid-1980s, he had worked his way to commanding officer of the school at the Miramar Naval Station near San Diego. During his tenure, Shewell served as technical consultant on the 1986 movie about the training of fighter pilots, which starred Tom Cruise and Kelly McGillis. Shewell logged more than 3,500 hours of flight time and made more than 800 carrier landings. After retiring, he worked briefly for EC Corp., a defense contractor in Nashville, Tenn. He is survived by his wife, Doris M. Shewell, of Knoxville, Tenn.; two daughters, a son, his parents, two sisters and a brother.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Conclude New Cancer Screening Test Doesn't Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Four years ago, a new test that seemed to detect all forms of cancer from tiny blood samples appeared destined to revolutionize the way doctors screen people for the disease. Now, many specialists doubt the method will ever live up to its promise. For reasons they cannot explain, the test seems to work only in the hands of the physician who invented it. In 1986, Dr. Eric T. Fossel of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital said he had found a way to tell whether a patient had cancer simply by examining a bit of his blood in a nuclear magnetic resonance scanner, or NMR. It would detect tumors too small to feel, or spot on X-rays. Fossel continued to work on the method and reported more encouraging results as he tested thousands of blood samples. The discovery was so important that many other doctors hurried to try it out. Apparently without reported exception, they failed. Two studies published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine _ the journal that first described Fossel's apparent breakthrough _ add to the mounting evidence against it. ``We were unable to determine whether or not a person had cancer based on the blood test,'' said Dr. Paul Okunieff of Massachusetts General Hospital. Carefully mirroring Fossel's methods, Okunieff tested blood from 79 people with cancer or pre-cancerous diseases and 66 people in the hospital for other reasons. The test could not tell them apart. Terje Engan directed a Norwegian group from the University of Trondheim that conducted a similar comparison of blood from 104 cancer patients and 164 healthy people. When the people studied were the same sex and age, the test could not distinguish those with cancer from those without. In his report, Okunieff reviewed 18 studies, including his own, that have used NMR to diagnose cancer. Only six _ all by Fossel _ worked. In one those studies, published last year, doctors from the West German Cancer Center in Essen sent blood samples to Fossel from 54 men with testicular cancer, 88 men who had been successfully treated for the disease and 57 healthy men the same age. Fossel, who had no information about the patients' status, conducted the NMR tests and sent back the results. The German doctors found that Fossel's findings were 90 percent accurate. So the question remains: How can a test work for one person but nobody else? ``I honestly don't know what went wrong, but there is this big difference between what he's getting and what other people reported,'' commented Dr. Robert Shulman of Yale University School of Medicine. Fossel refused to discuss the latest reports, but issued a statement implying that others have not duplicated his results because they failed to faithfully follow his methods. ``Clearly, the NMR cancer blood test requires close adherence to the specified techniques,'' he wrote, ``but when carried out correctly, this method is a candidate system for detection of cancer as well as for monitoring cancer therapy.'' The controversy is reminiscent of the debate over cold fusion. After a University of Utah team announced the spectacular discovery of nuclear fusion in a lab jar a year ago, other scientists have had trouble duplicating their findings. The Utah group responded by saying that the others had failed to precisely follow their techniques. At the National Cancer Institute, which has financed some of Fossel's research, Dr. Roger Aamodt said he is ``reasonably sure'' that the test will not be suitable for general cancer screening. However, he said it might still be of some benefit in checking the progress of treatment or recurrence in some individual cancer patients. Aamodt said no one knows why the test seems to work only for Fossel. While it's possible that the reasons have something to do with differences in techniques or the patient populations studied, the explanations are ``essentially all supposition and speculation.'' Aamodt and Okunieff said they thought Fossel had honestly tried to obtain accurate results. ``We are still in a position where it is up in the air,'' said Aamodt. ``This has been a controversial area since the first finding. A lot of people looked at this and said it didn't make sense. All along there have been questions. What you are seeing is science in action.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Jet Makes Emergency Landing; No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: A Boston-bound Eastern Airlines flight made an emergency landing at National Airport today after the rear stairway of the Boeing 727 popped open, an airport official said. No injuries were reported. Eastern Flight 192 radioed to the tower shortly after takeoff that a cockpit indictor showed the back stairway to be open, said airport spokesman David Hess. The pilot received clearance for an emergency landing and landed without incident, Hess said. No injuries were reported. The flight had 70 passengers and a crew of seven, Hess said. The pilot's call to the tower was received at 1:55 p.m. EDT, moments after takeoff, and after circling, the plane landed at 2:08 p.m., Hess said. The Boeing 727 model has a rear stairway under the tail of the plane. ``It dropped some but I don't have a report yet on how far down,'' Hess said.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Satellites Now Three Decades Old
DOC.TEXT: When that first fuzzy satellite picture of the earth arrived just over 30 years ago weather experts were overjoyed. Now, ``there was no way that any storm, anywhere in the world, would go undetected,'' John W. Townsend Jr., director of NASA's Goddard Space Center, recalled on Wednesday. And none has, though people sometimes ignore the warnings that weather forecasters issue when storms are reported, he noted at a news conference commemorating three decades of weather satellites. ``The 90s is turning out to be the decade of the climate. The point to be made today is that we've been around for 30 years measuring climate from space. We're not a `Johnny-come-lately,' '' said Russell Koffler of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Satellites have ``revolutionized'' the science of weather prediction, added J. E. Keigler, chief scientist for GE Astro Space, which builds the Tiros weather satellites. He recalled meteorologists saying that the original machine would be worthwhile if it produced just one picture. Tiros 1 went on to produce 22,000 pictures during its three-month lifetime, which began April 1, 1960. ``And since then there's always been a Tiros in orbit,'' he added, referring to the series of low-level weather satellites that still circle the globe, measuring the climate and weather every place on earth twice a day. The low-level satellites marking their 30th anniversary are generically called Tiros, which is an abbreviation for Television Infrared Observation Satellite. These days the public is more familiar with the GOES satellites that hover in place over the equator, looking down at the whole Earth from 22,300 miles in space. But still a pair of Tiros satellites zoom around the globe at a mere 700 or so miles, getting a close look. So far 32 of these satellites have been built and launched, with an average lifepsan of 2{ years. And, while the first satellites were limited to pictures of what is visible _ land, water and clouds _ now they measure much more. Air and sea-surface temperatures are taken, snow and ice cover is tracked, ozone is measured, cloud cover measured, water vapor in the air recorded and the radiation arriving from the sun and departing from the Earth is tracked by these satellites, explained Koffler. Even the amount of vegetation on the land is measured from the satellites, he added, noting that this information is expected to be especially useful in assessing the response to any global changes in climate. The satellites are operated by NOAA's National Environmental Satellite Data and Information Service and are known by the designation NOAA when in service. A new NOAA satellite is scheduled for launch in the fall.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Alabama's youngest elected official, 21-year-old Merle Flowers, is hoping his 18-month stint as a city councilman will help him win the vice presidency of Auburn University's Student Government Association. Flowers has served for two years as a student senator and as chairman of the association's budget and finance committee. He was elected a councilman in his hometown of Section at age 19 in October 1988. The 21,700-student university votes Thursday to elect student government officers, and Flowers faces three opponents for the vice presidency. Flowers said he wants to come across as ``low-profile but energetic,'' but not ``like a politician'' despite his familiarity with the electoral process. He said he was motivated to enter politics by a desire for change in his hometown of 1,500, and doesn't regard his youth as a disadvantage. ``After I was elected, I was more of a novelty to my school friends, who introduced me as `Mr. Councilman,''' he said. ``Now a lot of younger citizens are involved in the city's projects. It's really broken down the age barrier.'' Flowers travels home twice a month for council meetings and handles other business by telephone. He said he plans to study law and favors a career in politics but, for now, ``I'm taking it one election at a time.''

Ann Landers is annoyed at how impolite people become when they use video cameras and appealed to Eastman Kodak Co. to help out by printing a brochure on photography etiquette. Sorry, came back the reply. Eastman Kodak doesn't manufacture camcorders. Ann Landers' column published a letter Tuesday from a reader complaining about video camera enthusiasts who elbow their way to the best seats at public events. The columnist replied, ``I wish the film companies would come out with a brochure on photography etiquette and stick it in with the film. There's a real need for this sort of thing, as your letter clearly indicates. How about it, Eastman Kodak?'' ``We have nothing to do with camcorders,'' said Eastman Kodak spokeswoman Darlene Aiken. ``We sympathize with the writer and believe that common courtesy should be followed when using any product, whether photographic or otherwise,'' the Rochester, N.Y.-based company said in a statement.

A portrait of Harrison County's first and only woman sheriff, the late Virgie Huggins, is back in place in the Sheriff's Hall of Fame. The badge-toting widow, who temporarily took her husband's jobs as sheriff and tax collector when he died in January 1933, apparently had her picture removed soon after by a lawman who thought she didn't belong in the gallery. But the current sheriff, Joe Price, brought her back to the Gulfport courthouse Tuesday after the Huggins family offered him the portrait. ``I feel she should be up there like anybody else who served the duties of sheriff,'' Price said. Mrs. Huggins ran against six opponents for the job of sheriff in March 1933 but lost by 500 votes to a former sheriff, a man. ``The truth is, a lot of people hungered for the job of sheriff,'' said her son, Cleveland Huggins Jr., 73. ``It was a pretty good job then with the potential of making a lot of money.'' Price said ``she probably would have been elected if it had been a different era. 1933 was a little early for a woman.''

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Leader Says Hostages Should be Freed For Ramadan
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi said foreign hostages and prisoners of conscience should be freed to mark the holy Moslem month of Ramadan, the official Libyan news agency said Wednesday. ``He has called to mind the hostages in the Middle East of various nationalities and religions, in particular the French hostage'' Jacqueline Valente, said JANA. Valente was captured on a yacht off Cyprus in 1987 by Abu Nidal's Libyan-backed Fatah-Revolutionary Council. JANA, monitored in Rome, said the Libyan leader stressed Islamic humanitarian values and called on Moslems to refrain from detaining innocent people. Gadhafi appealed to ``rank and file Moslems the world over,'' said Jana, to release ``the hostages and prisoners of conscience on the advent of the blessed month of Ramadan _ the month of love and tolerence.'' Ramadan began in late March and lasts through April. During the Moslem holy month, Moslems fast from sunrise to sunset, and it is customary for rulers of Islamic countries to pardon prisoners to mark the holiday. In Washington, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater welcomed Gadhafi's appeal. ``Sometimes you get support from strange quarters,'' he said. ``Any release of the hostages would be welcome, and anyone who urges their release is saying the right thing.'' There are 18 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon. Most are held by Shiite Moslem groups loyal to Iran. The hostage held longest is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. Seven other Americans are among the captives. Gadhafi has previously called for the release of all hostages and has said it is against the teachings of Islam to take innocent people captive. Valente was was captured along with her two daughters and five Belgians. The Abu Nidal group claimed they were Israeli spies. The children were freed in December 1988, reportedly after Gadhafi intervened, but it is not known where their mother is.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Mourners Beat Motorist who Crashes into Funeral Procession
DOC.TEXT: Mourners beat up a motorist who accidentally crashed his car into a funeral procession and attacked a jail warden tying to rescue him, police said. About 100 mourners were making their way to a cemetery to bury Larry Waller, 21, killed in the crossfire of a gun battle last Wednesday, when a car plowed into the procession of cars at an intersection. ``It was a simple traffic accident,'' said police spokesman Wendell Creager. ``But the woman whose car was hit got out and started verbally abusing the other driver. Then some of the mourners gathered around and it got out of hand.'' Adler Nagy, 19, sought refuge in a Pinellas County Sheriff's Office van, which was in the procession taking one of Waller's relatives, a prison inmate, to the funeral. Scores of mourners surrounded the van, and several people jumped inside and pummeled Nagy and Corrections Officer Bernetta Blossom, 31, said sheriff's spokeswoman Marianne Pasha. Tuesday's fracas remains under investigation but no charges have been filed. Nagy and Ms. Blossom were treated for minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Collapses and Dies While Doing Exercises
DOC.TEXT: A 27-year-old inmate who had just arrived at the Mississippi State Penitentiary collapsed and died while taking part in group calisthenics in a paramilitary-style program, the Corrections Department said. Jones said Ronald Hall, who was sentenced to two years on a child molestation charge in Lowndes County, collapsed Tuesday afternoon and was pronounced dead at the prison hospital. ``This is a strange thing,'' Corrections Department spokesman Ken Jones. ``He wasn't doing anything different from anyone else. He wasn't asked to run 10 extra miles as a punishment or anything like that.'' Jones said he did not know what exercises the members of the Regimented Inmate Discipline Program were doing when Hall collapsed. An autopsy will be held at the University of Mississippi Medical Center, Jones said. Prison officials were not aware that Hall had any medical problems, he said. The Regimented Inmate Discipline Program, styled after military boot camp training, is a separate program for first offenders.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow Destroys Hawaiian Home, Threatens Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with one home destroyed. Picks up 4th graf, `Like his...'
DOC.TEXT: A molten flow from the Kilauea Volcano surged beneath a house today, destroyed it within an hour and threatened other residences in an 82-home subdivision. It was the first Kalapana Gardens home destroyed since lava enter the subdivision Tuesday, and the first destroyed by molten rock since a December 1986 flow wiped out dozens of homes in the subdivison. Tenants of the rented house moved out Monday, said Ed Torrison, whose home was 50 feet away, in the path of flow. The lava passed within several feet of two homes Tuesday and moved on to threaten two others besides the one engulfed at 6 a.m. today. Like his neighbors, Torrison moved belongings out of his home. That done, he sat back to await the verdict of Pele, the Hawaiian volcano goddess. ``Everybody's nervous, but nobody wants to admit it,'' said resident Dennis Gregory. ``People don't freak out here. This is Hawaii. Everybody is taking it slow and easy.'' Residents cheered the thunderous explosions of methane from inside the flow and the flames that flashed through trees as the lava cut a swath through the dense foliage. Several people watched the approaching lava from the balcony of the closest home, occasionally pitching beer bottles into the molten rock and laughing at repeated jokes about declining property values in the neighborhood. ``It's a party atmosphere,'' said Craig Heiser, a neighbor helping to evacuate residents. ``You can't do anything about it, so just enjoy it.'' The authorities said residents of 57 homes had been evacuated and the entire community was on alert, meaning an evacuation order could be issued within 72 hours. In addition to the subdivision homes, there are 43 other houses in the area. ``What's happening now is the worst-case scenario,'' said Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim. The lava late Tuesday overran a rock wall into the backyard of a home and filled the seven-foot gully in the yard. Its edge stopped just four feet from the home before it stopped moving sideways and moved down a gully. The flow moved 100 yards down the gully overnight to threaten three more homes. Lava had come within 20 feet of one of those three homes by early today. It surged forward, burned a backyard tool shed, then stopped as it built up a crust. But it could liquefy and surge in another direction. Another flow, to the east, was about a half-mile above the subdivision. Kim said it appeared the flow would not threaten homes for at least another day. Civil defense and Red Cross officials opened a shelter at a community center 12 miles to the east. Other Kalapana residents brought their families to view the destruction and creation. ``People who live here are emotionally prepared for it, but you still hope it's not going to happen,'' said Donna Olson, whose home was destroyed in the 1986 flow. She lives with her three children in a rented house threatened by the flow. ``I feel very emotional about this, but I also know there's a balance to Pele. I know everything here has been born from the lava. It's a circle.''

DOC.HEAD: `I Need 250 Thousand!': Lawyers Deal in Open Court; Trump Involved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 6th graf bgng: `At another ...' to UPDATE with deal accepted; picks up 7th graf pvs.: `Bankruptcy court ...; sent on financial wire as PM-Bonwit Bargaining.
DOC.TEXT: If deal-making really is art, then the bidding for Bonwit Teller that ended in a deal today was the aesthetic equivalent of finger painting. A bankruptcy court hearing Monday turned into a corporate casbah as attorneys frantically arranged offers for the failed department store chain _ not over the typical Wall Street power lunch, but within earshot of a federal judge. Deals came together, fell apart and came together again. Bidders changed sides. An 11th-hour proposal by a would-be savior failed. A lawyer played auctioneer as two sides upped offers $1 million at a pop. ``I need 250,000 from each of you and I need it now!'' Donald N. David, a lawyer representing deal-master Donald Trump, implored members of a group bidding on five of the 16 Bonwit department stores. David got an icy stare from one participant, who refused to raise his ante. A representative of Trump _ whose eponymous gold Tower on Fifth Avenue houses Bonwit's flagship store _ and two other groups contributed the difference. The deal lived. The Trump group's bid was accepted by the seller today, and the bankruptcy court indicated it would approve the plan. Bankruptcy court is becoming a home away from home for American big business in the 1990s as companies stumble under the weight of junk bonds and other takeover-related and expansion-related problems from the 1980s, the decade of debt. A new era of restructuring means more proceedings like the one Monday in a steamy bankruptcy courtroom overlooking New York Harbor. Amid shouting, cajoling, the toot of the Staten Island Ferry and pounding of a jackhammer six floors below, Bonwit's was carved up. Lawyers constantly pleaded for another minute as they huddled to cut a deal. The nearly 10-hour ordeal took place in open court, where judges rarely tolerate more than one person speaking at a time, let alone protests and open bidding. ``I've never seen anything like it before,'' David said Tuesday. ``I think if it weren't for that informality they wouldn't have raised anywhere near the amount of money they did for the estate.'' L.J. Hooker Corp., Bonwit's Atlanta-based parent, held the auction to raise the liquidation value of the upscale store chain it bought three years ago. Hooker had received just one bid for five stores before the auction. The take for Hooker creditors rose by millions. A first round of bidding included offers from a French retailer, a Florida department store, a Buffalo chain, a Canadian investor and a group that included Trump and the women's apparel store the Limited. As the second round began, the Trump group booted the Limited and embraced Pyramid Cos., a Syracuse-based shopping mall developer and owner that made the five-store bid. When it became apparent the group needed to raise its $20.25 million offer or lose out, the haggling intensified. David hustled about, seeking more money. He got it. In 20 minutes, the bid rose by $1.5 million, collapsing once in the process. The court looked like Sotheby's when two bidders battled for a Bonwit store in exclusive Palm Beach, Fla. Lawyers for Frances Brewster Inc., a Florida retailer, and Ralph Hibbard, a Canadian investor, called bids from opposite sides of the courtroom, raising the price to $2.2 million from $1.6 million. ``Sounds like an auction,'' Bankruptcy Judge Tina Brozman said to laughter. After the Hibbard group conceded, Hooker lawyer Sheldon Hirshon, serving as impromptu auctioneer, said: ``Going once, going twice.. .'' The final drama was provided by the day's hoped-for white knight. Hooker lawyers had wanted to preserve the chain. In the morning, they had announced that a group led by Bonwit's former CEO William Ruben was planning a bid for 13 stores. In the mid-afternoon, they said the deal was off. Around 6:30 p.m., lawyers told the judge it was on again. Ruben said his $36 million bid could make Bonwit ``viable again.'' All he needed was one day to arrange financing. Furious, David said reopening the bidding would violate an agreement and ``make a fool out of everybody here.'' Hooker attorneys eventually acquiesced, fearing they could lose all bids if the Ruben group collapsed. Attorney Alan Hyman said Hooker decided ``to resort to the heady and cerebral theory that a bird in the hand was worth two in the bush.'' David, an hour after pacing angrily and saying, ``It's off,'' gave associates two thumbs up.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Seeks To Blunt New Tax: A Gamble Rather Than A Climb-Down
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Recognizing it is in serious political trouble, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government has moved to blunt the impact of its unpopular new local government tax. But even though the so-called poll tax has provoked protest and a demonstration that turned into a riot Saturday, the government shows no sign of backing down. Instead, Mrs. Thatcher is taking a gamble that she can make the tax palatable by the mid-1992 deadline for the next election. And that, even close aides acknowledge, is an uncertain prospect. ``That's the question, and I don't know the answer,'' said a Thatcher aide, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It is not easy to be popular when you are taxing 17 million more people.'' On Tuesday, Environment Secretary Chris Patten ordered 20 high-spending local authorities to impose lower taxes and cut their budgets for the current fiscal year. He said the move would reduce the bills of 4 million people by $50-$160 a year. The tax that took effect April 1 averages $592 a person a year, about one-third higher than the government target. It must be paid by most of the 38 million adult Britons. Previously, only some 12 million property owners paid local government taxes. But the immediate effect of Patten's ``capping'' of the high-spenders was to exacerbate the controversy. The opposition Labor Party was angered that no authorities ruled by Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party were on the list. The targeted authorities claimed they would have to cut services and accused the government of being vindictive. Some threatened to fight the measure in court. Patten, who is in charge of the tax, is dropping hints of further fine-tuning. But Mrs. Thatcher says she will not abandon the community charge, as the tax is officially called. She introduced the reform believing a head tax was fairer than a property tax because it would net everybody, not just homeowners. She also believed that once the bills came in, taxpayers would blame them on Labor high-spenders. Instead, the blame is falling on her. And the Patten refinements appear to consist largely of spending more central government money to bring down the levels of the poll tax. That's precisely what Mrs. Thatcher did not want. It smacks of a retreat and prevents her from cutting income tax and boosting old-age pensions, health spending and other pre-election favorites. The furor over the tax is worsened by economic problems. A year ago the Tories were claiming to be whipping inflation and turning the economy around. Now interest rates have hit 15 percent, inflation is heading above 8 percent, and the Tories have fallen 20 points behind Labor. ``It is not possible to claim economic miracles one year and then be forced to put interest rates up to historically high levels the following year and retain a reputation for competence,'' said John Cole, a political analyst for the British Broadcasting Corp. ``But what has made this doubly difficult is the prime minister's own identification with the poll tax,'' he wrote in the weekly Listener. Saturday's riot appeared to be the work of groups of extreme leftists and anarchists. It shocked Britons and temporarily distracted from the tax itself. But the issue shows no sign of dying. And in the end it comes down to the personality of the 64-year-old grocer's daughter. She won't be moved on an issue she believes is right, and the poll tax is such an issue. ``She has never been popular, and her greatest strength is she has never actually aspired to be popular,'' said the Thatcher aide. ``She has never wanted to be loved and that is the overriding quality of a successful statesman.''

DOC.HEAD: Three States Come Aboard, Three Hold Out on King Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT `it's' to `it'
DOC.TEXT: Compromises have allowed Wyoming and Idaho to join the movement toward national acceptance of a holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and by Wednesday, 22 years after his death, only three states were holdouts. ``I think it shows that we are making headway,'' Lloyd Davis, executive director of the King Federal Holiday Commission, said Tuesday. He expressed confidence that Arizona, New Hampshire and Montana would not hold out much longer amid what he sees as dramatic applications of King's non-violent philosophy as far away as the Philippines, China, Poland and East Germany. ``What's happening around the world shows the universality of King,'' Davis said in a telephone interview from Washington. King was assassinated April 4, 1968, at age 39, while leading a non-violent movement for racial equality. In 1983, after considerable debate, Congress created a holiday to honor King on the third Monday in January, around his Jan. 15 birthday. Martin Luther King Jr. Day, first celebrated nationally in 1986, is an official state holiday in some form in most states _ Idaho is about to become the 47th. Wyoming, which calls itself the Equality State because it was the first to give women the vote, had legislators who supported a holiday commemorating equal rights but didn't want it in King's name. A compromise created Martin Luther King Jr. Wyoming Equality Day. Idaho legislators gave final approval Friday to an official state holiday honoring King, but only after a compromise added Idaho Human Rights Day to the designation. The bill has gone to Gov. Cecil Andrus, who called for its passage in January. New Hampshire legislators have voted down holiday proposals first introduced in 1979. After losing in 1989, supporters said they would try again in 1991, the next time legislative rules allow it. ``There are times when New Hampshire can feel pride in its unique posture,'' state Rep. Deborah ``Arnie'' Arnesen, said Tuesday. ``However, I feel that our unique status, vis-a-vis this holiday, does not suggest a badge of courage but rather a badge of intolerance and prejudice.'' Edward Dupont, New Hampshire's Senate Republican leader, says the proposal won't succeed if the holiday is meant to honor King alone. He suggested a day to honor King ``as one of many civil rights contributors,'' including Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, rather than going along with national practice. ``We always have the distinction of being the last or the first,'' he said. Montana's Legislature in 1987 approved a bill making Jan. 15 a ``day of observance'' and creating Heritage Day, a floating holiday to be designated by the governor. This year Gov. Stan Stephens used it to create a long Thanksgiving weekend, causing no controversy in a state whose black population was counted at 1,786, or a fifth of a percent, in the 1980 census. Arizona is the most populous state without a King holiday, but it hasn't attained that status without contortions. Former Gov. Evan Mecham, a conservative who opposed his predecessor's creation of a limited paid holiday in King's honor, proclaimed a Martin Luther King-Civil Rights Day for the third Sunday in January instead. Last year, the Legislature approved King Day as a paid holiday for state employees, and Gov. Rose Mofford signed the bill. But opponents petitioned to prevent the law from taking effect unless it's approved in a referendum in November. Some of the opponents were upset by revelations about womanizing by King or were persuaded by the Ku Klux Klan's repeated efforts to tar King as a Communist. Others had nothing against honoring King, but were up-at-arms that the Legislature made room in the budget for King Day by dropping Columbus Day as a paid holiday. The Legislature took that course because Republican members didn't like two alternatives: 1) combining the Lincoln and Washington birthdays into one Presidents' Day, as the federal government did, or 2) springing for an additional holiday. While a holiday costs overtime pay for indispensable workers, Mofford and other Democrats and some moderate Republicans argued that not having one could also be expensive. The state has faced a sporadic boycott, especially as a convention and meeting site. When the National Football League's owners awarded the 1993 Super Bowl to the Phoenix area March 13, Norman Braman, head of the site selection committee, said: ``If there is a smear on the Martin Luther King Holiday of any kind, I will personally lead the effort to rescind the Super Bowl. We wouldn't want to go there.'' Phoenix and suburban Tempe, where the game would be played, have their own King holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday called the emigration of Soviet Jews a ``modern Exodus,'' and some he met at a White House Passover ceremony said anti-Semitism was increasing in the Soviet Union. Natasha Stonov, a physician whose husband is still in the Soviet Union, said that the Jewish people in the Soviet Union ``are in panic, and it's massive panic.'' ``During my life, a long life, I feel there is the highest level of anti-Semitism. I may compare it with the Germany in 1938. I think the situation for the Soviet Jew is even worse,'' she said, speaking in English with reporters on the White House driveway. Asked whether Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev was making matters worse by encouraging a sense of Soviet nationalism, she said, ``I think so. I think in the Soviet Union, nothing is spontaneous. Everything is organized.'' Bush invited a group of Soviet Jews, many of whom will resettle in Israel, to a White House ceremony honoring Passover, the eight-day celebration beginning Monday night that commemorates the exodus of Jews from Egypt, Bush called Passover ``a poignant occasion in the year that has seen freedom's lights begin to glow all over the world: in Eastern Europe, in Central and South America, in Africa and even in the Soviet Union.'' ``This is a special time of rejoicing for the more than 15,000 Soviet Jews who have made their way to Israel this year.'' Bush said. ``The modern Exodus is a great event for all those who delight in human freedom,'' he said. Joining him at the ceremony was Vladimir Raiz and his wife Karmella. Raiz, permitted to leave the Soviet Union late last month after 18 years of trying, was praised by Bush as ``a brave symbol for all refuseniks.'' He wished the dissident and his wife ``and your children many years of happines in your new home in Israel.'' Karmella Raiz told reporters afterwards that the ability of her husband to finally leave the Soviet Union ``was a big victory of the United States government.'' But, she noted, ``So many people are still waiting in Russia to be free.'' She said that, as a Lithuanian, she was particularly sensitive to the struggles of that Baltic state to win independence from Moscow. ``I feel pity for the people, their country cannot be free,'' she said. Bush, in his White House remarks, said the United States would continue to apply pressure on the Soviet Union to allow more Soviet Jews to emigrate, including pressing for direct and indirect flights to Israel. The Soviet Jews remaining in the Soviet Union against their wills ``are not forgotten,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Black House Members Propose Defense Cuts, Added Domestic Spending
DOC.TEXT: The 24 black members of the House introduced their proposed fiscal 1991 budget on Wednesday, a plan that would dramatically alter President Bush's priorities for defense and domestic spending. The Congressional Black Caucus proposal, offered on the 22nd anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., would slash Bush's request for Pentagon spending and shift money into social programs. The caucus has been offering such budgets for a decade. Congress has never adopted the proposals, but they are generally seen as the liberal expression of how federal resources should be divided up. ``We can provide for a proper national security defense posture and increase spending for vitally needed social programs,'' said the caucus' chairman, Rep. Ronald V. Dellums, D-Calif. The black caucus would slash military spending to $280 billion, $24 billion below the level Bush wants. It rejects the $5.5 billion in cuts Bush has requested in Medicare aid to the elderly and handicapped. It boosts federal welfare programs by $5.3 billion and adds $4 billion to the $45 billion Bush is seeking for education and job training programs. The plan would raise $19.8 billion in new tax revenues _ $5.9 billion more than Bush _ by placing a 10 percent surcharge on the country's top-earning corporations, and by raising the tax rate on the nation's wealthiest individuals. The House and Senate budget committees hope to finish work on the 1991 budget later this month.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Soviet Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said Wednesday he will try to enter Lithuania, without a Soviet visa, to show the Soviet Union that the United States opposes the use of force in the Baltics. ``I think it's incumbent upon the United States, our Congress, our people, and those people who cherish freedom throughout the world, to stand and to say, `If you want trade concessions, Mr. Gorbachev, if you want access to our technological achievements, if you want to have the normalization of relationshps, then you make sure you don't suppress the rights of Lithuanians and others,''' D'Amato said at a news conference. D'Amato planned to leave Wednesday night on a commercial flight to Warsaw, Poland. He was traveling with several Senate staffers, at least one translator and several reporters. In Poland, the group was to be met by the Lithuanian foreign minister and other Lithuanian government officials who planned to accompany them on the attempted border crossing, probably Friday. D'Amato, who holds a Lithuanian visa, had been invited into the country by Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis.
