The senator admitted it was not very likely he'd succeed in crossing the border, which the Soviets closed Tuesday. But he said the trip would be a success anyway, because his message would get to the Lithuanian people. Neither the White House nor the State Department tried to discourage him from making the trip, D'Amato said.nesday. Therefore, he suggested, he had the administration's unspoken permission to play the heavy on Lithuania while President Bush continued a moderate stand. ``If you want to say `Bad cop, good cop,' then we should be the bad cop,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Agrees to Withdrawal of 7,000 American Troops by 1993
DOC.TEXT: South Korea has formally agreed to a U.S. plan to cut 7,000 of the 43,000 American troops stationed in the country by 1993, the Defense Ministry announced Wednesday. The ministry said the two countries also agreed to change their joint command system to give South Korea more control over its military. ``We have reached full agreement on a gradual U.S. troop withdrawal, which will initially affect 7,000 noncombatants,'' a ministry statement said. The announcement had been expected since February, when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney disclosed plans to close three of the five U.S. air bases in South Korea to save money. In talks with Seoul officials, U.S. officials indicated they would pull out 5,000 ground troops, all noncombatants, and 2,000 air support personnel in several years. The ministry said American troop withdrawal from South Korea would be made in three stages, with the first stage affecting 7,000 soldiers in the 1990-93 period. After the first stage, officials of the two countries will review the situation on the Korean peninsula, including North Korea's war capability, to decide whether to push further cuts in the 1994-95 period, it said. Third-stage cuts, if needed, would take place after 1996, it said. The ministry said the two countries also have agreed to alter their joint command system to give South Korea more control over its armed forces, the ministry said. Currently, most of South Korea's 650,000-member armed forces remain under the operation control of a four-star U.S. general in a combined command system officials say is aimed at maximizing combat efficiency. The system has been criticized by radical Korean students and dissidents as an example of American infringement upon South Korean sovereignty. The ministry said the system would be changed in the 1994-95 period, allowing South Korean generals to command their units in peacetime. In wartime, the joint command system would be restored, it said. Details of the change would be discussed at annual security consultative talks to be held in Washington in November, ministry officials said. Other issues under discussion between the two countries include appointment of a South Korean general to head the United Nations Command in armistice talks with North Korea, replacing a U.S. Navy admiral, they said. The command consists of the United States and 15 other free world countries that fought on South Korea's side during the 1950-53 Korean War. Also under discussion is the replacement of U.S. troops guarding the border village of Panmunjom and its vicinity with South Korean soldiers, the officials said. Nearly all of the 155-mile border with North Korea is guarded by South Korean troops. The 2nd U.S. Infantry Division, the only American combat division in South Korea, is based away from the border.

DOC.HEAD: Coastal Anti-Pollution Bill Advances
DOC.TEXT: Legislation to reduce pollution in coastal waters was approved Wednesday by the House Fisheries and Wildlife subcommittee. The bill would establish clean-water standards for ocean water, would require polluters to pay for cleanup and would police pollution from such diverse sources as storm drains and farms. Called the ``Coastal Defense Initiative,'' the bill would impose new penalties for industries, farmers, government agencies and individuals that pollute the ocean or coastal waterways. It would also involve collecting $150 million per year in new fees from those who legally discharge pollutants into the ocean. The new system of penalties is designed to ``take the profit out of violating our water pollution laws,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., chairman of the subcommittee. Next stop for the bill is the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, which is expected to send it to the House floor.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Aid Assailed
DOC.TEXT: Three powerful House Democrats said Thursday aid to Zaire should be eliminated because President Sese Seko Mobutu is corrupt and abuses human rights. ``No bill that bears my name will have any money for that turkey,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., referring to Mobutu. Obey, chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, was joined by Reps. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Africa subcommittee, and Stephen Solarz, head of the House Asia subcommittee, in seeking to slash all but development aid to Zaire. ``The time has come to cut this character off,'' said Solarz, who compared Mobutu to ousted dictators like Ferninand Marcos in the Phillippines and Nicolai Ceausescu in Romania. Solarz said conservative estimates put Mobutu's personal fortune at $2.5 billion, some of it siphoned off from the state. For instance, some $400 million in mineral revenues is missing from the Zaire budget, according to The World Bank. Mobutu reportedly has a 16th century castle in Spain, a 32-room palace in Lausanne, Switzerland, a $750,000 apartment in Paris and luxurious estates in Portugal, Italy and several African countries, Solarz said. Wolpe said he backed eliminating all military aid to Zaire and requiring that aid for food, development and health programs be given to private non-governmental groups instead of to the government. Congress required that provision last year. He said he wanted to end the assistance because ``most government-to-government economic aid as well as military aid such assistance condones government corruption.'' Human rights violations are commonplace in Zaire, Wolpe said. The State Department said in its annual human rights report that security organizations harass, detain and physically mistreat the government's political opponents. Secretary of State James Baker III visited Zaire last month and reportedly brought up the case of two American human rights lawyers who were attacked and robbed in Kinshasa, Wolpe said. The United States has long view Zaire as an ally and uses the mineral-rich former French colony as a transit point through which to ship weapons to anti-communist rebels in Angola. Wolpe has called for an end to the covert program in Angola. The Bush administration is seeking a total of $53 million in aid to Zaire, including $4 million for the military, $33 million for development and $16 million for food.
US Wants Nicaraguans to Return Firearms

The United States called Wednesday for a roundup of firearms passed out to civilians by Nicaragua's Sandinista government after its election defeat in February. ``An immediate gathering of weapons that have been handed out to civilians in recent weeks would help create conditions of confidence that would further the demobilization process, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters. She said that for demobilization of military forces to proceed in Nicaragua,it is essential that an expanded United Nations observer force be deployed at once to verify a mutual ceasefire between Sandinista forces and the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels. ``Artificial deadlines will not solve the problem,'' she said. ``It must be solved on the ground, with adequate security guarantees and verification mechanisms.'' She noted that the March 27 agreement between UNO, the party of President-elect Violeta Chamorro, and the Sandinista government, states that all weapons should be in the hands of the armed forces. On another subject, Ms. Tutwiler said the United States is encouraged that the United Nations has been able bring about the resumption of dialogue between the government of El Salvador and that country's leftist guerillas. ``There is no military solution in El Salvador,'' she said. ``Only a negotiated political settlement can end the violence so that necessary reforms can be advanced.'' She said Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani fully supported resumption of the talks with what she said was the ``strong, strong backing'' of the Salvadoran armed forces. ``The worldwide winds of change away from violence and toward democracy and reconciliation have reached Central America,'' she said. ``We hope that these negotiations will bring about an end to the violence so that Salvadoran democracy can be consolidated and the Salvadoran people can move towards reconciliation and real economic development.''

DOC.HEAD: Labor Claims Majority to Form Governing Coalition
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 4th graf, `If Peres...' to CORRECT Rabin to Shamir. Pickup 5th, `Peres' Labor...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL3
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said Wednesday he had enough support in parliament to form a ruling coalition and requested a special session to approve the new government. Peres refused to name the members of the proposed government. He said secrecy was necessary as he tried to recruit more lawmakers into a broader government. But radio reports questioned whether the Labor leader actually had the needed votes. ``I said we have a majority. More than that I won't say,'' Peres said on Israel radio. If Peres succeeds, the new government may move toward accepting U.S. proposals for starting Middle East peace talks. Yizhak Shamir's refusal to accept the proposals led to the fall of his government March 15. Peres' Labor Party had accepted compromise proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for opening a dialogue with Palestinians as a step toward Israeli-proposed elections in the occupied territories. Conservatives in the coalition government that was headed by Shamir refused to go along, creating an impasse that led to a vote of no-confidence against Shamir's government. Peres notified President Chaim Herzog that he had succeeded in getting majority backing in the 120-member parliament, or Knesset, to replace the coalition. He said he had appealed to the speaker of parliament to convene the legislature ``as soon as possible,'' preferably by Sunday, to approve the new government. Peres and other Labor leaders refused to provide details on the composition of the new government. ``I have time until the Knesset convenes to make the list and divide portfolios. There is still work before us,'' Peres said. Until earlier Wednesday, Peres had only 60 assured votes. He needed at least one more legislator to vote with him or abstain. State-run Israel and army radio stations quoted sources from the rival Likud bloc as saying they doubted Peres had the needed votes. They speculated he was simply trying to lure more supporters. Other reports said Peres succeeded in enticing a defector from the right-wing Likud, led by Shamir. Yossi Sarid of the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement identified the legislator as Avraham Sharir, a former tourism minister. Sharir could not be reached for comment. Sarid and leaders of two other left-wing parties _ Mapam and Shinui _ questioned the wisdom of bringing a defector into the government. They said it was not certain whether they would join such a Cabinet. ``We see this as a problem that goes to the very core of Israeli democracy,'' said Amnon Rubinstein of Shinui. ``I resigned from the government over peace, but democracy is also important to me.'' However, the leaders of the three parties said they might vote in support of such a coalition during the special Knesset session. Their 10 votes would still allow Peres to form the government. Labor legislators Chaim Ramon and Moshe Shahal said the party had decided on secrecy concerning the composition of the government because it did not want to expose defectors or parties willing to join a Labor government to pressure from Likud. ``The political system is full of pressure on all those who want to support this government,'' Ramon said on army radio. With the parliament vote not likely until Sunday, Likud has time to try to lure potential Labor coalition partners back into its fold. If Peres wins the vote of confidence in parliament, it could be the first time since 1977 that Labor rules without Likud. The two parties have shared power in coalition governments since 1984 following inconclusive elections. Peres was prime minister from September 1984 until October of 1986. Peres said he and his Labor colleagues had worked with a ``candle at our feet'' in order to form the new government before the beginning of Passover on April 9. ``If we didn't succeed in putting together the government before Passover, we would have stood for long weeks without a functioning government, without the defense ministry manned, with waves of immigrants to be absorbed, and with serious economic problems,'' Peres said. Shamir's coaltion, formed in December 1988, fell at a crucial time as Israel faced key questions on the peace process and on how to handle a wave of Soviet Jewish immigrants. The Baker compromises that split Labor and Likud called for Israel to accept Palestinian negotiators in preliminary talks who were deported from the occupied territories or who have ties to Arab east Jerusalem. Hard-liners in the right-wing party argued the two steps could bring the Palestine Liberation Organization into the peace process. They also said the moves might raise questions about Israel's hold over the eastern half of Jerusalem, which it captured in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel considers the PLO a terrorist organization and refuses to deal with it.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Jet Makes Emergency Landing; No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: An Eastern Airlines flight bound for Boston made an emergency return to National Airport shortly after takeoff Wednesday because the rear stairway of the Boeing 727 popped open, an airport official said. Eastern Flight 192, carrying 70 passengers and a crew of seven, landed without further incident, and no injuries were reported, said airport spokesman David Hess.

DOC.HEAD: April 4 is No Longer Hungary's `Greatest' Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Hungary on Wednesday dropped the last of its holidays celebrating Communist rule, ceasing to mark April 4 as the day the Red Army freed Hungary from Nazi Germany at the conclusion of World War II. Although Hungarians did not perceive their ``liberation'' as solving their problems, April 4 was officially marked the past four decades as the ``greatest Hungarian national holiday,'' accompanied by much pomp and ceremony. But Wednesday's issue of the trade union daily Nepszava said the ``liberation'' of Hungary by the Soviet army at the end of the war failed to stop the suffering in the country. ``Out of the blood and filth, the suffering and tragedy, not freedom, not independence, not democracy were born, but the occupation and oppression of the nation (by Soviet troops),'' the paper said. ``Let us bid goodbye to a holiday and to an empire celebrated under duress,'' it added. Soviet troops have been in Hungary since the end of World War II, associated mostly with the bloody crushing of the 1956 anti-Communist uprising for more democracy and a multiparty system. Moscow agreed to withdraw its troops in the initial days of the revolt, but instead of departing, the Red Army poured in reinforcements to quash the uprising. Under a historic bilateral agreement last month to remove all Soviet soldiers from the country by mid-1991, the first Red Army troops began to leave Hungary on March 12. Moscow has about 49,000 troops stationed in Hungary. On March 25, Hungarians went to the polls for the first free multiparty elections in more than 40 years and voted the Communists and their successors the Socialists out of power. Last year, parliament abolished Nov. 7 _ the day of the Bolshevik revolution in Russia _ as a national holiday. It was replaced by March 15, the anniversary of the abortive 1848 revolution for independence from Austrian Habsburg rule.

DOC.HEAD: Barco Offers Colombian Trial to Medellin Cartel Chief
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco on Wednesday promised that if the head of the Medellin drug cartel surrenders, he will not be extradited to the United States and will receive a fair trial in Colombia. A few hours later, the Medellin cartel threatened to kill a senator and explode a bomb in the capital if three men arrested last week are not released. The three are believed to be security men for the traffickers. Scores of policemen from an anti-terrorist strike force began arriving in Medellin, where traffickers' gunmen have killed 11 policemen in two days. Barco did not explain why he made his offer to cartel chief Pablo Escobar. He had repeatedly said he would not negotiate with traffickers, and last week the government extradited its 15th drug suspect to the United States since declaring war on drug lords last August. The drug traffickers have said they would rather die than face trial in the United States and have offered to turn themselves in if they are not extradited. ``Mr. Escobar has said that he is going to give himself up, and I say that if he surrenders, I guarantee the (Colombian) judges will judge him with complete impartiality,'' Barco told the Colombian radio network RCN. U.S. Justice Department officials say Escobar runs the world's most powerful cocaine traficking organization. Like all other trafficking suspects in Colombia, Escobar does not face any drug charges in his own country. Barco did not say what charges Escobar would be tried on if he surrendered. He is charged with several murders, including that of newsman Guillermo Cano. The publisher of the Bogota daily El Espectador was slain Dec. 17, 1987. His newspaper had urged government action against drug lords. National police say Escobar also ordered last month's slaying of a presidential candidate of the leftist Patriot Union Party. Bernardo Jaramillo, who was running in the May 26 election, was assassinated March 22 at Bogota's international airport. The drug war began when traffickers killed Luis Carlos Galan, the governing party's presidential hopeful. Police reinforcements began arriving Wednesday in the northwestern city of Medellin. Eleven policemen were killed and eight were wounded Monday and Tuesday in the city of 2 million people. The Medellin police chief, Col. Alberto Otalora, said Tuesday that drug traffickers shot all the policemen. Last week, the Medellin cartel said in a communique it was offering a $4,300 reward for every policeman killed. In the last week, 11 wealthy people have been kidnapped by drug traffickers in Medellin, police communiques have said. The latest was federal Sen. Federeico Estrada, abducted Tuesday. In a communique released Wednesday, after Barco's announcement, the cartel threatened to kill Estrada. It also repeated its threat to exploded an 11,000-pound bomb in Bogota if three men arrested last week are not freed. The communique, like all the cartel's messages, came via fax to Colombian radio networks. The communique carried the cartel's persistent message: ``We prefer a grave in Colombia to a prison in the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition March Dispersed by Police
DOC.TEXT: Police used tear gas to break up a demonstration by the opposition party on Wednesday, the West African nation's 30th anniversary of independence. The demonstrators, members of the Senegalese Democratic Party, attempted a parade parallel to the official independence march. Police blocked the demonstrators from entering downtown. After police fired tear gas, the marchers burned several vehicles and smashed store windows, witnesses said. The Senegalese Democratic Party and its leader, Adoulaye Wade, claim they won the Feb. 28, 1988, elections in one of the handful of multiparty democracies in Africa. Official returns gave President Abdou Diouf's Senegalese Socialist Party 73 percent of the votes, prompting extensive riots in the capital and several other cities.

DOC.HEAD: Government Panel Calls For Less Logging to Preserve Spotted Owl Population
DOC.TEXT: Logging must stop across a large section of national forests in the Pacific Northwest to keep the northern spotted owl from becoming extinct, a government panel of scientists said Wednesday. Environmentalists hailed the recommendations as an important step toward listing the owl as a threatened or endangered species, but industry leaders said the panel's proposals could devastate the region's timber-based economy. The interagency committee, led by U.S. Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas, recommended in a report a reduction of about 25 percent in the allowable cut in national forests and a 30 percent to 40 percent reduction on Bureau of Land Management areas. ``We have concluded that the owl is imperiled over significant portions of its range because of continuing losses of habitat from logging and natural disturbances,'' the report said. ``Current management strategies are inadequate to ensure its viability.'' The panel's recommendation is expected to weigh heavily in the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's decision on whether to list the owl as a threatened or endangered species. The service, which must make a decision by June 23, extended its public comment period until April 11 to receive the panel's recommendation. ``Make no mistake about it, this is a very influential document,'' said Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore. ``Here's the bluest of blue-ribbon committees yet put together, and it has recommended a (logging) reduction .... They say that's the minimum necessary to sustain a population of owls.'' The owl lives primarily in the never-logged old-growth of western Washington and Oregon. It's population has been reduced by about 60 percent since 1800, the report said. Thomas said during a congressional hearing Wednesday that if future federal harvests continued at current levels, there would be a dramatic reduction in the owl's population, especially on Washington's Olympic Peninsula. ``Certainly we would see local extinction. Ultimately, I think we would see (overall) extinction. I don't know how long it would take,'' he said. Thomas said there currently are about 1,700 breeding pairs of owls in the Northwest. He said if the panel's proposals are implemented the number could grow to 2,200 pairs within 100 years ``if everything went right.'' The study recommends current timber sales on federal lands continue as scheduled through the end of September, the end of the fiscal year. The report was delivered Wednesday to a joint meeting of the Agriculture Subcommittee on Forests, Family Farms and Energy; the Interior Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands; and the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Subcommittee on Fisheries and Wildlife Conservation. F. Dale Robertson, chief of the Forest Service, said his calculations indicated the recommendations would reduce timber-sale programs on national forests with owls by 1 billion to 1.3 billion board feet. That would be 30 percent to 40 percent below an already-reduced harvest level that resulted from a compromise worked out last year to ease the immediate threat to the spotted owl. ``National forests' gross revenues will decline, resulting in a loss of payments to counties, although these reductions may be offset with a rise in prices because of log shortages,'' he said. Robertson said the recommendations would affect 2.7 million acres of the Forest Service's commercial timber base, including about 1.9 million acres in Oregon and Washington and about 800,000 acres in northern California. Robertson said Thomas predicted more than 6 million acres would be affected overall, but that many of those acres already are being protected. Cy Jamison, director of the Bureau of Land Management, said the total cut on BLM lands in western Oregon would drop about 335 million board feet, or between 30 percent and 40 percent, if the proposals were adopted.

DOC.HEAD: About 25 More Prisoners Surrender, Negotiations Split
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five inmates surrendered at devastated Strangeways Prison on Wednesday and authorities negotiated individually with others in an attempt to end a 4-day-old uprising. ``Our tactic is to persist in patient negotiations to bring this dreadful event to a successful conclusion,'' said Terry Bone, deputy director of the north region of the Prison Service. Solicitor Barry Cuttle, a member of the negotiating team, said 20 to 25 prisoners remained inside the Victorian prison, which was severely overcrowded when the rioting began Sunday. ``A lot of them are very keen to come out and never wanted to have anything to do with this,'' he said. ``I can't say whether they were stopped from coming out, or remained from some misguided sense of loyalty.'' One prisoner, Derek White, died Tuesday of injuries suffered in the first day of the disturbance. White was awaiting trial on charges of assaulting three children. British media have speculated that up to 30 prisoners died in the rioting _ mainly sex offenders who are despised by other inmates. Cuttle said he had seen no bodies. Dozens of prisoners and guards were injured in the chaos. Bone said the authorities were trying to make sure facilities for the remaining inmates were reduced to ``an absolute minimum,'' though water was available from prison tanks. ``It is still a very confused situation, and it is possible that some food has been taken out of the kitchen and other areas of the prison,'' Bone said. Prison governor Brendan O'Friel, who characterized the uprising as ``an explosion of evil,'' told reporters more than 1,500 inmates had been caught up in the violence and vandalism. Cuttle characterized the attitude of the remaining inmates as ``calm, more reasonable, listening to the prison officers' side ... They're seeing sense.'' He said negotiators were moving through various parts of the prison to speak with individual prisoners who asked to negotiate. Asked why the prisoners had rioted, Cuttle said: ``They've all got their own personal reasons.'' Prison authorities apparently hoped snowy weather would drive the inmates out of their unheated and unlighted quarters. But bright sunshine lured many inmates to the roof, from where they could see as many as 300 supporters standing outside. By late afternoon, most had gone inside. The editor of the Manchester Evening News, who spent 10 hours inside the prison Tuesday as a neutral observer requested by the prisoners, said inmates complained of ``mental and physical brutality, misuse of drugs in controlling prisoners, poor food and cramped conditions.'' Strangeways was built in 1868 to hold 970 men, but held 1,648 prisoners when the riot broke out. It contains inmates of all categories, from extremely dangerous to low risk. In a story in Wednesday's edition of the News, editor Michael Unger said the areas he saw were devastated. ``Strewn around the stench-filled wings were smashed toilets, wrecked television sets, ripped-out telephones, and huge steel doors ripped off their hinges. Water was pouring down, and the stink of burning was almost too much to bear,'' Unger wrote. O'Friel told reporters Wednesday morning that the standoff was ``a delicate and difficult situation.'' ``My hope is that these negotiations will result in a peaceful end to this incident,'' he said. Following the death of her husband, White's pregnant, 24-year-old wife Jean called for the inmates to end the siege. ``I want them to know that my child will grow up without knowing its daddy,'' Mrs. White said. ``Now they have nothing to gain and should give themselves up.'' White's attorney, Basil Herwald, said his client had been refused bail even though prosecutors indicated he would face trial on only one of eight charges. Herwald said White's death was an example of ``how the system fails the innocent.'' ``Strangeways was a filthy inhumane system for the innocent and the guilty,'' Herwald said.

DOC.HEAD: Concorde Bound for New York Turns Back After Engine Problem
DOC.TEXT: A British Airways Concorde jet en route from London to New York turned back about an hour into its flight and made an emergency landing Wednesday night at Heathrow Airport after discovering a problem in one of its four engines, the airline said. Fire engines and ambulances stood by as the supersonic jet, Flight BA003 with about 80 passengers on board, landed safely at Heathrow Airport without incident. A British Airways spokesman, who by custom was not identified, described the incident as ``absolutely routine.'' ``There was a problem with the intake nozzle of the No. 3 engine so the captain decided to return. There was no drama and he turned back purely as a precaution,'' the spokesman said. Passengers were tranferred to a back-up Concorde, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Doors and a World of Hate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tinyes is pronounced tin'-yez
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a 13-year-old murder victim were comforted at home Wednesday by family and friends. Four doors down, the family of the murderer returned to the hatred of once-friendly neighbors. While there was relief over Tuesday's conviction of Robert Golub, the rage and ugliness that has pervaded Horton Road since the March 3, 1989, slaying of Kelly Ann Tinyes remained on the street. ``It's a nightmare. ... It's very difficult having the Golubs still living here,'' Kelly's mother, Victoria, said as she sat inside her red-shingled home. ``I don't know how they could possibly walk back into that house after what happened there,'' she continued. ``It has to say something about what kind of people they are.'' Golub, 22, was convicted of second-degree murder. He faces a possible sentence of 25 years to life in prison. Kelly's battered, slashed body was found in the Golubs' basement a day after she disappeared. Prosecutors said Golub lured her there with a phone call, then beat, strangled and sexually mutilated her. On Wednesday, trees along the block were tied with pink and black ribbons, a memorial to Kelly. While visitors poured in and out of the Tinyes' home, the Golubs' house stood silent, its doors and windows shut tight and three police cars parked outside. Thirteen months ago, Kelly's body was found in a closet in the basement of Golub's home. John Golub, standing in his driveway a day after his son's conviction, said he no longer feels sympathy for the Tinyes. The families have lived on the street for two decades. ``In the beginning, we cried for their daughter just as much as they did,'' said Golub. ``But I feel no sorrow for them now. They've burned it out of us.'' ``They created this monster,'' said Kelly's father, Richard, who owns a salvage company. Neighbors on the quiet one-way street agree. ``For 14 months, the neighbors were telling the world that this boy was guilty. Now everyone knows it,'' said Tom Callahan, who has lived next to the Golubs for 31 years. ``People on this street have been living with this horror seven days a week.'' Callahan knows first-hand how deeply the killing has affected the neighborhood. His 9-year-old daughter, Donna, took the witness stand at an age when most children are busy with homework and hobbies. ``I knew he was guilty,'' said Donna, who was the last person to see Kelly before she entered the Golub home on the day she died. ``Justice is done, but it's not going to bring Kelly back. We were friends.'' Golub, a service station operator, said other neighbors make obscene gestures or shout at his family as they drive past. Windows have been broken in his home and fires set in his garbage. ``We want to move, there's no question about it,'' said Golub. ``We'd like to pack up and move to Florida, but we'd have to give the house away.'' He can't afford to do that, he said, because his son's unsuccessful defense cost $50,000.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Costs Could Top $1 Billion Per Plane
DOC.TEXT: Reducing production of the B-2 bomber will raise the cost of a single plane to more than $1 billion, says a congressional study that several lawmakers on Wednesday called grounds for canceling the ``flying Fort Knox.'' ``It confirms my very worst fears that if you stretch out the B-2 program it simply adds billions of dollars to its costs,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., as he joined with a bipartisan group of B-2 opponents in releasing the Congressional Budget Office report. Leahy and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., introduced legislation to stop procurement of the stealth aircraft at the 15 planes now in production. The Bush administration's plans call for building 132 of the radar-evading aircraft by 1996 at a cost of more than $70 billion. Air Force Secretary Donald Rice told a congressional panel Tuesday that the Bush administration is weighing alternatives to that proposal. According to the CBO study, canceling the program would save $41.5 billion. ``What we ought to do is have the guts now to say enough is enough and stop at the 15 that are in production,'' Leahy told a Capitol Hill news conference. Legislation to kill the B-2 garnered just over 30 votes in the Senate last year. Leahy and Cranston said they have ``picked up strength'' but declined to provide numbers on the opponents. However, Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan., said Wednesday that a head count in the House indicates that 195 members oppose the bomber. The CBO report concluded that if the Air Force reduces its planned buy of 132 to 66 the total cost of the program, which the agency estimates is about $75 billion, will be reduced by $18.6 billion. However, the cost of a single plane _ now estimated at $530 million _ will rise to $860 million. If the administration decides to buy 33 planes, at a rate of three per year, the bomber would cost $1.7 billion a copy. ``The stealth is a budgetary black hole _ it attracts and devours public funds like a condensed star attracts and devours light,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., who joined Leahy, Cranston and Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., at the news conference. Further complicating the B-2 issue is the annual cost of the program. In the mid-1990s, the Pentagon plans to buy 10 planes in a single year and 24 the next year. Budget requests would then total nearly $10 billion a year. Leahy pointed out that last year Defense Secretary Dick Cheney urged Congress not to ``nickel and dime to death'' the program because stretching out the program would drastically increase the cost. ``He's right. The CBO report shows he's absolutely right,'' Leahy said of Cheney. The Vermont senator added that ``if we stretch it out as some who are trying desperately to save this flying Fort Knox, that assumes two or three years from now that we'll find $8 billion or $9 billion in the budget for that year's procurement alone.'' ``Nobody in their right mind thinks that we're going to find that much money in any one year.'' Cranston said the ``Pentagon is on notice: The B-2 won't fly in Congress. Not 132, not 66, not even 33.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Governor Says Veto Rejection Won't Change his Actions
DOC.TEXT: The governor said Wednesday that being stripped of a veto power that enabled him to strip letters from words of bills would not stop him from altering the meaning of unacceptable legislation. ``Absolutely not,'' Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said a day after voters approved by 62 percent a constitutional amendment curtailing that power named after ``Wheel of Fortune'' letter-turner Vanna White. ``I'm not going to hold back on vetoes at all.'' Elsewhere, voters in Kansas City, Mo., rejected a curbside recycling program that would have cost households $1.89 a month. St. Louis voters approved a 3.5 percent hotel-motel tax increase to help build a 70,000-seat, domed stadium. Thompson once used his veto to change the amount of time a juvenile could be held in detention, crossing out ``48 hours'' along with selective letters to make the time read ``t-e-n day-s.'' The veto was criticized by opponents who said it gave the governor unconstitutional power to change the meaning of legislation. ``I'm not overly excited about it but the people had a choice and I will live by it,'' Thompson said, adding he would not use the ``Vanna'' veto on the 221 bills pending on his desk. The amendment still allows the governor to delete numbers, words or sentences with a veto. A lawsuit is pending in federal court that challenges his right to strike numbers and decimals from legislation. State Rep. David Travis, a Democrat who backed the amendment, vowed to seek further limits on the veto power. ``We wanted it to be power to turn something down, not create it,'' Travis said. Wisconsin voters also re-elected Supreme Court Justice Donald Steinmetz to a second 10-year term, despite claims by Steinmetz's opponent, a deaf appeals judge, that the high court was not working hard enough. Steinmetz received 52 percent of votes to challenger Richard S. Brown's 48 percent, according to unofficial returns. Steinmetz acknowledged that Brown may have raised valid concerns about the court. Chief Justice Nathan S. Heffernan declined Wednesday to say how the election campaign might affect the court. ``I'm not about to say that the reputation of the Supreme Court was enhanced or hurt by the election,'' Heffernan said. ``It might have helped. Criticism is always good for people as well as institutions.'' In northern Wisconsin, state Rep. Jim Holperin defeated challenger Brian Sherren in the state's first legislative recall election in 58 years. Holperin was targeted by those opposed to allowing Chippewa Indians to exercise treaty rights to go spearfishing off the reservation.

DOC.HEAD: Fitzwater Theorizes Gorbachev Saw Need for His Own `Marlin'
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater has a theory about why Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev decided to appoint a presidential press secretary. ``I can only assume that (Gorbachev) took a look at my performance and said, `I must have one of those. Get me a Marlin,''' Fitzwater joked Wednesday. Fitzwater was referring to the appointment of Arkady Maslennikov, 58, as Gorbachev's chief spokesman. Fitzwater said he had not met Maslennikov previously but planned to send him a congratulatory message and hoped to meet him at an expected superpower summit in June. Maslennikov, making his debut before the Moscow news corps Tuesday, played down his image. ``I'm not Marlin Fitzwater. I am Maslennikov.''

DOC.HEAD: Teacher of the Year Thought of Quitting Because of Lack of Respect
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Bush, Gabay comments at ceremony, subbing 5 grafs for grafs 2-3 pvs
DOC.TEXT: Janis T. Gabay of San Diego, teacher of the year with a crystal apple and a presidential salute to show for it, says she once thought of quitting because she saw such lack of respect for her profession. But Ms. Gabay declared herself optimistic about U.S. education Wednesday as President Bush and his wife, Barbara, honored her at the White House. ``The kind of people Jan represents are ambassadors to the most powerful province mankind might command _ that great undiscovered realm right under your hat,'' Bush told a crowd that included 11 members of Ms. Gabay's family. ``For almost 40 years, the Teacher of the Year program has singled out the few, really because they represent the many,'' he said. ``The program's goal is really not to identify the best teacher but the best in all teachers.'' Fighting back tears, the petite high school English teacher accepted the award from Bush and a kiss from the first lady, thanking officials for giving ``a credible and assertive voice to this nation's concerns about education.'' Earlier, in an interview, she said, ``It is very easy to become disillusioned from all that we hear outside of education itself. It feels like oftentimes we are not supported. We're not acknowledged. We're seen as those people who do those tasks, rather than as professionals.'' ``That disappoints me and personally even affected me at one point where I really stopped to reconsider whether I was in the right profession,'' said the high school English teacher. Ms. Gabay said she is happy she was able to shake the doubts. ``I'm very optimistic about education,'' she said. ``I cannot be a teacher without being an optimist. I have great faith in the abilities of our students. That's my job _ to tap that, to elicit that, to bring out that performance. Every student is full of marvelous potential.'' She said teachers must be seen as professionals, who if given the support and resources, can push students to become top achievers. Gaining respect is no problem for her personally, according to one student at San Diego's Junipero Serra High School where she has taught 10th and 12th grade English the past 10 years. Steve Nguyen, 17, said Wednesday, ``I am Vietnamese and in my culture, the teacher has absolute power and respect. Here, teachers don't get much respect. But Ms. Gabay gets it from her students. No one ditches this class.'' ``To Ms. Gabay there is no wrong answer. That's why she really can bring out the critical thinking in all of us,'' the student said. Ms. Gabay, 39, was born in Hawaii and came to San Diego as a child. A graduate of San Diego State University, she has been a teacher for 17 years in all. As 1990 National Teacher of the Year, she said, ``I stand for the superior teaching that does in fact occur in hundreds of classrooms across the country.'' An innovative teacher, Ms. Gabay in 1983 helped organize a program, with the San Diego Union, in which students review, for pay, children's and young adult books for the newspaper. In passing on her love of writing and literature to her students and colleagues, she said her focus is on ``the entire range of human experience.'' ``I offer my students as many ideas as I can by showing them through literature that there is nothing that has not already been felt, experienced or thought, but much to be discovered in a new way.'' She was chosen from among the nation's more than 2.5 million elementary and secondary public school teachers by a special panel formed by the Council of Chief State School Officers. As teacher of the year, Ms. Gabay said she will encourage various groups during her yearlong ``ambassadorship'' to work together to bring about quality education. Gordon Ambach, executive director of the School Officers group, which sponsors the program in partnership with Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., said the program has taken on an international focus as last year's winner Mary V. Bicouvaris of Hampton, Va., recently visited the Soviet Union and both the 1988 and 1989 winners visited Japan. The other finalists this year were Rachel S. Moreno, a Spanish teacher at Flowing Wells High School in Tucson, Ariz.; Billy Dean Nave Jr., from the River Valley Alternative School in Winthrop, Maine, and Maria McAlister Pyles, a social studies teacher at Greenwood High School in Greenwood, S.C.

DOC.HEAD: Long-time Residents Wary About Decision to Relocate
DOC.TEXT: People who live in the shadow of the Conoco refinery on Ponca City's south side are glad a dispute about allegedly tainted groundwater is nearing an end with a tentative multimillion dollar settlement. But, for many, the worries are switching from their health to their future as they must think about selling homes they have lived in for decades. ``I've been here for 40 years and I'm no spring chicken anymore,'' Sadie Barnett, 74, said Wednesday. ``It has been upsetting to a lot of people.'' Like some, Mrs. Barnett said it was about time Conoco did something about the fumes and chemical-laced groundwater that seeped into basements and has been blamed for killing lawns, trees and flowers. The subsidiary of Du Pont announced Monday a $23 million settlement proposal, which includes $18 million to buy about 400 homes nearest the refinery and $5 million for the establishment of a settlement fund. The company proposed the settlement without admitting fault or liability. While the settlement must be approved by a federal judge scheduled to hear the case June 5, attorneys for the refinery said the proposal is one of the largest corporate settlements ever recorded in an environmental contamination lawsuit. Similar cases involved government money: the evacuation of homes built atop tons of chemical waste at Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and the virtual abandonment in 1982 of Times Beach, Mo., which was tainted by dioxin. Although residents had fought for years for a solution to the problems brought by the orange-tinted water, many are sad about the thought of leaving homes that have built up a lot of memories over the past quarter of a century. And they worry about finding places to live that they can afford after selling their old homes. ``We've been in the same house for 36 years,'' said Cecil Landis, 62, from his service station. ``My yard's been sinking. ``We have a cellar we can't go into because of the fumes and I bought the house on account of the cellar.'' ``My grandson says, `let's not move, Granny,''' Mrs. Barnett said. ``I lost my only son and my husband 16 months apart a while back, so it's got a lot of memories.'' Veda Lamb, who is bedridden, said she and her husband, Roy, will have a hard time finding a home within their reach. ``We can't go too high, because we're not rich,'' she said. ``There ain't no rich people that live around here.'' Most of the people who live in the area tend to be of retirement age and low- to moderate-income, said Chamber of Commerce information secretary Cheryl Flink. Much of the area, which one resident called the ``low rent rendezvous of Ponca City,'' is low-lying and susceptible to standing water during heavy rain, Ms. Flink said. Residents are not the only ones affected by the proposed settlement. Family Discount Pharmacy No. 2 owner Ron Terry said his business will be affected. ``A lot of business comes from that (area),'' Terry said. ``If those 400 homes are moved out, that will be approximately 1,600 people. ``They'll have to go to the east or west side of town,'' he said. ``It will definitely change the way we're doing business down there.'' But Terry, who has owned the drugstore since 1981, said he's glad for the residents. Ben Delaney, a former Conoco employee whose house faces the refinery, said he doesn't blame his former employer. ``You can't just point the finger at one and say it's their fault,'' said the 64-year-old retiree. ``I made a living with them for better than 30 years.'' Still, Delaney said he's not looking forward to leaving the neighborhood he's lived in for so long. ``I've known these people. My kids grew up with them, some have passed away,'' he said. ``It'll be difficult, but I think I can live through it.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Circus Clown Disappears After Nevada Performance
DOC.TEXT: A Moscow Circus clown has not been seen since the show ended its run and the case has been turned over to police and the U.S. government, a spokesman for the troupe said Wednesday. There's no indication that Sergei Uhanov is trying to defect from the Soviet Union, said Brian Lawson, publicist for Bally's Reno where the circus performed for two months. It closed on Sunday. ``At this point we're just concerned with his safety and welfare,'' Lawson said. ``He gave no outward sign that he was unhappy. He didn't seem upset about anything. He simply wasn't where he was supposed to be when the troupe left.'' A missing persons report was filed Wednesday with the Reno Police Department, and Lawson said the State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service had been notified. Uhanov, who hasn't been seen since Sunday night, didn't check out of his hotel, but his possessions were gone, Lawson said.

DOC.HEAD: Group Files Lawsuit to Halt Germ Warfare Research
DOC.TEXT: A private group said in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that the Pentagon's biological warfare research program should be halted because potential environmental dangers haven't been adequately examined. The Foundation on Economic Trends is seeking preliminary and permanent injunctions in U.S. District Court to terminate the program until the Pentagon assesses possible harm from the research in greater depth. An Army analysis completed last year fails to analyze safety and security measures and emergency medical procedures at research sites around the country, the lawsuit alleges. The Army study ``is grossly inadequate'' in assessing ``the nature of the severity of the impacts'' the research ``may have on human health and the environment,'' said the lawsuit by the non-profit group and its president, Jeremy Rifkin. Laboratory research with biological materials is ``potentially hazardous,'' concluded last year's study. But over the years, ``elaborate controls (have been developed) to assure adequate protection for the environment.'' The Army said last year that the process of working with deadly toxins ``has actually become safer over the years.'' ``Better containment equipment and facilities became available and more effective biosafety protocols were developed.'' The Pentagon's biological defense research program is conducted at more than 100 military, university and private laboratories in 27 states and eight foreign countries. Some $90 million was spent on the program in 1989, the lawsuit said. Last year, the Pentagon estimated the figure at $60 million annually. Chuck Dasey, public affairs officer for the U.S. Army Medical Research and Development Command at Fort Detrick, Md., declined to comment, saying he had not seen the lawsuit. Fort Detrick is one of the biological research facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Mililtia Gunners Knock Aoun's TV Station Off Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with Aoun's TV station knocked off air, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Right-wing Christian militia gunners knocked rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's television station off the air Wednesday night in renewed fighting, and clergymen appealed for a cease-fire in the 2-month-old power struggle. Twenty Maronite Catholic bishops met for three hours, then issued a statement after meeting with patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir at his mountain seat in the Bkirki monastery north of Beirut. Samir Geagea, leader of the Lebanese Forces militia, announced acceptance of an unconditional cease-fire in his continued showdown with Aoun for control of the Christian enclave north of Beirut. But there was no immediate word from Aoun, whose troops were locked in escalating artillery battles with Geagea's forces. Earlier, Geagea called on President Elias Hrawi's army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud, to move his 22,000 Moslem troops to take over Aoun's bases. But there was no sign the Syrian-backed Hrawi would use his poorly equipped forces to move against Aoun's battle-hardened veterans. Aoun's command said the antenna at his TV station in the mountain town of Beit Meri took direct hits in the bombardment by Geagea's forces. The general's headquarters reported the station went off the air at 7 p.m. when it was hit in a ``sudden bombardment aimed at silencing the voice of truth. But it will be back on the air soon.'' The statement was broadcast by Aoun's Radio Lebanon, which continued to function. The Maronite clergymen, who represent Lebanon's main Christian sect, met behind closed doors with Sfeir as artillery barrages thundered in the hills. Their statement also called for a withdrawal by both forces to barracks, a halt to propaganda warfare, an exchange of prisoners, the reopening of all roads and for Aoun and Geagea to work out a settlement ``that guarantees the existence of the Christians and their rights.'' Fifteen cease-fires negotiated by various parties since Jan. 30 have all collapsed. The bishops told Aoun and Geagea, both Maronites, that if they could not halt the fighting ``then it is our duty to tell you both that your persistence in shouldering the responsibility means persistence in wrecking the Christians' 2,000-year-old existence in Lebanon and thus the destruction of Lebanon.'' Geagea said he ordered the media under his control to stop all anti-Aoun propaganda at midnight. ``We're ready to facilitate all security and political solutions on the basis of the unity of all political and military establishments under the helm of legitimacy,'' Geagea said in a statement. But the fighting continued. Earlier, an apartment block in east Beirut was set afire by phosphorus shells fired by Aoun's troops in the day-long clashes in the Christian sector of the divided capital and the Kesrouan mountains to the mortheast. But police reported no casualties since the families living in the five-story block were hiding in their basement shelter. Nor were there any reports of casualties in other sectors of the Christian enclave, including the Kesrouan mountains, where the two sides clashed with howitzers, mortars and machine guns. By police count, at least 839 people have been killed and 2,295 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea in a bid to crush the main challenger to his claim to be the sole authority in the enclave. Police estimate that about 250,000 people, one-quarter of the enclave's population, have fled to safer areas in Lebanon or left the country since the fighting broke out. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the committee's report referred to Hrawi as ``the legitimate head of state'' and described an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war as ``a way leading to peace.'' Aoun has rejected Hrawi's election Nov. 24 to implement the peace accord worked out by Lebanese lawmakers in the Saudi Arabian resort of Taif last October. The general also rejects the accord because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. They entered Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate. But Aoun has branded the Syrians an occupation army that has sided with his Moslem foes. Hrawi is also a Maronite, the Christian sect that has dominated key government and military posts since independence from France in 1943. Aoun refuses to accept Hrawi as president because he was elected under terms of the peace plan, which Aoun also rejects. His opposition focuses on the failure of the plan to include a timetable for the withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Cattle Head For U.S. Feed Lots To Escape Drought
DOC.TEXT: Some Mexican cattle will be given fast-track clearance to enter designated U.S. feed lots because drought-shriveled pastures have been reduced to starvation levels, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said the agency's usual import regulations have been temporarily set aside so the cattle can be brought in. Normally, he said, imported animals and their herds of origin have to be tested and found free of cattle brucellosis and tuberculosis. The usual requirement is that imported animals must come from herds that have been tested for the diseases no less than three months before the date of U.S. entry. With the special waiver, the Mexican cattle will be able to enter approximately three months sooner. ``The drought-stricken pasture lands in parts of Mexico cannot support the cattle,'' Glosser said. ``By bringing the animals temporarily to U.S. quarantined feed lots under strict movement restrictions, we can avert starvation of the animals and still protect the health of U.S. livestock.'' Glosser said the cattle will be taken directly to quarantined feed lots in USDA-sealed trucks or rail cars. They will not be sold to any U.S. buyer and will return directly to Mexico from the feed lots. The animals will be kept apart from U.S. cattle while in the feed lots, which are mostly in Texas. All the cattle imported from Mexico still must be found free of tuberculosis, and all except vaccinated cattle under 24 months of age will need to test negative for brucellosis, Glosser said. There was no estimate of how many Mexican cattle may be imported under the special program, said agency spokeswoman Anita Brown.

DOC.HEAD: Island Evacuated as Volcano Shows Signs of Erupting
DOC.TEXT: All 21 residents of Anatahan Island abandoned their homes and set livestock free as a volcano that showed signs of erupting forced their evacuation. ``I really feel like I want to cry when we leave,'' Domi Taisacan said. ``I just want to think about going back as fast as we can. That's my home island.'' Taisacan, 30, and the other island residents were flown 75 miles south to Saipan on Tuesday aboard two U.S. Navy helicopters. In 1981, a volcano on Pagan Island, 195 miles north of Saipan, forced the evacuation of 54 residents. They have never been allowed to return because of the continuing eruption. ``How critical it is, we don't know,'' Gov. Larry I. Guerrero said. ``But the critical thing is we don't want to be another Pagan situation.'' Guerrero must decide when the islanders can return home. The island was hit by tremors last weekend as the unnamed volcano began spewing steam-like sulfur gas. The bottom of the volcano's 500-foot wide crater looked like a sulfur lake, said Joe Agulto, a Civil Defense official who few to the island Sunday. ``It's really white, just like somebody is boiling water,'' Agulto said. Some of the islanders thought the evacuation unnecessary. ``It's nothing dramatic at all,'' Jess Wabol said. ``I know the government here. They're very concerned about people's health. That's why we came here.'' Wobol said residents set livestock free because they didn't know when they would return.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Jury Deliberates Third Day; No Verdict Yet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top graf with deliberations ended for day; subs 7th graf, Defense lawyers, with judge denying request, deletes 14th graf, There was, outdated
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in John M. Poindexter's Iran-Contra coverup trial deliberated a third day Wednesday without a verdict on charges that the former national security adviser lied to lawmakers and obstructed Congress. The jury of eight women and four men sent no notes to U.S. District Judge Harold Greene that would indicate how the deliberations were proceeding. Poindexter, 53, a retired Navy rear admiral who was President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until he resigned as the Iran-Contra affair unraveled in November 1986, is accused of five felony counts of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements. The indictment charges that Poindexter falsely assured Congress the National Security Council was not covertly assisting the Nicaraguan Contra rebels at a time when U.S. military aid had been banned by Congress. Poindexter is also accused of lying by stating that he did not learn of U.S. involvement in a 1985 shipment of Israeli Hawk missiles to Iran until two months after it occurred. Prosecutors argued that Poindexter lied to conceal a politically embarrassing presidential ``finding'' signed by Reagan that authorized the arms deal as part of an effort to trade weapons for American hostages. The judge, meanwhile, denied a defense request to clarify an instruction he had given to the jury on Tuesday when it asked to review more than 5,000 copies of electronic messages stored in Poindexter's White House computer. Backup copies were found in the White House computer system. The indictment charges that Poindexter deleted the messages from his computer just days before he resigned. Greene told the jury it could not review them because the messages, known as PROF notes, had not been admitted into evidence. In a court filing, Poindexter's lawyers urged Greene to clarify this instruction, saying it ``may mislead the jury into believing that it cannot base its decision upon other evidence'' about the notes. The judge also denied the defense request that he tell the jury that the PROF notes were not admitted into evidence because they contained classified information. In a response, prosecutor Dan K. Webb said that Greene's remarks Tuesday were sufficient but that he did not object to further instructions ``out of an abundance of caution.'' But the language Webb proposed for the additional instruction contained no mention of the fact the notes were kept out of the case because they contained classified information. The defense is trying to persuade jurors that Poindexter's actions was just a normal security precaution to protect classified documents. In his closing argument last Friday, defense attorney Richard Beckler said Poindexter's deletions were ``the electronic equivalent of clearing out his desk.'' Prosecutors argued that at the time the files were deleted Poindexter did not know that he would be resigning his job in the wake of the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lobbies For Central American Aid Package
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lobbied for Senate passage of an emergency aid package for Panama and Nicaragua this week, but Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell left the White House Wednesday indicating that timetable won't be met. Bush invited more than a dozen senators to the White House to congratulate them on Wednesday's passage of tougher clean air standards. Afterward, he summoned Mitchell, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole and Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., who chairs the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that dispenses foreign aid, into the Oval Office to lobby for the Panama-Nicaragua package. Mitchell, who on Monday accused the administration of taking a ``jigsaw puzzle'' approach to foreign aid, told reporters, ``There's no point in worrying about something that we can't get to until we deal with the authorization bill.'' The authorization bill _ separate legislation that must first be passed before Congress can appropriate, or actually disburse funds _ ``isn't moving because Republican senators have so far been unwilling to permit us to proceed without amendment and in a short time limit,'' said Mitchell. ``We've gotten Democrats to agree, but Republicans have not agreed'' to refrain from offering amendments, Mitchell said. ``We first want to see action on the authorization bill. All else is speculation,'' said Mitchell. ``When we get action on the authorization bill, then we'll consider the next step.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater declined comment on the meeting, calling it private. Bush has been prodding the Senate to appropriate up to $800 million for Panama and Nicaragua before it leaves Thursday on an Easter recess until April 18. The House voted for $720 million in aid to the countries Tuesday. Panama is rebuilding following the U.S. invasion that ended the Noriega dictatorship in December, and Nicaragua will end Sandinista rule and install democratically elected Violeta Chamorro as president April 25. Mitchell sent Secretary of State James A. Baker III a letter Monday asking for a multi-year plan on how the United States should spend its entire $14 billion in foreign aid. ``I didn't ask for a multi-year bill. I just asked for a plan that would set forth the context in which this and other requests will be considered and its relation to the overall budget,'' said Mitchell.

DOC.HEAD: Khashoggi Portrayed as Naive Businessman
DOC.TEXT: Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi was portrayed by his lawyer Wednesday as a naive businessman who was taken in by a deal involving a shipload of gold proposed by former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos. In his opening arguments at the fraud trial of Khashoggi and Imelda Marcos, attorney James Lynn said his client had committed ``foolish acts'' in his business dealings but didn't commit any crimes. He used the never-realized gold deal to explain why Khashoggi made frequent trips and phone calls to the deposed Philippines leader's home in exile in Hawaii. Khashoggi, 54, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership in Manhattan real estate after the Philippine government won a U.S. court order in March 1986 to prohibit any further transactions involving the properties. Linn conceded that Khashoggi had many personal dealings with the late Marcos and that Khashoggi had signed one fake document involving the buildings, but said this was intended to help a Marcos associate, not to defraud anyone. Khashoggi, once described as the richest man in the world, was trying to head off moves by creditors to foreclose on the properties, Linn said. Marcos had offered Khashoggi 10 percent of a shipload of gold if Khashoggi could find a safe port for the vessel, preferably in an Arab country, Linn said. Marcos later told Khashoggi he had made other arrangements for the gold, he said. Prosecutors say Khashoggi had been in contact with Marcos to discuss faking documents to show that he, not the Marcoses, had actually owned four Manhattan buildings allegedly bought with more than $160 million stolen from the Philippines treasury. Linn said Khashoggi was innocent of the charges and had merely shown poor judgment in his dealings with the Marcoses. ``If this wasn't such a serious charge, this would be funny,'' he said. ``It is not the sinister thing that the government makes it out'' to be. Linn said he would call a handwriting expert to testify that Khashoggi's initials were forged on other documents. Mrs. Marcos, 60, has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. If convicted, she faces up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines. Khashoggi faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted. The prosecution's first witness, a former real estate broker with Sotheby's auction house, testified about an art collection that Marcoses allegedly bought with the embezzled funds. Thomas Bryan, of Fairfax, Va., said the collection of paintings, furniture and antiques had been housed in the Manhattan apartment of art collector Leslie Samuels, who hired Sotheby's to sell both the cooperative apartment and its contents after his wife passed away. Under questioning by Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella, Bryan said Mrs. Marcos first saw the collection in 1981 on a tour of the apartment with Gliceria Tantoco, a Marcos associate who owned a Philippine department store. Mrs. Tantoco and her husband, who had been the Philippine ambassador to the Vatican, fled after being charged with the Marcoses. Samuels personally showed them around the apartment and later invited them to dinner at his new residence at the Waldorf Towers, where Mrs. Marcos also was staying, Bryan testified. Later that evening, after the party had moved to Mrs. Marcos' rooms for entertainment, Bryan said Mrs. Tantoco approached him and said, ``We are very interested in purchasing the contents and the apartment itself.'' They negotiated a deal with Samuels and agreed on a tentative price of $8 million for the apartment and just under $6 million for the art collection, he said. At a later meeting, Bryan said he told Mrs. Tantoco and Mrs. Marcos that the apartment could not be bought by a corporation but only by an individual who was to be the principal user. After the two women held a brief discussion, he said Mrs. Tantoco asked if he would be willing to put his name on the contract. ``I said it was not possible due to my current financial situation and salary and because the board would have a hard time understanding how I came up with the money,'' Bryan said, prompting laughter. He said his salary at the time was $27,000 a year. Bryan said the art collection was purchased by a corporation, but the apartment fell through because Mrs. Tantoco was rejected as a buyer by the cooperative's board. When he expressed his regret to Mrs. Marcos about the board's denial, Bryan testified, she told him ``she had purchased another piece of real estate that day, the Genesco Building.'' That building, now called the Crown Building, is one of the four properties named in the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Corporate America, Environmentalists Clash at Exhibits
DOC.TEXT: The exhibits stretched more than a block in two large white tents on the National Mall as corporate America put its best environmental face on display Wednesday. But some environmentalists weren't impressed, and members of Greenpeace were escorted from one of the tents after several handcuffed themselves to a support poll near the Du Pont Chemical Co. exhibit. The U.S. Park Police said 19 Greenpeace members were arrested and charged with demonstrating without a permit. The organizers of ``Earth Tech'' said more than 100 companies brought exhibits to the five-day environmental technology fair being held as part of the numerous activities marking Earth Day, April 22. The exhibit and a series of technology forums, designed to attract members of Congress and other government officials, were estimated to cost about $1 million with participating companies paying most of the bill. The participants included Fortune 500 companies such as Du Pont and AT&T but also some unknowns such as Oil Stop Inc., which says it has invented a new type of boom to capture oil spills _ the ``self-energizing oil containment system.'' It's so compact, says company official Richard Lazes, that a 5,000-foot spool could be put on a tanker and unwound within minutes. That much boom ``would have surrounded'' the Exxon Valdez, he says. While several oil companies ``are excited about it, they've made no commitment yet,'' he said. Producers of solar, thermal and wind-generated energy were especially prominent, as were companies in the rapidly growing industry of waste management and disposal _ and, of course, recycling. The nature of many of the businesses, as well as their environmental track record, brought criticism from environmentalists. Several conservation groups also put up exhibits including the Wilderness Society and the Izaak Walton League. Workmen near some of the exhibits were still putting up banners including a huge one proclaiming ``Aluminum Recycling: America's Environmental Success Story'' when across the street members of Greenpeace denounced the industry effort. ``Corporate America has begun a campaign to paint themselves green,'' said Peter Bahouth, executive director of Greenpeace USA. A nearby banner read, ``Don't Be Fooled _ Industry Greenwash.'' Later several of the Greenpeace members entered one of the exhibit tent, handcuffed themselves a support poll and were cut loose by security officers and escorted away. At the Du Pont exhibit, displays touted the company's efforts to push for plastic recycling. A dummy _ Mr. R.E. Cycle _ made of recycled beverage, milk and detergent bottles sat on a wood-like bench made of recycled plastics. Du Pont officials also talked of their efforts to develop substitutes for CFCs, or chlorofluorocarbons, which are damaging the stratospheric ozone layer. Greenpeace has been among the environmental groups that have criticized Du Pont and others for not pushing for a replacement of CFCs earlier and charge the company is only doing so now because the government will ban CFCs anyway. Fair organizers maintained that many of the exhibits demonstrate the interest of businesses both large and small to push for environmental improvements. ``I don't think that you can make anything these days without using energy or polluting the environment. The question is how much,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., co-chairman of the fair's organizing committee. Among the exhibits were those that approached the exotic: a solar-powered car that had traveled across the country; a model of a ``wind plant'' to show that wind power already is generating millions of kilowatts of power in parts of California; and the $18-electric bulb that lasts seven years, won't break and uses one-fourth less energy than a conventional bulb. ``That's equivalent to not burning 400 pounds of coal over the life of the bulb,'' said Steve Waxman of Philips Lighting Co. The ``Earth Light'' isn't available in hardware stores yet but may soon be, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Says He Thinks Soviets Will Come Around on Germany in NATO
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Wednesday that the Soviet Union eventually may agree that a unified Germany should be in NATO. Genscher said at a news conference after meeting with President Bush that he expected international agreement would be completed on German unification this year and that the first elections in a unified state could take place next year. He said he expected the Soviets would raise their opposition to unified Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization when East and West Germany meet with the four major World War II victors in coming weeks. But, Genscher said, ``it is my belief that the opinions in the Soviet Union (about NATO membership) have not been finalized'' and that the Soviets could be persuaded that it will serve their security interests to have a unified Germany in NATO. The Western allies are convinced it will make Europe more stable to have Germany in NATO and that a neutral Germany would create uncertainty and lead to instability, he said. ``Also, countries like Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary will have an influence on the forming of the Soviet opinion in this respect,'' he said. ``The Soviet Union will ... (see) how this can preserve their own security.'' Genscher said the two German governments were determined that unity would threaten no other country and that ``the legitimate security interest of the Soviet Union will be taken into consideration to the fullest.'' He reiterated his support for developing a security framework for all of Europe, the United States and Canada by working through the process built on the 1975 Helsinki accords of 35 nations pledging themselves to security and cooperation in Europe. But Genscher said the German support for such a framework did not undermine Germany's commitment to NATO. ``The Western alliance will not be in any way abandoned,'' he said. ``There is no doubt that the alliance will last a long time.'' Genscher said the Europe Economic Community also would play a major role in fostering stability for the region. ``We are more and more convinced that the European Community will become more and more an anchor of stability in Europe,'' he said, adding that Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Romania and even the Soviet Union want the closest possible ties to the community and that some even want to become members. Bonn and Washington are ``in complete agreement'' on all the basic issues, he said. One area of difference between the two governments has been over U.S. insistence that West German-based short-range Lance nuclear missiles be modernized. The West Germans say the weapons are pointless because they can only hit Eastern Europe, which no longer poses a threat to the West. Genscher said the Lance didn't come up in his talks. Genscher, asked whether Soviet reaction to moves for independence by Lithuania would affect German unification, said, ``We hope that through responsible actions of all parties involved, we will get a responsible solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Soggy Weather In The Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Showers produced locally heavy rain over the Northeast during the night and into the day Wednesday, triggering flood watches in Maine and New York state. Heavy snow fell in New York state. Heavier rainfall totals for the 24 hours up to 8 a.m. EDT included 2.91 inches at Boston; 2.69 inches at Portsmouth, N.H.; 2.50 inches at Providence, R.I.; 2.17 inches at Hartford, Conn.; 2.05 inches at Albany, N.Y.; and 2.05 inches at Portland, Maine. By afternoon, showers extended across much of the middle and northern Atlantic Coast region. Flood watches were issued for streams and small rivers across much of Maine and for the St. Lawrence Valley and Lake Placid region of eastern New York state. The heavy overnight snow in parts of New York state left up to 6 inches in Steuben County in the western part of the state. Snow continued over some areas during the afternoon. Strong, gusty wind accompanied the rain and snow in the Northeast. Gale warnings were posted along the coast of Maine and New Hampshire. A cold front crossing the middle Mississippi Valley and the central Plains produced showers near southern Lake Michigan and over the central High Plains. Another cold front crossing the Canadian border brought arctic air into the north-central states. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 30s from the central Appalachians to the lower Great Lakes, and across northern North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. An upper-level weather disturbance off the southern Pacific Coast spread a few showers into southwestern California. Temperatures rose into the 70s across much of Oklahoma, Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana, and across southern Florida, and into the 70s and 80s in southern Arizona. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 16 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemalan Archbishop Asks Authorities to Ban Lamabada Films
DOC.TEXT: The archbishop of Guatemala asked authorities Wednesday to ban two films about the sexy dance lambada because they might ``incite young people to sin.'' ``The music isn't bad but the way of dancing is,'' said Monsignor Prospero Penados del Barrio. ``It's a sexual sport.'' ``Lambada'' and ``Lambada: The Forbidden Dance,'' two films about the popular Brazilian dance, have been playing to packed movie houses since opening last week in eight theaters. The prelate issued the public call to the Ministry of Culture and Sports, which has rated the films for audiences over 15. The archbishop said lambada ``is in very bad taste because it excites the basest passions.'' He also told Roman Catholics nationwide to boycott the movies.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Needs Chemotherapy For Dangerous Brain Tumor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to include Atwater's title; INSERTS 2 grafs after 10th graf, bgng: ``It does xxx to include background on brain tumors.
DOC.TEXT: The doctor treating Lee Atwater for a brain tumor said Wednesday the growth is ``aggressive and dangerous,'' and will require chemotherapy in addition to radiation treatment. In a statement issued through the Republican Party headquarters, Dr. Paul L. Kornblith said that working in Atwater's favor were the facts that he was in excellent health and ``the lesion is quite small and has been detected early in its development.'' Atwater was in Montefiore Medical Center in New York City where a team of physicians led by Kornblith implanted radioactive isotopes into the tumor Tuesday in an effort to kill the growth on the right frontal lobe of Atwater's brain. ``The procedure took approximately four hours and was uneventful,'' said Kornblith. He added that it was completed ``without apparent impairment'' to any neurological functions. ``Although it is obvious that this tumor is aggressive and dangerous, Mr. Atwater has many factors working in his favor,'' Kornblith said. A party official said the 39-year-old Atwater was receiving numerous visitors in a New York hospital Wednesday, though they had to stand behind a lead shield because of radioactivity. Party chief of staff Mary Matalin said the radioactive device would be removed on Friday, and that recuperation was expected to take several weeks. Atwater's wife, Sally, who is expecting to deliver the couple's third child on Monday, was in New York with him. Kornblith said the growth, known as a astrocytoma, was the most common primary brain tumor. ``It does not spread to other parts of the body but can cause damage to brain tissue by pressure and by invasion,'' the doctor said.
