A brain tumor undergoing unrestrained growth would cause pressure within the closed skull. This pressure would kill normal brain cells, thus bringing eventual death by destroying vital functions. Brain tumors can also spread by extension into other parts of the central nervous system and displace normal cells. During such a process, there would be a progressive loss of function as normal brain cells associated with memory, thought, muscle control and even heart beat and respiration are lost. Kornblith said that ``in order to assure that any tumor cells peripheral to the main lesion are destroyed, he will be receiving chemotherapy as well. ``This particular form of chemotherapy is given orally once every six weeks and will not limit his activities or functions.'' The doctor said Atwater will be able to be discharged from the hospital in a few days ``and may well be able to return to work in some degree within a couple of weeks. ``He will need to be followed closely and may need to have additional therapies in the future. For the present we are delighted with his progress.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire Hydrant Flooding Warps Hard Rock's Hardwood
DOC.TEXT: The Hard Rock Cafe, a watering hole for the hip and famous, was flooded with 200,000 gallons of water early Wednesday when a film crew truck hit a hydrant. The water warped the Hard Rock's hardwood floor, but firefighters were able to save such rock 'n' roll momentos as Elton John's sequined baseball uniform, Steven Tyler's leopard jump suit and an entire wall of Elvis memorabilia. Firefighters and employees used water vacuum trucks, mops and squeegees to clean up the Hard Rock in time for dinner, said Valerie Van Galder, a spokeswoman for the rock 'n' roll-themed club. The truck struck a fire hydrant at 3:47 a.m. and water shot up to the Hard Rock's roof. The water leaked into the restaurant, covering the floor with up to 8 inches of water, said city Fire Department spokesman Pat Marek. No injuries were reported. The truck that hit the hydrant was part of a camera crew taping an all-night TV special commemorating Earth Day called ``Hard Rock Cafe Presents Save the Planet.'' The show will air April 20 on CBS. Taking part in the taping were music stars MC Hammer, The Red Hot Chili Peppers and Taylor Dane, actress Katey Sagal of ``Married ... With Children'' and comedian Bobcat Goldthwait.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to add cycle designator
Genscher Says He Thinks Soviets Will Come Around on Germany in NATO
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Wednesday that the Soviet Union eventually may agree that a unified Germany should be in NATO. Genscher said at a news conference after meeting with President Bush that he expected international agreement would be completed on German unification this year and that the first elections in a unified state could take place next year. He said he expected the Soviets would raise their opposition to unified Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization when East and West Germany meet with the four major World War II victors in coming weeks. But, Genscher said, ``it is my belief that the opinions in the Soviet Union (about NATO membership) have not been finalized'' and that the Soviets could be persuaded that it will serve their security interests to have a unified Germany in NATO. The Western allies are convinced it will make Europe more stable to have Germany in NATO and that a neutral Germany would create uncertainty and lead to instability, he said. ``Also, countries like Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary will have an influence on the forming of the Soviet opinion in this respect,'' he said. ``The Soviet Union will ... (see) how this can preserve their own security.'' Genscher said the two German governments were determined that unity would threaten no other country and that ``the legitimate security interest of the Soviet Union will be taken into consideration to the fullest.'' He reiterated his support for developing a security framework for all of Europe, the United States and Canada by working through the process built on the 1975 Helsinki accords of 35 nations pledging themselves to security and cooperation in Europe. But Genscher said the German support for such a framework did not undermine Germany's commitment to NATO. ``The Western alliance will not be in any way abandoned,'' he said. ``There is no doubt that the alliance will last a long time.'' Genscher said the Europe Economic Community also would play a major role in fostering stability for the region. ``We are more and more convinced that the European Community will become more and more an anchor of stability in Europe,'' he said, adding that Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Romania and even the Soviet Union want the closest possible ties to the community and that some even want to become members. Bonn and Washington are ``in complete agreement'' on all the basic issues, he said. One area of difference between the two governments has been over U.S. insistence that West German-based short-range Lance nuclear missiles be modernized. The West Germans say the weapons are pointless because they can only hit Eastern Europe, which no longer poses a threat to the West. Genscher said the Lance didn't come up in his talks. Genscher, asked whether Soviet reaction to moves for independence by Lithuania would affect German unification, said, ``We hope that through responsible actions of all parties involved, we will get a responsible solution.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Proposes Destroying Chemical Weapons If Israel Does
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister told a session of Arab ministers Wednesday that Iraq will destroy its chemical weapons if Israel did the same and signed the 1968 nuclear non-proliferation treaty, an official said. The Egyptian official, speaking on condition of anonmymity, said Tareq Aziz of Iraq made the offer when he met behind closed doors with other foreign ministers of the Arab Cooperation Council. The Egyptian attended the talks. The organization, formed in February 1989, has Iraq, Egypt, Jordan and North Yemen as its members. Earlier, Aziz reiterated accusations that Israel is preparing to attack Iraq and other Arab countries. His comments came after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq declared Baghdad has binary chemical weapons and will use them against Israel if attacked. Saddam's disclosure Monday followed arrests in London last week of people accused of trying to smuggle nuclear bomb triggers to Iraq. Baghdad denied it is trying to build a nuclear bomb. The London incident occurred during international clamor over the March 15 execution of a London-based journalist on spying charges. ``Israel's motive in this anti-Iraq campaign is to harm the reputation of Iraq, terrorize us, besiege Baghdad and then prepare to launch an attack on us and other Arab nations,'' Aziz said. Aziz arrived in Amman in response to a call by Jordan to hold an emergency meeting of council foreign ministers to discuss a possible Israeli assault on Iraq. The Egyptian official said Aziz told the ministers Iraq was willing ``to give up its arsenal of chemical weapons, acquired for purely defensive purposes, if Israel does the same and like Iraq agrees to sign'' the non-proliferation treaty. The Egyptian said Jordan, North Yemen and Egypt ``welcomed the Iraqi proposal.'' Iraq has signed the 1968 treaty. Israel, believed to be the Middle East's only nuclear military power, has not. The official said Iraq also called for an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the 22-member Arab League to discuss ``the details of the tricky game.'' Meeting with Aziz were foreign ministers Marwan Kassem of Jordan, Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt and Abdel-Karim al-Eryani of North Yemen. In Kuwait, the daily Al-Anbaa reported Wednesday that Palestinian leader Salah Khalaf appealed to Iran to make peace with Iraq to help the Arabs confront a possible Israeli attack. Khalaf is right-hand man to Yasser Arafat in the mainstream Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Give Bush Chance to Remove AIDS from Entry Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: A bill introduced in Congress on Wednesday would give the Bush administration an opportunity to remove AIDS from a list of contagious diseases used to prevent foreigners from entering the United States. The bill was sponsored by Rep. J. Roy Rowland, D-Ga., on behalf of the National Commission on AIDS. The administration's position on the bill was not clear. The federal Centers for Disease Control recently recommended that AIDS be stricken from the list, along with several other diseases. That recommendation is under review by the Department of Health and Human Services, but officials say the department lacks authority to remove it. The bill would give HHS explicit authority over the list, sponsors said. The entry restrictions have prompted dozens of international organizations and agencies to call for a boycott of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Francisco in June. France and Switzerland also have said they won't send official delegations to the meeting. ``It seems such a compelling thing,'' said Dr. June Osborn, chairwoman of the National Commission on AIDS, whose members were appointed by Congress and the White House. ``The U.S. is being looked at with such astonishing horror'' by officials and organizations in other countries, she said. Under a law passed in 1987 by Congress, infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, was added to the list of contagious diseases for which foreigners can be barred from entering the country. Administration officials have said they do not have the authority to eliminate the restriction and have done all they can within the limits of their power, including expediting waivers for those who want to attend the conference. But they have said that since Congress directed that AIDS be put on the list, congressional action would be required to remove it. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., one of the co-sponsors of the bill, said that while he believes the administration already has the authority to act, the legislation would make that authority ``absolutely clear.'' The measure would give the HHS secretary authority to decide which diseases pose a threat to the public health and would require exclusion from the country. It does not mention HIV or AIDS. ``We should let health officials make the health decisions,'' Waxman said. ``That is what we did before 1987 and that is what we should continue to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Lockerbie Girls to Attend Flight 103 Memorial Studies in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Ceremonies took place in the Scottish town of Lockerbie on Wednesday to send two schoolgirls to Syracuse University on scholarships created as a memorial for the victims of Pan Am Flight 103. Fiona Griffin and Katharine Grant, both 16, will spend nine months at the New York university that lost 35 students in the bombing of the Boeing 747 airliner in December 1988. All 259 people aboard the New York-bound Maid of the Seas and 11 people on the ground were killed. The ceremony setting up the scholarship was signed at Lockerbie Academy by two academy teachers and local councilmen who are trustees of the air disaster fund. Students from the Lockerbie area of southern Scotland who meet university entrance qualifications will compete annually for the double scholarship., which is managed by the Lockerbie and Syracuse University Trust. The scholarship is funded jointly by the university and the disaster fund. Among those present at Wednesday's ceremony were two members of the Syracuse University staff, Margaret Himley of the English department and Peter Mollar of the school of communications, both teaching at the university's London center. Rector Drew Blake of Lockerbie Academy presented the two girls with scrolls and said, ``Any memorial from a young person's viewpoint should be living and ongoing, and that is what the scholarship will be.'' ``I am very proud of the two girls who have been chosen. Apart from gaining experience that they will cherish for the rest of their lives, they will be acting as our ambassadors,'' he said. Fiona and Katharine were among 14 pupils who competed for the scholarships. They had to write essays on why they wanted to go to Syracuse University and were selected by education staff of the Dumfries and Galloway district and representatives of the university. The girls will go to Syracuse in August. Fiona is a Sunday school teacher and school prefect who hopes to study law, while Katharine is a music and drama buff who wants to be a doctor.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Tab Expert on U.S. to Head Washington Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, bgng: His prospective xxx to CORRECT reassignment is not reflection on Dubinin, restoring dropped word ``not.''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, shuffling the top level of its foreign service, is expected to send a new ambassador to Washington in time for the June summit meeting betweem President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, administration officials said Wednesday. Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh would replace Yuri V. Dubinin, who has headed the Soviet Embassy here since 1986. Dubinin is slated to become the new Soviet ambassador to France, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bessmertnykh, an urbane, experienced and well-traveled 56-year-old expert on the United States, Canada and the Middle East, is the first deputy foreign minister. Dubinin, 59, who came to Washington fluent in Spanish and French, swiftly developed facility in English and oversaw the opening of the Embassy to news conferences and other sessions with diplomats and reporters under the glasnost, or openness, policy of Gorbachev. The wavy-haired, smiling envoy was a self-described ``popularizer of perestroika,'' the Gorbachev program for restructuring the Soviet economy. But he could also take on assignments with a hard edge. As the Soviet ambassador to the United Nations, Dubinin in 1986 blasted the Reagan administration's slashing of the Soviet staff there from 275 to 170 as ``large-scale political sabotage.'' Bessmertnykh, an arms control specialist and a graduate of the Moscow State Institute of International Relations, is considered particularly close to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who began three days of talks Wednesday with Secretary of State James A. Baker III. A specific date for the Bush-Gorbachev summit, to be held in Washington, is expected to be decided upon during Shevardnadze's visit. Bessmertnykh, who confers regularly in Moscow with U.S. Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr., accompanied Shevardnadze to Washington for the talks, which will culminate Friday with a meeting with Bush at the White House. His prospective reassignment as the Soviet ambassador to Washington is part of a revamping of the principal overseas assignments in the Soviet foreign service. It is not considered a reflection on Dubinin, who succeeded longtime Soviet ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin. Both envoys were known for their affability. Dubinin, who entered the Soviet foreign service in 1965, evidently was not accorded the special status by the Reagan and Bush administrations that Dobrynin enjoyed in the Nixon years. Dobrynin was used by Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, also the national security adviser, during the detente era of the 1970s as a special channel to the Kremlin. Bessmertnykh, who served here from 1970 to 1983, is responsible in the foreign ministry for Canada and the Middle East as well as for U.S. affairs. He was named chief of the foreign ministry's U.S.A. department in 1983 and was elevated to the post of first deputy foreign minister in October 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Chad Claims Libyan-Backed Enemy Destroyed at Two Outposts
DOC.TEXT: Chad's army said Wednesday night that it had retaken two eastern outposts in battles with Libyan-backed Islamic Legion forces that left more than 300 invaders dead. ``The Sudano-Islamic forces were totally destroyed on this day, and the rare survivors have fled in the direction of their Sudanese lair,'' the Armed Forces High Command said in a statement over state Radio Chad. Trucks with loudspeakers rolled through the capital calling on Chadians to assemble Thursday to ``condemn the Libyan aggression.'' The Islamic Legion has been attacking Chad from Sudan's Darfur province, an area over which the Sudanese government exercises virtually no control. The radio played military music following an initial announcement that Bahai and Tine had been retaken in fighting that left 330 enemy dead and captured 46 prisoners. It did not give government casualty figures, but the High Command statement announcing total victory said a complete count would be announced later. Radio Chad stressed Libya's role in backing the Islamic Legion, reportedly headed by Idress Deby, a former commander-in-chief of the government forces. Libya denies backing the Islamic Legion. Libya ``is at the origin, the very center, of this new center of tension in eastern Chad,'' the radio said. ``Libya is waging a direct war against Chad. Its objectives remain the same. Only the strategy has changed this time.'' The government of President Hissene Habre reported attacks on Bahai and Tine last week, the latest in sporadic Islamic Legion assaults since Chad and Libya announced a cease-fire. Since becoming independent in 1960, Chad has often been torn by fighting between north and south, between different tribes and political factions and between Libyan-backed rebels and government forces. In August, Chad and Libya agreed to put an end to 16 years of hostility and to reach a political settlement over the 45,000-square-mile Aouzou Strip that separates them.

DOC.HEAD: Government Introduces Citizenship Bill for Hong Kong Chinese
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday formally introduced its controversial bill that would grant British citizenship to an estimated 225,000 Hong Kong Chinese. It faces stiff opposition and possible defeat by a rare union of the socialist Labor Party, which considers the bill elitist, and right-wing legislators in the governing Conservative Party opposed to mass immigration. The bill was presented to Parliament hours after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Britain had a ``solemn duty'' to the colony before it reverts to China in 1997. Thatcher said that giving key people a safety outlet was essential to prevent a crippling brain drain over the next seven years and ``to keep the prosperity going'' in Hong Kong. But former Conservative Party Chairman Norman Tebbit said as many as 80 right-wing Tories have threatened a revolt against the government. The Labor Party's leadership on Wednesday night voted unanimously to oppose the bill. Deputy leader Roy Hattersley said it granted citizenship on the basis of ``wealth, power and influence'' and would not achieve its objective of keeping key people in Hong Kong. Hong Kong is subject to British rule under a 99-year lease with China signed in 1898. Hong Kong will revert to Chinese control on July 1, 1997, under terms of a joint declaration signed by Britain and China in 1984. The British Nationality, or Hong Kong, Bill allows the Home Secretary to grant citizenship ``before June 30, 1997, up to 50,000 Hong Kong residents recommended by the governor of Hong Kong under a selection scheme to be approved by Parliament.'' Citizenship also will be granted to the spouses and young children of the key residents. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd has estimated this will bring the total to 225,000 people. Under the bill, Hong Kong governor Sir David Wilson will appoint a committee to advise him on the citizenship issue. Most of the 50,000 will be chosen on a ``points system.'' The measure was given a formal first reading in the House of Commons but the first major test will come in the second reading on April 19. Home Secretary David Waddington said he was confident the bill would be adopted. ``I am sure we will persuade enough Members of Parliament to carry the measure,'' Waddington told Channel 4 TV News. But Conservative opponents already were gearing for battle. ``The government are about to do something which I never thought I would live to see _ legalizing an activity which was criminal, namely creating a market in passports,'' said Robert Adley, chairman of the British-Chinese Parliamentary Group. ``The employment market will be distorted by jobs to which British passports are attached. This scheme is going from the bizarre to the bazaar,'' Adley said. In 1989, 42,000 people left Hong Kong and 55,000 are expected to leave in 1990, he said. About 3.25 million Hong Kong Chinese now have British passports, but no residence rights.

DOC.HEAD: Novello Says Localities Must Decide on AIDS Education for Teens
DOC.TEXT: Surgeon General Antonia Novello said Wednesday it is important that adolescents be taught about AIDS, but communities must decide for themselves how to do that. ``What is good for Iowa might not be good for New York,'' she said. ``You always have to take into consideration ... the state where they live, what is the morality of that particular community and what is the incidence (of AIDS) in that community.'' She said that while some parents object to AIDS education because they feel their children are not at risk, ``at least some education has to be going on.'' ``You ... at least have (to have) the data out there,'' she said, ``but you have to make sure it's done with sensitivity.'' ``And in the cases in which monogamy and abstention doesn't work, then the adolescent should know that the condom, in the absence of a vaccine, might be the most common available form of prevention.'' Novello also said an educational AIDS brochure discussing condom use, a project begun more than two years ago at the Department of Health and Human Services, will be released soon. Critics had charged that conservatives in the department were trying to derail the publication because it discussed condoms. Jim Brown, a spokesman for the surgeon general, said the pamphlet has been reviewed by all levels at the department and is on its way to the printer. Novello, a pediatrician and the first woman and Hispanic to become surgeon general, met with reporters and answered questions on a range of public health issues. On many issues, though, she said she has not formed an opinion, since she has been on the job only about a month. On questions about abortion, she toed the Bush administration line, saying it should not be allowed except in cases of rape, incest or danger to the life of the mother. She also stood by the Department of Health and Human Services' ban on federal funding of fetal tissue transplantation research, saying that such research could increase the incidence of abortion. She said she will add her voice to that of HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan in campaigning against smoking. She said she does not favor banning tobacco advertising because ``advertising is freedom.'' Rather, the industry's ads need to be countered with prevention messages, she said. Novello said she also is worried that women ``might get too complacent'' about the risk of AIDS, since far fewer women have acquired the disease than men. From June 1981 through February, 12,370 cases of AIDS in females have been reported, compared with 112,614 cases in men, according to the Centers for Disease Control.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Detains More Religious Zealots
DOC.TEXT: Police have detained 269 religious extremists in connection with attacks on Coptic Christians in southern Egypt, Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said in Thursday's editions of a newspaper. The total arrested was 53 more than Moussa announced 10 days ago to parliament. The minister had said 216 Moslems and Coptics were detained after the anti-Christian attacks last month in el-Minya province. In an interview in the Cairo daily Al-Gomhouria, Moussa said the 53 suspects were detained for plotting new sectarian troubles. Moussa gave no details but said the new arrests brought to more than 700 the number of people in preventive custody under an emergency law enacted after Moslem extremists assassinated President Anwar Sadat Oct. 6, 1981. Moslem extremists stoned and set fire to two churches and a youth club in the el-Minya province. Three apartment buildings, a candy factory and several Christian-owned shops were gutted by fire. Fifteen people were injured. The government said the riots were triggered by a rumor that the son of the candy factory owner, a Copt, had taken obscene photographs of a Moslem teen-age girl after drugging her.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Helicopter Gunships Blast Guerrilla Base
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 2 grafs SUB for 4th graf, A guerrilla ... to UPDATE with Israeli statement. Picks up 5th pvs, `He said...'
DOC.TEXT: Three Israeli helicopter gunships blasted a Palestinian guerrilla office in the south Lebanon refugee camp of Rashidiyeh on Wednesday, and seven people were wounded, police reported. They said the gunships, flying low over the Mediterranean, fired four missiles into the office used by the Palestinian Communist Party at 3:50 p.m. The building was severely damaged. Guerrillas fired at the gunships with twin-barreled anti-aircraft guns. No hits were observed. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military command said air force planes attacked a guerrilla base near Tyre in south Lebanon on Wednesday, hit their targets and returned safely. The statement gave no details. No immediate explanation was available why Israel identified the raiders as planes and Lebanese police identified them as helicopter gunships. A guerrilla spokesman, who refused to be identified, told reporters in Rashidiyeh the missiles slightly damaged 10 refugee shacks around the office. He said two of the wounded were guerrillas and the rest were civilians. Rashidiyeh, 12 miles north of the Israeli border, houses 18,530 refugees registered with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency. It was the ninth Israeli air attack on targets in Lebanon this year. By police count, 10 people were killed and 22 wounded in the earlier air strikes. The last was directed against a base used by the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command in north Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Resumes Relief Flights to Southern Sudan
DOC.TEXT: The Red Cross said Wednesday it has resumed relief flights to two main towns in war-torn southern Sudan. Pierre Andre Conod, Khartoum representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said two planes carried medicine, medical equipment and personnel to Wau, capital of the Bahr el-Ghazal region, and Malakal, capital of the Upper Nile province, on Monday and Tuesday. Relief flights to south Sudan were suspended last year after fighting resumed between the government and the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. Christian and animist rebels in the south have waged a 7-year-old war for autonomy from the Moslem-dominated government in Khartoum. The war created a famine estimated to have killed 300,000 southerners in 1988. The United Nations says 4{ million southerners need emergency relief assistance this summer. About 2.3 million live in the war-torn areas in southern Sudan, 400,000 others fled to border areas and about 1.8 million displaced people have gone to Khartoum. Conod said relief flights will continue until April 16. After that, he said, a U.S-made Hercules C130 transport plane will transport seeds and agricultural equipment to Wau before the beginning of the rainy season. The ICRC is also planning to transport meningitis vaccine to Wau in cooperation with the Sudanese health ministry, Conod said.

DOC.HEAD: FAA: Pan Am Security Lapses Continued Eight Months After Flight 103
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am took more than eight months to correct serious security lapses at West Germany's Frankfurt airport after the bombing of Flight 103, top federal aviation officials testified Wednesday. The chairwoman of a presidential commission looking into the December 1988 bombing that killed 270 people at Lockerbie, Scotland, sharply criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for allowing the problems to persist for so long. ``I've never seen anything like this in my life,'' chairwoman Ann McLaughlin told FAA Administrator James Busey, who said part of the problem was that the FAA was leaderless during part of the period after the bombing. Busey took office in July. Ms. McLaughlin said that was an ``absolutely unacceptable'' excuse for failure to get Pan Am to correct problems at Frankfurt where the bomb may have been placed aboard the flight. The FAA is responsible for overseeing security of U.S. airlines in the United States and abroad. Pan American World Airways Chairman Thomas Plaskett, who also testified at the commission hearing, said the airline followed inspection procedures approved by the FAA. The airline is contesting $630,000 in fines levied by the FAA last September for security lapses related to Flight 103 and five other European flights around the same time. The latest allegations, however, have never been the subject of fines. FAA security chief Ray Salazar and Associate Administrator Monte Belger testified that Frankfurt inspections after the bombing revealed security problems that weren't corrected until September 1989. Salazar denied sworn statements in depositions by Pan Am officials that he gave them permission to X-ray checked luggage as an alternative to requirements that it be matched to passengers at Frankfurt. Investigators believe a bag was loaded at Frankfurt containing the bomb that blew up the airliner after the flight changed planes in London. Belger said he was ``extremely frustrated'' by repeated inspections at Frankfurt that continued to show uncorrected problems in checking personnel who service Pan Am airliners and other lapses. But he said that after top FAA and Pan AM officials met in August and sent a team to Frankfurt, the airline's security at the airport became ``a model for the industry.'' Paul Hudson, head of one of two victims' relatives organizations, said the FAA and Pan Am disclosures at Wednesday's hearing confirmed family members' deepest concerns about the airlines' security. ``My daughter had no chance at all,'' Hudson said in an interview outside the hearing room after Pan Am's top official testified that luggage at Frankfurt was not hand-searched and that no special procedures were used following threats against Pan Am flights to the United States. James Weidener, commission executive director, read a memo from an FAA inspector following a visit to Frankfurt last June which said security was ``totally unsatisfactory.'' ``All passengers flying out of Frankfurt by Pan Am are at great risk,'' the internal FAA letter said six months after the bombing. Weidener did not identify the FAA inspector or the two Pan Am official he said testified under oath this week that Salazar had given the airline permission prior to the bombing of Flight 103 to take less-stringent security measures at Frankfurt. The seven-member commission, including four members of Congress, is completing an inquiry into measures that might be taken to prevent terrorist attacks on U.S. aviation and to deal with them if they occur. The panel is to report to President Bush in mid-May.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Acyclovir Helpful in Chickenpox Treatment
DOC.TEXT: A new study shows that the drug widely used to treat genital herpes is effective in treating chickenpox in children, but one doctor cautions that its side effects should be weighed heavily. According to a report in this month's Journal of Pediatrics, acyclovir reduced the number of itchy blisters and shortened by a day the normal five-day course of chickenpox in 50 Twin Cities children who received the drug in pioneering trials. But Dr. John F. Modlin of Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore said he was worried that rare and toxic reactions to the drug would become widespread in chickenpox patients. The reactions include kidney failure and neurological disorders such as slurred speech, disorientation and seizures. ``I want to stress all in all that acyclovir is a very safe drug,'' Modlin said. ``It's a good drug and largely non-toxic. But when you give it to thousands of children there will be some who develop unusual toxicities. ``The most important question that has to be asked is, `How important is it to treat chickenpox in otherwise healthy children with a drug?''' Dr. Henry Balfour, the pediatrician who headed the University of Minnesota study, said the study found no serious side effects and he predicts eventual widespread use of the drug, which is also used to treat genital herpes. Balfour said there is ``room for dialogue'' about the treatment, but he said ``the burden is on the skeptics'' to prove whether risks outweigh benefits. ``We don't know about rare side effects, and that is true,'' Balfour said. ``But what there is to lose is definitely less than what there is to gain.'' He said doctors shouldn't wait for Federal Drug Administration approval of acyclovir's specific application for chickenpox. Because acyclovir already has FDA approval as an antiviral drug, doctors are free to use it as a chickenpox treatment based on research. The drug's effectiveness in shortening the normal duration of chickenpox is important because most complications develop near the end of a typical five-day infection, Balfour said. About 4,000 American children are hospitalized each year from complications of the disease, which can range from skin or ear infections to pneumonia or brain infections, Balfour said. About 100 to 200 die from the disease each year, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control. ``You can't tell at the outset which child is going to be the one of every 4,000 that get hospitalized,'' Balfour said. ``I'm more over on the extreme that you should treat all the children.'' He said some doctors may delay prescribing acyclovir until results of a larger, 10-city study are released, probably later this year. Other doctors may limit the use of acyclovir to youngsters 11 and older, who tend to have the most severe cases of chickenpox, Balfour said. The study, sponsored in part by Burroughs Wellcome Co., manufacturer of acyclovir, was carried out from February through June 1987. Testing for immunity and analysis took two years.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Charges Other Latin American Nations With Meddling
DOC.TEXT: Panama lashed out at its Latin American neighbors on Wednesday, accusing them of ``flagrant intervention'' in calling for new presidential elections. Seven countries told Panama last week that it should schedule elections to ``legitimize'' the government of President Guillermo Endara. Endara became president in December when a U.S. invasion ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who annulled last year's election results when it was clear Endara was beating Noriega's candidate by a 3-to-1 margin. ``President Endara's regime doesn't emanate from that military action. It comes from the will of the Panamanian people,'' Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Wednesday at a news conference. ``No country has the right to dictate the rules of the game to us,'' he added. Foreign ministers of Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela, Peru, Uruguay, Brazil and Argentina, meeting as the Rio Group in Mexico City, sent Panama a communique Friday, calling for elections, respect of hemispheric diplomatic asylum accords and limits on foreign army activities within its borders. Linares said the request is ``a flagrant act of intervention in our affairs.'' ``I don't think any self-respecting country would recognize it,'' he said. He called the Latin countries' request ``unjust'' and ``unconnected with the truth.'' Linares said Panama plans a referendum on constitutional reforms that will demonstrate the acceptance of the government. The vote could be scheduled in January or February, he said. Eighty-five people sought asylum in foreign embassies during the invasion, and Panama has denied safe-conducts to five, Linares said. The five are wanted for killings and misuse of funds, he said, urging the Rio Group to recognize Panama's right under multilateral accords to deny asylum on those grounds. He also said it is up to Panama to decide about foreign troop movements within its territory, where the United States has bases. Linares' comments last week deepened a rift between Mexico and Panama over each government's legitimacy. After the Rio Group's demand, Endara told Mexico that its ruling party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, uses electoral fraud to maintain power. That provoked a protest on Monday from Mexico's Foreign Ministry. In the latest exchange Wednesday, Panama told Mexico that both countries should get over their differences, but blamed Mexico for starting the fight. ``The unjustified attacks to which the legitimate and legally constituted government (of Endara) has been subjected and his reaction to them were the cause and effect of situation that both sides should overcome,'' Panama said in a letter to the Mexican Embassy.

DOC.HEAD: Editor Chides Colleagues For Becoming Too Comfortable
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS three grafs after 7th graf pvs, `He argued ...' to update with Halberstam remarks; picks up 8th graf, `In another ...' ^By MIKE FEINSILBER
DOC.TEXT: The nation's press is too comfortable, too well-paid, too much part of the establishment for the country's own good, the president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors told colleagues Wednesday. ``We often think of ourselves as Davids, fighting the establishment, but the public sees us more and more as status-quo, establishment Goliaths,'' said Loren Ghiglione, publisher and editor of the Southbridge (Mass.) News. He cited a poll showing most people think that news organizations are under the influence of ``powerful people and organizations.'' Ghiglione, addressing the society's 67th annual meeting, proposed that editors each ``adopt an institution that makes us uncomfortable _ a prison, a mental institution, a noisy, overcrowded, big-city school, an AIDS hospital ward _ and try to work in that world or at least understand it.'' He told of his own experieces removing his glasses, his belt, his watch and his shoes as he was admitted to a number of prisons in the past year while taking part in an ASNE study of prison journalism. Each time, he said, he vowed not to do it again, but ``in an era of law-and-order, electric-chair politics, I know I should go back.'' ``While we say we comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable, we need to guard against looking at the world increasingly through the eyes of the comfortable,'' Ghiglione said, arguing that newspapermen have lost touch with their readers. ``One poll showed that half of newspaper journalists earn over $40,000 a year, but only 18 percent of the public does,'' he said. ``And many of us live in almost exclusively white, middle-class worlds and send our children to private or suburban public schools.'' He argued that the world needs ``editors who will fight.'' He said that newspapers need to examine their own failings, should hire ``fact checkers'' like those who work for magazines and have reporters check their stories with sources for accuracy. And he said the press should quit ``participating in society's lies'' through such devices as printing ``pseudo-scientific horoscopes as `news you can use.''' Another speaker, David Halberstam, an author and prize-winning reporter, told the editors that the demands by owners of newspapers and newspaper company stocks for ever-rising profits are putting newspapers in jeopardy. ``There's a question of how much water you can bring out of the stone,'' Halberstam said. ``At what point are you taking out more than you're putting in?'' ``I think the threat to us is not from the outside, not from the government, not from television, it is from ourselves.'' In another report, Roy Aarons, an executive with the Oakland (Calif.) Tribune, presented the results of the first survey ever undertaken of homosexuals on the news staffs of U.S. papers. He said 205 ``openly gay'' newspaper people volunteered to take part, but only 13 percent agreed to be publicly identified. ``By overwhelming majorities, these journalists find that coverage of gay and lesbian issues _ other than AIDS _ is at best mediocre,'' Aarons said. ``Like other minorities before them, they would like to see gay coverage veer from the sensational and toward portrayal of gays as part of the fabric of our communities,'' he said. Just as newspapers failed to employ blacks to report on the black community until the riots of the 1960s erupted, he said, today's papers are not taking advantage of the viewpoints of their reporters who are gay while ``scrambling to stay on top of this rapidly evolving social issues.'' ``Domestic partners legislation, gay adoption, anti-discrimination laws, fundamentalist attacks on the gay lifestyle, morality and public responsibility and, of course, the still-raging AIDS epidemic have brought once-easily ignored issues into demanding focus,'' Aarons wrote in his report of the survey. Nearly a third of the participants said they found the term ``homosexual'' to be prejudiced, explaining that it refers narrowly to sex whereas the term ``gay'' refers to lifestyles or issues. ``Many newspaper editors are homophobic,'' one reporter told Aaron's ASNE committee, ``Their anti-gay opinions, however subtle or private, are a reflection of their systematically anti-gay upbringings; most of the rest are afraid to publicly challenge the status quo. How else to explain the scarcity of openly gay newspaper executives, editors and columnists, the insufficient number of articles on gay people and the epic silence that follows every civil rights setback for gay people? America would rather keep homosexuality invisible, and America's newspapers are complicit.'' Another participant wrote that she heard reporters and top editors on her paper ``make snide homophobic comments and jokes regularly,'' and added that they were ``the same people who wrote those sensitive stories and editorials!!''

DOC.HEAD: Luanda Water Supplies Sabotaged for Second Time in Two Months
DOC.TEXT: A bomb blamed on U.S.-backed UNITA rebels that ripped through water pipes on Wednesday forced authorities to impose rationing in the capital, the defense ministry said. According to ministry, the high-powered bomb exploded about 13 miles outside the city. The rebels, led by Jonas Savimbi, sabotaged water supplies in the same region in mid-February as party of a stepped-up urban guerrilla campaign that has included bomb attacks and downing electricity lines. Luanda, a chaotic metropolis of 1 million residents, often faces epidemics of cholera and other hygiene-related diseases when water supplies are interrupted. The National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, has been fighting to force a power-sharing agreement with the Soviet-backed Marxist government in Luanda since shortly after Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Peaceful Settlement In Lithuania Important To Superpower Relationship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Baker-Shevardnadze meeting; edits and tightens throughout; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Wednesday that how Moscow deals with the drive for independence in Lithuania holds ``very important'' consequences for superpower relations. Baker's strong statement, at the conclusion of a 3{ hour session at the State Department at the opening of a new round of U.S.-Soviet talks, elicited a public assurance from the Shevardnadze that the Kremlin would find a peaceful solution in the Baltic Republic. ``Let me tell you very authoritatively and seriously I have no doubt we will be able to find a solution to that situation, that we will find a wise and fair solution,'' Shevardnadze said. He added, without elaboration, that it would be in the interests of the Lithuanian people, the entire Soviet Union, Europe and peace. At the conclusion of the first of three days of scheduled talks, Baker said Shevardnadze had brought a letter for President Bush from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Baker declined to disclose any of the contents, saying that was up to Bush, who will meet with Shevardnadze at the White House on Friday morning. The two ministers also discussed nuclear missiles. They hope to agree on the extent of the limitations to be placed on nuclear-tipped cruise missiles in a treaty Bush and Gorbachev would like to sign at a summit meeting here in June. But the dramatic disagreement between Lithuanians determined to have their own nation and a Kremlin determined to avoid splintering the Soviet Union drew most of the public attention. ``This is a very, very important matter,'' Baker said. ``I have pointed out to the minister how very important it is in terms of the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union.'' Baker said there was no disagreement with Shevardnadze ``with respect to its importance, and with respect to the importance of resolving it through dialogue and through peaceful means.'' Earlier, Baker told reporters he was encouraged that the Soviets seemed to be considering a referendum in Lithuania to determine its future. ``A referendum is, of course, one way for parties to express self-determination,'' Baker said before he escorted Shevardnadze to his 7th floor office. ``We will be exploring the question of the degree to which there is, in fact, the beginning of some dialogue in Moscow,'' Baker said. Baker said he intended to ask Shevardnadze about the cancellation of scheduled meetings between Lithuanians and officials of the Soviet Interior ministry. Shevardnadze, however, seemed to be unaware of such scheduled meetings. ``What happened today I have no information yet,'' the foreign minister said through an interpreter. Later, neither Baker nor Shevardnadze gave any indication how the matter was resolved. But responding to a question before his meeting with Baker, the foreign minister insisted the Soviets had not used force to deal with the secession movement in Lithuania. ``Of course,'' he said, ``in any country, in any state, measures are taken in order to have order, in order to have a normal situation. And this is this elementary order that is being established.'' The State Department lobby was cordoned off and dozens of uniformed guards and security agents in civilian garb kept watch. A guard with a German Shepherd dog stood at the entrance. On Capitol Hill, lawmakers pushed Bush to take a stronger stand on Lithuania. House members voted 416-3 to approve a resolution urging the president to reaffirm his commitment to an independent Lithuania and take steps to normalize diplomatic relations between Washington and Lithuania. The resolution, which carries no legal weight, is similar to one passed earlier by the Senate. Meanwhile, 31 senators told Bush in a letter that U.S. warnings against the use of military force in Lithuania have not been effective. The administration, the letter said, must spell out the consequences Moscow will face if more force is used. The Baker-Shevardnadze sessions are expected to produce a date for Bush's Washington summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. U.S. officials said several options were being considered for holding the summit before the Soviet People's Congress in Moscow in early July. ``We're pretty flexible on dates,'' Fitzwater said. The administration has been banking on a peaceful solution to tensions between Lithuania and the Kremlin over the independence movement. ``A referendum is a starting point on the road to independence, which we support,'' said a U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A law passed by the Supreme Soviet on Tuesday provides that the first step in a secession process would be for a republic to hold a referendum. If the referendum gets the necessary two-thirds approval, a transition period of no more than five years ensues. The Soviet Constitution, itself, has allowed secession, but without a legal mechanism to carry it out. The official said the new procedure could give the Lithuanians and the Soviets time to resolve economic and political questions raised during the independence drive and that it might not take five years.. Baker was buoyed by the meeting Alexandr N. Yakolev, a close adviser to Gorbachev, held in Moscow on Tuesday with a delegation of officials from Lithuania, and the pledge of an ``honest dialogue'' by Shevardnadze in an arrival statement Tuesday. ``There would appear, at least, to be the beginnings of such a dialogue,'' Baker said. ``We are encouraged as well that we see references coming from both sides to the concept of the possibility of some sort of a referendum approach.'' Lithuanian leaders told the Kremlin last week that they were ready to discuss the issue of a referendum on secession if Gorbachev agreed to talks. The Soviet leader, having demanded the nullification of a March 11 declaration of independence, did not respond immediately.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges South African Blacks To Follow King's Nonviolence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to update with further Bush remarks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called on the black majority in South Africa on Wednesday to follow the example of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. and renounce violence. In a speech on the anniversary of King's 1968 assassination, Bush also predicted that one day, ``not far off,'' a black person will be president of the United States. ``When that day comes, the most remarkable thing about it will be how naturally it occurs,'' he said in remarks to the 20th anniversary dinner for the Joint Center for Political Studies, a nonprofit research organization that focuses on blacks in politics and society. He used the occasion to call for an end to the state of emergency imposed by South Africa's white minority government and the freeing of all political prisoners there. ``Most of all, there must be an end to the tragic cycle of violence, a task that demands great courage and resolve from all South African leaders, black and white,'' Bush said. ``Most tragically, the senseless violence perpetuated by blacks against blacks has become a major impediment to rapid progress toward a negotiated settlement,'' he said. ``All sides should follow the spirit of Mare Senate-passed measure to the president's desk for his signature. President Bush is expected to sign the measure, which would require the Justice Department to keep data on crimes related to victims' race, religion, sexual orientation or ethnic group. It is supported by a variety of civil rights, ethnic and police groups. Actually, the House already had passed the measure and this time merely consented to minor changes made when the Senate approved the bill on Feb. 8. Crimes that would be counted are murder, non-negligent manslaughter, forcible rape, aggravated assault, simple assault, intimidation, arson and destruction, damage or vandalism of property. First proposed in 1984 by Rep. Barbara Kennelly, D-Conn., the legislation grew from a series of arson incidents at synagogues in Kennelly's central Connecticut district. Authorities were never able to determine that racial or religiou prejudices led to the crimes. Some supporters say the measure is needed because of a rising tide of ``hate crimes'' on the part of neo-Nazi skinheads and other such groups, although there is no certainty that such offenses are on the increase. A May 1988 Justice Department report said an accurate count is not available. But it said: ``These types of offenses are far more serious than comparable crimes that do not involve prejudice because they are intended to intimidate an entire group.'' Estimates of the cost to collect the information have ranged from $1 million a year to $10 million a year. The Justice Department has said it would have no trouble making hate crimes part of its annually published uniform crime reports. The bill was brought to the floor Tuesday night and debated but the vote was delayed until Wednesday. There was no debate on Wednesday. The only lawmaker to rise in opposition to the bill was Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., who portrayed it as a concession to the gay community. ``Believe me, whether we like to accept it or not, there are persons outside this chamber who are crowing: namely, in the homosexual community,'' he told the House. He said homosexuals ``now have something in the law which they have sought diligently for the last 20 years, whereby they will equate homosexuality on a part with the traditional coverage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act ...''

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
Miami Sound Machine Singer Comes Home
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with arrival in Miami, editing to conform; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY27, MH6
DOC.TEXT: Singer Gloria Estefan, recuperating from a broken back suffered in a tour bus accident, was welcomed home by fans Wednesday after being released from a New York hospital. ``It's great to be home,'' Miami Sound Machine's 32-year-old vocalist told about 150 people gathered at the airport, expressing her gratitude to news media and to fans who showered her with encouragement, flowers and cards. ``I have felt every one of those prayers from the first moment,'' Estefan said. ``I think that was very important in the way that I feel and the way I recuperate.'' Estefan suffered broken vertebrae when a tractor-trailer struck her tour bus March 21 on a snowy Pennsylvania highway. She was transferred to the New York hospital the next day, and doctors performed delicate surgery to implant two steel rods in her spine. Estefan flew home Wednesday in a jet borrowed from entertainer Julio Iglesias. She walked down the steps of the aircraft, then rode in a wheelchair to a nearby podium, where she stood again to address fans and loved ones. She thanked her family, especially her husband Emilio, ``who waited until we got to the hospital before he fainted, and my son Nayib, who held my hand while we waited for the ambulances. He was very brave.'' The two presented her with a bouquet of yellow roses before she left the jet. At a news conference in New York before her release from the Orthopedic Institute for Joint Diseases, Estefan described the accident and its aftermath as the most difficult experience of her life and said she was simply ``thankful for the miracle of being alive.'' ``I promise I will work 100 percent to come back,'' she said. Estefan's surgeon, Dr. Michael Neuwirth, said the singer faces about six months of rehabilitation but added, ``We fully expect her to return and perform again.'' Estefan thanked the hospital staff for their support and had warm praise for the private nurses who ``helped me learn to sit and walk again.'' She praised her doctors, who she said ``gave me a couple of spare parts to go home with'' and joked that Neuwirth assured her ``I wouldn't beep when I go through airport security.'' Estefan, who was nominated for a Grammy award this year, said she planned to spend her time exercising, reading, sleeping and eating. ``It's the first time in my life I'll actually have to put on pounds,'' she joked, adding, ``Hopefully, in a few months, I'll be back good as new.''

DOC.HEAD: Carter Meets Arafat, Praises PLO Chief for Peace Efforts
DOC.TEXT: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Carter praising Arafat, quotes. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR15
DOC.TEXT: Former President Jimmy Carter praised PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat at the end of two meetings Wednesday for what he said were Arafat's efforts to advance peace in the Middle East. ``He has done everything possible these last months to promote the peace process,'' Carter said after a 90-minute private meeting at the Hotel Crillon. ``He's explored all the possibilities to make progress toward a total peace settlement.'' A jovial Arafat told reporters the peace process was given a new impetus by the Crillon meeting with Carter and one earlier Wednesday that included President Francois Mitterrand. ``I met the former president of the United States, the architect of Camp David, who constructed the peace treaty between the largest Arab country (Egypt) and Israel,'' said the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization. ``He consulted with President Bush ... before coming.'' Arafat described Carter as a ``personality of great stature.'' He said Carter offered no new proposals, but their talks touched on all Mideast issues. Carter spokeswoman Melissa Montgomery denied reports in the French press that Carter was on a special mission for Bush. Carter accused Middle East leaders of dragging their feet on the peace process. ``The problem is among the leaders who don't adequately represent the concerns of the people (for peace), in Israel, among the Palestinians, the Syrians, the Jordanians, the Lebanese,'' Carter said. He called peace ``inevitable.'' The former president, accompanied by his wife Rosalynn, shook Arafat's hand as they left Elysee Palace following the meeting including Mitterrand. At his news conference, Arafat delivered a stinging attack on the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Israeli leaders predict hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews will arrive in Israel the next few years. The PLO fears they will settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where the PLO hopes to establish an independent state. Holding aloft a crudely drawn map of a Jewish state expanded by immigration and extending into Saudi Arabia, Arafat said a ``greater Israel'' would be an obstacle to peace. ``No one can stop Jews from emigrating from the Soviet Union, but we are opposed to a massive transfer,'' he said. He praised advice given to Israel by Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III to keep occupied territories off-limits to Soviet Jewish immigrants. Carter and Arafat arrived for overnight visits. Arafat is expected in Rome on an official visit Thursday and his third meeting with Pope John Paul II. Carter was going to Oslo, Norway. Carter told reporters that he, Arafat and Mitterrand discussed delays in the peace process and how it could be rejuvenated. ``We had a common hope that these delays might now be overcome.'' Arafat said Wednesday's meetings proved that ``peace initiatives are not only Palestinian, that they are international.'' Jewish leaders objected to Arafat's meetings in Paris. The head of a coalition of French Jewish groups, Jean Kahn, demanded a meeting with Carter, saying he wanted him to explain his talks with Arafat. Police vans lined the Place de la Concorde and at least 200 riot police stood guard near the hotel on the edge of the Place where Arafat was staying. About 50 youthful Jewish demonstrators clashed with a half-dozen hecklers at the Place during rush-hour traffic. At least one person was injured but there were no arrests. ``We are against the visit of the terrorist Arafat here,'' said Edwin Sberro, a student and member of the Betar Tagar Zionist movement. ``Carter shouldn't talk with a terrorist like Arafat.'' Israel regards the PLO as a terrorist organization and refuses to negotiate with it. A meeting between Arafat and Carter had been expected for days, but Mitterrand's office made a surprise announcement Wednesday that the French leader would play host for initial talks. Arafat last came to Paris in May 1989, when he met Mitterrand and declared that the PL0 Charter was ``caduc'' _ a French word meaning either ``outdated'' or ``null and void.'' As president, Carter oversaw the negotiation of the 1979 Camp David accords that led to peace between Israel and Egypt. Carter recently concluded a Middle East tour of Israel, Syria, Egypt and Jordan.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Fuel Cell Possibly Damaged
DOC.TEXT: One of space shuttle Atlantis' fuel cells probably was damaged because excessive pressure was exerted when the unit was being prepared for removal, NASA said Wednesday. The extent of damage was not immediately known, said Dick Young, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. There are enough other fuel cells in the system for flight, and any damage will not affect Atlantis' next mission in July. Atlantis returned to Kennedy Space Center on March 13 following a secret Pentagon mission to send a $500 million spy satellite into orbit. Fuel cells provide electrical power to space shuttles through a reaction between liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. One of the fuel cell unit's 96 individual cells had failed a voltage test during a postflight checkout March 31, Young said. NASA decided to remove the entire unit and return it for repair to the vendor, International Fuel Cells of Hartford, Conn., Young said. The unit had been purged with gaseous helium following the March 31 test, and residual gas pressure was being vented out Wednesday. ``As the operation proceeded, it became apparent that the oxygen vent was working but the hydrogen vent was not,'' NASA said in a statement issued Wednesday night. ``It was discovered that a cap had been placed on the vehicle's hydrogen vent port, possibly as a conclusion of the March 31 electrical test.'' The procedure was halted immediately, and the area was cleared of workers as a safety precaution, Young said. The oxygen and hydrogen sides of the fuel cells are divided by a plate an eighth of an inch thick containing potassium hydroxide, a corrosive chemical used as an electrolyte. Pressure normally is kept higher on the oxygen side of the cell to keep the potassium hydroxide from seeping through. Young said the potassium hydroxide likely was forced into the oxygen side of the cell, causing the difference in pressure on either side to exceed allowable levels. That could affect the fuel cell's operation and corrode the oxygen piping, he said. The fuel cell will be removed as soon as possible, Young said. Young said NASA planned to appoint a review board to investigate the matter. He declined to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Gerald Ford Has Surgery to Replace Left Knee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf, `He was...' to UPDATE with Ford to have other knee replaced, quotes. Picks up 4th graf, `Murphy replaced...'
DOC.TEXT: Former President Gerald R. Ford underwent surgery Wednesday to replace his left knee with an artificial joint because of injuries dating back to his high school football days, a spokeswoman said. Ford, 76, went into surgery at 9 a.m. at the Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, said Ford's chief of staff, Penny Circle. The procedure, performed by orthopedic surgeon Dr. Robert Murphy, took 90 minutes, she said. ``The surgery was very successful without any problems or complications,'' Circle said. ``President Ford is resting comfortably.'' He was in good condition Wednesday night, Circle said. ``He tolerated the procedure extremely well. He is in phenomenal physical condition for his age,'' Murphy said. Ford will have to have his right knee replaced in October for similar injuries, Murphy said. The left knee had already been operated on three times, he said. ``He has had very bad arthritis in both of his knees dating to when he played football in the 1930s,'' Murphy said. ``He's just gotten to the point where he was walking bone-on-bone. There was no cartilege.'' Murphy replaced Ford's knee with a titanium prosthesis called a Miller Gallante II total knee, said hospital spokeswoman Sally Manassah. Former first lady Betty Ford was with the president at the hospital, the chief of staff said. Ford was to remain hospitalized for four to five days, and will undergo physical therapy for up to eight weeks, Circle said. Ford elected to have the surgery because of continuing problems with the knee, first injured when he played center for the South High School football team in Grand Rapids, Mich., and later at the University of Michigan, she said. The injuries were aggravated by skiing and tennis, she said. Ford played for Michigan's national championship football teams in 1932 and 1933. The following year he was named the university team's most valuable player and played in an east-west all-star game. Rancho Mirage is about 120 miles east of downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Tells Estonia to Back Off on Independence Drive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Four grafs SUB for grafs 10-12, `Both Lithuanian' to UPDATE with later Washington developments. Picks up 13th, `Soviet Foreign...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos VIL1,2
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Estonia it must back off from its declaration that it is an independent country illegally occupied by the Soviet Union, the president of this Baltic republic said Wednesday. Estonia is cautiously following the lead of its neighbor Lithuania, which declared independence on March 11. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel said Soviet President Gorbachev indicated he might react in the same tough manner. Ruutel, interviewed by Estonian radio, quoted Gorbachev as saying, ``When I heard of your resolution I was completely beside myself. You must declare the resolution null and void. It is an invalid one.'' ``It seems to me that I have to introduce similar measures as those taken in Lithuania,'' he quoted Gorbachev as saying. Soviet soldiers occupied public buildings in Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania, arrested some Lithuanian deserters and sent convoys through Vilnius as a show of force. Gorbachev ordered Lithuanians to hand over their weapons. Lithuanian legislators on Wednesday accused Moscow of threatening to overthrow their independent government, dampening some heartening talk of compromise from officials on both sides. A statement adopted by Lithuania's Supreme Council legislature said, ``The Soviet Union, with the aid of its army, supports a small group of its political supporters which is attempting to restore the old structures of the Soviet administration. ``There is therefore a threat to overthrow the legally elected authority and the government.'' The statement was read on Lithuanian radio and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Washington on Wednesday that how Moscow deals with Lithuania holds ``very important'' consequences for U.S.-Soviet relations. Shevardnadze gave public assurance the Kremlin would find a peaceful solution. As the two men opened three days of talks, the U.S. House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly a resolution urging President Bush to reaffirm his commitment to Lithuania. Both Lithuanian and Soviet officials on Wednesday praised a meeting the night before between a delegation of Lithuanian officials and Soviet Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev in Moscow _ the first direct contact between leaders of the two sides since the day after Lithuania declared independence. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh on Wednesday called the Lithuanians' meeting with Yakovlev ``a positive sign'' the two sides will be able to resolve their confrontation. Gorbachev said Saturday that Lithuania must renounce its declaration of independence before negotiations can begin on ending the dispute. Ruutel did not elaborate when asked by the radio interviewer what steps Gorbachev might have in mind regarding Estonia. Gorbachev also spoke Wednesday at a meeting in Moscow with Communist leaders of Latvia, the third Baltic republic. All three Baltic republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 following a secret pact between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union in 1939. The Latvian party will hold a congress this weekend. It follows a congress in Lithuania in December and in Estonia in March at which their Baltic comrades decided to split with the main Communist Party. Tass, the official news agency, said the discussion centered on ways to increase Latvia's sovereignty and increase the role of the Latvian Communist Party. It gave no details. Estonia's declaration calling itself a sovereign but occupied country came Friday and was aimed at laying the groundwork for a return to independence at the end of a still-undefined transition period. Marju Lauristin, deputy speaker of the Estonian Supreme Soviet, said Estonia would not back off. She said she was optimistic Moscow would prove willing to discuss Estonia's bid for independence. ``In spite of this first negative reaction, it is a contact and every contact is needed for negotiations,'' she said. Ms. Lauristin is a leader of the Estonian People's Front, the political movement that advocates complete independence from Moscow. On Tuesday, the105-member Estonian Supreme Soviet elected Edgar Savisaar, now chairman of the People's Front, as the republic's new premier. Savisaar said the main task of his Cabinet will be to restore Estonia's full independence. He said Communists would not be excluded from the government but indicated their role would be diminishing. Pavel Panfilov, a leader of non-Estonians who oppose independence, said, ``I think it's the aim of the ethnic Estonians to make as many non-Estonians leave the republic as soon as possible. ``Estonia has to belong to the Soviet Union. There is no other way.'' Ethnic Estonians make up about 60 percent of the republic's 1.6 million people. Slavs and other non-Estonian nationalities have expressed fear the move toward independence would hurt their interests.
