DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet Republics
LaserPhotos VIL1,2
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian legislators accused Moscow on Wednesday of threatening to overthrow their independent government, dampening some heartening talk of compromise from officials on both sides. ``The Soviet Union, with the aid of its army, supports a small group of its political supporters who are attempting to restore the old structures of the Soviet administration,'' said a statement adopted by the Supreme Council legislature. ``There is therefore a threat to overthrow the legally elected authority and the government.'' The statement was read on Lithuanian radio and monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. Legislative spokesmen confirmed by telephone that the statement was adopted by legislators. After an opening 3{-hour session Wednesday in three days of talks scheduled in Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze that the way Moscow handles the Lithuanian crisis holds ``very important'' consequences for U.S.-Soviet relations. The Soviet minister publicly assured Baker the Soviets will find a peaceful solution. The U.S. House of Representatives by a 416-3 vote approved a resolution urging President Bush to reaffirm his commitment to Lithuania. Both Lithuanian and Soviet officials on Wednesday praised a Moscow meeting the night before between a Lithuanian delegation and Soviet Politburo member Alexander N. Yakovlev. It marked the first direct contact between leaders of the two sides since the day after Lithuania declared independence on March 11. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. Thousands of people opposed to independence rallied outside the legislative chambers in Vilnius, the Lithuanian capital, on Wednesday and Lithuanian sources said one young man who unfurled a pro-independence banner was beaten. A spokeswoman for the legislature's information service, who refused to be identified, quoted Lithuanian Deputy Premier Romualdas Ozolas as telling a news conference the talks with Yakovlev were ``fruitful and useful.'' But Ozolas refused to go into detail, saying the contacts were unofficial and confidential, she added. President Vytautas Landsbergis told the news conference the talks represented a dialogue rather than simply an exchange of messages. Lithuanian leaders said they hoped regular contacts could develop out of the meeting. Most foreign correspondents were forced by Soviet officials to leave Lithuania days ago, and so could not report directly from the Baltic republic. The Lithuanian Supreme Council statement accused the Soviet Union of blocking international communications with Lithuania and cited the Soviet decision to ban foreign reporters and diplomats. ``These and other aggressive actions by the Soviet Union crudely violate universally recognized principles of international law, create a real threat to the state sovereignty of the Lithuanian republic, and the life and health of its people,'' it said. In Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri D. Gremitskikh characterized the meeting between the Lithuanians and Yakovlev as ``a positive sign'' the two sides will be able to resolve their differences. ``I think it's very important that Lithuanian representatives are aware of the ideas and thoughts that are held here in Moscow,'' Gremitskikh said. ``Our colleagues in Lithuania just have to tear themselves away from their narrow views and look at all these problems through the prism of the fact that a new basis for the federation is being created.'' Ivan Laptev, editor of the Soviet government newspaper Izvestia and newly chosen chief of the Soviet of the Union, one of two chambers of the Soviet legislature, said, ``I'm convinced there will be a successful dialogue.'' The Soviet Defense Ministry, in a statement distributed by the Tass news agency, accused the Lithuanian government of interfering with the draft of young Lithuanian men into the army this spring. Lithuanian legislators still were working Wednesday on their official response to Gorbachev's message sent March 31 demanding that the republic renounce its declaration of independence. Gorbachev has ordered Lithuanians to hand over their firearms, and Soviet soldiers arrested some Lithuanians who deserted from the army. The Soviet military occupied several Vilnius buildings and moved troops and armor through Vilnius in a show of force. Lithuania residents opposed to independence rallied outside legislative headquarters. Legislative spokesmen estimated about 5,000 people took part. Tass put the number at almost 10,000. Protesters carried signs asking the Lithuanian government to ``listen to the voice of reason'' and demanding it not split with the Soviet Union, Tass said. Some called for Gorbachev to impose direct presidential rule, it said. Aidas Palubinskas, a spokesman for the Supreme Council's information service, said by telephone he saw one young man beaten after he unfurled a pro-independence banner from atop a TV camera platform. Palubinskas said the crowd overturned the platform, chased the young man and beat him. He said police did not interfere for fear of worsening the conflict.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Tackles Acid Rain Provisions of Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with negotiations continuing; picks up 4th graf pvs, bgng: The Senate...
DOC.TEXT: Key members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee negotiated behind closed doors late Wednesday in an attempt to craft a compromise on the acid rain provision of a clean air bill. A day after the Senate approved a sweeping air pollution control bill of its own, the focus of the debated shifted to the House where the committee is trying to work out final details of similar legislation. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the panel's chairman, said he hopes remaining issues can be settled this week and a final committee vote taken. That might lead to House floor action on the bill early next month. Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., floated a revised proposal aimed at helping Midwest utilities cope with tough new acid rain pollution controls. The proposal involved a complex system of ``pollution allowances'' and was similar to a provision already in the Senate bill, according to committee sources. But as of 10 p.m. EDT, the measure was still being discussed and sources said it was unlikely a final agreement could be reached before Thursday. The Senate voted 89-11 late Tuesday in favor of a sweeping clean air bill that imposes new emission controls on automobiles, factories and electric power plants. The bill was a product of a compromise agreement between Senate leaders and the White House. President Bush, at a White House meeting, congratulated Senate leaders for ``helping us at last break the legislative logjam on clean air,'' but called it ``only a first step.'' ``More progress is going to be needed if we're to achieve the balanced bill that is essential,'' Bush said. He said the White House would keep pushing in the House and in the eventual conference committee for changes to ensure cleaner air ``without major job loss.'' Neither industry nor environmentalists have been happy about the Senate legislation with environmental groups calling it inadequate to solve urban smog problems and industry charging its toxic chemical controls and acid rain provisions are too expensive. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, meeting with reporters on Wednesday, said he would have preferred that it were stronger in some areas, including tougher second-round controls on automobile emissions. But Mitchell called the bill ``strong and comprehensive.'' Mitchell said he knew early on that he did not have enough votes to stop a filibuster on the original Senate bill and concluded the only way to enact the legislation was to work out a compromise with the Bush administration. ``We did what was necessary to pass the bill,'' said Mitchell. Mitchell indicated that he intended to push for some improvements he favored when the bill goes to a conference committee to be reconciled with the eventual House legislation. Much of the fight in the House, however, was expected to revolve around the strong acid rain control measures included in both the House and Senate legislation. Both bills call for a 10 million ton reduction in the annual releases of sulfur dioxide from coal-fired electric power plants. The curbs will hit Midwest utilities especially hard because they rely heavily on high-sulfur coal and have some of the dirtiest plants. A group of congressmen led by Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., has sought to include in the House bill a ``cost sharing'' measure to ease the financial burden of cleaning up the Midwest plants. The Senate provided some help by allowing Midwest states special pollution allowances that could be sold to other utilities, but generally rejected _ as has the White House _ further cost-sharing ideas. Dingell has proposed some cost-sharing options and Sharp was continuing to pursue a proposal calling for a fee on industrial polluters of sulfur dioxide, which are not covered by the acid rain provision, to offset the costs to utilities. If the acid rain issues can be resolved, there appears little impediment on getting the bill out of committee before Congress goes on its Easter recess at the end of the week, a congressional source suggested. Dingell said he hoped for a final vote Thursday or Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Town That Once Spurned Ryan White Joins Nation in Wishing Him Well
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, ```He's strictly ...,' to fix quote to `He goes in and,' sted `He goes in a'
DOC.TEXT: Residents of AIDS patient Ryan White's old hometown, many of whom fought to keep the teen-ager out of their schools, expressed hope Wednesday that he'd win his latest battle _ this one for his life. ``I hope he gets better and is able to do something in life,'' said Brian Correll, 22, a student at Indiana Unversity's Kokomo campus. ``I hope he can enjoy life a little more.'' White, 18, remained in critical condition at Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis, where he has been hospitalized since March 29 with an AIDS-related respiratory infection complicated by his hemophilia. Singer Elton John spent his second full day at White's room, playing tapes of his music, family spokewoman Carrie Van Dyke said. ``He's strictly here as a friend,'' Van Dyke said. ``He goes in and talks to Ryan, holds his hand and changes his music.'' Also Wednesday, a U.S. Senate committee voted unanimously for a bill aimed at easing the nation's AIDS crisis. ``This one's for you, Ryan,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said in a telephone conversation with White's mother, Jeannie, after the Labor and Human Resources Committee approved the Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency Act. The bill, which has bipartisan support, would provide an additional $600 million a year for two years to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome. White's physician, Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, said there was still cause for hope. ``He's holding on. His status deteriorated in the first day or two and then reached a plateau,'' Kleiman said. ``Any patient who is critical must stabilize before he can recover and Ryan has stabilized. ``There have been patients who have been this ill and have recovered,'' the doctor said. ``We can maintain patients at this level for prolonged periods of time.'' White is on a life-support system. He has been unconscious and heavily sedated so the equipment would function more efficiently. White, who contracted AIDS from contaminated blood products, has waged a five-year battle with the disease during which he grew from an object of scorn in his hometown of Kokomo into an international spokesman for AIDS patients. He fought a successful court battle to attend school and helped reinforce the message that AIDS cannot be spread through casual contact. ``I was stunned when I heard he was back in the hospital,'' said Kokomo resident Ron Shanks. ``I just figured he'd keep on living. I hope he can pull through.'' ``I hope he pulls out of this,'' said David Rosselot, the attorney hired by a group of Western Middle School parents to keep White out of school. In 1985, Rosselot pressed a lawsuit that relied on a state law barring children with communicable diseases from attending school. ``The attempt of the parents at that time was not to keep Ryan White out of school. The intent of the lawsuit was to keep acquired immune deficiency syndrome out of school,'' he said. Rosselot said he would not take a similar case today. ``I don't think that anybody in Kokomo feels good about what happened,'' said Art Peirce, an 18-year resident of Kokomo. ``I think it's something that had to happen,'' he said. ``The fear had to be expressed and if hadn't happened here it would have happened somewhere else.''

DOC.HEAD: Confident Premier Li Says Leadership Is United, Strong
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for grafs 10-11, `Exiled Chinese' to UPDATE with Tiananmen Square again cordoned off Thursday. Picks up 12th, `Some Beijing...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEJ3
DOC.TEXT: A confident, smiling Premier Li Peng asserted Wednesday that China's leadership is united and strong and that the public does not want a renewal of the massive pro-democracy protests of last year. Li's comments to reporters were his first since the protests were crushed last June. Also Wednesday, the Chinese parliament wrapped up its two-week annual session with measures calling for freer business practices but tougher law and order policies. The 3,000-seat National People's Congress, which largely rubber-stamps decisions by top Communist Party and government officials, also gave final approval to the basic law under which Hong Kong will be governed after Britain returns it to China in 1997. Legislators in Hong Kong immediately said the law was not democratic enough and asked that it be amended. Li was among top leaders on the rostrum at the congress' final meeting in the Great Hall of the People. Afterward, he told the annual post-congress news conference that the session was ``inspiring and heartening.'' The army killed hundreds and possibly thousands of people in June while crushing the pro-democracy movement. While other officials have lost their tempers while answering foreign reporters' questions about the killings, Li merely smiled and refused to answer. ``Isn't this question out of date?'' he said when asked who gave the army the order to shoot at protesters. Li predicted that Beijing's Tiananmen Square, at the center of the protests, would remain peaceful Thursday. That is when Chinese celebrate the Qing Ming Festival, a day to honor the dead. Exiled Chinese dissidents had urged Beijing residents to mourn those killed in June by strolling in the square Thursday. They urged similar action last Sunday, but Chinese authorities closed the square to the public all day and held an official rally there. And on Thursday, police again cordoned off Tiananmen Square. On the nearly deserted, 100-acre square, authorized groups of flag-waving schoolchildren joined soldiers for rites marking Chingming while police guards kept out the general public. ``We do not hope to see a repeat of (last year's) chaos, nor do the Chinese people hope to see a repeat of it,'' Li said Wednesday. ``We believe Tiananmen Square will pass the day in an orderly way.'' Some Beijing work units have barred employees from wearing black armbands or white flowers of mourning Thursday. The city has limited the number of people who can visit crematoriums, where the ashes of the dead are stored. Li, asked about his chances of being re-elected in 1993, said he did not consider himself ``extremely capable'' but said rumors in Hong Kong that he was in political trouble were bad guesses. ``The core of leadership in China with (party) General Secretary Jiang Zemin as its nucleus is united and strong, and I believe it commands the support of the Chinese people,'' he said. He rejected a political comeback for Zhao Ziyang, who was ousted as general secretary in June for allegedly supporting the pro-democracy protests. He said Zhao was still being investigated by the party but had not been stripped of his membership. Zhao is living at home in ``very good conditions'' and in good health, Li said. Zhao, who favored negotiations with the protesters, was last seen publicly on May 19, when he visited the demonstrators in the square. Before adjourning, the National People's Congress amended the joint venture law to allow foreigners to become joint venture chairmen and ruled out nationalization. China hopes the changes will attract more foreign investment, which has fallen since the army crackdown. The legislature also passed a resolution calling for strengthened ``public security, national unity (and) education in patriotism, collectivism, socialism and national defense.'' Under the basic law for Hong Kong, the territory ruled by Britain since 1842 is promised a high degree of autonomy within China and protection of its capitalist economic system for at least 50 years. However, many of Hong Kong's 5.7 million residents fear the guarantees are not strong enough, and they already are emigrating to escape Communist rule. The colony's legislature voted 20-6 on Wednesday to ask China to change the law before 1997. China's National People's Congress must approve any changes. The Hong Kong legislature wants faster progress on direct elections and eventual direct election of all 60 members of the Hong Kong legislature. The law provides for a 60-seat local legislature in which 20 members could be directly elected at first, 24 members in 1999 and 30 members in the year 2003. It also sets up a complicated split-voting procedure that gives appointed legislators power to veto controversial bills. After Hong Kong residents loudly supported last year's massive pro-democracy protests on the mainland, China added provisions for declaring a state of emergency in Hong Kong. It also banned subversive activities and contacts between Hong Kong and foreign political groups.

DOC.HEAD: Tiananmen Square Closed Again, Blocking Protests
With AM-China
DOC.TEXT: Police cordoned off Tiananmen Square for the second time in a week Thursday, blocking possible attempts to mourn the victims of last year's crushed pro-democracy movement. On the nearly deserted, 100-acre square, authorized groups of flag-waving schoolchildren joined soldiers for rites marking Chingming, the annual occasion when Chinese honor their dead. Police guards stood at 30-foot intervals around the perimeter to keep out the general public, while dozens of police with walkie-talkies patrolled adjacent streets. Overseas dissidents had called on Beijing students to ``stroll'' through the square on Chingming in a silent memorial to the hundreds, perhaps thousands of people killed when the military stormed the city last June to wrest control of Tiananmen from pro-democracy students. A similar appeal to walk through the square on Sunday was blocked when authorities closed it to the public, on that occasion for ceremonies to promote support for the Asian Games to be held in Beijing next fall. Beijing schools and factories have warned young people to stay away from Tiananmen and advised them against wearing black armbands or the traditional white mourning flower on Chingming. The city has also issued orders forbidding group memorial activities unless authorities grant permission. Some students have said they wanted to go to Tiananmen. Others say they are frightened by warnings of repercussions and will stay away. Security around the square has been noticeably increased. A dozen plainclothes police loitered outside the Great Hall of the People to the west of the square. Police vans and jeeps were parked at strategic points. Inside, children wearing the yellow caps of the Young Pioneers, a youth group that gives ideological training, participated in ceremonies around the monument to revolutionary martyrs. Red banners on the monument called on people to honor the Chinese revolution and to ``raise our Chinese spirit.'' Multicolored flags around the square gave it a festive look, but police yelled at foreigners who tried to take photographs. Premier Li Peng, asked at a news conference Wednesday about tightened security around the square, said Tiananmen is the symbol of Beijing and China and that it was ``quite normal'' for police ``to take all necessary measures to preserve order'' in the square.

DOC.HEAD: Fiery Plane Crash Takes Bizarre Twist: Murder-Suicide?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Hood's age, quotes and detail, DELETE outdated material; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Layne, an...'
DOC.TEXT: Police said Wednesday they are checking into reports that the fiery crash of a small plane may have been the result of a suicide-bound passenger who struggled for control of the craft. The Cessna 421 Golden Eagle streaked over the foothills west of Boulder on Sunday, slammed into a tree, then destroyed a vacant house, four garages and six parked cars, engulfing a large section of the residential block in flames. Killed were Gordon Larry Hood, 45, and the pilot, James Wilford ``Bill'' Layne, 56, police said. Eyewitnesses reported that the plane flipped onto its side and went into a power dive, behavior that might reflect a struggle going on in the cockpit, said police spokesman David Grimm. ``Was the pilot overpowered, was the pilot shot, was the pilot stabbed? We just don't know,'' Grimm said. ``As far as we can tell right now, the pilot just happens to be the unfortunate person who got hired that day.'' Police asked the National Transportation Safety Board to allow them back into the crash site after two out-of-state acquaintances told investigators that Hood was suicidal, Grimm said. ``The sources gave us information when we spoke to them that there were indications made to them that Mr. Hood was potentially contemplating suicide and in a manner similar to what occurred,'' Grimm said. ``We thought we were investigating an air accident, and it has turned into something else.'' Authorities released Hood's identity Wednesday, saying he is believed to be from Atlanta, but had recently moved to the Denver area. They believe Hood was a photographer. Layne, an employee of Intensive Air Care, a Denver-based private charter company, had taken Hood to Granby, a mountain community about 80 miles northwest of Denver, and the two were returning to Denver when the plane crashed. ``We don't necessarily get the impression that there was physical struggle going on,'' Grimm said. ``It could simply have been a struggle over control of the aircraft.'' Autopsy results released Tuesday showed Hood and Layne died of injuries suffered in the plane crash and not from other causes, according to Tom Faure, chief medical investigator of the Boulder County coroner's office. Grimm said Hood was seen carrying a briefcase into a post office in Granby, and investigators believe he mailed some cards or letters there. Police are asking anyone who may have received mail from Hood to contact them.

Secretary of State James A. Baker III is seeking a Soviet plan for a peaceful settlement in Lithuania and a date for the next superpower summit during three days of talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Baker also hopes to work out limits to be placed on nuclear-tipped cruise missiles in a treaty designated for signing at the summit by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, U.S. officials said Tuesday. Also on the agenda is the war in Angola between the Soviet-armed government and U.S.-aided rebels. Baker is trying for a cease-fire but insists on a commitment from the Luanda government that it will share power with the UNITA guerrillas led by Jonas Savimbi. Before the opening round beginning late this afternoon, U.S. officials had no word on whether Shevardnadze brought a reply from Gorbachev to Bush's letter last week reiterating U.S. hopes for a peaceful settlement in Lithuania.

Lithuanian officials say they are encouraged after a breakthrough meeting with a key adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but they will not abide by a new law that would make secession lengthy and costly. President Gorbachev, who refused to meet with the three-member Lithuanian delegation, decreed Saturday that the republic repeal its March 11 declaration of independence before negotiations can begin. Tuesday's talks were thus considered preliminary, though they constituted the first high-level contact between Lithuania and Moscow since the declaration. `If there are people who at least want to listen to us, it's very good,'' the Baltic republic's representative in Moscow, Egidius Bickauskas, told a news conference after the meeting with Alexander N. Yakovlev.

Some 1.5 million households nationwide received no census forms because the Census Bureau failed to print post office box numbers on the mailings, officials said. Each form will have to be delivered by census workers to the homes, instead of to the boxes, before the census can be completed, Gail Kremenec, spokeswoman for the regional census office in the Chicago suburb of Westchester, said Tuesday. Officials were unable to estimate the cost of the foul-up but said they don't expect any significant delay in completing the 1990 census. About 106 million forms were mailed nationwide in the last week of March. But forms destined for people who have their mail sent to box numbers went out without the numbers, and the Postal Service was unable to deliver them, census officials said.

The government says it is finally getting a handle on how many secrets it creates each year. Its best guess is that the ``top secret,'' ``secret'' and ``confidential'' stamps were wielded 6,796,501 times in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30. That was a 35 percent decrease from the year before, but the gains are somewhat illusory. ``It appears that this unprecedented drop is primarily the result of more accurate counting, rather than an actual tremendous decrease in classification activity,'' said Steven Garfinkel, head of the Information Security Oversight Office, created in 1982 when then-President Reagan rewrote all the rules for classifying documents.

The march toward national acceptance of a holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. gathered up Kentucky, Wyoming and Idaho recently, leaving only three states as holdouts today, 22 years after King's death. ``I think it's shows that we are making headway,'' said Lloyd Davis, executive director of the King Federal Holiday Commission. He expressed confidence that Arizona, New Hampshire and Montana would not hold out much longer amid what he sees as dramatic reverberations of King's non-violent philosophy as far away as the Philippines, China, Poland and East Germany. ``What's happening around the world shows the universality of King,'' Davis said in a recent telephone interview from Washington.

Chinese are being warned not to wear black armbands or white flowers of mourning on Thursday, the annual holiday when Chinese honor their dead and a potential time for anti-government protests. Chinese sources said today that some offices and factories in Beijing were advising workers against displays of mourning on Qingming, when Chinese traditionally sweep the graves of their ancestors. The Beijing city government has issued orders that ban organized group visits to cemeteries unless permission is received from authorities. Overseas dissident groups have called on students to ``stroll'' through Tiananmen Square on Thursday in a silent memorial to the hundreds of people killed when the military crushed the pro-democracy movement last June.

President Bush is turning up pressure on Congress to quickly enact his aid request for Panama and Nicaragua, as the House-approved measure faces delay in the Senate. The House voted 362-59 Tuesday for a $2.4 billion spending bill that provides $720 million for the two new Central American democracies. The measure includes nearly $1.7 billion in other spending, most of it for domestic programs such as disaster relief, food stamps and Forest Service firefighting. The bill is partly funded by a $1.8 billion cut from the Pentagon budget that amounts to the first use of a ``peace dividend'' from lessened East-West military tensions. Bush called his appeal a ``laser-like request to help Panama and Nicaragua,'' and State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said failure to pass the package quickly would threaten the fledgling democracies and be like ``playing with dynamite.''

DOC.HEAD: Prayer About Palestinians And Jews Packs Fireworks
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Something as seemingly innocent as a prayer apparently can be explosive when involving the taut feelings of Palestinians and Israel's Jews. That combustible mix has set off a Holy Week furor. It was ignited by a prayer prepared by the Middle East Council of Churches and distributed to U.S. church leaders, along with the council's request that it be read in Palm Sunday services this weekend. The prayer ``seems to be extremely provocative, recalling the worst uses of Christian Holy Week as a club against Jews,'' says the Rev. Elliott Wright of the U.S. National Conference of Christians and Jews. Protests also came from Jewish organizations. The Dutch Council of Churches and Protestant churches in West Germany reportedly have declined to approve use of the prayer. The Middle East Council of Churches, embracing heavily Palestinian denominations, proposed this Sunday's prayer as the start of a 50-day linking of world churches in prayers for Holy Land peace, culminating on Pentecost June 1. The Rev. Gabriel Habib, the council's general secretary, said in a letter presenting the plan: ``We hope that the solidarity in prayer ... will emphasize both the tragedy of the situation _ the denial of the rights and dignity of the Palestinian people _ and the faith that ... the grievous wrongs can be righted. ...'' As for wording of the opening prayer itself, it probably would seem thoroughly innocuous to most Christians, even blandly typical, at least on casual reading, but critics point out its stickier connotations. It ``is a thinly veiled attack on the state of Israel in liturgical form,'' said the American Jewish Committee, adding that using the prayer ``would inject a divisive and polarizing element'' into Christian services. Wright, senior vice president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, which for a half century has worked for interfaith partnership, said the prayer could ``cause Jewish-Christian tensions in U.S. communities.'' It is ``a carefully constructed, ideologically subtle document,'' he added. ``Sentences and paragraphs do not always end up where you think they are headed.'' He said some consider the prayer ``a pro-Palestinian political statement combined with a narrow, exclusive theological point of view.'' Rabbi A. James Rudin, the AJC's Interreligious Affairs director, and the associate director, Judith H. Banki, said the prayer ``is filled with mischievous inuendos.'' Criticism of the 400-word prayer focused mainly on three paragraphs, one of them dealing by implication with a Palestinian state, but not specifying it, saying in part: ``We come to Jerusalem ... and we see ... that people remain in agony and suffering. Strengthen those who ... have been deprived of the right to live in dignity. ... Free them from oppression; restore to them the right to life and to independence in their own land. ...'' Rubin and Ms. Banki said the wording ``makes the reckless and unjustified claim that Palestinian Arabs are being deprived of their `very right to life' by Israel. ``Such language implies that the physical destruction of the Palestinian community is the goal of policy of Israel. This is a malicious slander.'' Another criticized paragraph refers by implication to Israelis without naming them, saying in part: ``We come to Jerusalem ... and we see that there are those who live in fear. ... Free them from the illusion that depriving others of their rights, or even eliminating them, will provide security or reaffirm self-identity. ...'' The other criticized paragraph refers to Jerusalem itself and projects its unity in ``one body,'' equated with Christianity, saying: ``When we neet in you (Jerusalem) as one body ... carrying the Good News, and when we bring to realization your justice on Earth, then will Jerusalem become the community of all believers. ...'' Rudin and Ms. Banki pointed out that many noted Christian theologians have publicly repudiated such ``religious triumphalism,'' and added: ``We strongly believe that Jeruslaem is today, in fact, a community of all believers: Jewish, Christian and Moslem.'' The proposed prayer was distributed in this country to heads of denominations and to local ecumenical councils by the U.S. National Council of Churches, including most major Protestant and Eastern Orthodox bodies. But it stated in a covering memorandum that the material ``clearly reflects the perspective of the Middle East Council of Churches,'' and was being sent at its request. Wright said it was uncertain whether U.S. denominations would pass the text on to congregations, although indications were that some local councils planned events around the prayer. ``I expect that everyone would agree that prayer is in order for peace between Israelis and Palestinians,'' Wright said. ``Efforts to counteract anti-Semitism in no way diminish concern for the Palestinians and for a genuine and lasting peace in the area.''

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Missiles for Germany Obsolete, but Still on Drawing Board
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In private, the administration acknowledged long ago that there is no realistic prospect for the deployment of new short-range nuclear missiles in Germany. But the project remains on the table, a devalued bargaining chip in arms control talks abroad and budget negotiations at home. In both settings, rival negotiators know that the modernized missile plan is obsolete. West Germany doesn't want the weapons deployed on its soil, and that will go double in a reunified Germany. On a redrawn, post-Cold War political map, they will be missiles without logical targets anyhow. But the project remains in the budget, at $112 million this year, and a total cost estimated by the administration at $1.2 billion if it were to be completed. The weapon involved would be a missile called FOTL, because it hasn't been issued a name of its own. FOTL means follow on to Lance. The Lance is a short-range missile now deployed in Germany and four other NATO nations; it will be obsolete by the middle of the decade, and the alliance has been talking about modernization. The nuclear missiles were deployed to buttress outnumbered NATO troops in the event of a Soviet ground attack into western Europe. Modernizing that missile force was a contentious issue even before the political upheavals that transformed eastern Europe toward democracy, brought down the Berlin Wall and effectively dismantled the old Soviet satellite empire. When President Bush went to his first NATO summit 10 months ago, missile modernization was a problem. Bush proposed sharp cuts in conventional forces, East and West, and the alliance avoided the nuclear missile quandary by putting off a decision on modernization until 1992. In addition, the 1989 NATO compromise calls for negotiations to reduce the battlefield nuclear missiles _ but not to eliminate them totally _ after there is East-West agreement on reduction of conventional forces, and those cuts have started to take place. That shelved the question past the West German parliamentary elections scheduled late this year. The compromise nearly a year ago avoided an issue that would have been a problem for Chancellor Helmut Kohl; anti-nuclear sentiment had been growing in West Germany since the 1987 treaty to scrap intermediate-range missiles. That pact left the short-range missiles, defined as those with ranges up to 310 miles, as the only ones in the NATO neighborhood, and West Germany is the site for almost all of them. The current force of Lance missiles has a range of about 70 miles. NATO has 88 short-range nuclear missile launchers. The FOTL project is to turn out missiles that could deliver nuclear warheads up to 280 miles, with 1,000 of the weapons planned at an expected total cost of $1.2 billion. But all of that was drafted for use against a communist bloc that has been transformed. New governments in eastern Europe are pressing for Soviet troop withdrawals, and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has agreed to them. East Germans have elected a new government shaped to hasten the process of reunification. The West Germans didn't want nuclear missiles on their soil aimed at other Germans even when the presumed targets were in communist territory. They certainly aren't going to accept them now. The Bush administration is said to be considering changes in the plan for new short-range missiles, a topic that will have to be dealt with when NATO defense ministers meet next month in Alberta, Canada. There may not be many options short of dropping the whole notion. The chairmen of the armed services committees in both the House and the Senate have said Congress won't appropriate more money for weapons the West Germans won't accept. A study by defense experts and members of Congress in both parties concludes that the modernization plan should be dropped. That report, issued by the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute, says the funds could be better used elsewhere in the defense budget. And the conservative, defense-oriented Heritage Foundation advocates cancelling the missile program and relying on an air-launched tactical missile to serve the battlefield purpose if necessary. ``For one thing, German opposition to having this weapon on German soil is mounting and may be near-universal,'' the Heritage study concludes. ``For another, the NATO assumptions on which the need for FOTL has been based are that NATO conventional forces are inferior to the Warsaw Pact and that a clear front line exists between two Germanies. ``Both assumptions probably will not be valid for long.''

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Funds Don't Stand Still
DOC.TEXT: When you set out to evaluate a mutual fund, financial advisers say, it's useful to be aware that you are aiming at a moving target. Certainly, a given fund you have in your sights may have been traveling the same course, with the same stated objective, for a long time _ with an extensive performance record to boast about. But many things about a fund remain subject to unpredictable change _ its size and maneuvering ability, for example, or the identity of people manning its helm. As a result, funds cannot automatically be presumed to be fixed quantities with relatively interchangeable characteristics, the way some other securities such as Treasury bills or bank certificates of deposit can. This point was driven home late last month when Peter Lynch, manager of the enormously successful Fidelity Magellan Fund, announced plans to leave his job at the end of May. Though he has been running Magellan, the nation's largest mutual fund with more than $13 billion in assets, since 1977, Lynch is just 46 years old. It was easy for people in the money-management business to assume that when you bought Magellan shares you got Lynch to manage your money for some indefinite period of time. The resident star was unquestionably a prime reason for the fund's allure. So when Lynch stepped down, pleading a desire to do other things with his life that an ever-increasing work load wouldn't allow, it naturally caused a lot of commotion and uncertainty. Because of Lynch's renown, this has been the most celebrated case of its kind in recent memory. But it is hardly the only one. Fund history contains many instances of star managers _ sometimes running funds set up specifically to package their reputed genius _ abruptly departing for other endeavors. Furthermore, that's just one of several ways in which a fund can change important parts of its identity. Usually a fund prospectus sets out limits to this sort of thing, by declaring that no fundamental switch in philosophy or objective can be made without a shareholder vote. But even given such strictures, changes of many types can happen routinely. For example, Donoghue's Moneyletter of Holliston, Mass., recently deleted a couple of respected growth funds from its recommended list because they had raised their sales charges from 3 percent to 4.75 percent. Though that kind of move may not concern existing shareholders much, it could give pause to anyone making periodic new investments in a fund. It is certainly worthy of note for anyone contemplating a first-time purchase. What to do when a development as dramatic as Lynch's departure comes along? Most experts agree it is a matter of individual cases and preferences rather than blanket rules. For Magellan shareholders in particular, says the Boston-based United & Babson Investment Report, ``We suggest staying with it, especially if you have been in the fund a while and thus would feel a sharp tax bite if you switched.'' United & Babson's analysts recommend keeping a close watch on the results achieved by Lynch's designated successor, Morris Smith, who has chalked up a winning record running another, smaller Fidelity fund. Meanwhile, investors have seen a live demonstration of an enduring principle in mutual funds: The game can change even when the name is the same.

DOC.HEAD: Dueling Lists for Corporate America
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on assignment.
DOC.TEXT: It was a public relations coup that would have made their late chairman proud. The editors at Forbes magazine tried to upstage competitor Fortune this week by issuing a new and improved list of America's biggest companies the same day Fortune trotted out its latest edition of the venerable 500. It was the kind of rascality that made the late Malcolm Forbes famous. He was no doubt smiling down on the effort, which the Forbes staff managed to pull off before the magazine containing the list was even off the presses. Not since Forbes parodied its other main competitor, Business Week, by spoofing its cover for a 1987 issue on executive pay has the business-mag competition produced such high jinks. Forbes spokesman Ray Healey must have had tongue in cheek when he explained in a telephone interview that the simultaneous release of dueling Forbes and Fortune lists was simply ``a coincidence.'' Like it's pure accident when Time and Newsweek have the same cover story on, say, Madonna. Healey, who handles press relations for Forbes magazine, was able to get the jump on the competition through a combination of slick packaging and logistical wizardry. First, the magazine distinguished its list of 500 big companies with a so-called ``Super 50,'' described as the most powerful firms over a broad spectrum. That was to differentiate the Forbes list from Fortune's, a list of the 500 largest industrial firms ranked by sales. Forbes rated all public companies _ retailers, financial services, manufacturers, you name it _ by sales, profits, assets and stock market value. Second, Healey crunched a version of the Forbes list on his personal computer, copied it to a computer diskette and dispatched press kits to the news media before the magazine was printed. The information on the diskette could be dumped directly into a news agency's computer system, eliminating the need to hand-punch the data from the list. Fortune, filling the role of tortoise to Forbes' hare, sent copies of the actual magazine to the press along with other facts about the 500 in paper press releases. The result? Both lists got the ink their creators sought, although perhaps not in the manner they envisioned. The Associated Press, for instance, led its story on the lists by noting the obvious competition between the two. At least they agreed on who's on first. General Motors Corp., the only company with more than $100 billion in annual sales, led both the Fortune and the Forbes rankings. But you need more than fast footwork to make real news with a list. While Forbes grabbed a headline with its nifty 50, Fortune is sure to have the last laugh. ``Fortune has been at the 500 for years and years. It's part of the language,'' observed Fortune Managing Editor Marshall Loeb. ``Forbes has been anxiously and eagerly trying to catch up with us,'' he said. ``But frankly, I've never heard anyone in conversation say, `We're part of the Forbes 500.''' The Fortune editor is exactly right. Once something is established as a standard, it's hard to push aside. That's why we still measure in feet, not meters, or why a coach advises a kid to eat his Wheaties, not Total. It's not that the Forbes list is any less ambitious or newsworthy than Fortune's. Forbes, in a sense, does more than Fortune by measuring companies on four separate scales. It's just that for some lists the franchise is locked up. Fortune has the 500. Business Week has its executive pay survey. Forbes, for its part, has the richest 400 Americans. No substitutes will do. Of course, that won't stop the list purveyors from purveying more lists. It seems as if every other issue delivers a fresh register for us to peruse. Some journalists would say the public is definitely overlisted, but the appetite for such trivia appears insatiable. Malcolm Forbes, himself, must share part of the blame for this lopsided demand curve. He was the one at Forbes several years ago who dreamed up the richest 400 _ against the vociferous protests of some Forbes staffers, Healey notes. Three decades after Fortune spawned the list business with its first 500, news magazines have turned the ranking of the biggest and richest into a cottage industry _ and lists have become the Doritos of business journalism. So crunch all you want. They'll make more.

DOC.HEAD: Around Country, No Sign Drug Abuse is Abating
DOC.TEXT: The news from the nation's capital was somewhat encouraging _ fewer people taken into police custody tested positive for cocaine. But around the country, law enforcement officials say they see no sign that drug abuse and trafficking are abating. The situation is ``bleak in that cocaine is still readily available in the United States despite very significant and very effective law enforcement initiatives both domestically and in Latin America,'' said Frank Shults, a spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Agency. A DEA survey last September and October revealed that the price of cocaine at the kilogram level has increased slightly, moving from $13,000 to $14,000 in Los Angeles, he said. Unfortunately, he said, this doesn't mean there's a cocaine shortage. ``We attribute it to price gouging at low- and mid-level trafficking, and individuals who are taking advantage of the user's fear of a shortage,'' Shults said. He said the fear stems from some significant law enforcement advances: _The Colombian government's crackdown on drug trafficking has disrupted operations of the Medellin cartel. _The price of coca leaf paid to farmers in Bolivia and Peru has dropped to $5 to $10 per hundred pounds, far below the growers' break-even point of $30 per hundred pounds. The price drop occurred because of the Colombian crackdown, an oversupply of leaf, more efficient processing techniques and better controls of chemicals used to make cocaine, he said. _The seizure of 20 tons of cocaine at one Los Angeles warehouse in the fall, combined with several other major busts around the country. Nevertheless, the purity of cocaine at the kilo level has remained high, approximately 84 percent, throughout the United States, Shults said. At the street level, there has been a slight decrease in purity, but officials attribute that also to a perception of a shortage rather than an actual one. As it turned out, the decline in the percentage of Washington D.C. arrestees who tested positive for cocaine was temporary. Justice Department and local officials said the temporary drop may be attributed in part to the arrest of one major trafficker and the disruption of his operation. Law enforcement efforts have changed drug dealers' tactics, but there is no nationwide trend, police officials say. In some areas, crack houses have given way to open air markets to reduce the amount of drugs and money that police can seize in a single bust. In East St. Louis, Ill., for example, drugs were sold a few years ago primarily at homes known to locals as drug emporiums, and all deals were done behind closed doors, according to the chief of detectives, Lester Anderson. Now, he said, money and drugs are exchanged onstreet corners in broad daylight, known there as ``curb service.'' Even in Los Angeles, where crack houses once dominated the market for that drug, there has been a slight and recent trend toward deals on the street, said Sgt. Tim Beard of the county sheriff's narcotics unit. The reason: to avoid detection and to implicate as few people as possible in the event of a bust, But the reverse has happened elsewhere. In Washington D.C., law enforcement officials said dealers have closed some open air markets to avoid easy arrest. In Dallas, on-the-street drug trafficking today is not as blatant as in past years when dealers were ``standing on the streets waving down customers,'' said Capt. Doug Kolwalski, who heads the police department's narcotics division. Efforts by officials to increase public awareness and encourage neighbors to report drug dealing have paid off, he said. As a result, drug dealers have become more discreet. The same is happening in New York City where ``dealers are becoming more selective in who they sell to,'' said Capt. Robert Cividanes of the police narcotics division. ``Many move to off-street locations and employ ``steerers,'' the captain said. In Broward County, Fla., ``We're seeing smaller quantities on the street because the police are catching these people and the dealers don't want to lose large quantities,'' said Robert Deak, commander of the county's drug task force. Deak said dealers are adjusting their sales techniques depending on law enforcement tactics. ``As we do more of the sweeps, they do tend to move inside the buildings,'' he said. ``But as we do search warrants, they move out of buildings.'' John Rothlein, commander of the Metro Dade police narcotics unit, described the ebb and flow of drug markets as ``a cat and mouse game.'' In Denver, Capt. Rudy Sandoval of the police vice and narcotics bureau said, ``We've still got crack houses, but they're underground. They're not on the street bothering people like they used to.'' The street drug market in New Orleans has changed, but the overall situation hasn't improved, said Capt. Chuck Ladell, chief of detectives. ``There are more of them now but they are more discreet,'' Ladell said. Despite some increases in prices for kilos of cocaine, street prices have remained relatively stable, averaging $100 a gram nationwide, police said. Denver had some good news for those who believe cocaine use has at least stopped growing. Dr. Stephen Dilts, director of emergency alcohol, drug and psychiatric treatment at Denver General Hospital, said the number of patients showing up in the emergency room with cocaine-related problems appears to be leveling off after years of steadily increasing. ``Over the past few years, we've seen an increase in the number of cocaine addicts, but no particular increase in the last year,'' Dilts said.

DOC.TEXT: Robert C. Stempel, who worked his way up General Motors Corp. through its engineering and product development side, will become GM's chairman and chief executive officer in August, GM Chairman Roger Smith said. Stempel, GM's president and chief operating officer, will succeed the retiring Smith, who has headed the big automaker through a turbulent decade, on Aug. 1. Smith made the announcement Tuesday.

Fortune and Forbes magazines found one thing they could agree on, proclaiming General Motors Corp. the nation's largest public company in two dueling lists of America's corporate titans. The Fortune 500 list, the annual ranking familiar on Main Street as well as Wall Street, on Tuesday ranked the nation's largest industrial firms by sales. The Forbes ranking included all public companies measured by sales, profits, assets and stock market value. GM was on top either way, with nearly $127 billion in sales and $4.2 billion in earnings during 1989.

The government's main economic forecasting gauge plunged 1.0 percent in February, its steepest drop in nine months, the government said. The Commerce Department said Tuesday its latest Index of Leading Economic Indicators _ designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in advance _ wiped out three months of increases with the largest decline since last May.

The national debt on Monday totaled more than $3 trillion for the first time, the Treasury Department reported. The actual level of public debt subject to statutory limit at the end of the day Monday was $3.023 trillion. That's just $99.59 billion under the statutory limit of $3.123 trillion. The national debt stood at $2.989 trillion last Friday.

Unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines, frustrated by the company's mounting losses and plans to reduce debt payments, have agreed to seek the appointment of a special trustee to find a buyer for the carrier. The unsecured creditors' committee voted unanimously Tuesday to reject Eastern's latest reorganization proposal, which would give them only 25 cents for each dollar owed, and seek the appointment of a special trustee, sources close to the committee said.

OPEC nations held oil production steady in March but remained more than a million barrels a day above their self-imposed supply cap, according to estimates. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped a total of about 23.7 million barrels a day in March, the same as in the previous month, the Paris-based International Energy Agency said Tuesday. Sales of OPEC crude oil in March were believed to be lower than production due to apparent excess supply of heavy, sour grades and weaker than expected demand from refiners, the group stated.

American Airlines embellished its frequent flier program by allowing members to trade free miles for rebates on purchases of items ranging from cars to fur coats. The AAdvantage Extra program, announced Tuesday, would allow the nation's largest carrier to erase some the billions of unused free miles owed by the airline to its frequent fliers.

Cable television pioneer Ted Turner said cable TV's competitors and not cable subscribers are responsible for rallying efforts to impose more regulations on the cable industry. The chairman and president of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. lso said Tuesday that he opposed the heavy investment being made in developing expensive high definition television while half the world still doesn't have television at all.

Fines against fast-food restaurants and other businesses are climbing toward the $3 million mark for thousands of child labor law violations uncovered in a three-day federal sweep, officials said. The number of violations grew from 7,000 to nearly 11,000 after federal investigators gave the case files further review, officials said Tuesday. The total is about half the number for all of 1989.

Stock prices rose sharply and broadly Tuesday in moderate trading, boosted by a rebound in the Tokyo market and firm bond prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 36.26 to 2,736.71. The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies. Bond prices finished with small gains. Gold futures prices rose sharply in a burst of Middle Eastern buying; copper futures climbed strongly; cocoa futures surged; grains and soybeans advanced; oil futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: GM In Top Spot On Fortune, Forbes Lists
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. was the titan of corporate America last year despite tough foreign competition and cutthroat rebates that squeezed the nation's Big Three automakers, according to Fortune and Forbes magazines. With nearly $127 billion in sales and $4.2 billion in earnings in 1989, GM garnered first place on the Fortune 500 and Forbes ``Super 50'' lists, released Tuesday. The Fortune 500, as familiar on Main Street as on Wall Street, ranks the nation's largest industrial firms by sales. Forbes ranks all public companies by sales, profits, assets and stock market value. Both magazines have issued 500 rankings for years, but Tuesday was the first time in recent memory that the lists were released the same day. In an effort to upstage its competitor, Forbes topped its rankings with a so-called Super 50, which it described as the most powerful companies across all four categories. The Fortune 500 had a profit decline in 1989 after years of strong growth, reflecting the slowdown in industrial America. Behind GM, Fortune's top 10 were: Ford Motor Co., Exxon Corp., International Business Machines Corp., General Electric Co., Mobil Corp., Philip Morris Cos., Chrysler Corp., E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., and Texaco Inc. Rounding out the top 10 of the Forbes Super 50 were: GE, Exxon, IBM, Ford, Philip Morris, American Telephone & Telegraph Corp., Mobil, Du Pont and Sears, Roebuck and Co. The Fortune 500 list appears in the April 23 edition and is available on newsstands Wednesday. Forbes released its ranking two weeks before it is to hit the stands in the April 30 edition. ``It's a horse race every year,'' said Forbes spokesman Ray Healey, describing his magazine's rush to beat its rival. ``Information of this kind is old in a matter of minutes. As soon as we have it locked in solid, we send it out.'' Marshall Loeb, Fortune managing editor, dismissed the competition. ``Fortune has been at the 500 for years and years. It's part of the language. I've never heard anyone in conversation say, `We're part of the Forbes 500.''' Fortune 500 sales jumped 7 percent to a record $2.16 trillion in 1989, but overall earnings fell 8.2 percent to $105.6 billion. In the previous two years, profits among the big manufacturers had climbed an unprecedented 79 percent. Median profits fell in nine of Fortune's 27 industry groups and only 264 of the top 500 companies had earnings growth, down from 327 in 1988. Pharmaceuticals had the largest median increase in earnings, up 19.6 percent; followed by beverages, 18.3 percent; textiles, 15.3 percent; food, 14 percent; and electronics 10 percent. The motor vehicles and parts industry suffered the largest median earnings decline, down 25 percent, followed by aerospace, down 12.5 percent; petroleum refining, down 11.8 percent; transportation equipment, down 9.4 percent; and computers, down 9 percent. Fortune said six of the 10 largest industrial companies suffered double-digit earnings declines, including a 66 percent drop at Chrysler, whose ranking dropped a notch from 1988. Despite topping Forbes' earnings list, GM's profits fell 13 percent last year. Ford's profits fell 28 percent in 1989 to $3.84 billion but still ranked as the third highest after GM and General Electric, Forbes said. ``In the 1960s and 1970s, back before global competition became so intense and incessant, the earnings of the 500 companies invariably rose as long as the domestic economy was growing. Not any more,'' Fortune said. Foreign competition, especially from the Japanese, was particularly acute in the motor vehicles and parts industry, which ranked as the poorest performer by nearly every measure of profitability, according to Fortune. That sector also was hurt by high interest rates and rebates. GM had by far the largest profit during 1989, while No. 46 Sun Co., an energy business, had the biggest profit jump, up 1,300 percent. Maxxam Inc., an alumunium products and lumber company which soared to 184th place from 485th, had the biggest sales increase, up 366.7 percent, according to Fortune. Another big jump occurred because of Time Inc.'s acquisition of Warner Communications Inc. for $14 billion. The combined Time Warner _ Fortune's parent company _ jumped from No. 102 to No. 59. Foreign takeovers bumped several companies off the list. Among the casualties were SmithKline Beckman Corp., which merged with Britain's Beecham Group PLC in an $8 billion deal; Pillsbury Co., bought for $5.8 billion by Britain's Grand Metropolitan PLC; and Combustion Engineering Inc., acquired by Swiss giant ABB Asea Brown Boveri. Among the 39 newcomers were Lyondell Petrochemical, which debuted at 93rd on the Fortune 500 list.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes Debuts `Super 50' List of Top U.S. Companies
With PM-Biggest Companies Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Forbes magazine has taken a shot at competitor Fortune with a new list that Forbes claims more accurately ranks the most powerful American corporations. Dubbed the ``Super 50,'' the Forbes list ranks the biggest U.S. companies based on their ``across-the-board strength'' in sales, profits, assets and the market value of their stock. The new list was introduced on Tuesday, the same day Fortune released its venerable 500 list. Forbes derided the Fortune list _ which is limited to industrial companies ranked by sales alone _ as ``one-dimensional.'' It claimed the Super 50 best identified the companies _ financial as well as industrial _ with ``the capital, the resources and the financial stamina to compete in world markets.'' ``It's a horse race every year,'' said Forbes spokesman Ray Healey, describing his magazine's effort to compete with Fortune. He said the release of both lists on the same day was a coincidence. The Super 50 is a new wrinkle in Forbes' own 500 ranking, which the magazine has issued annually. Forbes measures all public companies four different ways, by sales, profits, assets and market value.
