DOC.HEAD: End List
Digital Unveils New RISC Workstation, Aggressive Pricing
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. launched an assault on the computer industry's hottest market, introducing its most powerful workstations, slashing prices on other models and vowing to take the lead in ``open'' systems. Digital showed off over 20 new computers, peripherals and software products Tuesday, including a 3D desktop workstation it claimed is the industry's highest performing model. The Maynard, Mass.-based company is playing catchup in RISC-based workstations and systems based on non-proprietary, ``open'' operating software, but it took a feisty stand in the first major product announcement at its Silicon Valley facility. In addition to price cuts on its entire family of RISC-based workstations _ the cheapest is now $5,950 _ along with servers and ULTRIX software, the company said it has improved discounts and will offer finder's fees for third-party sales. ``All of this reinforces our primary message,'' said Donald Gaubatz, Digital's group manager for workstations. ``We intend to be number one in the open systems market, and we are doing what it takes to achieve that goal.'' Wall Street apparently liked what it heard and sent Digital's recently depressed shares up $2.50 to $79.62. The price was over $100 last fall. Sales of workstations _ powerful desktop computers _ are expected to grow 35 percent this year to $8.1 billion, according to San Jose-based Dataquest Inc. Leading companies like Sun Microsystems Inc., Hewlett-Packard Co., Digital, and big newcomer International Business Machines Corp. have been bringing out new models and cutting prices relative to performance. That's good news for the businesses, banks and engineering companies that are the main buyers of workstations. ``This market is going to be hotly competitive for a very long time,'' said Barry Willman, an analyst with New York-based Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., who attended Digital's introduction. ``The companies are prepared to aggressively defend the installed base they've already developed and are aggressively focused on building that base,'' he said, adding that Digital appears to be embarking on a price war. ``Given how aggressively Digital was comparing themselves to H-P, Sun and IBM, I would expect those other vendors not to be silent in the face of that attack,'' he said. Digital's pursuit of market share comes at a time when it also needs to bolster profits. Analysts predict the company's revenues for the fiscal year ending June 30 will barely exceed last year's $12.7 billion, and earnings will drop for the second year in a row _ this time by 70 percent. The new products, most of which are ready for shipment, aren't expected to have an impact on revenues until the 1991 fiscal year. The company has been cutting overhead with a severance program aimed at reducing its 126,000 employees by 8,000. Until last year Digital was ambivalent about its commitment to open industry standards such as American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s Unix software and RISC, or reduced instruction set computers. Now, the company says that segment of its business will soon match its VAX workstations and proprietary VMS software lines. Domenic LaCava, Digital's vice president for low end systems, said the company expects ``incremental'' growth in its VAX workstation business and that ``over time the ratio of RISC workstations to VAX workstations will level out.'' ``Over this next year we should see something approaching 50-50,'' he said. ``The RISC line is starting to take off dramatically. We have seen the order rate double and triple in weekly orders over the last three or four months.'' Computer hardware analyst Kevin Landis of Dataquest was impressed but not overwhelmed by the capabilities of Digital's new 5000 series workstations, which start at $14,995. ``It doesn't cleanly leapfrog everybody but it's good,'' said Landis. ``It's a significant step for them to go to open systems and step away from their traditional line. They're making a lot of tough choices. It represents a strategic leap for them.'' Willman said the new computers, peripherals and software ``significantly broaden their product line from a performance standpoint and also significantly improve their price competitiveness in the market.'' Digital cites research by International Data Corp., in Framingham, Mass., that shows Digital is only slightly behind workstation market leader Sun Microsystems and ahead of Hewlett-Packard, which recently bought Apollo Computer Inc. Dataquest's Kathleen Hurley says Digital holds just under 20 percent of the market and is third behind Hewlett-Packard. In any event, all of the big three workstation leaders have to contend with a potentially invasive rival _IBM. IBM last month brought out a line of workstations it said would snare a major share of a market in which it never had success. The machines, called the RISC System-6000, represented the first time IBM has wholeheartedly embraced the Unix operating system.

DOC.HEAD: New GM Management Team Product Heavy
DOC.TEXT: Half of the new core management team at General Motors Corp. comes from the product-side of the automobile business, a change that should help the company rebuild its market share, analysts say. The team, led by Chairman-elect Robert Stempel, takes control Aug. 1, the day after Roger B. Smith retires as GM's 10th chairman, Smith said Tuesday. Stempel, now the company's president, also will become its chief executive officer in August. ``I think Mr. Stempel will take a very hands on interest in the North American turnaround,'' said auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan, Stanley & Co. of New York. ``There will be a lot of continuity in that.'' Smith, who became chairman on New Year's Day 1981, and Stempel, who became president on Sept. 1, 1987, have worked closely over the past few years, trying to fend off an assault by arch-rival Ford Motor Co. and Japanese companies on the company's North American market share. Stempel said Tuesday that defending and recapturing the lost share was his top goal. ``There is no higher priority in General Motors than increasing our market share profitably,'' he said. Joining Stempel, 56, in top leadership positions will be: _Lloyd Reuss, 53, executive vice president in charge of North American Auto Operations. He will succeed Stempel as president. _John F. Smith, 51, executive vice president in charge of GM's international operations. He will become one of two vice chairmen. _Robert J. Schultz, 59, GM's executive vice president in charge of the company's GM Hughes Electronics Corp., Electronic Data Systems Corp. and GM's technical staffs. He will become the other vice chairman. No one will assume Stempel's title as chief operating officer. There currently are no GM vice chairmen. ``In a sense, this whole thing is kind of a reassignment of titles,'' said auto analyst David Healy of the brokerage Barclays-BZW in New York. ``I think it's probably notable for how little change there is rather than how much. ``It's also notable that it is product guys rather than financial types or marketing types who really have pretty much all the top jobs now,'' he added. ``I thought it was very important to have this organization,'' Stempel said of his team, ``and recognize the importance I attach personally to our technical operation, EDS and Hughes, and worldwide operations ... and then of course the strength we have in North America.'' During the nine years of Smith's reign, GM's share of the North American car and truck market has fallen to 34.6 percent at the end of last year from 44.1 percent in 1980. But there are other problems Stempel must tackle immediately. ``I guess the one thing that one has to do if one is ascending to the top of GM is lower expectations,'' said analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. ``Bob (Stempel) hasn't got any magic bullet that he can whip out of his holster and point and solve the problem of market share. ``What he's going to have to do is set a leadership tone that is going to get that organization turned around.'' A key to GM's hopes for market share recovery is its much-ballyhooed Saturn Corp. The division is scheduled to begin production this summer in Spring Hill, Tenn., of a compact car aimed directly at Japanese models. The $3-billion project also is serving as a laboratory for new manufacturing and labor relations techniques. But perhaps the most significant test in Stempel's first days as chairman will be this summer's negotiations with the United Auto Workers. ``We remind Mr. Stempel that GM's single most valuable resource is a capable and dedicated work force that seeks to build the best products it is capable of building,'' UAW President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stephen Yokich, head of the union's GM Department, said in a statement. Merlis and other analysts have long urged GM to look to its successful European operations for leads in turning around its North American business. Stempel joined GM in 1958 as a senior detailer in the Oldsmobile Division's chassis design department. He rose through the ranks in Oldsmobile and Pontiac until he was appointed managing director of Adam Opel AG in West Germany. ``The key message here is that GM has a five-month (new car) waiting list in Europe and has nothing but product successes there,'' Merlis said. ``Now your chairman and vice chairman (John Smith) have had experience in Europe. ``They're well positioned to cross-fertilize the lessons learned overseas to North America.''

DOC.HEAD: Stockholder Vote Called Censorship
DOC.TEXT: A shareholder upset by ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' is urging other holders of MCA Inc. stock to tell the company not to make films that might offend religious groups. The proposal was included in proxy materials sent to shareholders this week ahead of a vote at the company's annual meeting May 8 in Chicago. A supporting statement for the proposal says ``Last Temptation'' showed Jesus as a ``disturbed man who frequents brothels, hallucinates seeing snakes, vows that he always tells lies, acts only as a result of fear...and feels tormented by God.'' The proposal, made by stockholder Dean Shahinian of Alexandria, Va., calls for shareholders to censure MCA for ``anti-Christian effects.'' ``We urge management to establish a corporate policy not to use corporate assets to falsely defame Jesus Christ or other major religious leaders,'' it says. MCA urged shareholders to reject the proposal, saying that censoring a film because it contains an unconventional religious viewpoint could stifle religious and creative expression. Noting that Martin Scorsese won a best director Oscar nomination for ``Temptation,'' MCA said the film was Scorsese's interpretation of a novel, not the company's view of Christ. The proxy materials also disclosed that MCA's top executives were awarded hefty compensation last year. Film chief Thomas Pollock was given MCA stock worth $5.7 million in 1989 and stock options worth $7.8 million when issued last August. Pollock also was paid a base salary of $627,000, bringing his total compensation to more than $14 million. His salary was raised to $850,000 this year. Sidney Sheinberg, president of the Universal City-basedmovie, TV, music and theme park giant, was issued stock worth $7.2 million last year. His salary jumps from $729,000 in 1989 to $900,000. MCA Chairman Lew Wasserman's salary also jumps to $900,000 from $559,000. The shareholders will vote on a new stock option plan under which Pollock was given his options. The plan authorizes the issuance of 5 million new shares, 600,000 of which would become available to Pollock at $55 a share over the next five years. He may exercise 20 percent of the options once per year, beginning this July. MCA's stock was trading at $68 a share when they were awarded last August. It has since fallen in value, closing at $50.50 on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. At that level, Pollock would lose money by exercising his options. MCA's last stock option plan was approved in 1968 but never exercised. The company said the new plan was needed to provide competitive compensation for MCA executives. That was a reference to corporations like the Walt Disney Co., whose Chairman President Frank Wells made $72.4 million on the sale of stock bought through options in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Clean Air Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the key provisions of clean air legislation passed by the Senate.

Requires states and local authorities to develop pollution control plans to reduce urban smog and bring air quality in more than 100 cities within federal health standards. Timetable for meeting the standards ranged from five to 15 years, with Los Angeles getting 20 years because of the severity of its problem. Smog-causing pollutants, or ozone, are reduced through controls on automobiles and industry, with annual pollution improvements of 4 percent a year required over first six years. Automobiles: _Tougher tailpipe emission requirements by 1995 cutting hydrocarbon releases by 22 percent and nitrogen oxide emissions by 66 percent. _Cleaner fuels for all automobiles in nine cities with the worst pollution. The nine cities are Los Angeles, Houston, New York City, Milwaukee, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Hartford, Conn., San Diego and Chicago. _Special canisters on auto fuel systems to reduce emissions during refueling. Industrial Sources: _Sources emitting 100 tons of smog-causing pollutants must install new smog control technology, although a waiver may be given in some cases if pollution control costs exceed $5,000 per ton. Current Law: Requires controls on tailpipe emissions, but curbs widely believed to be inadequate to meet air quality standards amid growing number of cars on the road. Despite law, more than 100 cities fail to meet federal air quality standards.

Requires industrial plants to install best available technology to control the release of about 200 hazardous chemicals linked to cancer, nervous disorders and birth defects. That affects a wide range of industries including oil refineries, chemical plants, smelters, dry cleaners and paint shops. The EPA now regulates only seven chemicals.

Requires annual sulfur dioxide releases to be reduced by 10 million tons by 2000, roughly cutting such emissions in half. It allows utilities to buy and sell ``pollution credits'' among themselves as long as total reductions in emissions are not affected. Extra allowances are given to Midwest utilities and some ``clean'' plants to ease the cost burden and allow for future growth. Nitrogen oxide releases, which also contribute to acid rain, must be cut by 2.7 million tons. It will affects 107 coal-fired electric power plants with Midwest utilities using high-sulfur coal facing greatest pollution reduction burden and likely increases in electric rates. Current law: Utilities must comply with local air quality requirements, but have avoided curbs on sulfur dioxide emissions by building tall smokestacks that send the pollution high into the atmosphere. Pollutants are carried hundreds of miles and fall as acid rain.

DOC.HEAD: Towns Try to ``Snuff Out'' Cigarette Machines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The first state to ban indoor smoking except for designated areas is now taking the lead nationally in trying to snuff out cigarette machines _ or at least keep them out of youngsters' reach. Since the St. Paul suburb of White Bear Lake passed the state's first ban on cigarette vending machines in October, at least 20 other Minnesota cities have prohibited or restricted the machines. The restrictions are part of a grass-roots movement for a smoke-free society, said Jean Forster, assistant professor in the University of Minnesota's School of Public Health. ``It's captured the imagination of local communities,'' she said. ``It's something they can do at their level. There are a lot of places watching what's happening in Minnesota.'' A measure pending in Congress, sponsored by Rep. Thomas Luken, D-Ohio, would ban cigarette machines in any location accessible to people under 18. Testimony at a hearing last year cited a National Automatic Merchandising Association report that only 2.5 percent of teen-age smokers buy their cigarettes from machines. But advocates of cigarette machine bans say any percentage is significant. ``It may not stop kids from smoking, but it puts another roadblock in the way,'' said White Bear Lake Mayor Jerry Briggs. A few other states and communities outside Minnesota have instituted or are considering cigarette machine bans. But Angela Mickel, director of the Tobacco-Free America Legislative Clearinghouse in Washington, D.C., said the local campaigns in Minnesota are the most widespread she's seen. ``Minnesota is looked at as a leader in health advocacy,'' she said. In 1975, the state passed the nation's first Clean Indoor Air Act. The law restricting indoor smoking was a model for laws across the country. White Bear Lake and Bloomington are among at least eight Minnesota cities banning cigarette machines altogether. Others have enacted softer restrictions. Redwood Falls bans the machines from ``public places.'' Preston restricts them to places licensed to sell liquor. Excelsior requires that machines be under constant supervision by employees. The local measures were almost nullified last month when Minnesota lawmakers considered a proposal that would have overridden local restrictions for the sake of consistent statewide regulation. The bill that passed instead preserves local governments' power to ban the machines while tightening restrictions statewide. That measure, which awaits Gov. Rudy Perpich's signature, requires electronic locks on machines that a business's employees can activate and requires that the machines be kept where workers can monitor their use. Walker Merryman, vice president of the Tobacco Institute, a Washington trade association for cigarette manufacturers, said the tobacco industry has taken no position on the matter. ``It's an issue that pertains to the vendors,'' he said. But he added that the bans are no surprise. ``Minnesota has a certain history of being receptive to any anti-smoking initiative,'' Merryman said. The vending machine industry argued unsuccessfully before state lawmakers that minors can be protected without a ban. ``We're looking for uniformity,'' said Tom Briant, lawyer for the Minnesota Coalition for Responsible Vending Sales. ``We think it would be in the public interest to regulate it on a statewide basis.'' Briant said about 275 people could lose their jobs by allowing bans throughout the state. But anti-smoking activists say bans are the only way to keep minors from buying cigarettes from vending machines. Jordan Cushing, a 16-year-old Minneapolis sophomore, said she knows many teen-agers whose addiction began by purchasing cigarettes from machines. ``It's really, really easy,'' said Cushing, who has worked with anti-smoking groups. ``If the machines are taken away, it would make a big difference.'' She said any potential loss of jobs is outweighed by health concerns. ``Their main argument is money, but these are lives, lives that haven't really even had the chance to get started,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies in European trading this morning. Gold was lower in thin and aimless trading. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 158.90 yen, down 0.05 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 158.75 yen. The dollar started higher following overnight gains in New York, but the currency gradually fell in Tokyo as market players _ mainly life insurance and securities houses _ sold the dollar against the yen in an attempt to reduce their dollar holdings ahead of the meeting of the Group of Seven key currency nations scheduled for April 7 in Paris, said Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank in Tokyo. ``Market players began to reduce their dollar holdings in case the G-7 meeting comes up with something they had not predicted, although nothing special is expected at the moment,'' he said. Other dollar rates at mid-morning, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6980 West German marks, down from 1.7005; 1.5028 Swiss francs, down from 1.5035; 5.7030 French francs, down from 5.7410; 1.9100 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9150; 1,247.00 Italian lire, down from 1,254.00; and 1.1675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1660. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6400, compared with $1.6345 late Tuesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $374.25 this morning, down from $375.05 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $374.40, from $376.00 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $3.40 an ounce today, to close at $375.34. Silver dropped in London to a bid price of $5.01 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.02 per ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lose Ground, Dollar Drops Slightly
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index erased its morning gains and fell back sharply in the afternoon, while the dollar declined marginally against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average ended trading down 316.78 points, or 1.10 percent, at 28,442.94. After reversing its 212.05-point morning gain, the index dropped steeply during the afternoon, then narrowed its deficit by about 350 points with a rally in the last 20 minutes of trading, helped in part by arbitrage buying, traders said. A Nomura Securities trader attributed the index's afternoon fall to broad declines in speculative shares that triggered selling of other issues, and to profit-taking from shares that had advanced in the past week. The trader spoke on condition of anonymity. Prompted by growing concern that some speculators may be in financial trouble, the Nikkei index fell quickly as investors tried to get rid of speculative shares, including some local bank issues, he said. Betty Wu, an analyst with SBCI Securities Asia Ltd., said the afternoon's drop resulted in part from index selling, as individuals were trying to curb their losses. She predicted relatively quiet trading in the next few weeks because corporations have just closed their books on fiscal 1989, which ended March 31, and are deciding future investment strategies. Trading was thin today, with volume on the market's first section estimated at 560 million shares, down from Tuesday's 650 million. On Tuesday, the Nikkei index gained 757.65 points, following Monday's drop of 1,978.38 points, or 6.59 percent, in the index's second-largest single-day decline. The plunge followed a 1,045.71-point fall in the index last Friday. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 158.90 yen, down 0.05 yen from Tuesday's close of 158.95 yen. It opened higher at 159.62 yen and ranged between 158.70 yen and 159.70 yen. The dollar started higher following overnight gains in New York, but the currency gradually fell in Tokyo as market players _ mainly life insurance and securities houses _ sold the dollar against the yen in an attempt to reduce their dollar holdings ahead of the meeting of the Group of Seven key currency nations scheduled for April 7 in Paris, said Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with the Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``Market players began to reduce their dollar holdings in case the G-7 meeting comes up with something they had not predicted, although nothing special is expected at the moment,'' he said. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno is to leave for the meeting in Paris on Friday. Some investors also sold the dollar for profit-taking, Tabata said. ``But the yen's strength is likely to last only temporarily,'' he added. A dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the U.S. currency rose in New York overnight because of speculation the U.S. Federal Reserve Board has halted its support for the yen in an attempt to pressure Japan to make trade concessions in talks with the United States now under way in Washington. ``The rumor has been in the market for some time, and it was brought up again in New York. Such speculation has been already factored into the market here,'' the Bank of Tokyo dealer said. The price of benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.45 points, down from Tuesday's close at 86.51. Their yield rose to 7.260 percent from Tuesday's 7.245 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Futures Begin Trading In New York
DOC.TEXT: Natural gas futures were traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange for the first time in what analysts termed a light but successful session. About 920 contracts for future delivery of natural gas traded hands during Tuesday's initial session. The volume was far below the 50,000 to 70,000 crude oil futures traded daily on the exchange, but analysts said the important traders were there. ``There certainly was trade participation, which is important in a new contract,'' said Andrew Lebow, an energy market analyst in New York with E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. ``Everybody in the industry was watching it and I think it's going to be a successful contract,'' he said. The contract for June delivery of natural gas traded from $1.58 to $1.655 during the session and settled at $1.635 per million British thermal units. Futures contracts are used by producers and consumers of raw commodities to hedge against financial risk by locking in prices in advance. Speculators also play futures markets in hopes of profiting from the constant change in prices.

DOC.HEAD: Contel Restructuring Telephone Operations
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta-based Contel Corp. said it planned a major restructuring of its telephone operations division that could eliminate about 600 jobs across the country. The cutbacks, which represent about 4 percent of Contel's telephone operations staff, will take place over the next two years. They are expected to be achieved largely through attrition and voluntary separation programs. Under the restructuring plan, Contel said it would combine the telephone operations from three regions and 12 divisions into six multistate operating groups reporting directly to headquarters. The restructuring centralizes policy setting and allows decisions to be made at the local level, said Brian Farley, a Contel spokesman. Although Contel has not determined the cost of employee separation programs, Farley said the company does not expect the restructuring to have an impact on financial results.

DOC.HEAD: General Development Closes Home-site Office Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp., mired in legal and financial problems, is closing its global network of home-site sales offices. General Development announced Tuesday it was shutting 24 offices in this country, as well as bureaus in Europe, Canada and the Far East, and laying off about 1,100 workers. The company is trying to stay out of bankruptcy court and recover from a scandal involving a scheme to sell overpriced homes. Thomas D. Wood, a Coral Gables-based mortgage banker and attorney, was named Tuesday to examine General Development's agreement to reimburse nearly 10,000 victims of the overpricing scheme. The agreement was part of a settlement of federal fraud charges against the firm. U.S. District Court Judge Lenore Nesbitt said Wood's role was to make the restitution pact ``acceptable, workable and realistic.'' General Development said the closure of its offices would not affect the restitution plan. ``The cost of generating sales in these offices no longer makes economic sense,'' said company president Charles Simons. ``Also, given the parameters of the proposed consent decree, we are not confident that those guidelines are being met on a daily basis in many of our offices.'' The company will continue to sell existing homes at its nine Florida communities, the focus of the U.S. attorney's office two-year probe into pricing practices. A federal indictment accused the company and two former executives of an elaborate scheme to sell homes with highly inflated prices compared with similar Florida dwellings. The victims _ many from the Northeast and Midwest _ were deceived into purchasing homes an average of 40 percent higher than market value, prosecutors said. A week after the March 16 indictment, attorneys for General Development entered a guilty plea to one fraud count that could bring a maximum $500,000 fine. At the same hearing, General Development's former president Robert Ehrling and former chairman David Brown also pleaded guilty to one fraud count. Each faces a maximum of five years in prison, a $250,000 fine and some restitution payments. Sentencing is scheduled for May 22. The plan, which still needs final court approval, covers General Development homebuyers from Jan. 1, 1983, to Jan. 1, 1989, and establishes a complicated formula to determine how much money will be returned. A court-appointed master will set the restitution amount by determining the difference between each home's net price and appraised value. In cases of cash purchases, for example, the difference would be paid in installments over 25 years. For those with a mortgage through the company's financial division, the company would offset a portion of the monthly payment. Under the plan, General Development would pay restitution up to $2.5 million a year for the first five years, and a smaller portion later. It would also be required to put up collateral valued at $12.5 million by July 1. Discussions of restitution are complicated by cash shortages at General Development, which announced Monday that negotiations for $60 million in short-term credit fell apart and it might seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Assistant U.S. Attorney Norman Moscowitz and company spokesman Otis Wragg III declined to comment on how a bankruptcy filing would affect the restitution program. Meanwhile, General Development is the target of several burgeoning class-action suits stemming from the overpricing scheme and conditions in the Florida communities. In Delaware, a major shareholder has filed suit seeking to oust six company directors.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Says Divided USX Worth 35 Percent More
DOC.TEXT: Takeover strategist Carl Icahn says spinning off USX Corp.'s steel division would increase shareholders' returns by about 29 percent. The New York financier told stockholders in a letter Tuesday he estimated that shares in a separate energy company would be worth $39 while stock in a steel unit would be worth $9. USX's stock closed Tuesday at $37.12{ a share, up $1.50 in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. USX spokesman William Keslar declined to comment on the letter today, saying the company was studying it. Icahn, the largest stockholder of USX with 34 million shares or 13.29 percent, has asked the shareholders for a non-binding vote on a proposal to spin off the steel division and call the new company U.S. Steel. Four-fifths of the new company would become a dividend to USX shareholders, who also would own Marathon Oil Co. and smaller USX interests. The rest of the new company would go to new investors. Icahn's plan would include no more than $1.5 billion in long-term debt incurred by the steel division. The stockholders will vote on Icahn's proposal at USX's annual meeting May 7. USX has opposed the plan. Executives said it would make Marathon and U.S. Steel more vulnerable to slumps in either the energy or steel industries. USX has said 65 percent of its revenue comes from Marathon, while 31 percent come from steel operations. Icahn, who is the chairman of Trans World Airlines, said in the letter USX could properly structure the division of its companies to make them essentially tax-free to the company and its stockholders. The plan would preserve net operating losses of USX, he said. USX Chairman Charles A. Corry recently told Wall Street analysts Icahn's plan had pitfalls because the company could lose tax credits resulting from steel losses in the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Wants Frequent Fliers to Cash in Miles for Other Goodies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AAdvantage is CQ throughout
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc., looking for ways to increase traffic and also eliminate free travel owed millions of travelers, will let frequent fliers turn miles into money rebates on purchases from fast cars to fur coats. The rebates, ranging from hundreds to thousands of dollars depending on the product and miles exchanged, will be paid directly to customers from the product makers, Michael W. Gunn, American's marketing vice president, said Tuesday. The program also will help manufacturers, such as automakers, boost sales. ``Our customer research shows that while most members will still claim travel awards, a significant number appreciate the option of savings on products and services,'' Gunn said at a news conference announcing a program called AAdvantage Extra. Most other major airlines said they were studying American's program, but Delta Air Lines spokesman Neil Monroe said the Atlanta-based carrier was pleased with its current frequent flier program and planned no changes. Gunn suggested the program would be hard to match because it took American 11 months to assemble. But Phillip J. Lederer, a management professor at the University of Rochester who follows the commercial airline industry, said, ``I would be surprised if the majors didn't follow.'' Some analysts have worried that the buildup of free miles could haunt the industry by slashing revenue as customers cashed them in. The Internal Revenue Service and accounting standards groups have been considering whether individuals or companies should be taxed or held liable for the miles. Randy Patterson, who publishes a magazine for frequent fliers, praised American's program as a way to reward customers at the same time the company gets rid of the potential free travel. ``I don't think they like the idea of having that liability on their books,'' said Patterson, who estimated the company owes customers some 70 billion frequent flier miles. Last year, American flew 73.5 billion revenue passenger miles, which measures the total travel of paying customers. Gunn would not confirm Patterson's estimate and refused to provide company figures. Neither would he reveal American's estimates of how many unused free miles the AAdvantage Extra program would eliminate. Gunn said American had more than 11 million members in its AAdvantage program, but less than half are active and only 2 million will receive one of the slick catalogs listing the rebate items. Under the AAdvantage Extra program, customers with more than 20,000 miles can trade some miles for cash rebates of up to $1,500 on three 1990 Toyota models, $1,000 on a GRiD Systems computer or $1,600 on a fox fur coat. The largest awards were a $15,000 rebate on an Adolfo lynx coat from the Fur Vault in exchange for 120,000 miles, and, with 90,000 miles, a 10 percent discount on Deck House homes costing more than $100,000. College Savings Bank will also allow AAdvantage Extra users to buy certificates of deposit at a lower rate and higher yield than the general public. Quick & Reilly, a discount stock broker, will charge reduced commissions in exchange for AAdvantage miles. AAdvantage members earn miles through flying on American Airlines and some other carriers, staying in certain hotels and using some rental cars. Miles also can be accumulated through using some charge cards. Generally, the miles are then exchanged for free, or reduced cost travel on American or other travel benefits.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Hostile Takeover Bill, Toughest in the Land
DOC.TEXT: The House has approved anti-takeover legislation considered the toughest in the nation, meant to make it more difficult for corporate raiders to grab or threaten Pennsylvania companies. The 182-10 vote Tuesday sends the bill back to the Senate, where members must consider amendments added by the House. Several senators and aides predicted the bill, backed by Gov. Robert P. Casey, would gain easy passage on its second trip through the upper chamber. If enacted, corporate takeover strategists would be denied short-term profits from takeover attempts. The provision would apply when a takeover artist tries to sell holdings within 18 months of a failed buyout bid. The bill also would deny raiders immediate voting rights and would require management to consider employee and community interests along with stockholder concerns in deciding takeover offers. Democratic representative Fred Taylor, a supporter of the measure, said it would protect Pennsylvania jobs, companies and communities. ``We're sending a message with this bill to corporate raiders who have gone into Pennsylvania, laid waste to companies and forced them to buy back their own stock, practically bankrupting them,'' Taylor said. ``We're telling them Pennsylvania is not the playground of Wall Street. This doesn't outlaw takeovers all together, but it is certainly going to make that proposition a lot more difficult to participate in,'' he said. Opponents have said the measure would stifle investment in Pennsylvania. The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission criticized the Pennsylvania bill Monday, saying it would disenfranchise shareholders and leave incompetent managers ``free to run a company into the ground.'' Republican representative Robert Godshall, who oppposed the bill, said it would take away ``fundamental and basic rights of shareholders. I don't think this is good for Pennsylvania labor, I don't think it's good for Pennsylvania industry and I don't think it's good for the state of Pennsylvania.'' The House made some minor changes to the bill but the its sponsor, Republican Senator Noah Wenger, said it appeared largely intact. Wenger said he expected the Senate to reconsider the bill in about two weeks. The Senate initially passed the bill in December, 45-4. ``In the long run, it will strengthen not only employment oportunities but investment opportunites. ... Those people who make the big bucks in takeovers would naturally be opposed to those things,'' Wenger said. The measure stems from an effort to help a prominent Pennsylvania company, Armstrong World Industries, fight off a hostile takeover attempt by the Belzberg family of Canada. Belzberg holds more than 10 percent of the company stock and is seeking to put its candidate on the board of directors. William A. K. Titelman, a Harrisburg lobbyist who represents the Belzbergs, said the legislation was a form of ``corporate Stalinism.'' ``The effect of this bill can be summed up in one sentence: Regardless of competence or performance, the top management of a publicly owned corporation shall not be changed except with their express consent and regardless of the wishes of the owners of the corporation,'' he said. More than half the states have enacted takeover laws, but only Indiana has a section similar to Pennsylvania's proposal to diminish directors' financial responsibility to stockholders. Under the legislation, company managers would be able to decide to exempt their companies from the proposed law within 90 days of its enactment. Workers laid off 90 days prior to the completion of a takeover would be eligible for a lump sum severance of one week's pay for each year of service, up to 26 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Creditors Reject Latest Reorganization Plan; To Seek Trustee
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to CLARIFY that vote to reject proposal was unanimous, while vote on trustee was a majority; picks up 3rd graf pvs bg'ng, ``This group ...
DOC.TEXT: Unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines, frustrated by the company's mounting losses and plans to reduce debt payments, have agreed to seek the appointment of a special trustee to find a buyer for the carrier. The unsecured creditors' committee voted unanimously Tuesday to reject Eastern's latest reorganization proposal, which would give them only 25 cents for each dollar owed. A majority of the creditors also voted to seek the appointment of a special trustee, sources close to the committee said. ``This group has had it and they're not going to take it anymore,'' one of the sources said. The move puts the creditors in alliance with Eastern's unions, which have sought a trustee since Miami-based Eastern filed for bankruptcy protection on March 9, 1989. The Chapter 11 filing came five days after the start of a crippling strike by pilots, flight attendants and Machinists. Until recently, the creditors had been supportive of Eastern efforts to rebuild. The unions, meanwhile, have argued that a trustee should take over the management of Eastern from Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. They accuse Lorenzo of draining Eastern's assets into its sister carrier Continental Airlines and Texas Air. In a meeting in New York Tuesday with officials of Eastern and Texas Air, the committee of unsecured creditors rejected Eastern's plan to repay 25 percent of the $980 million it owes them, the sources said. The creditors' committee authorized its attorneys to ask the U.S. Bankruptcy Court to appoint a special trustee to sell the airline, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The committee dropped an earlier threat to press for a liquidation of Eastern. The unsecured creditors include aircraft manufacturers such as Boeing Co. and Airbus Industrie and jet engine makers like General Electric Co. ``The plan presented today serves the creditors far better than any alternative transaction, including liquidation or sale of the airline, both of which are exceedingly remote,'' said Eastern spokesman Robin Matell in Miami. Referring to the creditors' move for a trustee, he said, ``assuming that is not a negotiating ploy, there is no legal or policy basis for the appointment of a trustee.'' Separately Tuesday, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland adjourned until May 9 consideration of the unions' request for a trustee, which previously had been deferred about half a dozen times. The creditors' committee could present its trustee demand at that time. The creditors also may be hardening their stance in an effort to extract fuller payment from Eastern. Last July, Eastern promised creditors full repayment of debts with interest. It slashed that proposal in late January to 10 cents on the dollar in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. After the creditors balked, Eastern reached agreement with them in mid-February on a plan that would pay 50 cents on the dollar upon emerging from bankruptcy. But Eastern told the creditors last week it couldn't fulfill that agreement because of problems in attracting passengers and rebuilding its operations. In response, the creditors' committee privately passed a resolution last week authorizing its attorneys to seek the appointment of a trustee to replace current management and to propose a plan of liquidation. The creditors' attorneys would take such action if Texas Air refused to cover Eastern's future operating losses, according to the resolution. At Tuesday's meeting, Robert Ferguson, a vice president of Texas Air, told the creditors the company would agree to cover only a portion of Eastern's losses, the sources said. The carrier's latest plan called for paying 10 cents on the dollar in the form of Eastern notes guaranteed by Continental, another 10 cents in Texas Air notes, and the remaining 5 cents in cash, the sources said. This time, the creditors responded by calling for a sale of Eastern rather than a liquidation. Earlier speculation about a possible liquidation had hurt the airline by scaring away passengers and travel agents. ``They took out the `l' word,'' a source said. The creditors have been soliciting possible buyers behind the scenes in recent weeks, sources say. The creditors' committee also was concerned that calls for liquidation could jeopardize the proposed sale of Eastern's prized Latin American routes to rival American Airlines for $349 million. Proceeds from that sale are central to Eastern's plan to rebuild. The transaction was approved by Lifland last Thursday, but still must be approved by the Transportation Department. A decision by the department is expected by Friday. A committee of the airline's preferred shareholders also has expressed disapproval with Eastern's reorganization and repayment proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Hills Says Japan Must Make Trade Concessions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf pvs, President Bush ... with White House comment; picks up 10th graf pvs, After months ...
DOC.TEXT: Complex trade negotiations with Japan entered an unscheduled third day today as U.S. Trade Ambassador Carla Hills warned that the Japanese must make concessions or face growing prospects of economic retaliation by the United States. The negotiations, aimed at making broad structural reforms in the economies of both the United States and Japan, began Monday with the arrival of a 64-member delegation from Japan. While both sides are insisting that progress is being made, the talks had originally been scheduled to conclude on Tuesday. However, negotiators met for a third day of closed-door bargaining at the State Department. Talks on both Monday and Tuesday went late into the night. Hills denied that the lengthy negotiations indicated unexpected roadblocks had developed. ``There is no deadlock. We are making progress,'' she told reporters following a speech to the National Association of Manufacturing. ``We want to get it done.'' Hills told officials of the big industry lobbying group that the market-opening moves being proposed by the American side were in the self-interest of Japanese consumers, who currently pay the highest prices in the industrial world for many products. As she has done in the past, she said that without trade concessions on the part of the Japanese to correct the huge U.S.-Japan trade imbalance, there would be growing pressure in this country to retaliate by raising the cost of Japanese products. ``If the Japanese do not open up the second largest market in the world, there will be enormous political pressure,'' she told the manufacturing officials. President Bush was scheduled to meet today with former ambassador to Washington Nobuo Matsunaga, who was dispatched to Washington as the personal emissary of Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki, who has made resolution of U.S.-Japan trade frictions a top priority of his government. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that ``we seem to have made good progress'' on trade disputes involving supercomputers and satellites in the two-and-a-half days of talks with Japan. ``We still have differences, we still have some difficult issues to resolve. But at least we feel that a good start's been made,'' Fitzwater said. After months of no progress with Japan on trade, there have been three agreements reached in the past 10 days _ on opening Japanese markets for sale of American-made telecommunications products, supercomputers and satellites. The satellite agreement was announced late Tuesday. Even with the flurry of new agreements, American business leaders urged caution, noting that the Japanese over the past decade have prepared a variety of trade packages which have not produced the promised results. America's deficit with Japan totaled $49 billion last year, close to half of the total $109 billion trade imbalance. ``I still think it is up in the air whether the trade talks will yield any meaningful results,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, which was to receive a progress report today on trade negotiations from U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. The Bush administration last July launched discussions with Japan aimed at removing broad structural barriers in both the United States and Japan that were viewed as primary reasons for the trade imbalance. Under the format for the talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, both sides have presented their own list of the economic failings they would like to see corrected in the other country. The United States has pushed for changes in Japan that would expand opportunities for U.S. and other foreign firms to provide products and services, arguing that such proposals were in the self-interest of the Japanese because they would lower consumer costs. Japan has targeted various U.S. failings that hurt America's ability to compete internationally. The Japanese would like to see more done by U.S. officials to lower the budget deficit, improve the educational system and get U.S. businesses to focus on long-term goals rather than quick profits. Negotiators hope to have an interim progress report completed by mid-April with a final report on structural barriers finished in July.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Denounce Nominee as Unqualified
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout to include Republican reply. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate began debate today on President Bush's choice as chief savings and loan regulator with Democrats denouncing the nominee as unqualified for the job. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a 44-year-old former senior Labor Department official, did not have the relevant experience needed to regulate the nation's 2,500 S&Ls at this crisis point in the industry. ``This is an enormous job. ... You want someone of towering capacity. ... At a minimum, you want somebody who has a well-established reputation as an expert in finance,'' Riegle said. ``... You can't settle for something less than what you need for the task at hand. Unfortunately, that is what you have here.'' Nevertheless, most senators and industry lobbyists predicted Ryan will be confirmed by a narrow margin to a five-year term as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Republicans portrayed Ryan as a strong manager and tough enforcement official who helped clean up the Teamsters Union as solicitor of the Labor Department. ``Management experts often recommend you bring in somebody from the outside. If there was ever an industry that needs to be shaken up, it is this one,'' said Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, senior Republican on the banking panel. Riegle said senators had not yet agreed when to vote on Ryan, but he said he expected two or three hours of debate, which would put the vote late today. Both sides say Ryan's admission of past drug use will play little role in the Senate debate. As part of his background clearance, Ryan told the FBI that he had tried marijuana and cocaine in the early 1970s, while he was in law school. ``I just don't think we can hold people responsible for something they did in their younger years forever,'' Garn said. ``I made my judgment based on the lack of qualification,'' said Riegle. Two Democrats _ Richard Shelby of Alabama and Terry Sanford of North Carolina _ registered support for Ryan last week when the Senate Banking Committee endorsed the nomination on an 11-10 vote. If the administration can hold all 45 Republicans in the 100-member Senate, it needs to pick up only three more Democrats. Vice President Dan Quayle then could break a 50-50 tie for the Republicans. Such an outcome would not overly upset Democrats, said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``You have someone in office who you can point your finger to and say, `I told you so','' he said. The administration is under pressure to appoint a thrift office director because of a judge's ruling March 21 that officials of the agency lack constitutional authority to seize failing S&Ls. An appeals court's suspension of the ruling expires April 11. If Ryan is defeated, Riegle has prepared legislation that would remove the basis of the legal challenge and allow acting thrift office director Salvatore Martoche to serve another 90 days. Democratic and Republican senators discussed the nomination at private luncheons Tuesday. In the Democratic caucus, ``There was a lot of loud talk, but the expectation was (Ryan) will get by on a tight vote,'' said one source who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I think he'll be confirmed, but I have no idea what the numbers will be,'' Garn said after the Republican meeting. Many savings and loan executives are leery of Ryan because at his confirmation hearing last week he said he was unsure if the S&L industry should survive. However, S&L trade groups say they've been staying out of the battle, not wanting to campaign against the man likely to be the industry's chief regulator. Charles H. Keating Jr., who as owner of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association is at the center the nation's worst thrift failure and defendant in a $1.1 billion fraud suit filed by regulators, wrote letters to all senators opposing Ryan. ``I submit this is hardly the time to shrink from the challenge of finding competent people to handle the important affairs of our government. ... I fear for the future of the republic,'' Keating wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Wants Basic Pact With East Berlin On Monetary Union By Early May
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Wednesday it wants a basic pact on monetary union with East Germany settled by early next month, although the East Germans are expected to be tough negotiators once serious talks begin. East German politicians firmly have rejected a proposal, made by West Germany's central bank, that their citizens receive one West German mark for every two East marks. The East Germans are demanding a 1-to-1 conversion. Under monetary union, West Germany's strong deutschemark will replace East Germany's nearly worthless currency. Monetary union is a cornerstone of plans to rescue East Germany's battered economy and is a crucial element in West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's blueprints for unification. Kohl's government has given conflicting signals about the central bank proposal. Some members of his coalition flatly have rejected the bank's recommendations, while others have suggested they are acceptable in principle. The issue will play an important role as East German politicians attempt to put together the nation's first democratic government. Officials with the Kohl-backed Alliance for Germany, which won the most parliamentary seats in March 18 elections, have scorned the central bank recommenor Party leader Shimon Peres announced Wednesday he has a majority to form a ruling coalition and that he has requested a special Parliament session to approve the new government. DOC.HEAD: MISSING AT SEA: Tragic Results After Someone Cried Wolf
DOC.TEXT: BOSTON _ The radio call was urgent and chilling: A ship somewhere off the Massachusetts coast was transmitting a last-ditch plea for help. But a minute later another distress signal came, and someone was laughing. It seemed like another of the hoaxes plaguing the Coast Guard, and no search was conducted until about a week later, when the agency realized the plea for help had been real. A father and son are lost and the Coast Guard cites the tragedy as an example that crying wolf at sea can be deadly. Slug AM-Missing Boat. Sent as a0587. By Tony Rogers. DOC.HEAD: Big Three Sales Down, Led by Big Drop At Chrysler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks by the Big Three automakers slipped 1.5 percent in late March compared with last year, extending the downturn that began six months ago, the companies said Wednesday. A severe drop in sales of Chrysler Corp. vehicles and a smaller decline in Ford Motor Co. car sales more than offset a moderate sales gain by General Motors Corp. The decline during the March 21-31 period this year came against a relatively soft sales period last year. Altogether GM, Ford and Chrysler, which account for about 85 percent of the domestically made cars sold in the United States, reported that their cars and light trucks were bought at a combined average daily rate of 37,623 during the period this year compared with a 38,193-vehicle-a-day rate last year. Car sales declined 4.3 percent and truck sales rose 3.1 percent. There were no definitive reasons for the overall decline, such as the presence or absence of incentives, which often color year-to-year comparisons. The figures indicate that consumers either are hanging on to their cars and waiting for incentives later in the year or simply that demand is weaker than during the late-March period last year. Through the first three months of this year, the Big Three's car and truck sales were down 3.6 percent compared with the first quarter of last year. Normally, sales pick up in March and April as consumers think more about road trips than they do in the winter months. But last year, and so far this year, that trend hasn't held. For March this year, Big Three car and truck sales were running 6.3 percent behind the rate last year. GM said late-March car sales were 3.9 percent ahead of last year and truck sales were up 10.9 percent, combining for a 6.1 percent increase in vehicle sales. The company's car and truck sales since January were down a slim 0.7 percent. Ford reported its cars and trucks were selling at a pace 3.8 percent behind last year during late March with car sales down 8.1 percent and truck sales up 2.9 percent. For the first three months of the year, Ford's vehicle sales were 6.3 percent behind last year's pace. Chrysler's vehicle sales were down 16.6 percent in late March with car sales falling 23.7 percent and truck sales dropping 9.4 percent. For the first quarter of this year, Chrysler's car and truck sales were 5.6 percent behind last year's pace.

DOC.HEAD: Notorious Wall Street Felon Ends Prison Term
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Boesky, the disgraced Wall Street speculator who made insider trading a household term in the 1980s, completed a three-year prison sentence Wednesday when he was released from a halfway house. Boesky, 53, signed release papers and left the Brooklyn House Community Corrections Center at 5:05 a.m., said Richard Luna, a U.S. Bureau of Prisons official in New York. Boesky was transferred to the facility Dec. 6 from a minimum-security federal prison in Lompoc, Calif., to finish out his term. He ended up serving just over two years, with time off for good behavior. On Nov. 14, 1986, Boesky paid $100 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission and agreed to plead guilty to one criminal count of lying to federal regulators to settle charges of rampant insider trading. The penalty was a record at the time, and Boesky's confessions of a rat's nest of illegal stock dealings using confidential information stunned Wall Street during its greatest boom time since the 1920s. Prosecutors used information supplied by Boesky, who cooperated in exchange for leniency, to bring charges leading to a record $650 million settlement by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and an indictment against Drexel junk bond division chief Michael Milken. Court documents alleged that Drexel, which collapsed last month, and Milken had a secret arrangement with Boesky that violated securities laws in at least 16 transactions from 1984 to late 1986. Boesky began his term at the Lompoc Federal Prison Camp in April 1988. He was granted a month-long furlough in New York last November _ when he was photographed by a New York tabloid with shoulder-length hair and a Rip van Winkle beard _ before his transfer to the halfway house. Starting Feb. 5, Boesky lived outside the center, reported in twice a week and called in daily, Luna said. Boesky now must to report to a probation officer regularly until September, said Eunice Jones, chief federal probation officer in New York. Boesky's lawyer, Robert McCaw, declined to comment on where Boesky has been living or what his plans are. Boesky owns a 75-acre estate in Westchester County north of New York City, where he had lived with his wife, Seema. While living outside the halfway house, Boesky was required to have a paying job, although officials declined to say what that was. Halfway house staff members visited Boesky once a week at his home and job, Luna said. Under his settlement with the government, Boesky is barred for life from the securities industry. But a loophole in federal law reportedly could allow him to serve as an investment adviser for up to 14 people. A source close to Boesky said he did not believe Boesky, who wrote a 1985 book ``Merger Mania,'' was compiling his memoirs. The source said Boesky would not grant any of numerous interview requests until he has finished his role as a government witness, if then. Boesky is expected to testify against Milken, whose trial may not begin until 1991, and at the securities fraud trial of former stock speculator John A. Mulheren, scheduled to begin April 30. Mulheren was a former business associate of Boesky's who at one point was arrested for weapons possession and allegedly told police he planned to kill Boesky. The silver-haired Boesky also still faces more than two dozen shareholder lawsuits and other litigation naming him, his defunct partnership CX Partners LP and affiliated entities such as Drexel and Milken. The lawsuits are pending in U.S. District Court in Manhattan before Judge Milton Pollack. Mitchell Kaplan, a Boston attorney for CX Partners, which was Boesky's main stock-trading fund, said information gathering is completed but the government has barred both sides from interviewing a list of about 200 witnesses, presumably because of Milken's pending trial. Under the first civil settlement of Boesky-related cases, reached in January, the 46 investors in Boesky's partnership will receive $248 million in liquidation proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Reject Challenge by Dissident Stockholders, Small Power Producers
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge rejected challenges Wednesday to shareholder and creditor approval of Northeast Utilities' takeover plan for bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire. Judge James Yacos refused to consider a bid by a lawyer representing a group of small power producers to have their votes counted as rejecting the plan. He said the request came too late. Lawrence Katz argued that the small producers claims aren't adequately recognized in the Northeast plan because its rate agreement says Northeast will try to renegotiate contracts between Public Service and 13 of the small power producers. But Yacos said any future contract negotiations between a reorganized Public Service and the small producers would be a two-way affair, and that the Northeast plan does not deny any contracts outright. ``This reorganization plan recognizes your claims,'' said Yacos in accepting the unsecured creditors' approval of the plan. The first half of Wednesday's hearing was devoted to officially accepting ballot results. Yacos said he would consider objections raised by small power producers and stockholders when actually discussing confirmation. A group of ``dissident'' stockholders led by Robert Richards of New York City told the judge that common stockholders aren't getting enough money back in the deal and that voting by rank-and-file stockholders was tainted. But Yacos said the $762 million figure was agreed upon after 15 days of disclosure hearings in November and he found no reason to reverse his approval. Public Service filed for bankruptcy protection in January 1988, the largest public utility to do so since the Great Depression. Much of its financial problems stemmed from expenses associated with the Seabrook nuclear plant, which became a nationwide focal point of antinuclear opposition. The majority of stockholders approved the $2.3 billion reorganization plan, calling for seven annual 5.5 percent electricity rate increases.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Cooks Up New Mall Invasion: Fast Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th paragraph, Despite the... to CLARIFY that restaurant logo shows Mickey holding burger and milkshake.
DOC.TEXT: There's a mouse in the kitchen, but call off the exterminator. He's a familiar guy named Mickey, and all he wants is to expand the vast Disney empire into restaurants. Walt Disney Co. already has capitalized in the retail industry through stores at shopping malls selling clothing and other products adorned with its characters. On April 28, the 50th Disney Store is to open at the Montclair Plaza mall 35 miles east of Los Angeles. Connected to it will be Mickey's Kitchen, a prototype that will be duplicated around the country if successful. ``The Disney restaurant will be an exciting new concept featuring fast food in a fun setting,'' says a mall sign seeking counter help and kitchen workers. Disney hopes store customers won't be able to resist stopping off for a quick bite to eat or a drink at the soda fountain next door. Disney Stores range from 3,000 to 5,000 square feet; the new connected store and restaurant will be about 12,000 square feet, with seating for about 150 at the counter and tables. The restaurant is the latest experiment in cross-marketing for Disney, said Harold Vogel, a securities analyst who follows Disney for Merrill Lynch & Co. ``They're looking at all sorts of concepts,'' Vogel said Wednesday. He said the Disney Stores ``have been very successful because the Disney brand name _ until recently, anyway _ seemed underexploited.'' Chuck Champlin, a spokesman for Disney's consumer products division, said the restaurant will use Disney's familiar characters in new ways. He wouldn't say exactly how, but noted that Disney Stores feature figures of the characters posed so they appear to be filming movies. In a Torrance mall, for example, the display takes the form of an outer space adventure, with cameraman Goofy filming Donald Duck in pursuit of a villain who has kidnapped Minnie Mouse. Despite the sign posted at the restaurant site and a restaurant logo that shows Mickey holding a burger and milkshake, Disney wants to avoid the association with high-fat, high-calorie fare that the words ``fast food'' often summon. ``We're very concerned, with the Disney image, that a restaurant with the Disney name is safe for you, so we want it to be healthier than in some fast-food places,'' Champlin said. However, he declined to reveal the menu, saying it still was being finalized. Disney has extensive experience with restaurants in its theme parks and hotels, Champlin said. No one at the mall thinks the idea is goofy, said Sonya Bennett, 19, the assistant manager of the Wild Pair shoe store directly across from Mickey's Kitchen. ``I've heard people talking about it,'' she said. ``They say they can hardly wait for it to open.'' Parents with small children and teen-agers were the most inquisitive, she said. It took about six months for the first Disney Store to prove its viability after it opened in the Glendale Galleria in April 1987. Disney is making no promises regarding the restaurants. ``The watchword is very slow development,'' Champlin said. ``We've got the one restaurant now, and we want to study carefully before going ahead with any more.''

DOC.HEAD: Says It Will Accelerate Integration Pace
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Italy vowed Wednesday to dedicate its upcoming presidency of the European Community to speeding up monetary, economic and political union in order to keep up with the pace of change in Eastern Europe. Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis said integration of the 12 EC countries needs to be accelerated as a result of the political upheavals throughout the Soviet bloc and the process of German reunification. He said Italy will seek to play a pivotal role in the creation of a new Europe when it assumes the EC's rotating sixth-month presidency on July 1. ``The events of the first months of this year are already compelling us to step up our pace in the wake of German reunification which is moving ahead of European unification,'' said a working paper on Italy's EC agenda. The document, presented at a news conference by De Michelis, described 1990 as ``an era comparable only to the aftermath of World War II.'' Common Market leaders are scheduled to open a special conference in Italy in December to rewrite parts of their founding 1957 Treaty of Rome. The revisions will clear the way for economic and monetary union, including creation of a regional central bank and a common currency. De Michelis said the monetary conference will begin Dec. 14 and should be concluded within the first six months of 1991, rather than the end of the year as originally envisioned. He said Italy wants a conference on political union to be held simultaneously with the monetary talks. These negotiations would reform EC institutions, extend the powers of the European Parliament and strengthen political cooperation with the aim of shaping a common foreign policy. De Michelis said the political treaty could be implemented as early as the next European Parliament elections in 1994. He gave no details of the new political structure, which has been variously described as the European Union or the European Federation. Although British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has opposed monetary and political union, De Michelis said the ``prevailing opinion'' among EC members favors the unity programs and that on the whole the Community is moving ``toward harmony and away from dissonance.'' With the EC scheduled to become a single market by the end of 1992, Italy will seek to push through approval this year of most of the remaining provisions necessary to meet the deadline, De Michelis said. The 12 nations have already approved 60 percent of the 279 directives, but the Italian working paper said ``a strong political will and a further stepping up of our pace is necessary.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
Precede LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended narrowly mixed Wednesday against major foreign currencies as dealers marked time before the release of government unemployment data and an upcoming meeting of industrial nations. Gold prices rose following a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $377.10 a troy ounce, up $1.80 from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $377.75 an ounce, up $2.50. Currency dealers said technical factors dominated trading in the absence of any strong buying or selling incentives. Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia, said the market was awaiting the March unemployment figures and the start of the Group of Seven meeting, both scheduled for Friday. While the March jobless report was expected to shed some more light on the direction of the U.S. economy, dealers said they expected little to come out of the G-7 gathering. ``There should be more of the same reiteration of how they are committed to free markets and exchange rate stability,'' Glamuzina said. The G-7 includes the United States and its six biggest trading partners: Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy. Glamuzina said the dollar appeared poised for further increases, at least in the near term, due largely to volatility in the Japanese financial markets and the lengthy process of reunifying East and West Germany. In Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar closed at 158.90 yen, down 0.05 yen from Tuesday. The dollar traded at 158.49 yen in London. In New York it finished at 158.875 yen, down from 159.765 yen on Tuesday. The dollar also was weaker against the British pound. Sterling was quoted at $1.6416 in London, up from $1.6345 late Tuesday, and at $1.64055 in New York, up from $1.6358. The dollar was quoted at 1.6999 West German marks in Europe, down from 1.7005 marks late Tuesday, and 1.6995 marks in New York, up from 1.6990. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5040 Swiss francs, up from 1.5035; 5.7095 French francs, up from 5.7085; 1,249.00 Italian lire, up from 1247.75; and 1.16725 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16565. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Tuesday included: 1.5060 Swiss francs, up from 1.5035; 5.7120 French francs, down from 5.7410; 1.9115 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9150; 1,249.50 Italian lire, down from 1,254.00; and 1.1672 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1660. Gold traded in London at $374.50 a troy ounce, down from $375.05 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold was bid at $374.50 an ounce, down from $376. Gold in Hong Kong rose $3.40 an ounce Wednesday to close at $375.34. Silver prices also were mixed.
