DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices dropped sharply Wednesday amid selling linked to a seasonal demand reduction and a report that showed abundant supplies. Market analysts said a bearish attitude toward oil futures intensified when crude fell below $20 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 52 cents to settle at $19.78 a barrel, adding to Tuesday's loss of 18 cents. Contracts for later delivery also posted declines. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale home heating oil for May delivery tumbled 1.48 cents to 54.02 cents a gallon, following a 0.23 cent gain on Tuesday. The June, July and August contracts fell by 1.25 cents to 1.50 cents. May unleaded gasoline, which declined 0.20 cent Tuesday, fell 1.02 cents to 64.86 cents a gallon. Later contracts finished with smaller losses. Natural gas for June delivery finished down 1.5 cents at $1.62 per million British thermal units. Peter Beutel, an energy analyst with Elders Futures Inc., said the American Petroleum Institute's weekly production and stocks report showed a large buildup in crude oil inventory. The buildup put the supply of crude significantly higher than it was a year ago, he said. The proximity of warmer spring weather also is a negative for the energy markets, Beutel said.

DOC.HEAD: Late-March Sales Up Slightly; Down for Entire Month and Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Sales of North American-made cars and trucks rose 2.9 percent in late March compared with last year, the automakers reported Wednesday, but the increase stemmed largely from gains by General Motors Corp. Auto industry analysts said the results were encouraging. Nonetheless they said it was unclear whether the 6-month-long slump was coming to an end. Vehicle sales by Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. fell by 3.8 percent and 16.6 percent respectively during the March 21-31 period this year compared with last year. GM's late-March car and truck sales rose 6.1 percent, mostly because of its light trucks, including minivans that were offered with buyer-luring incentives for the first time. On March 22, GM began offering $1,000 rebates and on its three-vehicle line of minivans _ the Chevrolet Lumina APV, the Pontiac Trans Sport and the Oldsmobile Silhouette. The program runs until May 2. Combined car and truck sales for the nine major U.S. automakers rose to a daily average of 43,688 during the period this year, compared with an average of 42,451 during the same time last year. Car sales were up 2.7 percent and light-truck sales rose 3.2 percent during the period compared with a relatively soft period in 1989. However, for all of March and for the first three months of this year, with imported vehicles included, sales lagged behind the corresponding periods in 1989. Combined domestic and imported car and truck sales of 1,271,465 vehicles last month was 3.1 percent lower than the March sales figures last year. For the first quarter of 1990, sales were 1.8 percent behind last year's pace. For the first three months of the year, Ford's car and truck sales were down 6.3 percent and Chrysler's were off 5.6 percent. GM's 3 percent decline in car sales was offset by a 4 percent jump in truck sales during the quarter. ``During the (three-month) period, compact van sales increased 41 percent (over the same quarter last year) due in large part to GM's newly introduced APVs,'' said J.I. Stark, executive director for GM's worldwide vehicle operations. ``The real story here, as we end the first quarter, is that a new trend has developed and GM is a market-share gainer,'' said auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Co. of New York. Chrysler, with its Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town & Country, has held a commanding lead in minivan sales since the vehicles were introduced in the mid-1980s. ``Chrysler minivans sales are up ... 15 percent for the calendar year, although there has been some dropoff following a record January,'' Chrysler said in a statement Wednesday. In January, Chrysler's minivan sales received a huge boost through a $1,000 incentive. That program expired at the end of January and minivan sales since then have dropped. Nonetheless, Chrysler's trucks, with minivans included, continued in late March to outsell the company's cars. For the first three months of the year, in fact, Chrysler sold 234,665 North American-made trucks compared with 194,879 cars. ``In 1990, we see once again that Chrysler is a super truck company,'' Merlis said. ``I think the best is yet to come in the car area. In some respects, this is a transition year.'' Chrysler plans to introduce cars built from a new basic design in late 1992. Merlis said the slump in the auto industry that began in October, as the 1990 model year got under way, appears to have bottomed out. ``Sales have found a resting point,'' he said. ``They've stabilized at this plateau. It's not a robust rate but it could be worse. The strong income growth in job creation and a stable prime (interest) rate has created a nice underpinning for sales.''

DOC.HEAD: Pepsi Using New Labels in a Summer Soda Promotion
DOC.TEXT: Pepsi-Cola Co. is giving the phrase pop art a new slant, with four jazzy new labels for cans of its flagship soft drink brand as part of a promotion to kick off the summer. The nation's second-largest soft drink company is calling its special package designs ``Cool Cans.'' The new packages are showing up in stores in the Northwest and will be available nationally by early May, the Somers, N.Y.-based company said. One of the new designs features a drawing of a surfer in in an array of red, yellow and blue colors along with the regular Pepsi label. In another, a drawing of a woman's face appears on the label with the Pepsi logo reflected in her sunglasses. A third design called ``Neon'' uses a black rather than a white background, while a fourth called ``Party'' incorporates red, white and blue streamers, dots, stars and diamonds into the label. Pepsi officials said 1.2 billion ``Cool Cans'' will be distributed during the promotion. They will account for more than half of the Pepsi cans on store shelves for the six- to eight-week period which ends in June. Some package design analysts warn that it is a mistake to tamper with a long-established label because loyal customers might mistakenly feel that signals a change in the product itself. But Michael Simpson, executive vice president for marketing and national sales at Pepsi-Cola, said Pepsi tried to avoid that problem by incorporating some element of the original trademark into the new designs. He said in consumer tests of the new labels ``people clearly understood it was Pepsi. There is no missing the Pepsi logo. Even the colors are consistent.'' He said the new designs appeal to consumers of all ages. ``It's a very exciting, contemporary look,'' Simpson said. ``It's fun, interesting and consistent with the Pepsi heritage and image.'' The introduction of the design labels will be staggered every two weeks starting in mid-May, the company said. In addition to the new labels, the company is creating a promotion in which customers who find special markings at the bottom of the inside of their Pepsi cans will qualify for $4 million in prizes ranging from $25 to $20,000. The promotion will be backed by a commercial expected to be on network television by the end of April or early May featuring the Grammy Award-winning rap artist Young MC. Last month, the nation's biggest soft drink company, Coca-Cola Co., announced its own ``Magic Summer'' promotion. Coca-Cola is distributing 750,000 cans of what appear to be regular cans of its flagship Coca-Cola Classic, but actually contain prizes. Each specially designed can contains a mechanism that will spring up when the top is pulled and deliver up to $200 in cash or a certificate for other prizes. The cans are designed so that the spring mechanism and the prize stay dry because they are separated by a barrier from liquid in the can bottom.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Drop On Peru Strike Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Wedneday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid selling prompted partly by settlement of a 24-day strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corp. On other commodity markets, silver led precious metal futures higher; coffee futures surged; petroleum futures sank; grains and soybean advanced; andlivestock and meat futures were mixed. Copper futures settled 2.95 cents to 4.7 cents lower with the contract for delivery in April at $1.235 a pound. The end of the Peruvian strike was ``kind of a surprise,'' said metals analyst Stephen W. Platt of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Some observers had not expected the company to negotiate with the striking miners until after Sunday's presidential election. Platt said further selling was linked to the possibility of an economic slowdown in Japan, a fear fueled by the recent decline in the Japanese stock market. Because copper is used heavily in construction and manufacturing, a Japanese slowdown ``could pull back on demand from one sector that has been quite strong,'' Platt said. Silver futures rallied strongly on the Commodity Exchange, leading gold higher, amid talk that Japanese financial institutions were moving assets out of the stock market and into silver in a ``flight to quality.'' Silver futures settled 15.2 cents to 16.8 cents higher with April at $5.16 a troy ounce; gold was $1.80 to $1.90 higher with April at $377.10 a troy ounce. Coffee futures prices jumped on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange on talk that Brazil is preparing to set a minimum coffee export price of 80 cents a pound. Further buying was prompted by strong roaster demand. Coffee settled 2.17 cents to 3 cents higher with May at 94.99 cents a pound. Petroleum futures sagged on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid selling that largely reflected Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute inventories report. The report showed larger-than-expected U.S. supplies of crude oil and heating oil but a smaller-than-expected gasoline supply. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 21 cents to 52 cents lower with May at $19.78 a barrel; heating oil was 1.21 cents to 1.5 cents lower with May at 54.02 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to 1.02 cents lower with May at 64.86 cents a gallon. Wheat and soybean futures rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by fears of a freeze this weekend in winter wheat country and by stronger overseas demand for soybean meal. Corn and oat futures also advanced. Wheat for May delivery rose sharply amid signs of tight available supplies for delivery against the May contract. After the close, Agriculture Department announced that 121,000 metric tons of U.S. corn had been sold for export to unknown destinations, which often means the Soviet Union. Wheat futures settled 2} cents to 8\ cents higher with May at $3.69} a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with May at $2.68\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with May at $1.52\ a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 5\ cents higher with May at $5.91 a bushel. Cattle futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantil Exchange amid perceptions that supplies of fed cattle are rising and that the market has reached a seasonal top. Pork futures ended mixed, with technically inspired selling offset by buying liked to higher cash hog prices. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .35 cent lower with April at 78.60 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .22 cent to .42 cent lower with April at 82.27 cents a pound; hogs were .02 cent lower to .35 cent higher with April at 55.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent lower to .60 cent higher with May at 55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Pays Record $6 Million in Rear Harness Restraint Case
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. is paying $6 million to settle a suit that stemmed from the automaker's failure to offer rear shoulder harness restraints for the traffic-accident death of a child and crippling injuries to his twin. The settlement announced Wednesday is the largest paid in a case involving the lack of rear shoulder harnesses, said San Diego attorney Craig McClellan. He negotiated the settlement on behalf of the twins' parents, Jim and Patricia Miller, who also survived the Nov. 13, 1988, accident. ``This landmark settlement clearly demonstrates that manufacturers will be responsible for failing to install the shoulder restraints in pre-1990 models,'' said McClellan. Dozens of similar suits filed throughout the nation are pending against Ford and other automakers. Under federal regulations, combination lap and shoulder safety harnesses in the rear are mandatory for all passenger cars as of this model year. In 1992, the requirement will be expanded to include minivans. Ford admitted no liability in the settlement, negotiated over the past two weeks before a Superior Court judge approved it. The Millers' car, a 1986 Ford Escort, was equipped with lap belts only in the rear, which both boys were wearing on the day of the accident. ``Reliable government studies show that lap belts in rear seating positions, which have been installed on 140 million cars, both Ford and non-Fords, are effective in reducing the risk of death and serious injury in a collision,'' Ford spokesman Mark Miller said from Detroit. He is not related to the victims' family. ``Certainly this is a tragic situation and Ford sympathizes with the Miller family. At the same time, Ford was not responsible for the accident. I think experts would agree it would be very unfortunate if people stopped using rear lap belts because they can enhance safety and reduce the risk of injury and fatality,'' Mark Miller added. The suit stemmed from a head on-collision on a notorious ``S'' curve on Rancho Santa Fe Road in Carlsbad, about 40 miles north of San Diego in which a another car crossed into the wrong lane and crashed into the Millers' car. The other driver also died. On Tuesday night, the Carlsbad City Council approved a $550,000 payment to the Millers to settle their claims. The city also has realigned the curve to make the roadway safer. The front end of the Escort was nearly demolished in the accident, but James and Patricia Miller survived with broken bones and bruises. They were strapped in their front seats with shoulder harnesses. McClellan said the Escort's rear compartment was left virtually intact but 11-year-old James Miller died in the crash and his twin brother, Richard, suffered a fractured spine when he was pitched forward violently. Both of the boys were wearing their lap belts. There is no question, McClellan said, that James Miller would have survived and Richard Miller would not have become a paraplegic if they had been wearing shoulder harnesses. Jim Miller said had he been given an option, he would have paid to have rear shoulder harnesses in his Escort. ``Our experience clearly shows that anyone riding or driving in a car without rear shoulder harnesses should be concerned about the risk they are taking every time they go for a drive, even buckled up,'' Jim Miller said. McClellan estimated the additional cost at $12 per belt. He also noted that Ford has been installing rear shoulder restraints in Escorts sold in Europe since the early 1980s. ``Ford never offered the U.S. market the rear-set shoulder harness mandated by law in European Escorts because of the expense _ $12 per belt,'' McClellan said. ``The Miller family tragedy is a result of that conduct.'' The attorney said Ford's own engineers told management years ago that a shoulder restraint system was more effective than lap belts in reducing the risk of injury or death in a collision and that any argument against their installation was outweighed by increased safety benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Recovering But Expect Flat Sales, Executives Say
DOC.TEXT: Federated and Allied department stores on Wednesday projected no sales growth for the quarter beginning in May but said the retailers are recovering under bankruptcy court protection. ``We clearly are doing better in Chapter 11 than we expected,'' James M. Zimmerman, president of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., told the first meeting of the retailers' unsecured creditors. Zimmerman and other executives said Federated and Allied don't know when they will complete a plan to repay creditors. The two companies sought U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection Jan. 15 because of huge debts stemming from their acquisition by the Campeau Corp. in the 1980s. It was the largest bankruptcy filing in retailing history. Zimmerman reiterated that except for attempts to sell the Bloomingdale's chain, the companies have no plans to sell subsidiaries to pay their debts. Federated and Allied on Monday reported combined losses of $45.7 million for February. On Friday, their corporate parent, Federated Stores Inc., asked to have itself added to the Chapter 11 filing. The companies expect sales for the quarter ending in April to decline 3 percent compared with the previous year, said Karen M. Hugolet, vice president for planning. She said that in May, June and July sales growth should be ``essentially flat, reflecting recovery in bankruptcy.'' Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive officer of Federated and Allied, said at the creditors' meeting that 98 percent of merchandise suppliers have resumed shipments to stores. He said that with a court-approved employee retention plan, employee turnover is only slightly higher than last year's. ``In almost all areas of our operation, we have restored normalcy,'' he said. Zimmerman said streamlining measures since Jan. 15 have saved the companies $50 million. He said their expenses were $5 million less than projected in February. Federated executives expect to decide within 30 days whether to take Bloomingdale's off the market. Lawyers for retired Federated and Allied executives who lost supplemental pension benefits when the companies sought Chapter 11 protection repeatedly asked the panel of executives when they would consider restoring payments. The bankruptcy court stopped the extra benefits that were part of the executives' contracts. ``These are not issues we take lightly, and I'm sure we would be moved by individual accounts of the retirees,'' Zimmerman said. ``But our information tells us right now that such action would be counterproductive.'' Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer for the committee representing Federated and Allied merchandise suppliers, said the retailers last week produced a list of suppliers left holding checks when the bankruptcy court froze Federated and Allied bank accounts. Rosenbloom said the suppliers have begun to research possible ways of seeking repayment before Federated and Allied issue their reorganization plan.

DOC.HEAD: Delegation Supports Camera Maker's Request for Trade Help
DOC.TEXT: House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt joined New Jersey's congressional delegation Wednesday in seeking to protect a New Jersey camera manufacturer from crippling foreign competition. The lawmakers endorsed higher import quotas and tariffs, saying 500 manufacturing and distribution jobs at Keystone Camera Corp. in Clifton, N.J., were at stake. The jobs are in the Clifton-Paterson, N.J., area, which the congressmen called one of the ``most economically depressed zones in America.'' Keystone, which describes itself as the sole remaining American manufacturer of conventional 35-millimeter and 110 cameras, filed a petition for trade relief March 29 with the International Trade Commission. Keystone requested tariff increases and quotas for five years on low-cost imported cameras. ``The staggering increase in imports and product inventory which Keystone revealed in its petition, together with the resultant depressions of prices, production, profits and employment, poses a compelling case for expedited relief,'' the 13 House members and Democratic Sen. Frank Lautenberg wrote in a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., a strong proponent of free trade, did not sign the group letter. Instead, he will send a separate letter urging Mrs. Hills to give the case ``fair consideration,'' spokesman Michael Jones said. ``He didn't sign the New Jersey letter because he believes the Trade Commission should arrive at its decision first and then he'll take a look at that to see whether he agrees with what its conclusions were,'' Jones said. ``This action was taken by us in response to a veritable flood of imports which began in 1987 and which drove prices to unreasonably low levels, causing a succession of deep operating losses,'' said Myron J. Berman, chief executive officer and board chairman of Keystone. The International Trade Commission must make a determination in the case by late July, a recommendation to the president by late September and can provide relief within eight months, the company said. Imports of 110 cameras under $20, 35mm fixed-focus cameras with built-in flash and 35mm autofocus cameras retailing under $50 rose from 11 million in 1985 to 27.5 million in 1987, Keystone said. ``We earnestly believe that what has happened to Keystone could happen to virtually any efficiently run U.S. manufacturing enterprise,'' Berman said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to show talks now expected to end Thursday. Picks up 4th graf pvs bg'ng, `To emphasize ...'; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators, insisting that they were making progress, struggled Wednesday to resolve final differences on an unprecedented agreement attacking the huge trade imbalance between the two nations. The discussions, which originally had been scheduled to end Tuesday, were taking much longer than planned. U.S. officials said the two sides would meet again Thursday in the hope of wrapping up the talks, which are aimed at altering fundamental economic and business practices in both countries to help reduce America's huge $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills denied that the extra negotiating sessions indicated the talks had run into unexpected roadblocks. ``There is no deadlock. We are making progress,'' she told reporters. But in a speech Wednesday to a U.S. manufacturing group, Hills sounded a warning on the possible consequences if Japan fails to agree to American demands to open its markets to more foreign goods. ``There never has been a nation that benefited so greatly as the Japanese from the freedom to sell and invest in foreign markets,'' she said. ``If the Japanese do not open their second largest market in the world, there will be enormous political pressure to restrict those opportunities that have given them so much. It will kill the goose that laid their golden egg.'' To emphasize the importance of the talks, President Bush met Wednesday with Nobuo Matsunaga, a former ambassador to the United States, and Deputy Foreign Minister Hisashi Owada, personal emissaries from Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. After the meeting, Matsunaga told reporters he had stressed to Bush that Kaifu was making a maximum effort to ease trade frictions. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was given a personal letter from Kaifu which detailed the efforts the Japanese government has made in the past month since Bush and Kaifu held a two-day summit conference to review trade problems. In recent days, the Japanese have offered market-opening moves in the area of American-made telecommunications products, satellites and supercomputers. Fitzwater said that Bush told the envoys that Kaifu ``deserves a very large share of the credit for settling the specific trade issues.'' Both sides have a lot riding on the outcome of the current negotiations. The Japanese are anxious to stem a rising tide of anti-Japanese sentiment in their largest overseas market while the Bush administration is seeking ways to reduce America's $49 billion trade deficit with Japan, nearly half of last year's total deficit. The latest round of negotiations began Monday and had been scheduled to go only two days. However, it was extended because both sides found it impossible to cover all the issues, even though the talks were lasting into the early morning hours. The talks are unprecedented in their scope because they aim not at boosting sales of specific products but at correcting broad barriers to trade in both countries. The effort has prompted Japanese critics to charge that the United States was trying to remake their nation and scrap centuries of tradition in the process. However, the Bush administration, which began the discussions last July, has maintained that its proposals would not only reduce the U.S. trade deficit by expanding opportunities for American sales in Japan but also lower prices paid by Japanese consumers, currently the highest in the industrial world. Negotiators this week were preparing an interim progress report outlining reforms each side is willing to make with a final report scheduled for early July. Among the changes expected to be offered on the Japanese side were proposals to increase enforcement of antitrust laws to discourage bid-rigging and other practices by Japanese companies that U.S. firms have claimed have kept them from cracking the Japanese market. The Japanese were also expected to offer to boost spending for public works projects and to relax restrictions on the establishment of large retail stores. U.S. companies believe that allowing large stores in major Japanese cities would expand opportunities for American retailers and for foreign-made products, which are not readily available in the smaller stores that predominate in Japan. On the U.S. side, the Japanese recently presented a list of 80 proposals designed to boost America's ability to compete internationally. The administration is not likely to agree to the most politically explosive ideas such as restricting Americans' use of credit cards, boosting the gasoline tax and eliminating tax deductions for home mortgage payments. However, the Bush administration was expected to point to efforts the president is making to provide expanded tax credits for personal savings, improve the U.S. education system and balance the federal budget.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Agency Adopts New Policy on Inquiries
DOC.TEXT: The government agency charged with selling off failed savings and loans has adopted a policy requiring its employees to maintain a log of all telephone inquiries made by or on behalf of public officials. The Resolution Trust Corp. action was announced Wednesday in response to policy directives in the S&L bailout legislation enacted by Congress last summer. The RTC action also calls for establishment of a special committee which will conduct formal reviews when RTC employes believe they have received inappropriate requests from public officials. It also outlined procedures for meetings between RTC employes, public officials and their constituents including a requirement that such meetings be attended by two or more RTC employees, one of whom must be a senior-level employee.

DOC.HEAD: Newman's `Salad Dressing' Case Goes to Jury
DOC.TEXT: Paul Newman was alternately portrayed as an egotistical movie star who reneged on a promise and a modest philanthropist before the ``salad dressing'' suit brought by a delicatessen owner went to a jury Wednesday. ``There are people in the world who operate on a different level,'' Richard Albrecht, attorney for deli owner Julius Gold, told jurors in his closing arguments. ``Some do so with grace, and some do so with raw exhibition of power. ``It's the race car thing,'' Albrecht added, referring to Newman's love of race-car driving as the actor sat smirking in the back of the courtroom. Gold is seeking an 8 percent stake in Newman's Own Inc. and Salad King Inc., claiming he spent four years advising Newman and helping him establish the food businesses. Newman's lawyer portrayed the actor as an honest businessman who started the two companies as a way to raise money for charity. He played down the portrayal of Newman as a rich celebrity by referring to Gold's success as a businessman. ``Gold is not some poor little shopkeeper,'' attorney W. Patrick Ryan said. ``It's not David and Goliath _ get that out of your head.'' The six-member jury began deliberations at mid-afternoon and were dismissed for the day about an hour and 45 minutes later. Gold said he was confident he would prevail. ``I would think the longer the jury stays out in this case the better it would look for me,'' Gold said. Gold is suing Newman, writer A.E. Hotchner and the two food businesses, claiming they reneged on a promise to give him stock in return for his participation in the development and marketing of Newman's Own salad dressing. An earlier trial ended in a mistrial in 1988 when the jury mistakenly received depositions that had not been admitted as evidence. Superior Court Judge George N. Thim told jurors they must conclude that Gold had an oral contract with Newman and the other defendants if they are to find in favor of Gold. Newman, who has been in court almost every day since the trial began March 20, contends that Gold's only participation was to sell some of the dressing in his Westport store. Newman and Hotchner started Newman's Own on a whim, beginning with salad dressing that Newman originally made in the basement of his Westport home and later expanding into spaghetti sauce, popcorn and lemonade. All profits _ $28 million to date _ go to charity. The companies had a record $42 million in sales last year, up from $36 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Hears Dispute Over Occidental's Funding of Museum for Hammer Art
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp. is justified in funding a museum to house the art collection of Chairman Armand Hammer because it enhances Occidental's image, a lawyer for a shareholder group said Wednesday. ``The oil and chemical business is risky,'' attorney William Prickett said at a hearing before Maurice Hartnett, vice chancellor of the Delaware Chancery Court. Prickett cited the Love Canal toxic waste incident and an explosion that killed 167 workers on a North Sea oil platform as examples of tragedies that have hurt Occidental's reputation. Given those risks, building a museum to house a prominent collection is a legitimate public relations expense for the company, he maintained. ``This is a unique chance for Occidental to be favorably identified'' in the public eye, he said. Prickett was defending a settlement the shareholder group has reached with Occidental that allows the company to continue to fund the museum within certain limits. The court proceeding was called to hear a challenge to the settlement by other shareholders, who have filed two separate class-action lawsuits seeking to stop the company from spending money on the museum. Attorneys for these shareholders contended the museum's main purpose is to enhance the reputation of Occidental's 91-year-old chief. The museum is ``a gift to Armand Hammer'' that ``raised more controversy and ill will than good will,'' said California's Deputy Attorney General Susan Henrichsen, representing the California Public Employees' Retirement System. Calpers, the nation's largest pension fund, owns 0.6 percent of Occidental's stock. Occidental has said it will cost about $95 million to build the museum and establish an endowment to sustain it. Construction already has begun on a site next to the company's headquarters in the Westwood district of Los Angeles. Hartnett listened to both sides, but did not rule and gave no indication when he would do so. Occidental is based in Los Angeles but incorporated in Delaware. Prickett's shareholder group originally filed a lawsuit challenging the museum. The group dropped its suit after reaching a settlement with the oil company that would limit its spending on the project and require Occidental's name to appear on the museum as well as Hammer's. The settlement also included a fee of $1.4 million for Prickett. Hartnett earlier called the proposed $1.4 million payment ``huge,'' and Prickett said he would not dispute the matter if the judge lowered the award. The Occidental chairman announced plans to build the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center after reneging on a promise to give his $400 million collection to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. He and the county museum had been embroiled in a dispute about how the art would be displayed. Prickett contended that a special committee of Occidental's independent directors was justified in approving corporate funding for the museum. He noted that Delaware courts have been hesitant to intervene in cases involving business judgments made after reasonable consideration, such as the Time-Warner merger. Grover Brown, a lawyer for the special committee, defended the panel's support for the project and said committee members had a combined 80 years experience in deciding what was best for Occidental. ``The egocentrism of Dr. Hammer is not a matter for the court,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Announces Agreement in Principle on Financial Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp., the nation's second-largest convenience store chain, said late Wednesday it has reached an agreement in principle with its main lenders to restructure part of its $1.3 billion debt. Circle K accumulated much of its debt during a rapid expansion that saw the company grow from about 1,000 stores in 1984 to 4,685 last year. The company said previously it might have to seek bankruptcy protection from creditors if it could not work out a debt restructuring. Last week, the company reported it lost more than $40 million on operations during the quarter ended Jan. 31. Circle K said the agreement involved its bank lenders, a committee of holders of $200 million Circle K senior secured notes and American Financial Corp., Circle K's largest shareholder and a creditor. The agreement envisions that the parties will enter into a standstill agreement that would be effective the earlier of either Oct. 31 or the successful completion of the company's financial restructuring, the company said. Until then, the banks, bondholders and American Financial ``would defer all principal and interest payments on their respective obligations and waive any existing defaults under their current loan agreements,'' Circle K said. The standstill agreement would require Circle K by Oct. 31 to buy back at least 90 percent of its $510 million in subordinated debt, Circle K said. Terms of a buyback haven't been determined yet, it said. The company said the standstill agreement is subject to approval by remaining noteholders. Ray Cox, a Circle K spokesman, declined to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Billionaire Won't Renew Bid for United Airlines Despite Invitation
DOC.TEXT: Investor Marvin Davis has no intention of making a new bid for UAL Corp. despite the company's invitation to do so, sources close to the negotiations said Wednesday. The Beverly Hills billionaire bid $275 a share for the parent of United Airlines last August, about $6.2 billion. He was topped by a $300-a-share offer for the Chicago-based company by team that included UAL management, pilots and British Airways. That deal fell through last October for lack of financing, however, causing UAL's share price to plummet. United's pilots, mechanics and flight attendants unions recently have made a new bid estimated to be worth about $185 a share in cash, debt and stock. Union spokesmen said they never believed Davis would make a new offer even though UAL last month called off a standstill agreement with Davis, freeing him to bid again for the company. The UAL move was seen as an attempt to avert a proxy war by the company's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL's shares, supported the unions' bid and said it would wage a proxy battle to take over the board of directors if the offer was not accepted. Crain's Chicago Business reported this week that Davis had suggested a ``concept'' to the UAL board for a bid of about $220 a share, the range the board has indicated would be acceptable. But two sources with knowledge of the situation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that Davis would not renew his bid for UAL. One source said the unions had made clear they would strike if Davis or another investor challenged their bid. ``No bank will lend into the face of a strike,'' he said. ``You've got the union trying to blackmail the board and they have the ability to keep anybody else from playing.'' He added that the unions will have problems arranging financing themselves, even at the lower bid level, since no one outside has offered to help them. ``There's no equity partner there, so the banks aren't willing to finance the deal,'' he said.
